HEADLINE: New York Can't Ask if It's Art Before Letting a Film Crew Shoot

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We understand the concern of Brent Staples in "New York, the Movie" (Editorial Notebook, June 15) that New York City might be wasting its precious resources on fool's errands and unprofitable ventures. But then Mr. Staples reminds us that "Hudson Hawk," the clunker whose shooting tied up Brooklyn several nights last summer, cost $51 million to make. 
 Part of that was disbursed in New York City, at $400,000 a day, for 16 days. Ten percent of those expenditures flowed directly into the city's tax coffers, and eventually some of it benefited every block in New York. The multiplier for feature films is 2.3, which means that for every dollar of that $6.4 million, $1.30 was spent in the community ($8.32 million).
That is not our only justification for permitting film crews to inconvenience our citizens briefly. This activity also provides jobs for a freelance production work force of 75,000 union members, which we want to see as close to full employment as possible.
Mr. Staples might find some satisfaction in the fact that New York got the better of the bargain on "Hudson Hawk." Metropolitan New York film consumption is usually the highest in the country: box office returns for the first three weeks in New York amounted to $1,039,444, a very favorable balance of payments.
In any case, the remedies Mr. Staples proposes cannot be acted upon. Under the First Amendment, a governmental body such as the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting cannot evaluate the contents of a film before determining to assist it or not. We have assisted many a low-budget project, like the well-received "Hangin' With the Homeboys," with as much vigor as a studio-backed film because our mandate is the city's economic development, not film promotion or criticism.
In any case, trying to evaluate in advance a show-business project's chances of success is as risky as picking the winning triple at Belmont. So the best bet is to help every production as if it were "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn."
 
JAYNNE C. KEYES
Director, Office of Film,
Theater and Broadcasting
New York, June 20, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Changes Set At World Bank

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The World Bank says its 22- member board has agreed to organizational changes sought by the United States to try to make the international lending agency more aware of private- sector needs in the third world.
The growing emphasis on helping the private sector is viewed as a means to further the bank's goal of alleviating poverty and promoting economic development, and not as an end in itself, Barber B. Conable Jr., the World Bank's president, said on Friday. 
 The board of the bank's private-sector lending arm, which has the same 22 directors, also recommended on Friday that its capital be increased to $2.3 billion, from $1.3 billion. The United States would contribute $250 million of the increase over five years.
The capital increase is subject to the approval of the World Bank's member countries, but Mr. Conable said he did not anticipate any difficulty in obtaining that.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Banking Gloom Clouds Outlook

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Just as the recession is ending, doubts about the health of the financial system seem to have re-emerged in the credit markets, raising questions about the viability of a recovery.
Most bankers and economists contend that corporate balance sheets are in much better shape than they were a year or even six months ago. But problems remain, particularly at big commercial banks. Those difficulties are probably not serious enough to abort an upturn, they said, but they can act as a restraint on the recovery. 
Moreover, the bankers and economists say concern about the financial system is yet another reason for the Federal Reserve to be slow to respond to renewed economic growth by raising short-term interest rates.
 
Banking Worry and Rumors
 Adding to the worries: reports that second-quarter earnings at the Wells Fargo Bank would be sharply lower because of a big increase in nonperforming commercial loans, and big upward revisions in estimates of how much money will be needed to bail out the savings and loan industry and replenish the commercial bank insurance fund.
Rumors that problems at the Chase Manhattan Bank and Citicorp's Citibank were deepening, speculation that has not been heard in the financial markets for months, seem to be regaining currency, even though the rumors have been denied.
Such concerns will probably heighten during the next few weeks, as banks report second-quarter results. But banks are in much better shape to cope with problems than they have been in the past year.
 
Signs of Healing
 "Bank liquidity is a lot better now, and six months or a year ago many banks simply didn't realize the magnitude of the credit problems they were about to face," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. "Now they do, and that's healthy. But it takes time to work out of these difficulties."
S. Waite Rawls, vice chairman of the Continental Bank of Chicago said that "with the exception of real estate, things are beginning to heal."
"But we are not out of the woods yet," he added, "because a lot of the credit crunch was induced by real estate, and the real estate problems won't go away quickly."
 
Record Level of Debt Is Issued
 Over the last six months, as banks have chosen to build liquidity rather than book new loans, corporations have taken advantage of rising stock prices and lower interest rates to improve their own balance sheets.
To pay down short-term bank loans and commercial-paper obligations, as well as finance new projects, investment-grade corporations issued a record $92.4 billion worth of new debt during the first half of 1991, according to the Securities Data Corporation.
"It is surprising that bond issuance has happened to the extent that it has," Mr. Rawls said, "because the very positive yield curve, with short rates so much lower than long rates, provides a strong argument to wait. Fear of ratings downgrades on instruments like commercial paper may have caused a lot of people to seek longer maturities."
 
Equity Up, Too
 In addition, nearly $26 billion worth of new equity was raised in the first half, more than 35 percent above the total for all of 1990. Analysts at Securities Data said more than 22 percent of the money raised from the issuance of new stock was used to reduce outstanding debt.
"The huge volume of corporate debt and equity issuance is extremely constructive," said Neil M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. "Those are the sorts of things that help the economy recover."
The process is a long way from over, though.
Mr. Soss noted that between 1983 and 1990 nonfinancial corporations retired $640 billion in equity, replacing much of it with debt.
"Deleveraging will be with us for a very long time," he said.
 
June Job Data Due This Week
 Worries about the credit crunch may well persist, but employment data for June will be a more immediate concern for the credit markets during this holiday-shortened week.
To the annoyance of many who wished to stretch the Fourth of July holiday into a very long weekend, the Labor Department is expected to adhere to its policy of releasing the job report on the first Friday of the month.
As usual, estimates on the figures vary, but most economists seem to be expecting to hear that the surprising rise in payroll employment reported for May was reversed in June.
Brian Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers, is forecasting that non-farm payroll employment fell by 50,000 in June, and that the unemployment rate rose to 7.1 percent, from 6.9 percent in May.
"If our relatively pessimistic payroll estimate proves accurate, it undoubtedly would call into question the strength of the nascent revival," Mr. Jones wrote in Salomon's weekly Comments on Credit.
"But," he added, "it would not change our view that the seeds of recovery are firmly planted."

HEADLINE: Domestic Stock Markets Retreated Slightly in the 2d Quarter

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
After a strong performance in the first quarter, the stock market caught its breath in the second.
"It was a boring quarter," said Laslzo Birinyi Jr., president of the Wall Street research firm Birinyi Associates. "Given what happened in the first quarter, some sort of setback was not unexpected." 
 In the quarter ended Friday, the stock market retreated slightly. Despite the excitement over the Dow Jones industrial average's closing above 3,000 for the first time (on April 17), the Dow closed down 7.11 points for the quarter, at 2,906.75.
 
Other Indexes Off Slightly, Too
 Other indexes also posted small declines, Mr. Birinyi said. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was down nine-tenths of 1 percent, while the American Stock Exchange composite index fell three-tenths of 1 percent. The over-the-counter index was off 1.3 percent.
Of the 3,999 stocks tracked by Media General Financial Services, 1,891 were up in the second quarter, 1,951 were down and 157 were unchanged.
On the New York Stock Exchange, Media General said 740 stocks finished higher, 776 were down and 45 were unchanged. On the American Exchange, 198 stocks rose, 275 were down and 17 were unchanged.
 
Edge for Over-the-Counter Stocks
 Advancing issues outnumbered those declining only in the over-the-counter market. Media General said 953 over-the-counter stocks rose, 900 declined and 95 were unchanged.
The relatively strong performance of the over-the-counter exchange was one noteworthy aspect of the second quarter, Mr. Birinyi said, given that the over-the-counter market did better than the other exchanges in the first quarter. "The fact that it did not consolidate or correct more was pretty significant," he said. "It would suggest that there really is a long-term positive outlook for the over-the-counter stocks."
Technology stocks took a beating during the most recent three months. "They did well in the first quarter and fell apart in the second," said Byron Wien, United States investment strategist for Morgan Stanley.
Hard-hit technology issues on the Big Board included Compaq Computer, down 50.3 percent, to $31.125; Commodore International, 36.7 percent, $11.625, Conner Peripherals, 35.5 percent, $16.125; Silicon Graphics, 28.8 percent, $28.375; Western Digital, 25.7 percent, $4, and Applied Magnetics, 24.8 percent, $9.50.
Another trend to emerge, Mr. Wien said, was the growing importance of cyclical stocks like paper, machinery and chemical stocks, compared with the consumer-goods stocks that have led the market for much of the last 10 years.
"It looks like there is the beginning of a leadership change taking place, from the consumer nondurable growth stocks to the more economically sensitive issues," Mr. Wien said. "It could create a dynamic shift in institutional portfolios. A change in leadership creates new heroes in the market."
 
Orion the Big Loser
 The top performer on the New York Exchange was the Best Buy Company, a consumer electronics retailer based in Minneapolis. Best Buy benefited when a financially troubled competitor, Highland Superstores, withdrew from several markets. Best Buy also gained market share as its new warehouse-style electronics stores attracted customers.
"People are getting a sense that they are long-term survivors in this business," said Richard Pyle, an analyst with Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis.
On the Big Board, the Orion Pictures Corporation was the big loser, despite the success of "Dances With Wolves" and "The Silence of the Lambs." Orion stock collapsed after the studio posted a loss for the year and investors reacted negatively to a debt-restructuring plan that the company recently announced. The company said it planned to restructure about $285 million of debt, with the goal of eliminating about $400 million in interest payments by 1998.
Details in documents related to the restructuring caused some investors to worry about the small studio's aggressive accounting practices in estimating future revenues from its movies. Orion was also sued by investors who said it misled shareholders about its financial condition by overstating the value of its film library.
 
Hair and Beauty Products Winner
 American Medical Holdings Inc., based in Dallas, was the big gainer on the American Stock Exchange. The health-care company announced a plan that could save it more than $45 million in annual interest payments by selling stock to refinance a large portion of its high-interest debt.
A health-care company was also the biggest loser. Health Concepts IV Inc. in Tulsa, Okla., was distracted by a proxy fight begun by a top officer after he left the company. The company operates drug and alcohol rehabilitation centers. The Stephan Company, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and makes hair and beauty products, was the top gainer in the over-the-counter markets. The company posted its best first quarter ever, the result of cost-cutting and increased sales of private-label salves.
Peter Ferola, Stephan's administrative manager, said he was aware of no particular reason for the increase in the company's stock price.
"We've got a good story and people are finally hearing it," he said.
Sprouse-Reitz Stores Inc., a troubled retailer based in Portland, Ore., posted the largest decline in the over-the-counter markets. Investors soured on the company's prospects after a takeover bid was withdrawn. The Transaction Financial Corporation withdrew its bid in April and said in a statement, "We have no confidence in management and are unwilling to leave our offer on the table indefinitely while the company's financial condition deteriorates rapidly."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New York Woman Opens Its Gold-Card Mine

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Here she comes, the New York Woman! Street smart. Ambitious. Sexy. A young urban survivor, who never, never leaves home without her American Express gold card.
Or so New York Woman magazine, which is published by the American Express Publishing Corporation, would have its advertisers believe. 
 In an unusual attempt to revive its sagging advertising, the 110,000-circulation magazine will guarantee advertisers in its December issue a circulation of 300,000 women. The additional 190,000, who will get the December issue in the mail at no cost, are American Express gold card holders who charge at least $3,000 a year in retail sales to their cards.
 
Access to Millions of Names
 Like its sister publications within the American Express family, the five-year-old-magazine, which publishes 10 issues a year, has access to the millions of names in the parent company's formidable data base. These data tell how many times a card was used and the amounts paid and have enough verified information about how the woman shops to make any media director drool. Holders of gold cards are the biggest spenders in the data base.
"No one can profile a woman's spending the way we can," the magazine's publisher, Amy Rappeport, said. "In publishing New York Woman, our single greatest advantage is our connection to our parent, American Express."
Most magazines pay a lot for lists of names of people who fit the demographics that advertisers are seeking. American Express publications have all these data in house.
Like most city publications, New York Woman is heavily dependent on local retail advertisers. These advertisers include department stores, restaurants and small boutiques, which are often among the hardest hit in a recession. New York Woman saw its advertising pages decline 28 percent for the first six months of this year.
Ad pages in two other American Express city magazines are also down this year -- L.A. Style by 35 percent and D., a Dallas-based magazine, by 16 percent. The company's other city publication, Atlanta, is even with the first six months of 1990.
The typical New York Woman reader is 36 years old and has a household income of $90,000. Ninety-five percent of the readers live in the New York metropolitan area. Half are married. And -- this is, after all, New York -- 40 percent say they have at least one facial a year.
The magazine's founder and editor in chief, Betsy Carter, who had been with Esquire and Newsweek, said she started the magazine because she felt there was a singular sensibility among women in New York.
"I realized I could connect with almost every woman I met in New York," she said. "New York women are smart, quirky and funny. It's part of a kind of urban survival."
 
Remaking the Magazine
 Still, the magazine may have an image problem. Some readers have said they feel the magazine cannot quite seem to make up its mind whether it is a consumer magazine or a feature magazine. Others criticize it as being "too neurotic."
With the September issue, the magazine will have a new tag line, calling itself New York Woman, the Life of the City. It will undergo a total redesign to broaden its appeal, in Ms. Carter's words, "to make it intimate, to make it fun, to make it loose."
New sections will include information on looking for a job and reviews of books, art, dance, music, theater, movies, television and food.
Ms. Rappeport said New York Woman was close to being profitable; it has not yet posted its first profit.
For two or three months last fall, rumors swept the industry that the magazine was about to cease publication. Ms. Rappeport and Ms. Carter said the rumors were unfounded.
The move to increase December's circulation is mainly intended to attract advertisers at higher rates during the Christmas holidays, said Ron Prince, vice president and group publisher for American Express's City Magazine Group. It is not part of a subscription drive.
In fact, since American Express conducts many magazine subscription drives by pulling names from its data base, the chances are that some women who will receive the magazine free in December already passed up a were a subscription offer.
Mr. Prince said that even if permanent subscriptions expanded substantially as a result of the December circulation increase, it was unlikely that advertisers would be willing to pay higher rates during the less-active retail months in the winter.
Rates for the December issue will be increased by 75 or 80 percent. This increase will not cover the full cost of printing and mailing; Mr. Prince and Ms. Rappeport declined to say how much the effort would cost over all.
A number of advertisers responded positively to the planned increase in December's circulation.
"I think fishing when the fish are biting is the best thing to do," said Matt Rubel, president of the specialty-store division at Revlon Inc.
And Stacy Demeo, vice president for merchandising at Bloomingdale's department store, concurred. "The more people you can get your hands on, the better," he said.
Mr. Rubel said of New York Woman: "It's probably the most effective vehicle in a major metropolitan area that can bring a customer to a counter in a very immediate manner. We've found that through advertising services with gift certificates in the magazine, we get a very high response rate of people bringing them back to our counters."

HEADLINE: Ethiopians to Discuss a New Regime

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 30

 BODY:
The new rulers of Ethiopia are convening a conference in Addis Ababa on Monday to form a more broadly based provisional government -- a step viewed as vital to healing the ethnically divided, financially strapped country after years of civil war and famine.
But the meeting of Ethiopian factions, including the three rebel fronts that worked together to overthrow the Soviet-backed regime of the past 14 years, is expected to put off for the time being an issue critical to the country's long-term unity. That is the question of whether the province of Eritrea in the north of the country should become independent, an outcome favored by the rebel organization now in control there. 
 The meeting is taking place largely at the urging of the United States, the main foreign mediator in the Ethiopian conflict. Washington won a pledge that such a conference would be held from the front led by rebels from Tigre Province. In return, Washington gave political support to that group's takeover of Addis Ababa, the Ethiopian capital, last month.
 
Possibility of Economic Help
 A senior American diplomat said that if the Tigrean-led front can form an ethnically diverse government, then Western governments and the World Bank may show more interest in economic support for Ethiopia. Under the Marxist-Leninist rule of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, Washington gave large amounts of humanitarian assistance to Ethiopia, but because of the Mengistu Government's poor human rights record there was no economic assistance.
Diplomats said the question of the future of Eritrea was being put aside at this conference to allow the rebel group in Addis Ababa to broaden its base without the interference of such a contentious issue. An independent Eritrea would leave the rest of the country landlocked, depriving it of ports on the Red Sea.
At a meeting on June 16 between Isaias Afewerki, the leader of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front, and Meles Zenawi, the leader of the Tigrean-dominated Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, the two men agreed that Mr. Isaias would attend as an "interested observer" with no participation in the planned new transitional government, Mr. Isaias said.
 
Referendum on Independence
 The Tigrean-dominated front has agreed, as part of its tactical alliance with the Eritrean rebels, that Eritrea be allowed a United Nations-sponsored referendum on the question of independence. The Eritreans have said they are willing to delay the referendum for up to two years to give Ethiopia time to stabilize politically.
The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, is attending the meeting as an observer, he said, in contrast to the role he played as mediator at talks on the future of Ethiopia in London last month.
The United States played a key role in the Ethiopian conflict last month by encouraging the Tigrean-led fighters, who were at the outskirts of Addis Ababa as the Ethiopian Army of Col. Mengistu crumbled, to enter the city and fill the power vacuum. Mr. Cohen made clear at the time that United States economic assistance and political support was contingent on the rebels calling a conference by July 1 to form a provisional government.
Despite his insistence that the United States is only an "observer" at Monday's meeting -- along with European countries and perhaps the Soviet Union -- Washington officials appear to be playing an active role in the pre-conference proceedings.
 
U.S. Official in Addis Ababa
 Another State Department official, Irwin Hicks, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, is already in Addis Ababa talking with officials of the Tigrean-led front and its leader, Mr. Meles. The front started out in the early 1970's as an extreme Marxist-Leninist group but asserts that in the last few years it has shed its Communist program.
Mr. Cohen said he hoped that the conference would, as the front had outlined, establish a provisional government "representing all facets of Ethiopian society." It would work out election procedures for a constituent assembly which in turn would write a constitution, he said. The elections for the assembly would probably be held within six to nine months.
The front had also expressed the intention for the new provisional government to sign a charter on such principles as human rights and freedom of the press, Mr. Cohen said.
Both Ethiopians and Western diplomats said that two developments augured well for the conference to be held in Africa Hall, the headquarters of the Organization of African Unity.
 
Independence Demand Dropped
 The first was the pledge by the Oromo Liberation Front, one of the three partners in the loose coalition that fought the old government, to drop its demand for a separate state of Oromia. In an interview last week, Yohannis Lette, the deputy secretary general of the Oromo group, said the front would attend the conference with the hope of taking part in a multi-ethnic Ethiopia organized as a federation.
The Oromos are the largest ethnic group in Ethiopia, making up almost 50 percent of the population. They are predominantly Muslim and live mostly in the southern part of Ethiopia stretching from the Sudan border in the west to the Somali border in the east.
The second promising factor, officials said, was the decision of an exile group dominated by the Amhara ethnic group, the rulers of Ethiopia for the last century, to attend the conference. The Coalition of Ethiopian Democratic Forces, based in Washington, which has been extremely critical of the Tigrean group, said it would go to Addis Ababa in a "spirit of compromise to initiate a process of national reconciliation and lasting peace."

HEADLINE: A Period of Retrenchment for the World's Stock Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The second quarter was one of retrenchment for most of the world's major stock markets.
After first-quarter rallies fueled by the allied victory in the Persian Gulf war and the anticipation of economic recovery in the United States, many markets experienced consolidations and disappointments in the last three months. And with the absence of a hoped-for decline in interest rates in Europe, most of the Continent's markets suffered.
 
Mexico Still on Top
 According to an index compiled by The Financial Times of the performances of the stock markets in 24 countries, 18 declined in dollar terms in the second quarter, compared with 3 in the first, and half declined when measured in their own currencies, compared with none in the first quarter. 
 Mexico held its position as the top performer. Investors continued to bet that the country would benefit from an economic reform program and a free-trade agreement with the United States and Canada that is now being negotiated.
Mexico's market grew by 25.9 percent in the second quarter measured in pesos, and 24.9 percent in dollar terms. For the first six months of the year, it grew by 72.4 percent in pesos and 68.8 percent in dollars. But the rate of appreciation slowed by 10 percentage points in the second quarter from the first.
Reflecting the problems in Europe, the French stock market fell 3.6 percent measured in francs in the second quarter, compared with an 18.3 percent rise in the first quarter. For the first six months, the market rose 14 percent in francs but lost 5.6 percent in dollars.
The British market fell 2.5 percent in pounds in the second quarter after a 15.4 percent rise in the first quarter. In the first six months, it rose 12.5 percent measured in pounds, but slipped 5.6 percent in dollars.
The Swiss market inched up 83-hundredths of 1 percent in the second quarter in local currency after a 19.1 percent rally in the first. It grew 20.1 percent in local currency in the first six months, but dropped 1.7 percent in dollars.
The United States stock market declined 1.3 percent in the second quarter, compared with a rise of 14.1 percent in the first quarter and 12.6 percent in the six months.
 
Weakness in Tokyo
 The Tokyo stock market suffered from continued high interest rates and a scandal involving two of the nation's biggest brokerage houses. For the second quarter, the Tokyo market fell 7.4 percent in yen terms after a 13.1 percent rise in the first quarter. It rose by 4.6 percent measured in yen in the six months.
One surprise was the German stock market. In the first quarter, it was the worst performer in dollar terms, down 5.2 percent, and 21st measured in marks, with a rise of 7.7 percent. In the second quarter, the market kept the same pace, as confidence grew in the assimilation of eastern Germany, and some major foreign investors returned to the market.
Through Thursday, The Financial Times index for Germany was up 7.7 percent in the second quarter in local terms. But the market, worried about the imposition of new taxes, dropped sharply on Friday, ending the quarter with only a 4.7 percent rise in mark terms and a 2 percent decline in dollar terms. For the six months, the German market rose 12.8 percent measured in marks but fell 7.1 percent in dollar terms.
South Africa was another surprise, as local indexes exceeded or neared all-time highs. The market gained 16.3 percent in local currency and 15 percent in dollars in the second quarter, the second-best performance after Mexico's. The market had grown only 4.2 percent in terms of the rand and 8.3 percent in dollars in the first quarter. It grew 21.2 percent in rands and 24.5 percent in dollars in the first half.

HEADLINE: In Walkout at a G.M. Plant, Pay and Benefits Are Beside the Point

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, June 28

 BODY:
Randy Yates walked the picket line outside the General Motors minivan plant under a punishing sun, his shirt dark with sweat, and talked about why his co-workers were striking for reasons that have nothing to do with wages or benefits.
Since 400 workers were laid off in February at the plant on the Baltimore waterfront, Mr. Yates and his colleagues said, the remaining workers have had to work faster to keep up with the assembly line. They said the pace had led to numerous injuries. 
 "It's really a safety issue for us," said Mr. Yates, a 20-year veteran who works in the body shop. He said the body shop was "like an amusement park -- jobs come flying in and stop in front of you."
Tony Maraschillo, a 26-year veteran who works on the line, agreed that the company was, in effect, demanding that employees work faster, and that workers were being injured as a result. "When you don't have enough time to pay attention to what you're doing, you're going to get hurt," he said.
General Motors executives declined to discuss the strike, and the company's public relations department referred all inquiries to Terry Youngerman, the personnel director at the plant. "We haven't publicly discussed the issue at all," Mr. Youngerman said in a brief telephone interview, adding that the company intended to maintain its silence.
An estimated 3,200 members of Local 239 of the United Automobile Workers walked off the job on Monday, contending that there were not enough employees to keep up with the pace of the assembly line.
At the time of the layoffs in February, the company reduced the number of Chevrolet Astros and GMC Safaris required to be completed each hour. But the union contends that despite the reduction, to 42 from 47, the assembly line is still too fast to assure the safety of the reduced work force. It says there have been 300 injuries since February, 10 times the rate before the layoffs.
 
'Thumb Cut to the Bone'
 "One guy got his thumb cut to the bone," Mr. Yates said. "One guy got his tendons cut, and one guy got cut right through his glove."
The union also complains that the company has unfairly restricted employees' vacations because of a shortage of workers.
General Motors has sustained major financial losses this year, and has lost more than $2 billion in the past three quarters. Industry experts say reduced sales and profits have forced the company to cut costs wherever possible to maximize profits on lines of vehicles like the minivans, which have sold well even in the recession.
Negotiations on the production and safety issues began March 25. But the two sides failed to resolve the dispute before a union-imposed deadline of June 24. The union said 94 percent of its members had voted to strike.
 
New Talks Are Scheduled
 Union officials said negotiators had made some progress in talks since the strike began. Talks are scheduled to resume on July 1.
The union contends that its contract allows workers to strike over "production work standards."
"The bottom line is human rights," said Rodney A. Trump, president of the local.
Of the 400 workers who were laid off last winter, 200 were placed in programs to train them for other jobs at the plant and in education programs to obtain a high school equivalency diploma. These programs are jointly administered by General Motors and the union, and the employees receive their full salaries.
The remaining 200 workers received 95 percent of their net wages, less taxes and the cost of traveling to work. This comes to about 80 percent of what they earned on the job, Mr. Trump said. But these benefits expire after 36 weeks.
Union officials at the 56-year-old plant said that the base pay averaged $28,000 a year and that union members earn up to $40,000 with overtime.
Strikers receive $100 a week from the union, their full medical benefits, but no dental or optical benefits.
"We're not out over money," said Milt Slowikowsky, a union health and safety representative. "We're out because they're abusing our people."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Markets
 Mexico held its position as the world's top-performing stock market, as investors continued to bet that it would benefit from economic reform and a free-trade agreement with the U.S. and Canada. But many of the world's markets underwent consolidations and disappointments in the last three months, after rallies fueled by the allied victory in the Persian Gulf and the anticipation of an early economic recovery in the U.S. Stocks fell 3.6 percent in France, 2.5 percent in Britain and 7.4 percent in Japan. In the U.S., stock investors caught their breath after a strong previous quarter. [Page D3.] The Dow Jones industrial average closed 7.11 points lower for the quarter, and other indexes posted small declines. The New York Stock Exchange composite index was down 0.9 percent, while the American Stock Ex change index was down 0.3 percent and the over-the-counter index was down 1.3 percent. Of 3,999 stocks tracked by Media General, 1,891 were up in the quarter, and 1,951 were down, although more over-the-counter stocks rose than fell. The technology sector had a particularly bad quarter, with Compaq Com puter down 50.3 percent, Commodore Inter national down 36.7 percent and Silicon Graphics off 28.8 percent. [D3.]

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1991

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1535 words

HEADLINE: Kemp's Proposals on Poverty Given Sympathy, Not Action

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
A year ago, White House aides drafted a 10-page memorandum to provide President Bush with a vision for a war on poverty. They ran it past Jack F. Kemp, the Administration's Housing Secretary and anti-poverty czar.
"That's not a vision," Mr. Kemp complained in a letter to the White House. He was particularly annoyed by the document's call for two technical studies of how anti-poverty programs are financed and managed. 
 In a White House already criticized for "studying the problem to death," he wrote, the studies would drag on for another year. "Meanwhile, what's going on in our neighborhoods and on the streets?"
It is now a year later, and many Administration officials say Mr. Kemp's prophecy of endless study is close to coming true. When the President convened a Cabinet meeting this month for an anti-poverty report, the discussion swirled around one unenacted -- and some say tepidly endorsed -- legislative proposal, and the same two studies that had made Mr. Kemp cringe. The meeting then adjourned, pending further study.
In the Bush Administration, the fight against poverty has been a slow go. Its pace illustrates the difficulties that arise when a conservative like Mr. Kemp tries to rally a Republican Administration around what have historically been Democratic concerns.
Mr. Kemp's anti-poverty platform sails under the banner of "empowerment," a market-driven strategy that seeks to give the poor more power by letting them bypass Government bureaucracy. Arguing that such bureaucracies have ruined public housing and education, he calls for programs to help the poor buy their own homes and choose their children's schools. In addition, he wants tax breaks for businesses that locate near poor neighborhoods.
Inside the Administration, officials are quick to voice their sympathies for Mr. Kemp's plans but slow to provide the financial or political capital needed to make them a widespread reality. Mr. Kemp's anti-poverty plan may even be at peak political utility in its current, unrealized form -- costing nothing but giving the Administration an answer to those who say it lacks domestic vision.
 
Seeking to Help Republicans
 Mr. Kemp has argued that a fight against poverty is both morally right and politically profitable for the Republican Party. But his rivals note that it would also be politically profitable for Mr. Kemp, giving increased prominence to the former Presidential contender who is likely to be one again in the future.
And Mr. Kemp's critics say his oratorical onslaughts often outpace his ability to produce new proposals. "If you try to corner him, there's nothing more he wants to propose," said one White House aide, noting that the President has already backed Mr. Kemp's main ideas.
Mr. Kemp's admirers say the President should emulate his passion; his distractors call Mr. Kemp bombastic.
Visibly frustrated, the Secretary continues to seek a fuller commitment from Mr. Bush, urging him, at the June 20 Cabinet meeting, to put pressure on Congress by appealing directly to the American people.
 
Like to See 'High-Profile'
 "I don't want to be quoted saying I'm urging him to go public, but it's no secret I'd like to see a high-profile, anti-poverty, pro-growth and opportunity agenda," Mr. Kemp said in an interview shortly after the meeting. "The Cabinet needs to do a better job of highlighting it and so does the White House."
White House memorandums and copies of Mr. Kemp's correspondence were provided, on the condition of anonymity, by someone outside his office who is dissatisfied with the Administration's domestic policy. Asked about them this week, Mr. Kemp worried that other officials would suspect him as the source and accuse him of disloyalty.
But he made few efforts to disguise his dissatisfaction. "I don't think the prophecy has come true, but it's in danger of coming true if we don't convert our legislative agenda," he said.
In making the transition from Mr. Bush's Presidential rival to his Housing Secretary, Mr. Kemp has faced political perils. As a free-wheeling, high-profile Congressman, he had managed to keep himself in view with pronouncements on issues from Russian history to the gold standard. Now he is parked atop an obscure bureaucracy, with fewer opportunities to round out a Presidential resume.
 
Other Events Take Stage
 He played virtually no role in the two biggest events of the past year: a budget deal he disliked and a war that pushed him and his anti-poverty plan further from public view.
Until last September, the Administration's anti-poverty planning was controlled by a junior White House group called the Low Income Opportunity Board, whose cautious efforts provoked Mr. Kemp's exasperation.
In May 1990, Mr. Kemp voiced his frustrations in a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who coordinates the Cabinet's domestic planning. "It is past time for the Administration to aggressively highlight a new comprehensive anti-poverty agenda," Mr. Kemp said.
And his agitation grew last June, when White House planners circulated their 10-page memorandum, cautioning against major new intiatives and recommending two studies. "The Administration has already been criticized in the press for studying the problem to death and throwing up its hands," Mr. Kemp wrote to Mr. Thornburgh in July.
By September, Mr. Kemp had persuaded the President to replace the board with a new planning group, the Economic Empowerment Task Force, headed by Mr. Kemp. But White House officials treated the change with what Mr. Kemp's admirers regard as a characteristic lack of enthusiasm, avoiding any public announcement.
The inclusion of the word "empowerment" marked a subtle but important change. It is a favorite phrase of Mr. Kemp and like-minded young conservatives who argue that its market-driven principles are radically new and can be widely applied.
But the term gained a new enemy last fall when the budget director, Richard G. Darman, set off a minor fury in a speech mocking what he called sloganeering. Instead he called for better "resource allocation" and improved management.
Mr. Kemp fumed. "Solving poverty does not mean green-eyeshade thinking about 'resource allocation' and 'better administration,' " he wrote last fall to the White House.
Mr. Kemp was additionally hemmed in by last fall's budget deal, which required that any expansion of domestic spending in one area be accompanied by cuts in another.
Despite the impediments, Mr. Kemp managed to get Mr. Bush to endorse an eight-point legislative agenda.
It included the items central to the empowerment proposals, like those involving homes and schools. It also included other Administration causes, like an expansion of the Federal death penalty.
Some officials point to this agenda as evidence that Mr. Bush has a distinctive domestic program and they blame Congress for failing to enact it.
But some Kemp allies complain that the program has received little more than Presidential lip service.
"It's a repackaging job, a way of describing a few things without any strong intellectual or political commitment to it," said Stuart Butler of the Heritage Foundation, who is an intellectual godfather to the empowerment movement. "What's lacking is Presidential leadership."
Asked about Mr. Butler's view, Mr. Kemp hedged, "I would say all of us need to do more."
 
Going It Alone
 Mr. Kemp's supporters say the Congressional fight over the proposal on home ownership reveals the tepid White House support. After Mr. Kemp's request for $855 million was cut to $200 million by the House Appropriations Committee, he lobbied the full House and squeezed out an extra $150 million.
But he did so alone, with none of the White House push that accompanies top priority items. "Kemp's off getting his head dented trying to push Congress into things that are broader, deeper, larger," said one White House aide involved in the anti-poverty plans.
Some of what makes Mr. Kemp different from others in the Administration is his political calculus. He sees his proposals as an opportunity to win over new voting blocs and talks about restoring Republicans as the party of Lincoln and black liberation. But others see political peril. Last summer's White House memorandum warned that giving poverty "greater visibility" could lead to measures that are "too expensive" and that create a need "to demonstrate concrete success by 1992."
Mr. Kemp greets such arguments with impatience. "Poverty already has a high public visibility," he wrote Mr. Thornburgh last spring.
 
Back at Planning Stages
 As its legislative proposals languish, empowerment is back at the planning stages, as was clear at this month's Cabinet meeting.
Mr. Kemp himself had nothing new to lay on the table, except his familiar calls for a firmer White House embrace of his current program. Once again, he received a polite Presidential reception, but no commitments.
As the meeting adjourned, Marlin Fitzwater, the President's press secretary, turned to an associate and remarked on Mr. Kemp's value as an oratorical asset. Mr. Kemp sounds good, he said, noting the benefits in keeping him talking.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Gadflies of Today Parcel the Blame Among Old Allies

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
A decade ago, a Harlem community organizer was instrumental in mobilizing an emotional protest against New York City's plan to close Sydenham Hospital.
The protesters ultimately lost. But the city's decision to shut the hospital generated enduring distrust of the Koch administration by many black New Yorkers. Years later, that animus helped elect Mayor David N. Dinkins. Now, with poor people again bearing the brunt of many city economies, the organizer from Harlem is back -- this time as Mr. Dinkins's deputy mayor. 
 "In the Sydenham days, it was very easy to criticize and make judgments about what should be," Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch recalled the other day. "I might have come to the same conclusion, but having the information and the responsibility makes a big difference."
That Mr. Lynch and so many other gadflies came in from the cold to join city government has, in effect, inhibited the latest crop of community organizers. Otherwise, they might have been more vigorously protesting the threatened reduction of hospital services and the closing of health clinics planned now not only in Harlem but, perhaps more equitably, all over the city.
 Last week, the individual who was most instrumental in goading Mr. Dinkins and the City Council to restore more than $50 million in vital medical services was no radical street organizer, but a Fifth Avenue physician. Dr. Kevin M. Cahill, a Koch appointee to the city's Board of Health, had threatened to invoke the board's broad powers and declare a health emergency unless the cuts were restored.
No newcomer to public service, Dr. Cahill was a key adviser to Gov. Hugh L. Carey, who, with the financier Felix G. Rohatyn, helped rescue the city from bankruptcy in 1975.
Yet New York today is a very different city from the one that survived the fiscal crisis in 1975. It is difficult to quantify that difference. And surely some benchmarks are for the better. But officials say a city that sheltered 2,400 homeless adults then now houses about 7,500 adults and 7,900 children. Nearly twice as many one-parent families with children are living in poverty. The AIDS virus, unreported in 1975, now afflicts more than 32,000 New Yorkers. The number of children living in foster care has climbed from 29,000 to more than 49,000.
The social and economic ramifications of these crises have inspired Mr. Lynch's fresh perspective. They provoked Nancy G. Wackstein, an exasperated former private advocate who now directs the Mayor's Office of Homelessness, to express concern about encampments by homeless people and declare: "Maybe if you turn down the comfort level in public places they will come inside." And they prompted Barbara J. Sabol, the Human Resources Commissioner, to appeal to homeless men living in a Brooklyn armory to recognize their responsibilities -- a word applied infrequently -- to their temporary home and neighborhood.
The political implications of the new social and economic realities inherited by Mr. Dinkins are also compelling, considering that many of his constituents are, understandably, less interested in shrinking the pie than in belatedly getting a bigger slice.
"There's a trust factor -- that David Dinkins really does care and that if he could do something different he would," Mr. Lynch says. But when Dennis Rivera, head of the hospital workers union, dined with Mr. Lynch and the Mayor last month, he put his cards on the table: "Today, we would not be able to get the kind of enthusiasm to get 8,000 members to come out to elect a mayor who won by 43,000 votes out of 1.8 million."
Mr. Rivera is leading a new coalition to elect more independent Council members -- more independent of the current leadership, that is. And, depending on whether the Mayor and Mr. Lynch embrace the coalition's platform, perhaps more independent of Mr. Dinkins, too.
"My appeal to the Mayor was to rebuild his coalition, to re-energize the people who elected him," Mr. Rivera said, "not for the objective of getting re-elected, but for governing."
Many people who voted for Mr. Dinkins the first time may have been more confident that he was the right candidate at the right time in New York's political evolution than, necessarily, the right Mayor. "The primary was between a healer and a divider, the general election between a Democrat and a Republican," Mr. Rivera recalled. "But there was not a clear vision of what we get once we elect him."
What they have gotten after 18 months is a Mayor who expanded the police force and slashed the rest of the budget, including social services, while largely keeping his core constituency quiet, which may have been one of the unspoken reasons some people supported him.
Mr. Dinkins, says Mr. Rivera, "has de-mobilized the coalition that elected him."

HEADLINE: Bank of Japan Cuts Its Rate To 5.5 Percent

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, July 1

 BODY:
Japan today lowered its benchmark interest rate by a half percentage point, to 5.5 percent, ending its two-year-old policy of keeping interest rates high to wring inflation out of the economy.
The announcement by the Bank of Japan, which came at 12:15 P.M. here, appeared intended to spur Japan's economy from a recent slowdown in growth. The country is headed toward its longest-running economic expansion in post-war history -- it is two months short of the record of 57 months, set more than 20 years ago -- and the bank has reccently come under increasing pressure to lower its rates to spur capital spending and revive the lagging stock market.
 
Tokyo Stocks Surge
 The announcement came after widespread speculation that an increase was imminent. The speculation sent the Nikkei index of 250 issues up 370.71 points, or 1.59 percent, to 23,661.67, in active morning trading, reversing a steady decline last week. And the yen strengthened somewhat against the dollar. At noon, the American currency was quoted at 137.80 yen, down from its close of 138.15 on Friday. 
 Today's reduction in the discount rate, the rate the central bank charges banks for short-term loans, was the first since February 1987, when the Bank of Japan cut the discount rate to just 2.5 percent. But in May 1989, the bank began to push up interest rates in an effort to stem what the central bank's governor, Yasushi Mieno, said were dangerous signs of inflation. Mr. Mieno has consistently viewed inflation as a bigger threat to the country's health than a slowdown in growth.
 
Urged by Washington
 The reduction seems likely to be welcomed by the United States, which has been pushing Japan and Germany for months to ease interest rates. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had urged rate cuts to quicken economic growth around the world at a time of recession in the United States.
Lower Japanese interest rates would also tend to free more Japanese capital to flow abroad to areas with shortages of capital, like Eastern Europe and the United States. Washington's big budget deficits require the sale of tens of billions of dollars of Treasury bonds to foreigners each year.
Politically, a rate cut now seems excellently timed.
The leaders of the seven leading industrial democracies plan to meet in London in two weeks. The cut may ease American pressures on Japan at the meeting and give more weight to Japan's views -- in particular, its staunch opposition to providing financial support to the Soviet Union.
Over the weekend, Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, said that Japan would not extend massive help to the Soviet Union until it made significant progress on resolving the longstanding territorial debate over the Northern Islands, a cluster of four islands that the Soviets have occupied since the last days of World War II.
The announcement capped several weeks of conflicting signals about whether the Bank of Japan would acceed to pressures for a reduction. Several newspapers, including the Nihon Keizei Shimbun, Japan's leading financial daily, have predicted in recent weeks that the cut was imminent, only to be contradicted by Mr. Mieno.
 
A Cooling Economy
 After the Japanese economy blazed ahead at a rate of more than 5 percent last year, economists are predicting that it will grow about 3 percent to 3.5 percent this year. That rate is still considered a healthy pace, particularly compared with growth in the United States.
Paul Summerville, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities here, said there were clearer signs now that the economy was cooling. Housing construction and industrial production have been declining, according to figures released last week.
Consumer inflation appears to have diminished to about 3.5 percent, from its high of about 4.5 percent in January. There are also indications that Japan's labor shortage, while still severe, is easing somewhat. Overheated property prices -- one of Mr. Mieno's special targets -- have also shown some signs of slowing.
Not least, the stock market has been sluggish for more than a year, and it has fallen sharply in recent weeks. Analysts have attributed part of the recent drop to a scandal involving Japan's Big Four securities houses. But they have also said it stemmed from disappointment that the central bank had not moved to cut interest rates at a time when the economy was clearly expanding at a slower pace.

HEADLINE: New York Area Military Sites Spared

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
On Staten Island, where jobs for 4,200 civilians and about as many military personnel were at stake, sailors voiced relief. So did officials in New Jersey, who had worried that Fort Dix would be closed.
Both military installations were recommended for reprieves yesterday by a seven-member commission that had been considering closing them along with other forts, shipyards and naval bases the Pentagon had said it no longer needed. 
 "Anchors aweigh," said the Staten Island Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, after the Base Closure and Realignment Commission voted to keep open the naval port there.
 
Glee and Gloom
 Dozens of other communities from Massachusetts to California that are home to military bases got a glimpse of the future yesterday -- bright or bleak, depending on what the seven-member decided.
Military bases mean big money for cities and towns; soldiers and their families pump billions of dollars into local economies.
For towns facing base closings, which still have to go the President and Congress, the panel's decisions may mean big problems. Landlords began worrying about how to fill apartments now rented to soldiers. Owners of shoe stores worried about not outfitting military families with fast-growing children. Managers of movie theaters worried about empty seats at their sixplexes.
 
Concern From Dinkins
 But on Staten Island, the mood was upbeat.
"This was definitely the right decision," said Lieut. Roxie Thompson, who is stationed at the Staten Island installation. "I would have hated to leave New York, as it has treated us wonderfully."
The Staten Island port came off the drawing boards in the Reagan Administration days of big military budgets and dreams of a 600-ship fleet. Now the Navy appears headed for 500-ship strength, and there is less of a threat of nuclear war.
The Staten Island port had been the target of protests because the Navy wanted to it to be the home base for warships with nuclear weapons. Mayor David N. Dinkins, who announced his opposition to the project during his 1989 campaign, said yesterday that keeping the port open could endanger the city.
"While I fully recognize that our nation must always keep a strong defense in place, I continue to have great concern over the establishment of a base with nuclear-capable weapons in New York Harbor," he said.
 
Reprieve for Fort Dix
 The Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission, which is led by a former Congressman from New Jersey, Jim Courter, also gave Fort Dix a reprieve by rejecting the Pentagon's plan to close the base and leave only a skeleton crew to train Army reservists. Gov. Jim Florio took time out from budget deliberations in Trenton to applaud the action.
"Losing Fort Dix would have been a mistake that would have hurt the people who work there and live in the area," the Governor said, "and it would have compromised our nation's ability to respond to a crisis as swiftly and surely as we did in the Persian Gulf."
Officials in Philadelphia were glum after the commission voted to close the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard and the Philadelphia Naval Station, which employ more than 9,000 people in Philadephia and southern New Jersey.
"This is penny-wise, dollar-foolish bureaucratic nonsense and we've got to fight it to the end," said Senator Harris Wofford, a Pennsylvania Democrat.
Representative Thomas M. Foglietta, a Democrat, accused the Bush Administration of telling Pennsylvania and Philadelphia "to drop dead." But he said that a Congressional directive sending the U.S.S. Kennedy to the Navy yard for repairs would keep that installation going until mid-1996.
That would save some but not all of the military jobs in Philadelphia. Robert C. Wonderling, president of the Penjerdel Council, an non-profit association of businesses in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, said that closing the base would put 23,000 Pennsylvanians and 8,700 New Jersey residents out of work.
He estimated that the shutdown would mean a loss of $24 million in annual tax revenues to Pennsylvania and another $43.2 million in annual tax revenues to the city. He also estimated that between 13 and 17 percent of the laid-off workers would leave the Delaware Valley region.
In California, local officials tried to calculate what the panel's split decision on installations in Long Beach would mean. The commission voted to close the Long Beach Naval Station, but spared the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, which the Navy said was vital to its mission.
The local Chamber of Commerce estimated that Navy families spend about $1.5 billion a year. "You can reduce that figure by about half and that's what we'll be losing," said John Higginson, a retired admiral who is the president of the Long Beach Area Chamber of Commerce.
Mr. Higginson breezed through the calculations: There are 35 ships based at the Long Beach Naval Station, with 200 to 400 sailors each. That means that the community will be losing 7,000 to 14,000 military people, not including spouses or children.
"It's a large number and it will make a significant impact on Long Beach," he said. "Fortunately, we saved half a loaf" by keeping the shipyard open.
 
'Everyone Is Upset'
 Fort Ord, near Seaside, Calif, was not so lucky. The commission went along with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's recommendation that it be shut down.
"Everyone is upset about it," said Sharon Green, a manager of a grocery store in nearby Marina, Calif. "Almost all of the businesses in Marina rely on military families."
The manager of a Denny's restaurant in Marina speculated that the base closing would mean laying off a third of the restaurant's 93 workers.
But for some business people, the only certainty was uncertainty. Joseph Anastasi, the owner of a seafood restaurant on Fisherman's Wharf in Monterey, said the shutdown would "hurt the whole community, but I really don't know how much."

HEADLINE: King's Dream Lives Again at Site of His Death

BYLINE: By MARY B. W. TABOR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, June 30

 BODY:
For years, the motel where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968 stood amid dilapidated warehouses, a crumbling memorial to the civil rights leader.
But this week, the Lorraine Motel celebrates its rebirth as the National Civil Rights Museum. 
 The motel, once one of the few lodging houses in the city where blacks could stay, has been gutted and rebuilt to hold what museum officials say will be the first comprehensive exhibit documenting the civil rights movement in this country. Only the facade resembles the original Lorraine.
Civic leaders hope that the museum will both revitalize the forlorn Mulberry Street neighborhood, long overrun by prostitutes and drug dealers, and sweeten racial relations. Businesses and foundations managed by whites donated $1.3 million for the $9.7 million museum, with the rest of the money coming from city, state, Shelby County and other private donations.
Construction delays have postponed the museum's opening, scheduled for July 4, until Aug. 31. But keeping with the original schedule, celebrations honoring the museum began today, and several of the museum's exhibits are already in place.
Focusing on the civil rights movement during the 1950's and 1960's, the museum's 10,000 square feet of exhibition space will include an auditorium and extensive audio, video, and photographic diplays of civil rights protests in cities and towns across the country.
Visitors, to be charged $5 for admission, will be able to sit at a lunch counter alongside statues of black students defying the ban against their presence and two jeering white men. Film footage of actual demonstrations will play on a screen behind.
Museum-goers may also board a city bus from Montgomery, Ala., like the one Rosa Parks rode in 1955 when she refused to give up her seat to a white passenger, setting off a 381-day bus boycott by blacks.
Those who sit in the front seats of the bus will trigger a recording of a southern male voice, like that of the bus driver Mrs. Parks encountered, asking them to give up their seats. The message becomes progressively harsher until the driver explains that in the 1950's such defiance from a black passenger would have resulted in an arrest.
 
Bloodstained Slab Is Reset
 Two of the motel rooms, those Dr. King rented so he could lead a march in support of striking city workers, have been restored and preserved. One, which motel residents had turned into a shrine, now displays original furniture set up as it was the night of April 4, 1968, when Dr. King stepped out on his balcony before leaving to visit a local minister. It was there that James Earl Ray, aiming from a building across the street, shot him.
The bloodstained concrete slab where Dr. King fell has been reset on the balcony walkway. His body lies entombed at the Martin Luther King Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta.
More than 100 celebrities and civil rights advocates, including Mrs. Parks, Coretta Scott King, the actor Morgan Freeman and the folk singer Pete Seeger, are taking part in events that began today and will continue through Thursday in honor of the museum.

 
Easter Site of King Story
 The festivities opened with a citywide worship service with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the Rev. Joseph E. Lowery at Mason Temple, where Dr. King, on the eve of his death, said God had "allowed me to go up to the mountain and I've looked over and I've seen the Promised Land," adding, "I may not get there with you."
At the service, Mr. Jackson, who witnessed the assassination, called Memphis the Easter site of the King story. "To not have this museum in Memphis would be like the Christians celebrating Christmas and never celebrating Easter," Mr. Jackson called out to a congregation of 1,000 people, who sat fanning themselves in the steamy heat.
"Memphis, his last sermon. Memphis, the vision of the mountaintop. Memphis, the last march. Memphis, the last interruption. Memphis, the last breath," he said.
Most Memphis residents welcome the civil rights museum as an asset to the city, which has long relied on Elvis Presley's Graceland mansion as its major tourist attraction.
 
'A Blessing for Generations'
 "The museum will serve as an anchor for growth and revitalization for an otherwise deteriorating section of downtown Memphis," D'Army Bailey, a state circuit court judge and president of the not-for-profit foundation responsible for the museum, said in an interview. "It also serves as a signal to the world that Memphis has come to grip with the tragedy of Dr. King's death here, and has drawn from it the tools to mold a unique educational tool."
Calvin C. Brown, who lived at the motel for 16 years and used to show Dr. King's room to interested visitors, agreed. "It isn't going to draw like Elvis Presley, but it should attract people from all parts of the world and will be a blessing for generations to come," he said.
But others have protested that Dr. King would have wanted the museum money used to help the destitute. One woman, a former motel employee and resident who was evicted in 1988, has defiantly camped across the street outside the project for three years.
 
'A Waste of Money'
 "These people are playing with history in order to make a buck," said Jacqueline Smith, who lived at the Lorraine for 16 years before her eviction. "It should have been converted into housing for the poor, the homeless or the elderly. That's what we need in this neighborhood." The $5 admission charge will be too expensive for many of the poor people who live there, she added.
Arun Gandhi, the grandson of Mohandas K. Gandhi, and a journalist who is starting up The Gandhi Institute for the Study of Nonviolence at Christian Brothers University in Memphis, has also criticized the project.
"I think my grandfather and Martin Luther King had the same dream," Mr. Gandhi said. "And they didn't want people to erect statues and museums in their memory. It's a waste of money."
Still, the museum is expected to serve as an important bridge for a city where blacks and whites have often been slow to join hands.
Although blacks make up 55 percent of Memphis's more than 900,000 residents, whites have kept a tight grip on the city's social, political and economic institutions. The Mayor, Richard C. Hackett, is white, as are 10 of the 13 City Council members. A majority of blacks work in low-paying jobs, and many live at or below the poverty line.
 
Cause for Hope
 Tensions worsened in recent months when black leaders trying to find a black mayoral candidate held community meetings and made it clear whites were not welcome. In addition, a pending Justice Department lawsuit charges that the city's election system has undermined black voting strength.
But on Tuesday, in an effort to defuse some of the tension, the City Council approved a redistricting plan that creates another city council district with a black majority.
Many here see the opening of the museum as another bright spot.
"I cannot think of anything in my experience in Memphis that has had a more unifying impact for blacks and whites here," said Mr. Bailey. "They are really proud of this."
Sitting alone in his downtown tailoring shop, just a few blocks from the new museum, Ellis Rivers grows solemn when asked what effect the project has had on him.
"It makes me think," said Mr. Rivers, who attended Dr. King's mountaintop sermon and his funeral. "If all of us could love each other as God's children, not looking at color," he said, his voice trailing off into silence.

HEADLINE: AT THE BUDGET WALL;
ACCORD REACHED FOR GRIM BUDGET IN NEW YORK CITY

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
With Mayor David N. Dinkins and the City Council splitting much of their difference on tax increases and service cuts, New York City officials reached an agreement last night on the outlines of a grim, recession-dominated budget that will raise the cost of living and lower the quality of services in the city.
The agreement came after months of wrangling that culminated in tense negotiations that ended only as the deadline for adopting a budget loomed. In the hours before the agreement, the Council, operating under new powers granted under the new City Charter, had renewed a threat to adopt its own version of the budget without input from the Mayor. 
 Under the agreement, taxes in the $29 billion budget would rise by $735 million, including a $335 million income tax increase pending in Albany and a property tax increase of $400 million, about half the property tax rise proposed by Mr. Dinkins. Council approval is needed for the property-tax increase, which would mean an average rise of 10.7 percent for homeowners and 8 percent for owners of cooperative apartments.
 
Layoffs Are Not Reversed
 Most of the $1.5 billion in service cuts proposed by the Mayor would go forward under the agreement, along with the layoffs of 10,000 workers, including 6,000 who were dismissed on Friday.
But at least $117 million of the most damaging reductions in city services -- from the closing of prenatal clinics to the padlocking of libraries -- will be restored. The Council had sought to restore about $220 million in proposed service cuts but seemed to split the difference with the Mayor.
"This budget contains a lot more pain, and a lot less gain than any of us would like," Mr. Dinkins said at a news conference last night he held jointly with Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone.
"This is an example of what we can do in the worst of times," Mr. Vallone said.
The changes from the Mayor's budget would be paid for in part by at least $200 million in other cuts, including $10 million from an across-the-board cut in managers at city agencies, $20 million in supplies and $50 million from cuts in the Police Department that would result in the postponement of the hiring of civilian workers who were supposed to free deskbound police officers for patrol duty.
The rest would come out of nooks and crannies in the city's complex budget, including $125 million through bond refinancing and other one time revenues and $150 million from higher forecasts of tax estimates.
Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director, attributed the higher tax revenues to higher estimates of real-estate, corporate and business tax collections made in the last week as new tax collection data became available. Though fiscal analysts often criticize the use of nonrecurring revenue in city budget balancing, Mr. Michael said he expected little concern over the revenues found by his office to clinch the budget agreement.
 
Seeking Concessions
 Mr. Dinkins is seeking concessions from city unions in an effort to avert some or all of the layoffs, and late last night city officials were considering a proposal from union leaders that would avert many layoffs through a wage deferral, an early-retirement program and stepped up attrition.
City officials discounted the possiblity of an imminent agreement. Asked if he was optimistic, Barry Feinstein, the teamsters union leader, said: "It depends on what they come back with. All the elements for a solution are on the table."
In reaching an agreement, Mr. Dinkins was forced to give way on tax increases that he had fought vigorously for over many weeks, and to embrace a budget that included service cuts he considered unthinkable only a few months ago.
But at the same time, succeeding in putting together any kind of budget at all under such adverse circumstances could serve the Mayor well in the face of relentless questioning of his administration's ability to manage the city's affairs. And it also makes calls for a takeover of the city's finances by the state's Financial Control Board seem a far more distant possibility.
 
Sweet Compromise for Some
 For the often maligned Council, the compromise was sweet. By fighting both for lower taxes and fewer service cuts, Council members gained political capital to use in the November elections. And by dropping plans to pass their own budget -- after establishing it as a credible threat -- they avoided the risks of a prolonged fight with the Mayor.
The budget agreement came so late, that negotiators said it would take most of the night to fill in all the details and most of today to print the budget, delaying the adoption until tonight at the earliest. Some Council aides said the delay was the longest in at least several decades.
But with the city's fiscal problems so severe, many officials were predicting that whatever budget was put into place now would soon change to take into account concessions from municipal unions or the further decline in the city's fiscal picture forecast by the City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.
In addition, the budget could be further altered if Mayor Dinkins succeeded in his quest to get up to $350 million from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation, through bond refinancing, to reduce or postpone the impact of the worst of the service cuts. Felix G. Rohatyn, the corporation's chairman, said he would consider the move later in the year after the city can show that it has a long-term plan to solve its fiscal problems that is acceptable to the city's bond rating agencies.
The financial crisis and the ensuing negotiations with the state, the City Council and the unions have been a crucial test for Mr. Dinkins as he struggles with the most difficult political and fiscal challenge of his career.
For weeks he has agonized publicly, over the possibility that the Financial Control Board, a state oversight body, could step in and usurp much of his governing authority, a move that the Mayor has abhorred as what could be a devastating personal and institutional symbol.
Mr. Dinkins remained closeted in his office and did not directly pariticpate in any negotiations with the council in the last few days. He first appeared in public at a 10 P.M. news conference, five hours after the agreement was reached by his aides yesterday. In staff talks that began at 1:30 A.M. yesterday and broke off near dawn, negotiators for the Mayor and the Council had all but agreed on the outlines of a new budget, divided by as little as $40 million, or a little more than one-tenth of 1 percent of the budget.
But when negotiators returned to City Hall later yesterday, the talks faltered -- a breakdown the Mayor's aides attributed to a misunderstanding but the Council said stemmed from disarray and disagreement among the Mayor's aides.
Late last night, negotiators continued to work out a list of programs that would be restored, at least in part. Few details were available, but officials confirmed that the Central Park Zoo would not be closed, libraries and musuems would get more funds, while many social service programs targetted for elimination would be saved.
The income-tax rate increase has been help up by the State Senate out of concern that the overall tax burden in the city was going too high while the government was not being trimmed enough.
But yesterday, after meeting with state legislative leaders over the weekend on a new state budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said the city would get the $663 million in help from the state that it was counting on as part of its current budget. "They can now feel secure that they will get the entire $663 million they needed in revenues, mandates and cash, either in exactly the form they asked for it, or in some alternate form," he said.

HEADLINE: AT THE BUDGET WALL;
Budget Package For New Jersey Signed Into Law

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 30

 BODY:
The state adopted a new budget tonight for the fiscal year that begins on Monday, and the plan's Democratic sponsors said it would result in the layoffs of 2,000 to 3,000 state employees.
The $14.7 billion budget, which was signed by Gov. Jim Florio at 11:54 P.M., also includes the $400 million sale of a section of highway in Bergen County to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. 
 Although its sponsors said the budget included no new taxes, it was immediately assailed by Republicans in the Senate and General Assembly as fiscally irresponsible and bound to bring higher taxes in future years.
The plan was passed by both houses this evening in votes that divided generally along party lines.
Days of legislative wrangling came to a dramatic denouement shortly after the 43-to-37 vote in the Assembly, when a bomb threat sent members scurrying into the summer night.
A state trooper rushed the budget documents out of the State House, as Democrats and Republicans who had recently been attacking one another on the Assembly floor mingled on the sidewalk exchanging jokes about exactly who was the intended target. No bomb was found, and the members returned to the chamber a few minutes later. Mr. Florio then signed the budget documents at the Governor's Mansion in Princeton.
"I'm pleased to be able to sign a budget that keeps opportunity very much alive for the people of New Jersey," Mr Florio said, "even as a national recession threatens other states' ability to provide basic services."
The budget, agreed to by legislative leaders late Saturday night in closed-door negotiations, appeared to strike a balance between Senate and Assembly Democrats who had argued bitterly over the number of layoffs necessary to balance the budget and protect the state's bond rating.
Facing a deadline of 12:01 A.M. Monday to have a balanced budget in place, the Senate approved the budget plan earlier this evening by a vote of 22 to 18, mostly along party lines.
Earlier in the evening, the Democratic leaders of both houses also agreed to repeal a sales tax on household paper products -- a tax that had become a rallying cry to anti-tax protesters, who often went to Trenton in the last year waving rolls of toilet paper.
"The full mosaic of this budget makes the best of difficult economic conditions," said Senator Laurence S. Weiss, the chairman of the State Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee. "This is a responsible budget that will withstand the pressure of an uncertain economy."
Even though the budget plan included layoffs, the package won the support of leaders of the state's largest public employees union, the Communications Workers of America. In recent weeks the union had voiced fiery opposition to cutting costs at the expense of their members' jobs.
The union's national vice president, Jan D. Pierce, praised the package today for not affecting the raises and other benefits promised in the union's current contract.
 
'No Layoffs,' T-Shirts Say
 "A militant and aggressive posture on the part of a union pays off," Mr. Pierce said, standing in a State House lobby amid a crowd of union members wearing red T-shirts that said "Fund the contract, no layoffs."
Under the plan, the state would fill a $1.5 billion budget shortfall with a combination of measures, including the $400 million sale of four miles of Interstate 95 in Bergen County to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority. The state would also add $620 million in revenues by speeding up the collection of utility taxes. In addition, officials said an accounting change would enable the state to receive $220 million in increased Federal reimbursement for Medicaid.
The new budget plan would give colleges and universities $48 million more in aid than originally proposed by Mr. Florio in January. A total of $4 million would be restored to the New Jersey Network, the state-run public television system. The plan also provides an increase of $5.5 million for social-services programs for people with AIDS.
But Republican legislators said they were far from sanguine about the compromise package, especially the highway sale, which they described as fiscally irresponsible.
"Instead of downsizing government, you chose instead to resort to a series of one-shot gimmicks that build in deficits for every budget year well into the 1990's," the Assembly minority leader, Garabed Haytaian, said as he faced Democratic legislators in the Assembly chamber this evening.
