HEADLINE: AT THE BUDGET WALL;
Weicker Vetoes a Sales-Tax Plan, But Delays Budget Deadline a Day

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Monday, July 1

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vetoed a plan by the Legislature early this morning to solve Connecticut's budget crisis without an income tax, but he postponed for 24 hours his threat to shut down a large part of the state government.
Mr. Weicker had threatened to furlough thousands of state employees and suspend all nonessential services beginning today if no budget was approved by 12:01 this morning, the start of the new fiscal year. But shortly after the midnight deadline passed, he said that progress was being made and that one more day could bring forth a budget he would sign. 
 The Governor said, however, that the no-income-tax budget passed by the Legislature Sunday night would harm the state's economy. "It was a shocking display of ignoring reality in favor of personal philosophy," he said.
Lawmakers said they were uncertain that Mr. Weicker's executive order to postpone the shutdown was enough of a legal stopgap until a full budget was in place. The Senate unanimously approved a resolution to pay the state's bills for the next two weeks, and the House adjourned at 2 A.M., with its leaders saying the resolution would probably be taken up later today.
Mr. Weicker declined to say what specific progress he saw in the negotiations. But one alternative income-tax plan, sponsored by Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich, was thought to be gaining in support among lawmakers even as the non-income-tax plan -- a proposal to greatly expand the state's sales tax, applying it to many more kinds of transactions -- was being passed and vetoed.
The Nickerson plan would impose a 4.7 percent flat income tax on $25,000 for a couple filing jointly, or $12,500 for an individual, and would lower the sales tax from 8 percent to 6 percent. It was portrayed as a compromise: a lower income tax and a higher sales tax than in Mr. Weicker's proposal, which had been definitively rejected by the House of Representatives late Saturday.
Mr. Nickerson said this morning that no count had been taken as to how many votes the plan might have in either chamber.
But sponsors of the sales-tax plan vetoed by the Governor said that it might not be dead either. Deputy minority leader Richard O. Belden, a Republican from Shelton, said that if a Nickerson-type plan came up for a vote and failed, a move might be made to override the Governor's veto. The Senate, with a 24 to 12 vote on the non-income-tax plan, already apparently has the two-thirds needed to override.
The actions came on a harrowing day as officials struggled to resolve the crisis caused by a $2.8 billion gap in the $8.1 billion budget. With tempers frayed and time running short, Mr. Weicker's threats hung like a sword over every decision and closeted party caucus.
Late Sunday, after hours of wavering back and forth about what to do, legislators apparently decided to push back, announcing that they would bring up for vote the sales-tax expansion that Mr. Weicker said he hates
The Senate approved the sales-tax plan at about 11 P.M. The House had just passed the measure on an 83-to-66 vote.
But many legislators said that they knew this effort was little more than a symbolic action: in May Mr. Weicker vetoed an almost identical non-income tax plan, calling it anti-business and harmful to the poor. That veto forced the Legislature into special session and on the road that led to the frantic search for a solution at the capitol tonight.
"I don't think I knew what 'Nero fiddled while Rome burned' meant until this evening," said Representative Doreen Del Bianco, a Democrat from Waterbury who voted against the bill.
 
Gubernatorial Threats
 Mr. Weicker, a third-party independent Governor, proposed a sweeping budget overhaul and income-tax plan in February, which lawmakers grumbled about for months, finally killing it Saturday night by an 88-to-61.
The lawmakers picked up their discussion today against a backdrop of gubernatorial threats: Governor Weicker repeated his promises to veto any continuing resolution that extends negotiations into the week without a budget, and to treat the failure to pass a budget as a state emergency roughly equivalent to a natural disaster. All but essential services would be shut down.
Former House Speaker Irving J. Stolberg, a Democrat from New Haven, warned his colleages that the reputation of the entire legislative branch was at stake, and the General Assembly could live through a "generation of disdain if we end up looking like clowns."
The night-into-day-into-night bargaining sessions that began on Saturday, in the final two days of the fiscal year, were held in corridors and offices and even between offices as enthusiasts for one plan or another bent ears and gripped elbows. There were moments that revealed the stress -- House Speaker Richard J. Balducci, for example, turning from the dais to gulp Pepto-Bismal straight from the bottle.
And there were moments that showed the stifling boredom of waiting on the edge of an abyss -- as lobbyists filed into a makeshift screening room in the legislative office building to watch a rented copy of a movie, "A Fish Called Wanda," on videocassette.
Heightening the crisis atmosphere, workers out of a total of about 48,000 by Tuesday.
All state parks and beaches would be closed, for example, along with Off-Track Betting parlors and many other smaller agencies such as the Board of Parole, the Department of Housing and the Civil Air Patrol.
 
Weicker Defends a Shutdown
 Lawmakers, labor leaders and other state elected officials including the State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., all expressed doubts about the wisdom and savings from the shutdown, but Mr. Weicker defended it as an important measure to insure that essential state services are continued. All those employees furloughed were deemed "non-essential," according to the administration, but no estimates were available as to how much money might be saved.
The so-called conventional tax plan that lawmakers pushed forward today would extend the state's 8 percent sales tax -- already the highest statewide rate in the nation -- across a broad new spectrum of transactions, from taxi rides to parking garage fees to haircuts to boat slip rentals. It would also increase business tax collections, which Mr. Weicker had identified in May as another reason for vetoing the plan's earlier incarnation.

HEADLINE: How to Make OPEC Obsolete

BYLINE: Edward L. Morse; Edward L. Morse is publisher of Petroleum Intelligence Weekly.

 BODY:
A two-day conference between oil exporting and importing countries to find ways to stabilize the world's oil market, talked about for nearly two decades, is finally being convened in Paris today.
But with 24 countries and half a dozen international organizations invited to participate, it's likely that the meeting, dominated by conflicting individual agendas concerning oil prices, production levels and income distribution, will be a bust. 
 This is a shame. Since 1973, the oil sector has been the largest segment of international trade without any clear rules. The result has been imbalance, disruption and price shocks. Holding a large international gathering cannot change this.
What should be done instead is simple: the world's largest oil consumer and importer, the U.S., and the largest exporter, Saudi Arabia, can build a new oil regime by taking painless actions that serve both their own and global interests. And in the aftermath of the gulf war they have a remarkable opportunity to do so.
They can start by negotiating a bilateral agreement based on a concept the Saudis have already proposed by urging that "reciprocal security" should be the cornerstone of oil relations between the two countries. In return for even modest demonstrations of good will, the Saudis promised that consumer nations could gain access to a "fairly priced ocean of oil." After a war that demonstrated our good will, we should not wait any longer to pursue this.
The agreement could begin with plans for energy crisis management, building on an agreement to store Saudi oil in the U.S., both under Saudi control and also leased cheaply to the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve. For the Saudis, this would be a safe and inexpensive way to store oil. It would also demonstrate the kingdom's commitment to U.S. energy security and provide a steady outlet for production.
The agreement should also guarantee the Saudis' unfettered access to the U.S. economy through exports of crude oil and refined products and capital for further investment in refining, marketing, storage and even production.
In return, the accord should grant U.S. oil companies long-term access to Saudi oil, with contracts offering American companies the equivalent of equity ownership of that oil.
Why would the Saudis reopen their oil sector? It would provide the money they need for postwar reconstruction in the region. Moreover, it would symbolize a commitment to supply oil over the long term. Though these arrangements would lead to more diversity in the Saudi industry, it need not reduce Government control. Norway, for example, has maintained such control while allowing foreign investment.
The key problem of oil instability stems from the large-scale nationalization of oil reserves in the 1970's. Since then, oil companies have lost access to long-term supplies, and need to invest and rely upon high cost oil outside of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. For their part, the big monopoly producers like Saudi Arabia, with insecure outlets, disrupt the market with their search for buyers.
Eventually, the bilateral agreement could be opened to others, with the Saudis signing similar agreements with Japan and the European Community, and the U.S. negotiating with other large exporters.
Building new international institutions would not require the dismantling of OPEC or of the International Energy Agency. Yet, it could eventually supercede both, providing the basis for a General Agreement on Petroleum and Petroleum Products, much as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade emerged from bilateral trade agreements built on reciprocity and the extension of most-favored-nation treatment to many countries.
This agreement would address short-term energy insecurity and crisis management. It would subject oil to a free market regime needed for long-term stability, providing predictable prices to the Saudis and reasonable prices to American consumers. Over time it would create a more sensible way for the world to manage its oil relationships without forcing oil exporters to give up control over their own resources.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Mr. Justice Marshall

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

 BODY:
The year Thurgood Marshall was born, 1908, 89 black men were lynched in the United States. When he went to law school, in 1930, he could not go to the University of Maryland, in his home state, because it did not admit blacks. In the 1940's, when he traveled through the South trying cases against segregation, his life was at risk.
All that is history. Young Americans must find it hard to imagine a time when lynchings were commonplace in this country, when even border-state universities were segregated, when it was physically dangerous to challenge segregation. 
 It is history, in good part, because of Thurgood Marshall. As lawyer and judge, he did more than any other American to lift the burden of racism from our society.
To know the record is to know what courage it took, what daring. Just two years into law practice, in 1935, he sued the University of Maryland for admission of a black student to the law school. Everyone thought it was a hopeless case, but he won in the Maryland Court of Appeals. It was the first time any American court had ordered an educational institution to admit a black.
For more than 20 years, as chief counsel to the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense Fund, he went into the courtrooms of the South to fight white supremacy. He tried the issue of segregated schools in Columbia, S.C. He challenged racial zoning in Alabama, all-white Democratic Party primaries in Texas.
In all those places he had to undergo the humiliation of segregation, and the fear. Many times he was threatened. Jack Greenberg, his longtime associate and successor at the Legal Defense Fund, said: "You never knew what was going to happen. You had no security. Danger was in the atmosphere."
Justice Marshall told me, as he told others over the years, of the time he had to change trains in Mississippi. As he stood on the platform, a white man with a pistol sticking out of his pocket came up to him and said, "What are you doing here, boy?"
"I'm waiting for the next train," Justice Marshall said he replied. "The man said, 'What did you say, boy?' Then I remembered. I said, 'I'm waiting for the next train, sir.' And he said, 'You'd better be on it, because the sun's not going down on a live nigger in this town.' "
That was the reality of life in the Deep South not so long ago. It changed beyond expectation, beyond hope. There has been what amounted to a revolution, one of an extraordinary kind: a revolution under law.
Thurgood Marshall stands for the possibility of change by law. He gave those without power, white as well as black, reason to hope that the system could care for them. In a country still riven by antagonisms of race and economic inequality, that is not a small thing.
An N.A.A.C.P. member who was there when he won his first legal victory in desegregating the University of Maryland Law School, Juanita Jackson Mitchell, told Juan Williams of The Washington Post:
"We didn't know about the Constitution. He brought us the Constitution as a document like Moses brought his people the Ten Commandments."
One of Justice Marshall's burdens on the Supreme Court has been to remember the bitter past of black Americans when others seemed to want to forget. In the Bakke case in 1978 he wrote:
"The position of the Negro today in America is the tragic but inevitable consequence of centuries of unequal treatment. . . . In light of the sorry history of discrimination and its devastating impact on the lives of Negroes, bringing the Negro into the mainstream of American life should be a state interest of the highest order. To fail to do so is to ensure that America will forever remain a divided society."
Justice Marshall's retirement deprives the Supreme Court of that link with history and with reality. More than any other justice he fought comfortable abstractions. He tried to make his colleagues understand what it is like to be poor, to be weak.
He is a man without pretension, a mixture of earthiness and dignity, gruffness and tenderness. But he cannot escape being a symbol of possibility. I heard him speak years ago at the University of California in San Diego, and afterward black students came up to say a word, to touch his hand. Where will they look now?

HEADLINE: Gains at Large Law Firms Slowed Sharply Last Year

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
The nation's largest law firms suffered an unmistakable glancing blow from the economic recession last year, according to the annual financial survey by American Lawyer magazine. The survey will be published today.
Revenues for the top 100 firms totaled $13.5 billion last year, up 9 percent from 1989. That gain outstripped most segments of the economy but was a sharp decline from the 17 percent increase in 1989. The slower growth stemmed from a decline in merger and acquisition activity, the real estate slump and client resistance to fee increases. 
 "You've still got a majority of firms doing better than a year ago, which you can't say about other parts of the economy," said Steven Brill, publisher of American Lawyer.
Another survey suggests that the American Lawyer report probably errs on the rosy side. Altman Weil Pensa Inc., a consulting firm that focuses on law firms and corporate legal departments, found revenue for law firms in general grew 6 percent last year and the income of the average lawyer in private practice rose by 2 percent.
Altman, based in Newton Square, Pa., used data from 750 law firms that responded to a 22-page survey sent to more than 8,000 firms. Only a handful of them are also part of the American Lawyer survey, Altman says.
Large law firms are among the most profitable but were also hardest hit by last year's slowdown, said Thomas S. Clay, a partner at Altman. "It isn't completely linked to the economy," he added. "The bigger firms are bloated. They staffed up to maintain a growth rate that is impossible to sustain. The heyday is over."
Mr. Brill said big firms would continue to grow at a healthy clip despite the pressures to restrain fee increases. "The world -- especially the world of big business -- is getting steadily more complicated," he added.
American Lawyer's survey includes estimates to cover the performance of firms that did not respond, and the magazine will not say how many estimates are used. It said "the vast majority" of the firms ended up providing data but cautioned that some firms may have "fudged the numbers upward."
Mr. Clay said the American Lawyer figures in previous years had been off by 20 percent or more for the key financial figures at large firms that retained Altman as a consultant.
Of those on the top 100 list last year, 97 firms are still there. The top 100 range in size from Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, a New York firm with revenues last year of about $503 million, to Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn in Washington, which had revenues of $67 million.
 
Most Lucrative Location
 New York, home to one-third of the top 100 firms, continues to be the most lucrative location to practice law by most measures. The city's law firms include 23 of the top 30 firms when ranked by revenue per lawyer, which is a reflection of how active they are and how much they charge.
Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, the smallest of the top 100 by size, with just 99 partners and 54 associates, led the way in revenues per lawyer, at more than $1.1 million. The firm expanded more slowly than a number of others during the 1980's and was able to find enough deal-making activity last year to stay busy, Mr. Brill said. "They simply turned away less business," he said.
New York was also home to 98 of the top 100 firms in profits per partner. Cravath, Swaine & Moore, with 284 partners and 66 associates, had a net income of $102 million on revenues of $205 million, producing operating profits per partner of more than $1.5 million. Cravath also ranked as the most profitable firm on an index American Lawyer created to measure the performance of an entire firm, including associates.
The magazine cited the firm's contingent-rate deal to represent the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in a lawsuit against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as a strategy more firms should pursue when faced with resistance by clients to rate increases. Under the agreement, Cravath is charging low rates initially but getting paid a handsome premium if it recovers more than $200 million in the suit against Drexel, which is defunct.
New York also reflected the impact of the recession more vividly than most cities. The city was home to 13 of the 17 firms that had stagnant or declining revenues. Cahill, Gordon & Reindel, which once counted on Drexel for as much as 25 percent of its business, saw revenues decline 11 percent, to $130 million, last year, dropping it from 26th to 37th on the top 100 list. Profits per partner dropped 28 percent.
But Cahill's experience underscored how rich many of the top 100 are. Profits per partner remained at more than $1 million, fourth on the list. Dykema Gossett, the Detroit firm that ranked lowest in profitability, still produced operating profits of $195,000 per partner.
 
Healthiest Legal Markets
 Chicago and San Francisco were the healthiest legal markets for big firms last year, the survey found. Gross revenue rose 15 percent at the 13 Chicago firms that made the list and 13 percent for the 9 San Francisco firms.
Chicago firms benefited from an increase in litigation and their heavy involvement in the activities of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency charged with sorting out the affairs of savings and loans. San Francisco firms saw continuing demand for their services in the Pacific Rim countries and were more successful in raising their rates, which had been substantially lower than those in Los Angeles and New York.
The rankings provide only an approximation of the activity in any region because many firms derive substantial portions of their revenue and income from offices in other regions. For example, Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld ranked as the biggest firm in Washington by revenue, with a total of $133 million, but many of its lawyers are in Dallas.
The least specific portion of the survey tried to grade the top 100 on how much legal work they contribute to nonprofit groups and the poor, and on how many lawyers in the firm do such work. Fourteen received an A for such pro bono work, but only one of the 14, Cravath, came from the list of 10 firms with most profits per partner.
Wachtell was the only one of the most profitable firms to refuse to discuss such activity, and it received a D. The firm did not return calls from The New York Times.
"The most common reason firms give for not responding to these questions is that they don't track such activity," Mr. Brill said. "Our experience is that the only way to have an active pro bono program is to keep track of it."

Wachtell has a total of 99 lawyers, 54 of them partners; Cravath has 284 lawyers, 66 of them partners.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Answers to Almost Any Question, for a Price

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, June 30

 BODY:
It is every Trivial Pursuit player's dream come true. How do you make a horse walk downstairs? What is the deepest point of the Mississippi River? How many movies did Alfred Hitchcock make? Call SVP for the answer.
It is also every research department's secret weapon. What is the market share of a competitor? How do debt-for-nature swaps work in Costa Rica? Has wine consumption in Japan fallen? Again, a quick call to SVP should bring the answer. 
 Started in 1935 as a service that deals rapidly with any kind of question, the Paris-based company is flourishing in a world in which instant information is more than ever a valued resource. The company says it is the leader in management consultancy by telephone. Its name derives from "s'il vous plait," meaning "please" in French.
 
More Than 1,500 Clients in U.S.
 The company says it has about 11,000 subscribers in France alone. Through its subsidiaries and affiliates abroad, it now claims an additional 11,000 clients in 23 other countries, including more than 1,500 in the United States. And keeping up with the times, its researchers now work with computers instead of depending on just memory and encylopedias.
The "trivial" questions are, of course, part of SVP's folklore. "A local newspaper once wrote that all the French needed was a little elbow grease to succeed," recalled Brigitte de Gastines, who owns and runs the company. "The next day, we were swamped with calls asking where it could be bought."
But an overwhelming majority of the million questions that SVP handles each year deal with more serious economic, business, political and cultural issues, for the simple reason that the service is only available to clients who pay $120 to $6,600 a month, depending on their needs. SVP's clients include the oil and gas company Elf Aquitaine, the auto maker Renault and the chemical producer Rhone-Poulenc, as well as the Paris newspaper Le Figaro.
Recently, offering what it calls "a global strategy of communications," SVP has diversified into direct marketing, market analysis and publishing. "We are not only interested in reinforcing our original service but also in seizing shares of other available markets," Mrs. de Gastines said.
 
26,000 Calls an Hour
 For example, with a switchboard that can handle 26,000 calls an hour, SVP often contracts out its telephone operators to radio and television programs that take calls from the public.
The expansion of SVP to a company that in 1990 made a 15 percent profit on revenues of $65 million has mainly been the work of Mrs. de Gastines, 47 years old, who became managing director after Maurice de Turkheim, her father and the company's founder, retired in 1976.
"SVP was his idea and his vocation," she said. "We have just developed it naturally, but it is still young. I have my life ahead of me. SVP has its life ahead of it."
When she took over 15 years ago, the company was only breaking even, so she introduced the new services and began looking for partners abroad. Today, Mrs. de Gastines owns all the SVP subsidiaries in Europe and Asia, although she still works with an independent American partner, Andrew Garvin, who operates the company's United States affiliate, Find/SVP Inc.
SVP owns approximately 20 percent of Find/SVP, which is based in New York and operates under a licensing agreement. The American company's revenues rose 12 percent last year, to $16 million, although it posted a $123,000 loss. Find/SVP was founded in 1969 by Mr. Garvin, who had been a reporter in Paris for Newsweek and a client of SVP. Find/ SVP says its clients include Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and National Geographic.
Indeed, Mrs. de Gastines is turning her attention to expanding in the United States. "For me, it's a model of sorts," she said. "If I don't succeed there, I will lose all my credibility."
In France, though, SVP's credibility depends not only on providing fast and accurate responses to questions, but also on its discretion. "If a client asks for very precise information on another client, we refuse to give it," Mrs. de Gastines said. "And for that we are respected."
 
Privileged Information
 The questions, though, often give SVP privileged information. "If a textile company asks us for information on the food sector, we know there is a diversification in the air," she said. "If a big company repeatedly asks us for information about a smaller company, we know there is the possibility of an acquisition."
Beyond its 1,050 employees worldwide, including 265 researchers trained to delve into 1,800 computer information banks, the company can also tap an international network of more than 900 freelance consultants.
Yet, despite these resources, SVP acknowledges that it does not have all the answers. One client urgently needed to know the number of virgins in Patagonia, New Guinea, Argentina and Brazil. But in this case, Mrs. de Gastines recounted, he was told he would have to find out for himself.

Bingham, the affiliate's executive vice president, founded the company in 1969 with Andrew P. Garvin, its president.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Creating Jobs By Building Export Trade

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
THE Xport Port Authority Trading Company has a job-related mission. Operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, it helps small- and medium-sized companies to export products, with the aim not only of improving United States trade figures, but also of creating more jobs.
For example, the jobs created may be export manager and assistant at a company that never had such a department, nor could afford it, until the Xport staff helped the company get started in export markets and bolstered its sales. 
 Herbert Ouida, a lawyer and director of Xport since its inception eight years ago, has a permanent staff of 23.
"Our clients are able to establish partnerships overseas," he said last week. "We negotiate sales for the companies and finance them. In essence, we become their export managers. So far, we have generated about $150 million in sales for small companies. I estimate that we have been responsible for creating at least 3,000 manufacturing and related support jobs."
The parent, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, specializes in operating bridges and tunnels, airports, seaports, the PATH commuter railroad, and the World Trade Center, many of whose tenants are exporters. In addition, the agency has many smaller operations, including a language institute and courses in the intricacies of exports and imports.
In 1982 Congress approved a law that empowered banks, corporations and agencies like the port authority to set up world trading companies to help small- and medium-sized companies. Sears, Roebuck & Company and the General Electric Company were among those that organized trading companies.
"Xport actually started in 1984 with a staff of two, me and an assistant," Mr. Ouida said. "Many, like the Sears and General Electric trade companies, have gone out of the business," he added, explaining their failures mainly to the fact that they were not willing to make a long-term commitment.
Mr. Ouida attributes Xport's staying power not just to the money that the port authority put up but also to its approach -- no fees charged until a sale is made by the company wanting to export. "We could use our clout to open doors for small companies," he said.
Xport's staff does market research for its clients. It walks the clients through a myriad of often confusing details of export selling. "That includes building relationships overseas, handling transportation, doing documentation, arranging financing, obtaining government approvals and advising the clients on tax aspects," he said. "We also do translations."
When a sale is made, Mr. Ouida said the trading company collected a fee of 5 to 15 percent of the sales made during the basic three-year contract. "On average our fee is 7.5 percent." he said, explaining that helped to defray costs.
In addition, to his regular staff, Mr. Ouida has an intern program. The foreign interns, usually in their final years of advanced trade studies, make contacts and help handle the details.
"One young woman just arrived from Paris," Mr. Ouida said. "She is in her third year of a business program at the Ecole des Praticiens du Commerce International, and the school partly financed her."
The student, Katja Meixner, said she had already begun to work on preparations for a trade show in Toulouse. Xport hopes the show will attract the interest of companies in New York and New Jersey.
The largest source of Xport's interns is a German foundation called CDS International, which sponsors worldwide internships.
Currently Mr. Ouida has eight young business school students from western Germany working in his office for a year. They receive about $925 a month from CDS and supplement this from their own savings, since many held jobs before they went to business school.
One student, Reiner Wichman, said: "I am engaged in doing research for an apparel company named H. W. Carter & Sons that wants to sell abroad. It is a difficult market now for the apparel business."
Another intern, Thomas Weiss, is doing market research for a small company named Firesafe, which makes fire-retardant fabrics. Both are New York City companies.
"They spend about a year and I think they find it enriching," Mr. Ouida said. "It helps them make meaningful career decisions." The German interns also give Xport an ever-widening group of contacts in Europe, where Germany ranks as one of the largest trading partners with the United States.
"I was a skeptic at first," Mr. Ouida said last week about the intern program. "It works. and I am astonished."
This year Xport received a $100,000 grant from the Ford Foundation and Harvard University. "We have sent four Americans abroad as interns this summer," Mr. Ouida said. "It costs about $7,000 to send one to Japan for six to eight weeks, which is expensive, but we have three there now, one in India and a young woman in Milan." He said he wished he had the money to send more.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Inc. Expects Losses

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., July 1

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. said today that it would likely post a loss this fiscal year, its first since 1984, as a weak economy continues to cut into demand for earth- moving machines.
Caterpillar, based in Peoria, said that a loss for the year was probable and that a second- quarter loss was a virtual certainty. The company said it would release second-quarter results on July 18. 
 The world's leading maker of earth-moving equipment, Caterpillar lost $32 million in the first quarter. It made a profit of $210 million last year on sales of $11.4 billion.
Gil Nolde, a spokesman, said Caterpillar had no plans to cut its worldwide work force of 56,400.
Caterpillar said the continuing recession and economic conditions remained very weak in Brazil, a large market for Caterpillar products.
Mr. Nolde said Caterpillar's economists generally agreed with Government experts that the recession appeared to have bottomed out.
Nevertheless, "we have seen absolutely no impact on our sales," he said.

HEADLINE: Retirees' Plight in Bankruptcies

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Connie Patterson, who worked 35 years for Eastern Airlines as a flight attendant, has Parkinson's disease and spends $95 a month on medicine, in addition to the costs of visits to the doctor.
Miss Patterson can handle those costs for now because of the group health insurance provided through Eastern. But with the bankrupt airline undergoing liquidation, those benefits may not last much longer. And the disease will become more debilitating. "This condition can only get worse," she said. 
 She and 10,000 other Eastern retirees are at the center of an increasingly common situation as more and bigger companies file for protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code. Many companies are seeking to end or cut back benefits because they have not put away money to finance the plans in case of a business failure. Another company that has reduced benefits is the Bicoastal Corporation, formerly the Singer Company.
 
Issue Raised by LTV Case
 So far the courts have avoided defining legally how long bankrupt companies should be financially responsible for providing medical benefits and have instead pushed for out-of-court compromises. Cutting back on health benefits did not become a major issue until the LTV Corporation sought protection in bankruptcy court in 1986 and requested reductions in the benefits of 78,000 employees.
Many of the former employees of these companies cannot afford the cost of private insurance plans and many plans will not accept retirees with serious illnesses.
Thus the bankruptcy courts have become a major battleground between retirees and those in charge of companies seeking to liquidate or re organize under the bankruptcy codes.
Many like Miss Patterson face having their health insurance cut off before they reach 65 and become eligible for Medicare. She is single, 60 years old and earns about $2,000 a month from a part-time job and Social Security.
For the next six months most of her benefits will probably continue but she and the other Eastern retirees worry about what will happen after that.
Judge Burton R. Lifland, chief judge of the Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York, put pressure on both sides to work out a compromise last month that will guarantee the benefits for another six months, although Eastern workers will have to pay part of the cost of $75 a month.
But the two sides in the dispute are arguing whether Eastern is complying with the court order. Some of the lawyers representing the retirees charge that the carrier is reneging on its agreement and that benefits could be cut.
Eastern's lawyers said that they were seeking a workable plan but had been blocked by the retirees' lawyers.
The judge was moved by the retirees' argument that unlike other creditors in the case their health and possibly their lives were at stake if their health benefits were suspended.
One of those who testified in an affidavit, Jean E. Rae, who was the chief agent in baggage service for the airline for 28 years, has had open-heart surgery and a kidney transplant.
Her medicine to counter her body's rejection mechanisms costs about $350 a month. She has been able to offset some of her bills by working part time but such jobs do not provide medical insurance.
 
Can't Buy Insurance
 Attempts to get insurance herself have been fruitless. "Most insurance companies don't take people with pre-existing conditions," she said. "That's all there is to it."
One of the central issues in the case is whether her plight is graver than that of thousands of workers who lost their jobs at Eastern, some of whom are still struggling financially while some have become homeless.
The retirees' lawyers are pressing their argument that retirees who face the loss of medical benefits should be placed above other groups in a bankruptcy case.
Cessation of health insurance, they argue, could leave them without proper treatment for illness and in some cases increase their risk of death.
Robert S. Clayman of the Washington law firm of Guerrieri, Edmond & James, who represented the machinists' union in the Eastern case, said at a hearing before Judge Lifland in May that such large and financially strong creditors as Boeing, Airbus Industrie, United Technologies and General Electric could better absorb the losses from the Chapter 11 filing than people like Miss Patterson.
Mr. Clayman maintains that the needs of these people are greater than other creditors. "Equity has to be tempered by mercy," he said.
What will happen in six months is uncertain since the amount left in the airline may be enough just to pay for its liquidation.
The company is continuing to pay salaries for a skeleton staff and is maintaining airplanes and other facilities that it is trying to sell. The cost of liquidation is expected to run in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
The retirees' lawyers have also argued that employers have generally assured workers that their benefits would be for life, although most employers have retained the right to modify medical plans.
In the case of the reorganization of Bicoastal, Alexander Paskay, chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Tampa, Fla., refused to allow severe cuts in the medical benefits for 15,000 retirees. Instead he pushed the two sides to come up with a settlement.
 
Retirees Pay $50 a Month
 After months of bargaining, a plan was worked out under which retirees under 65 contribute $50 a month to keep most of their benefits.
Jerome Tauber, a lawyer representing the retirees, said that the $50 monthly fee would be a burden on some retirees but "considering the current climate it was a pretty good deal."
Those like Martin R. Shugrue Jr. of Eastern who find themselves having to defend the cuts in benefits argue that they are caught in the middle.
Mr. Shugrue, the trustee appointed by the court to run Eastern, and whose job is to liquidate the company, must try to satisfy creditors' claims. He said he sympathized with the retirees, but that the issue was complex.
Of the $2.4 billion in claims on Eastern, Mr. Shugrue said, more than $1 billion come from other Eastern employees for severance and back pay and the like. Many of the same employees are also individual bondholders who face losses.
Even the larger unsecured creditors like airplane, engine manufacturers and banks will probably end up with nothing.
Bruce Zirinsky, an Eastern lawyer, said that 30,000 workers had lost their jobs since Eastern filed for Chapter 11 in March 1989. Some are still without jobs and have run out of unemployment insurance.
Thus, he said, it was not simply the retirees versus large creditors but the retirees versus other employees, some of whom are also undergoing hardship.
By agreeing on a short-term solution both sides did not have to tackle the implications of a law passed by Congress in June 1988 called the Retiree Benefits Bankruptcy Protection Act. The law was enacted after LTV filed for bankruptcy protection and sought to cut off medical benefits involving a large number of employees.
The law provides that benefits can be cut only after a judge has determined that "the affected parties are treated fairly and equitably."
Judge Lifland, who decided to seek a compromise not using that law as a guide, succeeded in getting lawyers for 60 percent of the retirees to accept the six-month accord. The judge ordered the other 40 percent, who declined to join the compromise, to be put under the same plan.
Judge Lifland will hear new arguments at the end of the six months. The task facing him then will be to define what is equitable.

Miss Rae and another retired Eastern employee, Van Dyne Martz, attended a Federal Bankruptcy Court hearing recently in New York on the Eastern case. (Neal Boenzi/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New President Named At Bell Laboratories

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
John S. Mayo, a veteran designer of advanced communications and computer systems, was chosen yesterday as the seventh president of A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories since the research center was founded in 1925 as part of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Dr. Mayo, who is currently senior vice president for Network Systems and Network Services at Bell Laboratories, will replace Ian M. Ross, who has been president since 1979. 
Dr. Ross, 63, had been planning to retire in mid-1992. He has been appointed to a new position to help develop A.T.& T.'s global businesses. He will work with A.T.& T.'s vice chairman, Randall Tobias, who last week was put in charge of the company's global business initiatives. Dr. Ross will be president emeritus of Bell Labs, in Murray Hill, N.J.
Dr. Mayo, who is 61, will become a member of A.T.& T.'s Management Executive Committee. He said he would pursue two goals in his new posts: to strengthen the ability of Bell Labs to deliver basic scientific innovations and to shorten the time it takes to get these innovations to market.
"My passion is that we do something for our customers and society that allows them to prosper and improves the quality of life," he said.
Bell Laboratories has been strengthened in terms of both resources and number of employees since the divestiture by A.T. &T. of the regional Bell operating companies in 1984, Dr. Mayo said. Financial support for the laboratories has risen from $2 billion in 1982 to $3 billion now, and employment has increased from 16,000, to 30,000.
Dr. Mayo began his career with Bell Labs in 1955, working on the design of the first transistorized digital computer, a military development project named Tradic. Later, he worked on another early experimental programmable computer named Leprechaun.
His research included contributions to the digitization of national and global telecommunications networks. He also contributed to the Telstar communications satellite program, the development of electronic systems for ocean sonar and the development of the world's first long-distance digital switching system.
At Bell Labs, he has been director of the Ocean Systems Laboratory, executive director of the Ocean Systems division, executive director of the Toll Electronic Switching division and vice president of Electronics Technology.
Dr. Mayo holds B.S., M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering from North Carolina State University. Last year, he received the National Medal of Technology award from President Bush.

HEADLINE: Ethiopian Factions Seek Broad Coalition

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 1

 BODY:
Ethiopian political factions gathered here today to try to form a provisional government that would represent the country's first step toward democracy after 30 years of civil war and a century of imperial-style rule.
Meles Zenawi, the rebel leader whose group took control in the capital after the fall of the Marxist-Leninist Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam inMay, said efforts had been made to include "most sectors of society" at the meeting. But he conceded that not everyone would be happy with the representation. 
 At the opening of the conference in Africa Hall, the usual forum of the Organization of African Unity, some of the groups in attendance voiced early reservations at what they said were prearranged quotas for representation in the provisional government.
 
A Destitute Nation
 But Mr. Meles who leads the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front, urged the meeting to resolve its differences quickly so that a provisional government could get on with resolving the problems of a country left destitute by war, drought and a Communist-run economy.
The conference was called as part of an agreement reached with the United States at talks in London in May. Washington blessed the coming to power of Mr. Meles's group, which is dominated by forces from Tigre Province, but insisted the group move to organize a broad-based provisional government by July 1. The United States said it would not offer any economic aid unless the new government was made more representative of Ethiopia's varied ethnic groups.
The conference is supposed to form a provisional government that will pave the way for elections within 12 months. The United States has said that it also expects the conference to embrace a charter committing the government to uphold human rights and allow freedom of the press.
The American Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, attended the conference today as an observer, along with representatives from the Soviet Union and the European Community.
 
Eritrean Leader an Observer
 Also present was Isaias Afwerki, the leader of the separatist guerrilla organization now in control of Eritrea Province. Apparently to emphasize that Eritrea was not part of Ethiopia. Mr. Isaias sat in the gallery reserved for observers rather than on the conference floor with participants.
His group, Eritrean People's Liberation Front, fought against the Mengistu Government in a loose alliance with Mr. Meles's group, and has won an agreement for a referendum on independence for the province. Mr. Isaias has said he will seek a United Nations referendum on the independence of Eritrea within two years, a position that the United States said last month it supported.
Many of the people on the conference floor were rebel leaders who, because of their armed opposition to the Mengistu regime, had been banned from Addis Ababa for more than a decade.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, attended the conference of Ethiopian factions in Addis Ababa yesterday as an observer. He met there with Meles Zenawi, left, who took control in the capital after the fall of the Marxist-Leninists in May. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars on Expectation U.S. Rates Will Hold Firm

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply yesterday as the outlook for firm United States interest rates brightened and the Bank of Japan lowered that country's discount rate.
Analysts said the dollar was also helped by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Management that the June survey of its members showed the United States manufacturing sector had ended a yearlong decline. 
 With such signs that economic growth is resuming, interest rates are likely to remain stable or rise. Higher interest rates support the dollar by raising foreign demand for American investments.
The drop in the Japanese discount rate, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent, helped the dollar by making American interest rates more competitive.
Walter Simon, a vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York, said a big rally on Wall Street also drove the dollar higher. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 51.66, to 2,958.41, also advancing on the purchasing managers' report and the Japanese rate decline.
Mr. Simon said the Japanese move was a signal that the Group of Seven industrialized nations "aren't as concerned with the levels of the dollar; they're concerned with their own individual domestic situation."
Finance ministers of the Group of Seven met last month but did not take a strong stand against the dollar's surge in recent months. The seven nations are the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Canada and Italy.
Overseas dealers said the dollar also gained on worries about political turmoil in Yugoslavia and fears that tighter German tax policies could hurt the mark.
The dollar rose 1.65 pfennigs against the mark in New York, closing at 1.8280 marks, up from 1.8115 late Friday. In earlier European trading, the dollar rose to 1.8220 marks, from 1.8135.
The dollar also gained nearly 1 yen in New York, rising to 138.42 yen, from 137.525 yen late Friday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar fell to a closing 137.14 Japanese yen, from 138.15 yen at Friday's close. It was higher in London, at 138.40 yen.
The British pound fell to $1.6095 in New York, from $1.62175. In London earlier, sterling fell to $1.6135, from $1.6185 late Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's, included: 1.5652 Swiss francs, up from 1.5525; 6.1920 French francs, up from 6.1380; 1,358.00 Italian lire, up from 1,346.25, and 1.14285 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1418.
Gold prices inched higher in New York after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange, gold rose 10 cents, to $368.20 an ounce. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $368, unchanged from Friday.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $369, from $369.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold's closing bid was $368.25, down from $368.40 Friday.

HEADLINE: Fed Clears Deal for Bank of New England

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Board today dismissed objections by the Justice Department, Maine and community organizers, and approved without any conditions the proposed acquisition of the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks by the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc.
By a 3-to-2 vote, the governors found that the merger would not create antitrust problems in several markets in Maine and Connecticut. The board also unanimously rejected arguments by community-improvement groups that had sought a hearing to determine whether Fleet/Norstar had complied with Federal laws requiring banks to make loans to low-income communities. 
 The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation picked Fleet in April as the winning bidder to buy the Bank of New England and two affiliated banks -- the Maine National Bank and the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company. The three banks were seized by regulators in January after being declared insolvent and are expected to be among the most expensive bank failures in history, costing taxpayers more than $2.5 billion.
 
Antitrust Concerns Raised
 Lawyers at the Justice Department and the Maine Attorney General's office had challenged the deal on antitrust grounds because the banks involved have such a large presence in several cities in Connecticut and Maine.
Fleet is already the largest bank in Maine, holding about 21.8 percent, or $2.9 billion, in deposits. The Maine National Bank is the sixth largest in the state, controlling 7.2 percent, or about $1 billion, in deposits.
In Connecticut, Fleet is the eighth-largest bank, holding $1.8 billion, or 2.8 percent, in deposits in the state. Connecticut Bank and Trust is the second-largest bank, holding $6.9 billion, or 10.5 percent, in deposits.
Two board governors, Wayne D. Angell and Edward W. Kelley Jr., dissented in today's decision, saying the acquisition would have "serious anticompetitive effects" in three sections of Maine and Connecticut. They said they would have required Fleet/Norstar to sell branches in Bangor and Pittsfield, Me., and Willimantic, Conn., to avoid what they said would be "a significantly adverse effect on competition."
Officials at the Justice Department and the Maine Attorney General's office said today that they had not decided whether to appeal the decision by seeking an injunction to delay the proposed acquisition.
In dismissing the arguments by the Justice Department and the Maine Attorney General, two members of the Fed, the chairman, Alan Greenspan, and John P. LaWare, said the Government lawyers had failed to include the competition afforded by "thrift institutions." David W. Mullins Jr. was the third board governor to vote with the majority.
 
Abusive Practices Charged
 Community groups said Fleet had not made enough loans in lower-income areas. They also asserted that a mortgage subsidiary, Fleet Finance Inc., had engaged in abusive practices by charging borrowers inflated interest rates and high loan fees, even though the borrowers did not have enough income to repay the loans.
Those charges are being examined by the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and the Federal Trade Commission. The Fed said it had decided not to await the outcome of that study.
With much fanfare, Fleet announced last week what it said would be an $11 million plan to aid low-income and minority homeowners. That plan was cited today by the Fed as evidence of the bank's commitment to low-income customers.

HEADLINE: British Steel Profit Off 66%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, July 1

 BODY:
British Steel P.L.C. said today that its profit sank 66 percent in the year ended March 30 because of the British recession and intense competition in Europe.
British Steel reported net profit of 193 million, or about $311 million, for the year, compared with 564 million, or $907 million, in the previous year. Sales fell 1.4 percent, to $8.1 billion. 
 The company said it took a one-time charge to carry out cost-cutting measures. British Steel, which employs 51,500 people, trimmed 2,000 jobs in the latest year and plans to continue to reduce its costs, a spokesman said.
The company said an oversupply of steel in Europe, along with the recession in the United States, led to lower prices and increased competition in the European Community.
Sir Robert Scholey, British Steel's chairman, said any upturn would be steady rather than dramatic and "the prudent view is to assume that the current depressed conditions will persist for a longer rather than a shorter period."

HEADLINE: Close of Canada Paper Mill By End of Year Is Planned

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Most of a Canadian paper mill owned by a joint venture of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and The New York Times Company will be shut down by the end of the year. The decision follows the failure last week of the companies, the province of Ontario and an employee-led group to agree on a way to keep the enterprise going with more modest cuts.
The joint venture, the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, was formed more than 60 years ago by the two American companies and is the major employer in the remote Kapuskasing region, some 500 miles north of Toronto. It employs 1,450 people, of whom all but 250 will be laid off. 
 "We are facing utter devastation," said Theodore K. Jewell, Kapuskasing's mayor and spokesman for the employee-led group.
 
Dividend of Over $100 Million
 An agreement would have involved selling the Spruce Falls power plant at Smoky Falls to state-owned Ontario Hydro and then giving the mill, which is 50 miles to the south in Kapuskasing, to the employee group. The sale of the power plant would have paid a dividend of more than $100 million after taxes and guaranteed the mill 80 years of power, valued at $300 million.
Kimberly-Clark and the Times Company had also agreed to put some of their dividend from the sale into a $40 million loan at low interest rates as part of a business plan that was to have included millions of dollars in contributions from the employees and Kapuskasing, changes in union rules, and various benefits from the province.
The sticking point was the requirement by Kimberly-Clark that the deal be completed by Sunday, many years before Ontario expected to complete a proposed environmental review of how the power plant could be enlarged and made part of a plan involving numerous other hydroelectric sites in the vast wilderness south of Hudson Bay.
 
Deadline Set in March
 Darwin Smith, the chairman and chief executive of Kimberly-Clark, set the deadline in March, saying the precarious competitive position of Spruce Falls would weaken rapidly if its future was left unsettled beyond this year. Kimberly-Clark owns 50.1 percent of the joint venture and represented the American companies throughout the negotiations.
Provincial officials pushed Kimberly-Clark and the Times Company to agree to accept a smaller dividend from the sale of the power plant in the event that the environmental review eventually concluded that Ontario Hydro was barred from enlarging the dam and power plant. The officials characterized their proposal as sharing the environmental risk.
Mr. Smith, with the backing of the Times Company, refused, saying the proposal amounted to taking on risks the companies did not have because Spruce Falls had no plans to enlarge the power plant.
"We thought our offer was more than generous," Mr. Smith said yesterday.
 
Sale of Company Planned
 The employee takeover of the mill would have led to a gradual elimination of about one-third of the 1,450 employees of Spruce Falls. Instead, the company will lay off 1,200 of the employees over the next few months and eliminate about 240,000 tons of its 350,000-ton capacity. Once the cuts are complete and profitability has been restored, Kimberly-Clark and the Times Company plan to sell the company.
Both Kimberly-Clark and the Times Company have already taken write-offs to cover the costs of disposing of Spruce Falls. Kimberly-Clark took a $44 million after-tax charge against earnings last year. And the Times Company took a $27 million charge against earnings in 1989 to cover a number of one-time costs in its forest products division, including plans to dispose of Spruce Falls.
Mayor Jewell said he hoped to persuade Ontario's Premier, Bob Rae, to pursue an earlier offer from Mr. Smith to sell all of the assets of Spruce Falls for $150 million. Mr. Smith said yesterday that he had no intention of pursuing further negotiations until the downsizing was completed. Yesterday was a national holiday in Canada and province officials could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Interest Rates, The Real Ones

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
SINCE the spring of 1989, the American economy has grown either weakly or not at all. And all through this period, what economists call real interest rates -- the difference between interest rates on borrowed money and the inflation rate -- have remained high. High real rates are usually seen as a threat to economic activity and an obstacle to a strong recovery after recession.
Such concerns are justified, most economists say. The real test of the impact of interest rates is their level in relation to the inflation rate. The closer the two rates are to each other, the greater the likelihood that salaries and prices will rise sufficiently to offset the cost of a loan. Sometimes interest rates on loans can be falling, but if the inflation rate is falling even faster, the real cost of the loan rises. 
 Economists typically arrive at real rates by looking at the rates on such things as car loans, mortgages, and Treasury bills and notes, and then subtracting the expected inflation rate. But like so many generalizations in economics, the broad rules about real interest rates fail to adequately reflect their actual impact on individuals. As Albert Wojnilower, a senior economist at First Boston Asset Management, puts it, "People have to look at their own personal rate of inflation in income and expenses to know what real rates mean to them."
A home buyer who takes a $100,000 mortgage at a cost of 9 percent annually, for example, is hurt if his $100,000 income rises by only 3 percent in the first year of the mortgage. The salary increase is the home buyer's personal rate of inflation in determining the mortgage's real cost. In this case, the rise in salary covers only $3,000 of the $9,000 interest payment. The buyer's initial real interest rate, then, is 6 percent, and he has to draw from savings, or reduce other expenditures, to cover the cost.
Many Americans are in this fix, which helps to explain why home sales are not booming. Similarly, real rates are high on most auto loans and on credit-card debt.
Or take a clothing store owner who borrows $100,000 at 8.5 percent to stock shirts and pants for the coming year. If he can mark up this merchandise by at least 8.5 percent, or $8,500, then the real interst rate on his loan is zero. But if, like many retailers today, he is forced by weak demand to discount his wares, selling them finally for only the $100,000 purchase price, then the real interest rate on the money he borrowed is high: 8.5 percent.
Such high real costs help to explain why many businessmen are not yet rushing to build up inventories as the recession appears to be ending. High real rates also help to explain why the construction boom of the 1980's collapsed. The rents from all the new hotels, offices and shopping centers were not growing fast enough to pay the interest on the loans borrowed to build them.
"The Donald Trump story is the story of a financial genius done in by high real rates," said Nicholas Sargen, a Salomon Brothers economist.
There are, of course, many winners. Americans who invest their savings in, say, one-year Treasury bills at the current 6.3 percent rate are ahead of the game. That's because the inflation rate is expected to be about 4.5 percent over the next 12 months, according to various surveys, including those conducted by the University of Michigan's Survey Research Center. So the real rate of return for bill holders is 1.8 percent, representing the earnings from interest after deducting the impact of inflation. Inflation, in effect, reduces savings by 4.5 percent while they are tied up in Treasury bills.
David W. Mullins Jr., vice chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve, says that the 10-year Treasury note is commonly used as a guide to rates. For inflation expectations, he and others cite various estimates, including a poll of portfolio managers conducted periodically by Richard B. Hoey, a Wall Street economist. The nominal rate on 10-year notes is about 8.25 percent. The expected inflation over that period is roughly 4.25 percent, according to the Hoey poll, so the real rate is about 4 percent.
Two things are striking about real rates on the one-year Treasury bill and the 10-year note, both representative of incomes from savings and outlays for loans. One is that the real rates are nearly as high today as they were in July 1990, when the recession started, suggesting that the Federal Reserve's efforts to lower nominal interest rates have barely reduced the true cost of borrowing.
The other is that these real rates, although affected by changing tax laws, have been much higher on average over the past decade than in any decade since the 1920's. Various explanations are offered for this phenomenon, each of them subject to much dispute. But one thing is clear: the nation's creditors, the people wealthy enough to lend out more than they borrow, are doing far better than the net borrowers. High real interest rates in the past decade have widened this gap.
"When you talk about a declining standard of living for many Americans, this is one of the dimensions of it," Mr. Wojnilower said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Fall After Report

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A survey indicating that the nation's manufacturing sector expanded during June, the first such rise in a year, helped to push down prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday.
The report came as a surprise to most credit market participants and analysts, who had expected that the survey of the nation's purchasing managers would show that activity remained weak to sluggish, at best. 
 Those expectations were not borne out, as the survey's business activity index jumped to 50.9 percent, from 45.4 percent in May.
The increase in the index carried it past the point at which the National Association of Purchasing Management, the group that compiles the monthly reading, says the nation's manufacturing economy begins to expand. It was the highest level since April 1989, when the index stood at 52.1 percent.
 
'Strongest Confirmation Yet'
 "The numbers were the strongest confirmation yet that recovery is under way, and may be spreading into the manufacturing sector," said Stuart G. Hoffman, a senior vice president and chief economist at the PNC Financial Corporation in Pittsburgh. "And I would imagine that autos and auto-related industries are an important contributor to this recovery in manufacturing."
Prices of Treasury securities dipped immediately after the purchasing managers' report was released. But a further drop in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 leading spot commodity prices, an inflation indicator that has been attempting to break a five-year low recently, helped to limit the price slide.
"With commodity prices down it is hard for the market to totally collapse," one trader in government bonds said. "But the purchasing managers' news was not good. It is the fourth straight month that the index has gone up. It has really changed the way people had been thinking about the economy."
 
Japanese Move Was Expected
 Traders and analysts said a decision by the Bank of Japan to lower its discount rate had been expected for weeks, if not months. Therefore yeterday's rate cut, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent, had no impact on activity in American financial markets.
"After a very strong first quarter, the Japanese economy is slowing down fast, and money supply growth has been very weak," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S.G. Warburg & Company. "Our market has been looking for a Japanese rate cut since the spring."
A rise in stock prices and the contents of the purchasing managers' report helped to push up interest rates on outstanding short-term Treasury bills. But the day's developments had little impact on bids for new three-month and six-month bills sold at the Treasury's weekly auction.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.59 percent, compared with an average rate of 5.58 percent at last week's sale.
 
Six-Month Rate Down
 Meanwhile, bids on the new six-month securities produced an average discount rate of 5.71 percent, down from an average rate of 5.76 percent at the auction a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury issues, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 96 21/32, down by 6/32, to yield 8.43 percent, compared with 8.40 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 98 11/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.24 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offerd at 100 3/32, down by 3/32, to yield 6.94 percent.
In the Treasury bill market, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.56 percent, up two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 5.69 percent.
 
US West Notes Priced
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, U S West Financial Systems priced $100 million worth of two-year notes through an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers.
The 7.5 percent securities, which mature July 15, 1993, were priced at $100, or par, 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 percent two-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
 
New York Bids Improve
 The apparent resolution of New York City's budget crisis was only barely visible in the tax-exempt municipal bond market yesterday. Traders said that bids on some outstanding New York City bonds improved by about three-eighths of a point, but that few securities changed hands.
Traders said that prices of most tax-exempt issues were unchanged to up about an eighth of a point in very light trading.
Signs of an economic recovery may be building, but the recession took its toll on corporate and municipal debt ratings in the first half of 1991. In a report released yesterday, Standard & Poor's said that corporate and muincipal credit quality continued to deteriorate in the first six months of the year.
From January through June Standard & Poor's downgraded a record $408 billion worth of outstanding corporate debt, only $100 billion less than the agency downgraded for all of 1990. During the first six months, S.& P. downgraded almost five times as many corporate issues as it upgraded.
 
More Downgrading Expected
 Leo C. O'Neill, president and chief rating officer at Standard & Poor's, said the number of rating downgrades was likely to exceed the number of upgrades through the balance of the year and "probably" well into 1992.
Total dollar volume of municipal bond downgrades was $11.6 billion during the first half of the year, roughly unchanged for the same period a year ago, Standard & Poor's said.

HEADLINE: Fed Feels Left Out;
2 Vacancies and Chief's Term Is Up, But Washington Pays Little Attention

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers will hold one of their most important meetings of the year here Tuesday with two seats on its board vacant and Alan Greenspan's future as chairman at least officially in limbo.
 Fed officials say that the vacancies and the uncertainty over whether Mr. Greenspan will be given another four-year term are no more than inconveniences and that they will have no problem on Tuesday agreeing on a target range for the growth of money supply over the next six months. 
 Maybe so. But when pressed, the officials concede that they wish the White House and Congress would pay a bit more attention to the Fed, the agency of the Government with the most influence over the economy.
"I don't know whether it's that they're not interested in us or that they just don't want to have anything to do with monetary policy," said one staff assistant.
The decisions on monetary policy made in secret Tuesday will be announced July 16 when Mr. Greenspan testifies before a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee. If the Fed lowers the target range for growth in money supply, currently 2 1/2 percent to 6 1/2 percent, that will be seen as a renewed commitment to fight inflation. If, on the other hand, the target is raised or even left as is, the markets will probably take that as a signal that the Fed is encouraging a strong recovery from the recession.
Mr. Greenspan's term expires Aug. 11. It is widely assumed throughout the capital and on Wall Street that he will be reappointed, but no word has come from the White House.
 
Awaiting Better Times
 Why not? One theory is that President Bush wants to give the economy as much time as possible to improve before renominating Mr. Greenspan. If the recession is unequivocally over when the Senate holds confirmation hearings, according to this line of thought, the Government's economic policy will not be subject to such intense scrutiny.
Another view is that the decision cannot be made without the participation of John H. Sununu, but the President's chief of staff has been distracted by ethical questions.
Only four or five people know for sure what is going on -- Mr. Bush, Mr. Sununu, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and probably Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director -- and they will not say.
Mr. Boskin and Mr. Brady have maintained publicly that Mr. Greenspan has kept interest rates too high. But they are known to think highly of the Fed chairman and are believed to want him reappointed. Still, a top official at the Treasury said last week that Mr. Brady had not even discussed the matter with his staff.
Mr. Sununu's position is less clear, but White House officials say that if Mr. Brady and Mr. Sununu are at odds on this issue, the President will almost certainly side with his Treasury Secretary.
Rumors travel fast in Washington and on Wall Street, and when Vernon A. Walters announced last week that he was resigning as Ambassador to Germany, word spread that the Administration was creating a graceful way for Mr. Greenspan to be eased out of the Fed. After all, the reasoning went, Germany is a plum assignment, and Arthur F. Burns was given that post in the Carter Administration after he left the Fed chairmanship.
But Administration officials now say Robert M. Kimmitt, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, will get the post.
Despite the Fed's importance to the economy and despite politicians' occasional statements about interest rates, the simple truth may be that people in political circles pay little attention to the Fed. Mr. Bush prefers focusing on foreign affairs. Mr. Sununu has been preoccupied with his traveling travails. Mr. Brady has been busy promoting the Administration's banking legislation.
 
Two Empty Seats
 If they were going to select someone else to be chairman of the Fed, the White House would have had to act by now. Otherwise, after Aug. 11, the agency would be without a chairman or Mr. Greenspan would be in the awkward position of being a lame duck. But if Mr. Greenspan is going to get another term, it makes no difference if he has not been officially confirmed when this term expires.
The politicians' lack of attention to the Fed is clearly the main reason the two vacancies remain on the seven-member board. Manuel H. Johnson resigned last August. He had been vice chairman of the board.
In January, more than five months later, Mr. Bush nominated David W. Mullins Jr., already on the board, to the vice chairmanship, and named Lawrence B. Lindsey, a White House economist, to the vacant seat. The Senate Banking Committee did not hold hearings on Mr. Lindsey's nomination until May and on Mr. Mullins's until last month. And while their confirmation is assured, the panel has not held a meeting to vote.
Asked last week why the long process, Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, the Democrat who heads the committee, said, "We've just been absolutely swamped."
In January, Martha R. Seger announced that she planned to leave the board, and she resigned in March. By early May, the Administration had settled on Susan M. Phillips, a former chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, to fill the vacancy. But the nomination still has not been announced.
 
An Increased Workload
 The Fed has functioned quite well short-handed, its officials say, but the remaining five governors have had to double up on some assignments. For example, no governor has been concentrating on international finance for the last year. That had been Mr. Johnson's specialty.
None of this should, however, put a damper on Mr. Greenspan's annual Fourth of July party for political and financial figures and Fed reporters. He holds it in the penthouse ballroom of one of the Fed's office buildings, with one of the city's best views of the fireworks. All this gossip is sure to be hashed out there.
