HEADLINE: Our Towns

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J.

 BODY:
When Rick DePollo touches a sizzling flare to the first fuse out in the dark end of Veterans Park here at dusk Thursday, he will have one second to duck. Then will come that familiar "THUNK" as a four-pound packet of powder vaults into the holiday sky. Two seconds later, 600 feet overhead, the sudden explosion will ignite the crowd's excitement.
In good times and bad times, blowing up colorful gunpowder in the Fourth of July sky and "oohing" and
"aahing" together in a chorus of strangers united for a few thrilling minutes have become a familiar, comforting ritual across the land. Economically, this is not one of the good times in older blue-collar communities like Ridgefield Park. So the Town Council voted to chop the $23,000 fireworks expense from the municipal budget. 
 What happened then, as it has in many towns this year, illustrates how important seemingly silly civic rituals can be to a community's sense of routine and identity.
Explosive extravaganzas are not new in American history. So important were fireworks on both sides of the War of 1812, for instance, that the British stopped the fighting to lend gunpowder to the enemy Americans clustered in Calais, Me., so they could have a proper Fourth of July celebration.
Like many suburban residents in these days of budget stringencies, the 12,500 citizens of Ridgefield Park must survive with fewer pickups of garbage and recyclables, among other things. But so important is the summer rite of sitting on blankets while startled babies cry and famished mosquitoes dine that this year, Ridgefield Park residents will buy tickets for this privilege. As might be expected, the solution grew from the work of another of those special committees that suburbanites instinctively create when they want something done quickly.
"To some people," said Chuck DeLuca, chairman of the special Fourth of July subcommittee, "some of these budget cuts can seem trivial -- a park here, a playground there, a parade now and then, and July Fourth fireworks. But they are a part of a community's personality. If you lose that familiar fabric, you're not a community anymore. You're just a collection of people who happen to live in the same place."
Mr. DeLuca says he married into Ridgefield Park. A Lodi native, he was admitted after exchanging vows with his fiancee, Barbara. He fell in love with Fourth of July celebrations here, which begin with a cannon shot down Euclid Avenue at 7:45 A.M. All day there are parades of babies, bicycles and bands on Main and other streets. There are burgers, hot dogs and ice cream. There are screaming fire engines and unobtrusive judges with the dubious, delicate distinction of picking the best floats.
Three generations of DeLucas have worked on the family float for weeks now out in the garage with the windows papered over. And not by chance, the DeLucas's residence overlooks the parade route. "I have such good memories about the Fourth," says Mr. DeLuca, "and I wanted my kids to have them, too."
Which is why the fireworks' demise hit so hard. The DeLucas protested, nearly alone, at a March Council meeting. They got little response. So they packed the next meeting with fireworks supporters.
The resulting fireworks subcommittee set to work. Members wrote every business in town, all 325 of them. That produced $2,000 in donations. They studied what other towns in similar straits had done and settled on selling tickets. With promises of a share of the gate plus a chance to solicit donations from the anticipated crowd of 10,000-plus, the subcommittee enlisted the aid of clubs with their own fund-raising needs. So the junior football and soccer clubs will run the park gates with the Boy Scouts. Others take turns selling $2 tickets at the Municipal Building from 9 to 5 and 6 to 8. (At the gate, a ticket will set you back $3.)
By 8 P.M. Thursday, the boring official speeches will be over at Veterans Park, where the Little League and the Ridgefield Park Scarlets do regular athletic combat. The food stalls will be bustling. The grandstands will be full by then and the blankets will blanket the grass and base lines.
The Harrison Bushwackers, a drum and bugle corps, will entertain the growing throng. And then, about 9:30, it will happen once again. Within 30 minutes Rick DePollo will send several hundred packets of gunpowder flying into the New Jersey sky.
Sitting there on the grass, Barb and Chuck DeLuca will be holding their daughters. This will be Michelle's fourth Fourth. Glimpsed in the staccato flashes, her face will be as excited as usual. This will be Christine's first Fourth. She won't understand the fireworks. But eventually she'll get the message, watching her father watch all that money go up in smoke with such delight.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
The Twisting Road to a Budget Deal

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
At about 3 P.M. Sunday, under the curious gaze of a pair of police officers and lulled, perhaps, by the pungent aroma of boxed red geraniums, two deputy mayors and two City Council tacticians adjourned to a park bench outside City Hall and, in less than half an hour, resolved the budget impasse that had threatened New York City with fiscal chaos.
The two Council representatives, Joseph Strasburg and Marc V. Shaw, then left Deputy Mayors Bill Lynch and Sally Hernandez-Pinero and rushed to join Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, at Angelo of Mulberry Street, a restaurant in Little Italy. There, as they consumed half-orders of the house specialty, spaghetti with light tomato sauce, they briefed Mr. Vallone and Councilman Jerry L. Crispino on the tentative accord. 
 At City Hall an hour later, the deal was sealed with a cigar. Mr. Lynch plucked a prized Havana from a plain wooden box on his desk and presented it to Mr. Strasburg as a trophy of their elusive compromise, which may represent a turning point in the strained relations between Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Council.
All that had separated them, as it turned out, was one-tenth of 1 percent of the proposed $29 billion budget. In the end, both sides winked, rather than blinked, in a surprisingly amicable endgame to a test of wills with profound political implications.
 
Weeks of Jockeying
 The jockeying between the Mayor and the Council that had gone on for weeks and the negotiations that had begun in earnest only Friday were as much about public perceptions as about the public purse. They redefined power-sharing between the two branches and reflected the quirky intimacy that New York's 19th-century City Hall bestows on the democratic process. "The Council let the Mayor save face and the Mayor let the Council off the hook," said Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge.
Both sides staked out their bargaining positions back in May, when Mr. Dinkins proposed his budget. But for weeks, they merely sparred from afar, with Mr. Vallone insisting that the Council would not approve more than $300 million of the $776 million property tax increase that the Mayor was seeking. The Speaker championed the businesses and middle-income homeowners who make up the city's tax base. The real-estate industry, meanwhile, bombarded officials with calls and postcards demanding that the Council hold the line.
Then 10 days ago, details of the Council's proposed $465 million in alternative cuts were leaked by the Mayor's office. That shifted public outrage from the Mayor's doomsday budget to the Council's economies, but it also deepened the emnity provoked by irritants ranging from the role of the Mayor's representatives in Council redistricting to an apparent oversight that led Mr. Vallone to believe he had been snubbed during last month's parade for Persian Gulf war veterans.
The Council refused to discuss a further increase in property taxes. The administration ridiculed the Council's proposed economies.
Last Thursday, the Council once again seized the initiative and embarked on a collision course with the Mayor. It began drafting its own budget -- one that would have required thousands more layoffs than the Mayor had already imposed -- and threatened to adopt it by the Sunday deadline unless an agreement was struck.
But Council insiders recognized that the threat, while not empty, represented more of a public-relations gesture than a genuine fiscal strategy. The new City Charter that gave the Council broader powers still reserved for the Mayor the wide discretion to estimate revenue; if the Council's revenue projections were too optimistic Mr. Dinkins could impose further cuts or, more likely, require a property-tax increase after all.
 
'It's Only Thursday'
 Mr. Lynch, a veteran of many labor and political negotiations, was sanguine when he was asked late in the week why no serious talks had begun. "It's only Thursday," he replied. "Wait until Sunday."
Meanwhile, he had mobilized community groups, civic organizations and city commissioners to protest the Council's proposed cuts.
Intense negotiations finally began at City Hall late Friday. That night, Mr. Vallone encountered the Mayor at a reception in Astoria and misread Mr. Dinkins's public embrace as a conciliatory sign. Mr. Vallone returned to City Hall. Mr. Dinkins did not. It was the last time they spoke until moments before they announced an agreement Sunday night.
While Mr. Dinkins was at City Hall over the weekend, his agenda went beyond the immediate budget talks. Anticipating moves by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the Mayor was also fashioning some joint review of city and state fiscal problems that would allow for help from the Municipal Assistance Corporation but avoid triggering the oversight authority of the State Financial Control Board.
The first sign of a break came unexpectedly Saturday afternoon. A reporter told Leland T. Jones, the Mayor's chief spokesman, that the Council was acknowledging that it needed to make technical adjustments to bring its proposed budget into balance. "I said to Norman, 'They're caving,' " Mr. Jones recalled telling Norman Steisel, the First Deputy Mayor.
Mr. Lynch was largely handling negotiations with Mr. Strasburg, the Council's chief of staff. But sometime after midnight Saturday, Mr. Steisel invoked a relationship that demonstrates the role personal dynamics play in politics. He reached out to Herbert E. Berman of Brooklyn, who heads the Council's Finance Committee, whom Mr. Steisel has known for years -- since he used to tag along when his sister dated a friend of Mr. Berman.
Conferring with Mr. Berman, what Mr. Steisel apparently intended to convey was the administration's final offer: The Council would have to raise its last offer of a property tax increase from $388 million to $400 million. The administration, for its part, raised its offer on budget restorations.
But either Mr. Berman or Mr. Strasburg, whom Mr. Steisel subsequently briefed, or their staffs misunderstood, so that between 4:30 A.M. Sunday, when negotiators wearily left City Hall, and about 10:30 A.M., when they returned, what had seemed to be grounds for a settlement had all but collapsed. The dispute appeared to center on whether the administration had been willing to budge beyond $40 million in restorations -- the so-called "L list" of life-saving services -- or beyond $100 million, still well short of the $169 million demand that the Council had retreated to from $220 million.
Deputy Mayor Hernandez-Pinero was apparently instrumental in reviving the talks. She telephoned Mr. Strasburg, with whom she shared friends as fellow graduates of the Bronx High School of Science, and determined that both sides wanted an agreement before the deadline and that they were feuding over many cuts that both sides hoped to restore.
 
Meeting a Deadline
 That call led to the walk in the park -- literally, not figuratively. The park-bench protocol, Mr. Lynch recalled, "was when we closed it all up."
It rapidly set in motion the compromise that Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone announced at 10:30. In the time warp in which city government often operates, their vague agreement to agree on a budget constituted what both agreed was compliance with the deadline.
Ultimately, the administration budged slightly and increased the amount it would agree to restore to $117 million. That, combined with $350 million in higher projections of tax collections and one-shot revenues, provided the basis for the agreement.
Even without the Mayor's personal plea to Mr. Vallone -- which the Council staff had demanded -- the Speaker agreed to raise property taxes by $400 million. That was about half of what Mr. Dinkins had proposed and well within the figure real-estate lobbyists had said would be acceptable. By acting jointly, the Council averted as much as $500 million in cuts it might have had to make itself.
Mr. Dinkins was flanked by Mr. Berman and Mr. Vallone when he read the text of the agreement. Two words were underlined: "together," which was how the two sides had managed to piece together a budget; and "independence," which was what they hoped that budget would achieve for the city if it passes muster with state monitors and with bond buyers.

HEADLINE: Kohl Threatens to End German Aid to Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 1

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl toughened his position toward Yugoslavia today, threatening to cut off all German aid if the Belgrade Government again sent troops against the independence-minded republics of Slovenia and Croatia.
He also raised the possibility for the first time that Yugoslavia might not survive the current crisis intact. 
 "One does not hold a country together with tanks and violence," Mr. Kohl told journalists in Bonn.
Like most other European leaders, Mr. Kohl has spoken often about the need to preserve Yugoslav unity. Today, facing domestic political pressure set off by the fighting that broke out in Slovenia and Croatia last week, he instead stressed the right of national and ethnic groups to self-determination.
Treaties signed by European leaders in recent years, Mr. Kohl noted, guarantee "human rights, the legitimate rights of minorities, and the right to free elections."
 
Sympathy for Republics
 Mr. Kohl suggested that hostile factions in Yugoslavia try to negotiate a loose confederation. "If that doesn't work, then we'll have to think again," he said.
German aid to Yugoslavia last year totaled about $550 million, according to official figures. Mr. Kohl made his threat to suspend this year's aid after Foreign Minister Jacques Poos of Luxembourg announced that the European Community was considering halting its $900 million aid program.
Public opinion in Germany, as in much of Europe, is sympathetic to the secessionist republics. Leading politicians and commentators have been urging the Government to back away from what is widely understood to be its pro-Belgrade stance. Among them have been senior leaders of Mr. Kohl's own Christian Democratic Union.
The Christian Democratic chairman, Volker Ruhe, urged in a radio interview today that Germany and other nations of the European Community formally recognize the independence of the breakaway republics.
"If we Germans think everything in Europe can stay just as it was, if we accept the status quo and do not recognize the right of self-determination in Slovenia and Croatia, then we have no moral or political credibility," Mr. Ruhe said. "We should start a movement in the E.C. to lead to such recognition. It can't be done alone."
 
A Test for European Agencies
 German reaction to the crisis in Yugoslavia reflects an ambivalence felt in many European capitals as well as in Washington. Political leaders want to appear sympathetic to oppressed minorities, but they are afraid of setting precedents that could encourage nationalist movements from Flanders to Kurdistan.
The crisis also tests the ability of new European agencies to deal with threats to peace. Austria has asked the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to set its new crisis-prevention mechanism into action, and today Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany flew from Bonn to Yugoslavia as a representative of that organization.
Before leaving Germany, Mr. Genscher discussed the crisis with the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is visiting Bonn.
"It is important that we try and use all our powers to end the military deployment in Yugoslavia," Mr. Genscher said.
Slovenian and Croatian leaders have urged the European Community to send observers to monitor the current cease-fire. Such a step would be a minor landmark in the community's evolution from an economic union to one with political and security powers.
"We understand their request, and we told them we are willing to consider it," the Dutch Foreign Minister, Hans van den Broek, said in The Hague today after returning from an overnight visit to Yugoslavia.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hans-Dietrich Genscher, German Foreign Minister, during his peace mission to Yugoslavia. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Japan's Central Bank Lowers Discount Rate to 5.5 Percent

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 1

 BODY:
Japan lowered its benchmark interest rate today by a half percentage point, to 5.5 percent, ending its two-year-old policy of keeping interest rates high to wring inflation out of the economy.
The announcement by the Bank of Japan, which came at 12:15 P.M. here, appeared to be intended to spur Japan's economy after a recent slowdown in growth. The country is headed toward its longest-running economic expansion in postwar history -- it is two months short of the record of 57 months set more than 20 years ago -- and the central bank had recently come under increasing pressure to lower its rates to encourage capital spending and revive the lagging stock market. 
 The announcement came after widespread speculation that an increase was imminent. The bank's action caused a stock market rally in Tokyo, reversing the steady decline of the last week. The Nikkei index of 250 issues soared 817.80 points, or 3.51 percent, in active trading today, closing at 24,108.76. And the yen strengthened against the dollar in Tokyo, with the American currency falling to 137.14 yen from its close of 138.15 on Friday.
In the United States markets, the overnight surge in the Nikkei contributed to a sharp rise in the Dow Jones industrial average, which gained 51.66 points. The move, however, had no impact in the credit markets, which had expected the move, traders said.
Today's reduction in the discount rate, the rate the central bank charges banks for short-term loans, was the first since February 1987, when the Bank of Japan cut the discount rate to just 2.5 percent. But in May 1989, the bank began to push up interest rates in an effort to stem what the central bank's governor, Yasushi Mieno, said were dangerous signs of inflation. Mr. Mieno has consistently viewed inflation as a bigger threat than a slowdown in growth.
There was no offical reaction in Washington today to the rate reduction, though it was expected to be welcomed. The United States has been pushing Japan and Germany for months to ease interest rates. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady had urged rate cuts to quicken economic growth around the world at a time of recession in the United States.
Lower Japanese interest rates would also tend to free more Japanese capital to flow abroad to areas with shortages of capital, like Eastern Europe and the United States. Washington's big budget deficits require the sale of tens of billions of dollars of Treasury bonds to foreigners.
Politically, the rate cut seems excellently timed.
The leaders of the seven leading industrial democracies plan to meet in London in two weeks. The cut may ease American pressures on Japan at the meeting and give more weight to Japan's views -- in particular, its staunch opposition to providing financial support to the Soviet Union.
Over the weekend, Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, said Japan would not extend large-scale aid to the Soviet Union until it made significant progress on resolving the longstanding dispute over the Northern Islands, a cluster of four islands the Soviets have occupied since World War II.
The announcement capped several weeks of conflicting signals about whether the Bank of Japan would acceed to pressures for a reduction. Several newspapers, including Nihon Keizei Shimbun, Japan's leading financial daily, predicted in recent weeks that the cut was imminent, only to be contradicted by Mr. Mieno.
 
A Cooling Economy
 After the Japanese economy blazed ahead at a rate of more than 5 percent last year, economists are predicting that it will grow about 3 percent to 3.5 percent this year. That rate is still considered a healthy pace, particularly compared with growth in the United States.
Paul Summerville, an economist at Jardine Fleming Securities here, said there were clearer signs now that the economy was cooling. Housing construction and industrial production have been declining, according to figures released last week.
Consumer inflation appears to have diminished to about 3.5 percent, from its high of about 4.5 percent in January. There are also indications that Japan's labor shortage, while still severe, is easing somewhat. Overheated property prices -- one of Mr. Mieno's special targets -- have also shown some signs of slowing.
Not least, the stock market has been sluggish for more than a year, and it has fallen sharply in recent weeks. Analysts have attributed part of the recent drop to a scandal involving Japan's Big Four securities houses. But they also said it had stemmed from disappointment that the central bank had not moved to cut interest rates at a time when the economy was clearly expanding at a slower pace.

HEADLINE: The Dow Advances 51.66 Points, to 2,958.41

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
An exceptionally strong stock market in Tokyo and a favorable purchasing managers' report did wonders for Wall Street yesterday as stocks bounced back sharply and recovered almost everything they lost last week.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which sank nearly 59 points last week, soared 51.66, or about 1.8 percent, to 2,958.41. 
 Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Company, said the National Association of Purchasing Management's report was a "real stimulus" in the price rise, along with the reduction in Japanese interest rates and the rise in the Nikkei stock index.
The purchasing managers' index rose to 50.9 percent in June, up from May's level of 45.4 percent.
"It was a very positive report on the economy, particularly the manufacturing end," Mr. Sinai said, "and it is clearly saying the recession is over."
The much broader Standard & Poor's 500 index climbed a little more than 1.8 percent. The day's trading brought the Dow industrial average to within 77 points of its all-time high of 3,035.33.
The smaller stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite, advanced a bit more than 1.1 percent, while the American Stock Exchange's market-value index of small stocks rose seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The rise spread across most leading stock groups, from airlines, chemicals, technology and drugs to oil, insurance, retailing and telephone stocks. Except for a few banking companies, even the bank stocks, a big worry for most of last week, turned upward.
Trading activity, while still sluggish, rose to about 167.5 million shares, from 163.8 million on Friday. Almost 30 million of the total came in the final hour. Birinyi Associates, which monitors computer-programmed activity, said that four big buying waves lifted the Dow 33 points, thereby accounting for most of yesterday's strength.
Traders cited the sharp rise in Tokyo's Nikkei index of 225 stocks. It climbed 817.80 points, or 3.5 percent, to 24,108.76. Much of yesterday's gain came after the Bank of Japan lowered its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
[At the close of trading in Tokyo today, the Nikkei index was down 113 points, or 0.47 percent, to 23,995.76]
 Kenneth P. Ducey, trading director for the BT Brokerage Corporation, said of the trading in the United States, "There's no real resistance as far as selling goes."After last week's big selloff, he added, "most of the selling seems to be out of the way."
Noting that like many Wall Street people he tracked the market on a color-coded Bridge machine, where falling stock prices show up in red and rising ones in green, he said, "My machine is all green; it's the first time it's happened in a long time."
 
Dow Is Up From the Opening
 The rise in the Dow seemed impressive from the opening bell. Within minutes it was ahead 24 points. Within an hour it had jumped almost 40. The average drifted somewhat higher from then on, climbing another 15 points by the end of the day. Program buying was at its heaviest early in the session, Birinyi said, with the Dow climbing 17 points on a 14-minute wave of buying started around 10:30 A.M.
Among the big movers were Japanese stocks like Hitachi up 3 7/8, to 82 5/8; Matsushita 2 3/4, to 122 3/4; Ito Yokado 3, to 131, and Tokio Marine 2 7/8, to 44 3/8.
Dillard Department Stores rose 4 1/8, to 125 1/2. Last week, Fourteen Research and First Manhattan raised their 1992 earnings estimates.
UAL climbed 3 1/4, to 142, after Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of the airline, said in an Orlando, Fla., news conference that second-quarter results would be substantially better than in the first quarter.
Merck jumped 3 1/8, to 119 1/4, and United States Surgical added 3 1/8, to 65 3/4, both in brisk trading, but there did not appear to be any news to account for the buying.
SciMed Life Systems, maker of disposable medical supplies, rose 4 1/2, to 70, in heavy trading in the wake of last week's better-than-expected first quarter. Dow Jones said Kurt Kruger of Hambrecht & Quist and Jonathan Osgood of Alex. Brown & Sons subsequently recommended the stock and that Carol Winslow of Vector Securities recommended it yesterday.
Wells Fargo, which plunged 17 7/8, or almost 21 percent, last week, slid 3 3/4 more, to 65 1/4, in strong trading in continued reaction to last week's announcement that it would reserve $350 million in the second quarter against possible loan losses.
Shearson Lehman Brothers, one of the nation's biggest brokerage houses, revealed its 1992 list of the top 10 stock picks; all 10 rose in brisk trading. HEADLINE: June Surge In Economy Is Reported

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday that their monthly survey of economic activity indicated that the economy surged in June to its highest level in more than two years.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's main economic index rose to 50.9 percent in June, up sharply from May's level of 45.4 percent. It was the highest reading since April 1989, when the index stood at 52.1 percent. 
 A reading below 50 percent indicates that the manufacturing economy is declining, while a reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion. Before June, the index had been below 50 percent for 12 consecutive months.
 
Some Await Future Data
 The group contended that the rise in the index indicated that the recession was over. Economists generally agreed but were more cautious in their interpretation of the figures, with some suggesting that the next few months would better gauge whether the recession had indeed reached an end and how robust a recovery would be.
The report surprised most credit market participants, who had expected that economic activity would remain weak to sluggish in June. Prices for Treasury issues fell as traders feared that a rise in economic activity could lead to a resurgence in inflation. The news helped the stock market stage a rebound, with the Dow rising 51.66, or 1.78 percent, to 2,958.41. [Pages D8 and D14.]
The purchasing managers' report is considered an important economic indicator because it is based on a survey of managers from a wide range of industrial companies. Also, it is the first important indicator each month of how the economy performed in the previous month.
 
'Recession Is Essentially Over'
 "With the index over 50 percent, the recession is essentially over for the manufacturing sector as well as the overall economy," said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the association's business survey committee and director of corporate purchasing at Pitney Bowes Inc. "The continued sharp increase in the engine of growth, new orders, virtually assures continued growth in production in the months ahead."
Wolfgang H. Demisch, director of research at UBS Securities Inc., said that questions remained "about the slope of the upturn." He added that the pace of the economic recovery was likely to be more moderate than previous recoveries. "It's hard to see the financial fuel that would propel a more vigorous ascent," he said.
Richard D. Berner, a senior economist with Salomon Brothers, agreed that the purchasing managers' report was one in a series of data indicating that the economy was emerging from the recession. "We've begun to see some firming in demand in the industrial sector," he said.
The index of economic activity was pushed up in June by a surge in new orders, a measurement considered by economists to be the most important component of the monthly survey. Activity in new orders in turn affects the level of production, employment and inventories. The association's index of new orders soared in June to 59.1 percent, from 50.6 percent in May. It was the highest reading for new orders since August 1988, when the index stood at 50.2 percent.
"The new orders are particularly strong, which suggests that the pattern of improvement has set in and is likely to persist for a meaningful period of time," said Neal Soss, chief economist with the First Boston Corporation. "They say that the figures signal the end of the recession and I think that's a correct assessment."
 
Production Index Climbs
 Production increased sharply in June, with the association's production index jumping to 55 percent, from 48.8 percent in May. The report said that the sharp increase in new orders in June should provide continued growth in production in upcoming months.
The association's price index rose for the second consecutive month, to 39.5 percent in June, from 36.9 percent in May. The report said tht prices would rise further, because "they lag the economy, which has just begun its recovery."
The purchasing managers' employment index rose to 43.3 percent in June, fom 37 percent in May.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
New York Taxes Batter Middle Class

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
The middle class is likely to feel the greatest impact from the $735 million increase in income and property taxes that the Dinkins administration and the City Council has agreed to impose to balance the budget, tax experts say.
Businesses will also be hit hard, the smallest ones the worst. 
 Throughout New York City the prospect of higher taxes was generating a variety of responses. For Helen Daniels, a 42-year-old single parent who owns a brownstone in Harlem and who is trying to put her two children through college on her $47,000 salary, the tax increase is more unwelcome pressure.
She was already finding it tough to juggle a $1,000-a month mortgage payment and a $10,000 tuition fee she expects to pay for her daughter to transfer to George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., this fall. Now she must make room for a $150 increase in her water and sewage charges, to $500; an estimated $162 increase in the personal income tax she pays to the city, to $1,320, and an estimated $119 increase in her property taxes, to $969.
 
'Struggle Is So Great'
 "People tell me I'm a member of the middle class, but the struggle is so great just to maintain the basics that in one respect I don't feel like it," Ms. Daniels said. Many of her neighbors, she said, are also single women with children. The talk these days is about leaving the city, taking in boarders or being forced to sell the houses they have spent years making livable.
The outlook is not much happier for Dan Tubridy, the owner of a seafood restaurant in Rockaway Beach, Queens, who has a wife and five boys. To pay the increase in a variety of different business taxes, he fears that for the first time in 13 years, he may have to close his restaurant for several weeks or months this winter to save on labor costs in a slow period.
"For the first time in my life I'm saying, 'Is there a better place to be?' and that scares me," said Mr. Tubridy, whose family has lived in the Rockaways since the early 1900's. "I love this city!"
Of course, tax increases are never popular. But in the case of New York City, there is more than just rhetoric behind the current round of complaints. Before the prospect of new increases loomed, city residents were already paying three times more in city taxes than residents in other localities, according to City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
 
City Services at Risk
 City officials defend the latest rises as necessary to insure that city services are not slashed to the extent that the city becomes unlivable. And they say property and income-tax increases are the fairest because they are spread over the largest group.
"We were going for taxes that had the broadest base and that were deductible," said Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's Commissioner of Finance.
The middle class feels the impact of these taxes more than the wealthy because the latter are still enjoying the benefits of sharp cuts in their Federal income-tax burden during the 1980's, when the rate for those at the top end of the income scale fell from 50 percent to 31 percent. Because of those reductions, many people with high incomes are still better off -- even with this latest round of local taxes -- than they were at the beginning of the 80's.
But many small businesses are facing new hardships with a new round of tax increases.
 
Landlord's Lament
 Winifred Dozier-Davis, a 55-year-old widow who owns an apartment building in Harlem with 67 units, has for the last few years been hit with property-tax increases of about $3,000 a year. This year, she said, her water and sewage charges went up by about $1,700.
Because so many of the apartments in her building fall under rent-control or rent-stabilization guidelines, she cannot pass along those increases, or the ones just agreed upon, to her tenants. And currently five tenants are delinquent in rent payments.
 
286,000 Jobs Predicted to Be Lost
 The prospect of higher taxes in an already weak economy troubles some economists.
The Comptroller's office estimates that this latest round of tax increases will result in twice as many jobs being lost as would have occurred if the economy had been healthy. Stephen Kagann, the office's chief economist, predicts that the tax increases agreed to on Sunday will result in a loss of 286,000 jobs by 1994.
Not only might companies have to cope with a business climate that will continue to be weak, but they also will bear a disproportionate share of the city's new property-tax increase. Because of ceilings put on the rates of taxes on one- and two-family homes in the city, businesses paid 63 percent of the city's property taxes in the fiscal year that ended in June 1990, compared with just 55 percent at the time of the last fiscal crisis in the 1970's, according to a tax commission appointed by former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
Cuomo and Dinkins Strive to Find Long-Term Solutions to Fiscal Ills

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
With their immediate budget crises not fully resolved, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins turned yesterday to finding ways to solve New York City's and the state's deep long-term fiscal problems by shifting and streamlining their complex burdens of taxing, spending and providing services.
Just what form such a joint review would take or what force its recommendations might have remained in some dispute, and both sides jockeyed yesterday to be seen as leading the effort. City Hall proposed the creation of a new city-state commission, while the Governor said he favored increasing coordination through existing staff-level efforts. 
 Both sides said the review should weigh issues like how the state might assume a greater share of welfare and Medicaid payments.
Political leaders, civic groups and fiscal monitors have argued for months that the best solution to the city and state's interwoven fiscal troubles would be a fundamental restructuring of their responsibilities.
For this year, city officials are hoping that labor concessions will help avoid some service cuts and thousands of layoffs, and yesterday two major union leaders said they would be willing to offer as much as $100 million in givebacks. [Page B5.]
But for future years, long-term solutions could include having the state take on new burdens by increasing state taxes, which now raise only aout two-thirds as much as local taxes throughout the state.
Movement toward such changes, with money-saving concessions Mr. Dinkins is seeking from the municipal unions, could pave the way for hundreds of millions of dollars in aid through refinancings by the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the state body set up to help bail the city out of its last fiscal crisis. The authority's chairman, Felix G. Rohatyn, has tied help from the corporation to long-term changes to reduce the cost of government.
Governor Cuomo and Mayor Dinkins have both been under increasing pressure to address the problem of the economic relations between the two governments. But it has been politically sensitive, because Mr. Cuomo was not eager to be seen as usurping the Mayor's powers or to get tied up in the city's problems. And the Mayor has vowed repeatedly to resist any effort that meant expanding the role of the Financial Control Board, the state oversight body headed by Mr. Cuomo, whose binding powers over city spending lapsed after the city's recovery from the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's.
But recently Mr. Cuomo has said he wanted to play a more active role. Yesterday, on the eve of a control board meeting to review the city's new budget, at which Mr. Cuomo planned to outline his ideas for government restructuring, City Hall aides said Mr. Dinkins was pressing what they described as their own proposal for a formal state-city commission, to the consternation of the Cuomo administration, which had hoped to dominate public attention with its announcement today.
Asked what he thought of starting a commission to review ideas that have been in the air for weeks on the economic relations of the city and the state, Mr. Cuomo said: "They're not in the air. They're in the speech I'm delivering tomorrow."
Mr. Dinkins, who complains in most of his speeches that New York is the only state in the nation that requires localities to pay 50 percent of Medicaid costs, totaling $1.5 billion a year for the city, said a review of that and other problems was "damn important."
 
'Not Just a Study Group'
 He added: "The most important thing in getting it off the ground, I think, is for there to be some sort of commission that is seen as being serious. Not just a study group."
The Mayor and his aides said such a group could take actions ranging from making recommendations to elected officials to proposing big changes in state law that could be voted on in the State Legislature, though they stressed that no particular version had been decided on.
Albany and City Hall have been quietly discussing the idea for weeks, with Cuomo aides preferring to expand an existing program called New York-New York, which involves cooperation on financial issues between the state budget director and the Mayor's Office of Operations. Mayoral aides said that they wanted a higher-profile effort but that the Governor was concerned that could open a rancorous debate with the Legislature over who would pay for such a group.
They said the Governor was also worried that such a group could leave him more open to embarrassment should its recommendations fail and could entail a host of changes in the state's dealings with all municipalities, not just New York City.
But the Governor dismissed those notions. "I'm easy when it comes to profiles," he said. "They can make it as a high a profile as they want. I'm a back-room guy myself. But if they want to have profile, they can have it."
Mr. Cuomo would not comment on the implications that restructuring the governments would have on persuading Mr. Rohatyn of the assistance corporation to provide money. He said: "I asked Felix if I could get M.A.C. money if I did it right. He said, 'If you do it very right, maybe.' "
For Mr. Dinkins, creating a new body to review such ideas, and perhaps help carry them out, would be a way to play a major role in such decisions without the intervention of the Financial Control Board, which some officials have suggested might shape such efforts. Mr. Dinkins has vowed to resist a more active role for the board.
But Mr. Cuomo, while repeating his desire for "cooperation, not control," said: "The Financial Control Board will absolutely be dealing with this subject. It must. The F.C.B. will be meeting regularly. Of course, the F.C.B. will be a very big part of it, but not in any way that should be threatening to the city."
For some time, senior Dinkins and Cuomo aides have been talking quietly about how best to handle efforts to restructure the city-state roles. First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said the Mayor had asked him and Finance Commissioner Carol O'Cleireacain to "explore formulas and vehicles for thinking about it."

LENGTH: 954 words

HEADLINE: 9 States Miss Deadlines for Budgets

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 1

 BODY:
California entered its new fiscal year today without a balanced budget. So did eight other states where politicians were also unable to make the painful decision of raising taxes and cutting spending in a time of deep recession.
For now, missing the deadline in California meant only another tense day of nail-biting and head-banging at the Capitol in Sacramento, but in Maine, Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. declared a state emergency and furloughed 10,000 state employees considered nonessential. 
 In Connecticut, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. vetoed a no-income-tax budget passed by the Legislature, warning that he would furlough 7,000 workers if the legislators did not approve a state personal income tax.
The other states still hammering out budgets today are Illinois, Louisiana, Massachusetts, North Carolina, Ohio and Pennsylvania.
 
Some Timely Budget Action
 One state that did pass a budget before the start of the new fiscal year today was Iowa, but its Governor, Terry E. Branstad, said today that he was ordering an additional $104 million in across-the-board cuts.
Another state that beat the deadline, barely, was New Jersey, where Gov. Jim Florio signed a $14.7 billion budget at 11:54 P.M. on Sunday after the Legislature approved it earlier in the evening. The budget could force the layoffs of 2,000 to 3,000 state workers.
Nevada and the state of Washington also reached budget agreements within minutes of their midnight Sunday deadlines.
In New York City, officials reached an agreement on the outlines of a grim budget a few hours before the deadline. The agreement provides for tax increases, service cuts and the layoff of 10,000 municipal workers.
 
A $14.3 Billion Gap
 Nearly every state has had a tough time balancing its budget in this recession year, but nowhere has the task been more daunting than in California, which faces a gap of $14.3 billion between spending on state programs and expected revenue. This shortage alone is so large that it dwarfs the entire general fund expenditures of every other state except New York.
By Sunday night the California Legislature had passed additional sales and other taxes and cut welfare and other services enough to erase all but $2 billion of the shortage. But, in a special session Sunday night, they were unable to reach agreement on the final measures, which might include raising the income tax for the wealthy and cutting the salaries of state employees by 5 percent.
Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, has threatened to veto the $56 billion budget passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature on June 20 if the additional taxes and spending cuts are not made by this Wednesday.
"We're definitely standing," said Franz Wisner, a spokesman for the Governor. "We just don't know where we're standing."
 
A Question of Taxes
 The chief sticking point is whether to raise personal income taxes. Democratic leaders, backed by big-business interests, prefer to raise the tax on individuals who earn more than $100,000 rather than impose a 2 percent tax on utility bills. Governor Wilson, who has long opposed any such income tax increase, appeared to yield over the weekend.
The process has been complicated by last-minute demands, advanced by Republicans in the Assembly, for new legislation to make it harder for employees to claim workman's compensation benefits for stress. It is opposed by the Democrats in the Assembly, led by the Speaker, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco.
"The Assembly is hopelessly deadlocked and unable to send the Senate the tax bills backed by Wilson," State Senator David A. Roberti of Los Angeles, the President pro tem, told reporters Sunday night. But Mr. Wisner said today, "We are still counting on the budget being passed before Wednesday."
If not, the immediate consequences would not be devastating. A spokesman for Gray Davis, the Comptroller, said the state would have to pay an extra $11 million in interest in money borrowed to maintain normal cash flow after Wednesday.
The real showdown would not come until the next pay day, on July 15, when highway workers and other state employees might go payless, as happened last year. But the Health Services and Social Services departments said they planned to continue essential services to the sick and poor under a court order issued in a similar impasse last year.
A larger concern was that the state's AAA bond rating might be downgraded by Standard & Poor's, the New York-based rating agency.
 
The Situation Elsewhere
 In Maine, about 200 furloughed state employees rallied outside the Governor's office in Augusta, The Associated Press reported. "We hope this impasse is going to be resolved as quickly as possible and we want to get back to the normal operation of government," Governor McKernan said. Despite the furloughs, the number of state employees working at prisons and mental health centers was normal.
In Pennsylvania, a marathan legislative session ended shortly before 9 P.M. Sunday with only a stopgap plan to keep money flowing for welfare recipients and for interest payments. State offices were to remain open, but $250 million for schools and pay for 10,000 state employees would be suspended on July 5.
In Massachusetts, the Legislature sent Gov. William F. Weld a $12.9 billion budget that called for deep cuts in social services and increases in the property tax.
Elsewhere, procrastination was the watchword. The Ohio Legislature, unable to reach agreement, passed a 30-day temporary spending bill. In Illinois, the debate continued amid the prospect of the shutdown of some state services. And in North Carolina, the Legislature gave up temporarily and took the weekend off.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
With Stalemate, Connecticut Enters Budget Abyss

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Tuesday, July 2

 BODY:
Connecticut's government stood today on the threshold of an undefined, but sharply worsened budget crisis.
For the first time in this century, there was no state budget in place through the first full day of business of a new fiscal year. Senior state officers warned that the void could lead to huge legal claims and constitutional questions about who pays the bills when the budget process breaks down. 
 Late Monday night, House Democrats emerged from a three-hour caucus announcing that they had enough votes to pass a compromise income-tax plan to finance the budget. The plan would require a smaller tax than the one sought by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., but would establish the precedent of a tax on income in Connecticut. If passed by the House, the measure would still require approval by the Senate to take effect.
The Governor, who had threatened 24 hours earlier to make good on a previous threat to shut down state government if a budget was not approved by 12:01 A.M. today, relaxed that deadline, but continued to threaten to begin closing parks, motor-vehicle offices and other services deemed nonessential to the public safety if a tax plan was not approved sometime overnight.
The previous 24 hours had been filled with ultimatums, and much of the air of drama involved figuring out which ones might be real, which ones might be feints, and which ones should be taken seriously -- however unlikely or irrational they might seem -- because of the bargainer's reputation.
People in both the legislative and executive branches of government were staking out positions about whose voice should prevail in maintaining economic order.
Mr. Weicker, a third-party governor who has insisted now through two budget vetoes that an income tax is necessary to resolve the state's revenue shortfall, had issued an executive order early Monday saying that essential state services would be maintained even without a budget. His action came after he vetoed the Legislature's efforts to resolve the state's fiscal crisis with an expanded sales tax in place of the income tax.
 
'Uncharted Legal Territory'
 Many lawmakers immediately questioned whether Mr. Weicker was exceeding his powers by pledging to spend money that the legislative branch had not appropriated. The State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, disagreed, saying Mr. Weicker had the authority to act.
But Mr. Blumenthal said the government shutdown would be a complete disaster for the state and he publicly urged Mr. Weicker not to veto an extension if lawmakers need more time.
"There's a world of very serious potential legal liabilities, risks, costs and lawsuits that will result from a shutdown," Mr. Blumenthal said in an interview. "We are in completely uncharted legal territory."
Mr. Blumenthal said that because Connecticut has no legal framework or court precedent for segregating essential from non-essential services, the Governor would be exposing the state to a lawsuit from anyone -- whether furloughed employee or discomfited residents -- who felt that the decisions to be wrong. And he said that the state would have little legal ammunition with which to defend itself from the claims that the decisions were arbitrary because without a law to help define what is "essential," the decisions would be arbitrary almost by definition.
The State Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., whose office is responsible for paying the state's bills, said that because of the recession, the state was falling $100 million deeper into debt each month. The lack of a budget could push that to $200 million a month, partly because of higher borrowing costs, or about $270,000 for every hour that no budget is passed, he said.
"Everyone agrees that the essential operations of government continue to be authorized," he said. "But what are the essential operations of government? Payment of interest, or payment of welfare -- try making that Hobson's choice."
Lawmakers were also divided among themselves about when and how to press a continuing resolution to keep paying the state's bills. The Senate passed a two-week budget extension early Monday morning, but House leaders deliberately postponed taking up the Senate's resolution, pressing instead toward the compromise income-tax plan that looked like it might somehow go where no income tax plan has gone before and obtain a majority of votes.
That compromise plan, sponsored by a Republican Senator whose party has been all but unanimous in opposing Mr. Weicker's efforts to overhaul the state's revenue system, would enact a smaller income tax than Mr. Weicker has sought, and would thus allow lesser cuts in business taxes, which Mr. Weicker identified as essential to stimulate the state's economy.
The new plan would create a 4.75 percent flat rate income tax on adjusted gross income over $12,000 for an individual or $24,000 for a couple filing jointly. It would thus provide a lower tax rate than the last income tax plan, a graduated income tax that rose to a rate of 6.5 percent at the highest income levels. That earlier plan was defeated in the House on Saturday night by a large margin, thus setting the stage the effort on Sunday to pass the no-income tax plan that Mr. Weicker vetoed early Monday.
The no-income tax plan would have resolved the state's revenue shortfall -- now projected to reach $2.8 billion in a budget of about $8 billion -- through a drastic expansion of the sales tax system. Governor Weicker, signing the veto papers on live television, said it would only make the state's problem worse because falling sales tax collections are at the heart of the current shortfall.
And while some elements of the drama were perhaps best appreciated by accountants, other acts of brinksmanship or bravado were clear enough for all to understand. The state employee unions, for example, held a news conference to announce that they might still accept a $340 million package of wage and benefit concessions negotiated with the Weicker administration if lawmakers could approve a budget in the next few days.
A spokesman for the group, Robert Krzys, decried the pain that would result from a state government shutdown, even though Mr. Curry and other officials said the state employees would probably be among the least harmed.

HEADLINE: Union Leaders Are Willing To Make More Concessions

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Two major leaders of municipal unions in New York City said for the first time yesterday that they were willing to give back as much as $100 million in wages and other concessions to avert some of the thousands of layoffs called for in the budget.
City officials are hoping that the concessions will eventually help restore cuts in services and the jobs of many of the 10,000 workers slated to be laid off -- including 6,000 laid off last week -- as part of the budget agreement reached Sunday night after tough bargaining between the City Council and the Dinkins administration. 
 Based on the formula that $23,000 in give-backs saves a job, the $100 million in concessions could avert 4,300 layoffs. Union leaders are also pushing an early-retirement plan that they say would save an unspecified number of jobs, and a plan to shift laid-off workers to fill job vacancies.
The union leaders' statements came as the City Council struggled to resolve a range of last-minute snags that kept it from formally passing the budget. As of early today, the Council still had not voted on the budget, more than 24 hours after it was technically due.
 
Safe Streets Plan Is Reduced
 Yesterday, the Dinkins administration said that in the late budget maneuvering it had cut $70 million, or more than a third of Mayor Dinkins's ambitious public safety plan, "Safe Streets, Safe City."
The city will cut its planned hiring of police officers by 125, to the minimum levels required by the State Legislature when it approved taxes to pay for the plan, and it will not hire the officers required under the plan until June 29, 1992, officials said.
The possiblity of union concessions is only one uncertainty in an unusually tentative budget, and city officials predicted that it would be heavily revised.
Complicating the city's budget picture, the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, yesterday reiterated his reluctance to allow the city to raise income taxes by $335 million. He said the Republican-controlled Senate would be willing to consider the tax increase if it lapsed after a period of time "considerably less" than the four years the Democratic-controlled Assembly announced it would approve.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said that the simple act of agreement on a budget was likely to shore up the confidence of the financial community.
 
Impact on City's Economy
 But she said she was concerned that the city's revenue estimates were far more optimistic than ones she put out only a few days ago. "Layoffs, tax increases and service cuts are themselves going to have an impact on the underlying economy," she said.
Raymond D. Horton, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a research group supported by businesses, called the budget "transitory."
"There are so many assumptions going into it that probably are risky, so that some if not all of them will fail to materialize and put it out of kilter," he said.
The new union position was disclosed at an angry news conference on the steps of City Hall yesterday, in which the two union leaders, who had helped elect the Mayor, accused him of betraying them by refusing to make a deal to stop the layoffs.
 
'Political and Sacrificial Lambs'
 "I cannot stand by and allow my members to be the Mayor's political and sacrificial lambs to Wall Street," said Stanley Hill, executive director of the 140,000-member District Council 37 of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees.
Barry Feinstein, the teamsters leader, said that the union leaders would unleash an army of 10,000 workers to press the Mayor to restore their jobs. "The damage that will be done to the city is the sole responsibility of the Mayor."
But even as they attacked the Mayor, the union leaders for the first time publicly acknowledged that they were considering $100 million in concessions through a five-day payroll lag, forgiving some or all of the wage increases won in the last year and forgiving welfare fund payments owed by the city.
The payroll lag would push back the issuance of paychecks by one day for each of five pay periods.
City negotiators said that despite the fierce speeches, the commitment of the union leaders to make concessions went beyond any statements they had made privately over the last two weeks, and was grounds for hope, if not optimism, that an agreement could be reached this week.
Mr. Feinstein and Mr. Hill are considered crucial pegs in the efforts to avert layoffs. Other union leaders, citing either past concessions or the lack of a contract, have shied away from the talks. But because a settlement by one municipal union often sets a pattern for others, city officials hope that whatever concessions are made by Mr. Feinstein and Mr. Hill will eventually be applied to other city workers.
Both sides said the talks broke down Sunday night, the night the Mayor and the Council agreed on the outlines of a new city budget. The breakdown occurred after Mr. Dinkins's negotiators said that even if the union leaders made substantial concessions they could not guarantee that the city would not lay off workers later, if the city's fiscal situation deteriorated.
 
'They Are Still My Friends'
 Asked about the union positions at a news conference yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said: "They are still my friends. They have over time used intemperate language. I understand they are speaking to the members."
Under the budget agreement between the Council and the Mayor, Mr. Dinkins, who had been pressing for a $776 million property-tax increase, agreed to accept a little more than half that, while the Council agreed to change its list of restored cuts from $220 million to $117 million.
But after that simple agreement a cloud of confusion settled over City Hall.
The Mayor and the Council jockeyed over which programs to restore. According to a Council spokesman, at the last minute, Mr. Dinkins insisted that a prison mental health program be given the highest priority for health and safety reasons, and a $3.2 million restoration was raised to $14 million. This in turn forced a reduction in the amount of money restored to the recycling program, the spokesman said.
 
8 Cents Back for Each Dollar
 Even so, the city was able to restore about eight cents out of every dollar in previously announced cuts. Out of a $42 million cut in libraries made by the Mayor only $14 million was restored in the final budget. Out of a $53 million cut in the Parks Department only $3.7 million was restored.
And to pay for the restoration and smaller tax increase, $200 million in still other cuts were made, raising the total service cuts in the budget to $1.6 billion, with $68 million or about a third of the reduction programs coming from Mr. Dinkins's own "Safe Streets, Safe City" program.
The passage of the program was a highlight of Mr. Dinkins first year in office. But yesterday, new spending for both police and youth programs were cut back, with the Board of Education losing $30 million in expected aid and the expansion of youth programs slowed. The hiring of two police classes was delayed, along with plans to hire more civilian aides for the Police Department.
"Everything else was cut to the bone," said Philip R. Michael, the city budget director.
School officials said that while the Board of Education may have gained as much as $70 million in state aid in the last week, the $30 million loss in the city budget, on top of a $500 million cut, was devastating.

HEADLINE: Engineers Teach 'Smart' Buildings To Foil Quakes

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

 BODY:
LAST week's earthquake in southern California may jolt even the building industry, notoriously slow to innovate, into experimenting with new kinds of earthquake resistant buildings. Among the most interesting are so-called smart buildings in which a system of computers, sensors and moving weights detects and moves to counteract the alarming motions generated by earthquakes and strong winds.
Traditionally, building engineers have taken a brute strength approach to structural safety. They use massive, heavy materials and build stiffness into a building's infrastructure to resist winds and earthquakes. To filter out shaking, some newer buildings have been constructed on huge rubber pads or materials that act as springs that help dissipate energy. It has taken 30 years to get such passive control systems into the building codes, because American construction companies are extremely slow to innovate, said Dr. Tsu T. Soong, a professor of civil engineering at the National Center for Earthquake Engineering Research at the State University of New York in Buffalo. 
 But in Japan, where destructive earthquakes are an ever-present threat, five major construction companies compete for contracts based on new technologies, and the company with the best new ideas tends to win more contracts. Japanese construction companies invest 10 percent of their gross income in research and development, said Dr. S. Chi Liu, program manager of the Earthquake Hazard Mitigation Project at the National Science Foundation in Washington. They are particularly interested in active and passive control systems to resist earthquakes and wind. U.S. companies invest virtually nothing.
As so often happens, Dr. Liu said, many of the most innovative ideas for such systems are originating in the United States but are being developed by the Japanese. To help spur American involvement, the foundation expects to award $5 million over the next five years to American researchers, Dr. Liu said. But whether American construction companies will use that research, he said, is hard to say.
The world's first building with an active control system was built on a sliver of land in a Tokyo suburb in 1989. The Kyobashi Seiwa office building is only 12 feet wide, 100 feet long and 11 stories high, he said, and the owners worried that wind would buffet the slender structure.
To stabilize the building, the construction company Kajima suspended a four-ton weight and a one-ton weight, one above another, on the building's roof. Sensors were embedded into the building's walls and base and attached to a computer. When the ground shakes or the wind blows, Dr. Liu said, the computer sends signals to hydraulic arms called actuators that move the weights to counteract the motions in the building.
Kajima claims that 80 percent of the building's motion has been dampened out by the active system, Dr. Liu said, although the building's performance has not been independently verified.
A second structure, also built in Tokyo in 1989, is a joint venture between between the Buffalo researchers and the Takenaka Corporation of Japan, another leading construction firm. It is a six-story, 600-ton building without walls that was built solely to demonstrate both weight and bracing systems, Dr. Soong said. Its performance is being monitored and will be published in scientific journals.
The weight consists of a six-ton slab of steel suspended on the roof. Sensors in the basement, third and sixth floor detect motion from earthquakes, wind and even local traffic and send the information to a computer that activates the actuators. The building's motion in strong wind and small earthquakes has been reduced by half, Dr. Soong said.
The bracing system is even more effective, Dr. Soong said, reducing motions by up to 70 percent. The braces are conventional steel tubes of the type that hold all buildings together, but these have been fitted with actuators at each end. When the computer sends its signals, the actuators lengthen or shorten the building's internal braces to accommodate motions from earthquakes and wind.
Both systems are capable of making the building shake, Dr. Soong said, so that one can be used to test the other's ability to dampen motion. Data will be collected for two more years.
The Tokyo buildings are performing very well, Dr. Liu said, and four more "smart" buildings are on the drawing board. But the technology is still in research and development stages, as safety, reliability, and cost questions are explored in the different designs.
People are going to need "a lot of convincing" before these concepts become acceptable in construction, Dr. Soong said. Whenever human lives are dependent on computers and mechanical systems, he said, people want to be sure about reliability.
Active control systems have long been used in airplanes, ships, spacecraft and other mobile structures. They are just beginning to be applied to stationary objects on land like buildings, bridges and elevated freeways.
 
Disrupting Seismic Waves
 Active control systems will make new buildings more expensive, Dr. Soong noted. But the new technology may also allow architects and engineers to design more economical buildings using lighter, more flexible materials instead of the heavy, steel-reinforced materials used today.
During earthquakes, many buildings collapse when they naturally oscillate at the same frequency as seismic waves traveling through the earth, amplifying their effect, said Dr. Thomas Heaton, a seismologist at the United States Geological Survey in Pasadena. Active control systems might prevent that from happening, he said.
Many skyscrapers sway tens of feet near their top floors in strong winds, Dr. Heaton said, and suspension bridges sometimes bounce vertically by tens of feet. Although such motions do not threaten the safety of the structures, he said, they can make people feel sick and disoriented. Again, active control systems might eliminate this problem.
A different idea for an active system is being developed at the University of Southern California by Dr. Sami Masri and his colleagues in the civil engineering department. When the wind or an earthquake imparts energy to a building, Dr. Masri said, it takes several seconds for the oscillations to build up to potentially damaging levels. Chaos theory, he said, suggests that a random source of energy injected into this rhythmtic flow should disrupt the system.
In Dr. Masri's scheme, the random energy is provided by jet thrusters mounted on the roof. Once again, sensors alert a computer that the building has begun to move and a signal is sent to the thrusters. The thrusters, powered by compressed air, would fire for short periods, just enough to destabilize the oscillations, Dr. Masri said. When the motions ceased, he said, the compressors would be recharged.
All three systems, the two Japanese ones and Dr. Masri's, could be added to old buildings and built into new buildings, bridges and elevated freeways, Dr. Liu said, but not until safety questions are ironed out. Active weight systems require a lot of energy, he said, and may have to be powered by power lines which may be knocked out in an earthquake. People are not going to trust "smart buildings," he said, if sensors, computers and actuators can fail.
An unanswered question, Dr. Masri said, is whether active systems should be used to save lives or merely to make buildings and structures more comfortable.
In the meantime, four new active control systems are in the planning stages. Two will be built overseas, Dr. Liu said. Two others are going to be added to existing buildings in the United States, one of which sways excessively in the wind. Because building owners do not like to admit their problems, he said, the names of the buildings are confidential.

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Self-Stabilizing Buildings"
 
Instead of swaying in response to an earthquake, some new buildings are designed as machines that actively suppress their own vibrations by moving a weight that is about 1 percent of the building's weight. In an experimental building in Japan using the system, the sway was said to be reduced by 80 percent. (Source: Dr. S. Chi Liu) (pg. C10)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Demise and Pall Of the Indians

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
If Columbus had sailed east, if the Wright brother had preferred trains, if George Steinbrenner had bought the Cleveland Indians . . .
In fact, 20 years ago, Steinbrenner and his partners tried to buy the Cleveland Indians. In fact, they thought they had bought the team from Vernon Stouffer, the latest of the Indians' transient owners. 
 "George knew Stouffer from the time he was a little kid," Gabe Paul, who was long associated with the Indians and was a member of the Steinbrenner group, recalled. "He went to school with Stouffer's son. They thought it was a done deal. George called Vernon, and Vernon was burned up because the story had leaked in the paper. Vernon said, 'Nah, I'm not interested,' and that was it."
That certainly was it for the Indians. Had Steinbrenner bought the club and made the moves that he did in his early years with the Yankees, the history of Cleveland baseball most likely would have taken a dramatic turn and not left the Indians and their fans wondering why, in 1991, the team has been incapable of producing a winner -- a contender even -- for more than three decades.
 
Club Hasn't Won A Division Title
 This is a franchise that has not won any kind of championship since 1954, when they won the pennant before losing the World Series to the New York Giants. The Indians have had only six winning seasons in the last 31 years, finishing higher than fourth only once in that span (third in 1968). They are the only American League East team never to have won a division title. In the last 31 years, except for the strike-split 1981 season, they have not finished a single-digit number of games out of first, but they have finished 20 or more games behind 16 times.
This season has been more of the same for the Indians. They entered last night's game against the Yankees with a 24-48 mark, the worst record in the major leagues that included 20 losses in the last 23 games.
Some people trace the Indians' generation of despair to an alleged curse that Bobby Bragan put on them (he has denied that he did) after they fired him as manager less than halfway into his first season (1958). Others point to their trading of Rocky Colavito, their best player and a favorite of the fans, for Harvey Kuenn just before the start of the 1960 season. The real reasons, however, are more mundane.
*Frequent changes in ownership have created instability and a lack of continuity in planning.
*Given the weak financial status of their owners, the Indians have not had the money needed to develop players in their minor league system, or retain their own players, or go after free agents.
*Their 60-year-old stadium, a dreary, cavernous edifice, works against the team, psychologically and economically.
In their 31 years of misery, the Indians have had more owners than above-.500 records. Beginning with William Daley and running through the current owners, Richard and David Jacobs, the club has had eight owners or ownership groups.
"You've had an awful lot of change in ownership," said Peter Bavasi, who was the Indians' president for two years in the mid-1980's. "Then management changes and plans change. Any time you change plans, you go one step forward, two steps back. That's an element of instability."
 
Ownership of Team Has Often Changed
Hank Peters, who is the current club president and was the club's director of player personnel in the latter half of the 1960's, has experienced the ramifications of change first-hand.
"It seems every few years somebody would sell the club and someone else would buy it," said Peters, who is retiring after this season. "There was no commitment to doing some of the things you need to do to establish competitive and winning teams. The income was limited, and player development was the last thing on the budget."
 Peters recalled the time during his earlier role with the team when the $1.2 million player development budget was to be cut by a third. Peters was asked by Stouffer whether the cut would affect the team.
"I said, 'Are you going to keep the club?' " Peters said. "I said, 'The reason I ask is the things you do in player development are never reflected immediately. If you intend to keep the club for a few years, you've just committed suicide.' That's what has happened. The club keeps committing suicide."
 Bob Quinn, the Reds' vice president and general manager who spent 13 years working for the Indians in player development, recalled how Phil Seghi, the general manager, used to say, "The good news is we're entered in the Indianapolis 500. The bad news is we're driving a Volkswagen."
 The lack of money has also resulted in the departure of many of the team's better players through trades or free agency. Why couldn't the Indians afford to develop players and hold on to them? Paul offered some insight in describing the financial state of some of the owners.
 When Stouffer bought the Indians in 1966, Paul explained, he had recently sold his food business to Litton Industries in a stock transaction. "He took it at 108 and it went down to 8, and we had trouble paying the bills," Paul said. "He had plenty of money when he bought the club and he would've spent it. But things got tough and he couldn't do anything."
 Steve O'Neill, whose purchase of 57 percent of the club brought Paul back to Cleveland in 1978, had "plenty of money," Paul related. "But he felt the 15 to 20 others should share in taking some of the load, and they didn't do it," Paul explained in referring to the minority partners.
 Paul was the largest stockholder, with about 21 percent, in the group that owned the Indians from 1963 until Stouffer bought them. "I got out, Paul said, "because while a lot of the partners would've been willing to put in their share, I didn't have enough money to put in mine."
 
Outmoded Stadium Is Difficult to Play In
If money has retarded the Indians' growth, the absence of growth has kept the fans away from ancient Cleveland Stadium, built as a public works project.
"The park served its purpose," Al Rosen, a former Cleveland star and the San Francisco Giants' general manager, said. "It's outmoded. The stadium is cold. You don't warm up there until July. It's just been a series of bad dreams for them."
 Ralph Kiner, the Met broadcaster, who finished his Hall of Fame playing career with the Indians in 1955, recalled the mammoth stadium as a "very difficult place to play."
"It has to be worse than when I played there," he added. "It certainly isn't any better and it never was any good at its best."
 Doc Edwards, a Met coach who played for the Indians in the early 1960's and who became the Cleveland manager late in 1987 until he was dismissed late in the 1989 season, said the stadium on Lake Erie holds good memories for him. "But for players today," he said, "there's no nostalgia, They're just looking for a place that's comfortable."
 The stadium presents another problem, one that goes to the club's economic difficulties. Although the Indians have held many attendance records and still hold some, the stadium, with 74,483 seats, is just too big.
 "If you win a game in April, you should sell a ticket for August or September," Paul said. "But you don't do that in Cleveland. They wait until the day before the game. Then you have to have a winning streak. Nobody ever has been turned down in the Cleveland ball park, not even in the World Series. When they had the big crowd of more than 80,000 they didn't turn anyone down, They squeezed them in."
 The Indians, though, not only don't generate an advance sale, but they also don't get much of a game-day sale. They haven't drawn 2 million fans in a season since 1949, and they have attracted less than 1 million in 22 of the last 31 years. This season they are averaging 15,000 a game, lowest in the league.
 "The stadium can be depressing because you can have a pretty good-sized crowd and not notice it," Jeff Torborg, a former Indian manager who is now the Chicago White Sox manager, said.
 
Lack of Enthusiasm From the Fans
 The stadium atmosphere, Quinn said, does not breed enthusiasm.
 "It's very difficult to play at the stadium," the Reds executive said. "You say a player should put on the uniform and go out and play. But if you walk into a house and it's gloomy and it's been lived in by a couple in their 80's, it's not as perky as a young couple's house. The stadium is a gloomy place. A new stadium would do so much for the psyche of the 25 players on their roster. You'd see a marked improvement in the caliber of play."
 The Indians have not played at even a mediocre level this season. And there's no improvement in sight from the team that became even less experienced last week when Tom Candiotti, a veteran pitcher, was traded because he planned to leave as a free agent after the season.
 But the future does hold one bright hope. A new stadium is planned, although the Indians, the city and Cuyahoga County reached a self-imposed deadline Sunday without having reached agreement on the financing package and a lease. Despite the unfinished negotiations, officials are optimistic that they will reach agreement and make the new stadium a reality. Meanwhile, the Cleveland fans wait for positive signs that would jerk them out of their indifference and their resignation to having a disaster for a team.
 "It's been discouraging, no question about that," said Morton Klein, a 69-year-old Cleveland area resident who has been an Indians' fan for 60 years, and who in his youth was employed as a stadium vendor and usher. "But you become complacent and you don't expect them to win the pennant. I don't. It's discouraging, but we've gotten so we don't expect anything anymore. We go crazy if in July the team is still in contention."
