HEADLINE: Base Closings, Without Politics

 BODY:
A Federal commission's recommendations for shutting 25 more military bases have caused understandable anguish in the communities that will lose thousands of jobs and millions in income. But closing bases is as necessary as it is painful. The commission did its unpleasant work with intelligence, compassion and admirable independence.
The commission was created by Congress to handle a hot potato that the members of Congress were afraid to handle themselves. The seven commissioners didn't look too comfortable doing it, either. They sat in open session all day Sunday and into the night -- gavel-to-gavel on C-SPAN television -- discussing, debating and finally casting their fateful votes. It was high drama, and a rare display of decision-making in the open. 
 The commission received the Pentagon's list of proposed closings in mid-April. In a short 10 weeks, the commissioners mastered a mountain of information. Courageously, they kept both the Pentagon and the politicians at arm's length, challenging the military's arguments for closing the bases as coolly as they examined local pleas to keep them open.
It is no mystery why Congress ducked this chore. Thousands of jobs are at stake. Small towns and big cities long dependent on huge bases like Fort Devens in Massachusetts, Long Beach Naval Station in California and the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard will have to build a new economic base. Families will have to build new lives. But there's time. The closings will come gradually, over several years, and the Pentagon stands ready to help with the adjustment.
The commission's recommendations are only the first step. President Bush, who has two weeks to accept or reject the whole list, says he is likely to accept it as is, even though it differs somewhat from the Pentagon's. It will then be Congress's turn to accept or reject the whole package.
Some members with targeted bases will try to scuttle the whole procedure. There were unsuccessful attempts to kill the first round of closings in 1989, and there are already signs of scheming against the new list; for example, defenders of the Philadelphia yard are pushing appropriations for ship repairs to keep it going.
The overriding consideration is, and should be, wasted taxpayer dollars. It sounds cruel to yank the props out from communities whose livelihood depends on the military's presence, but continuing to pour hundreds of millions of dollars into installations that are now obsolete is inexcusable.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Labor: Key to New York's Crisis

 BODY:
All the celebrating at City Hall because New York met its budget deadline is understandable but premature. Of course it is better to have a budget than not to have one. But the new budget that emerged over the weekend is more a draft than a finished document. It relies on optimistic hopes for tax collections, and it is still missing one big piece of the budgetary puzzle: a contribution from the municipal unions.
Yesterday, labor leaders indicated that they would be willing to make concessions. But what a paltry beginning it was. Labor was talking of concessions worth about $100 million in the new fiscal year while the city was seeking about $600 million. 
 If labor leaders do make meaningful concessions, and can buy back some of the thousands of layoffs that began Friday, the city truly will have something to celebrate, despite a budget that will include higher taxes and many painful cuts.
What can the unions do? Precisely what they and city bargainers have been talking about. They can agree to reduced city payments to the union welfare funds, and rescind part of the wage increases several of them won only months ago. The city couldn't afford those increases in the first place, and now it could dearly use some of that money to soften the impact of its austere budget.
Union concessions in the form of furloughs or wage deferrals, like those already negotiated with the United Federation of Teachers, are not the sole answer to the city's economic problems. But they can save the jobs of thousands of men and women instead of forcing layoffs that worsen the city's economy and deprive all citizens of services.
Moreover, labor's cooperation would pave the way for the Municipal Assistance Corporation to help the city with $1 billion through debt refinancing over four years. This is money the M.A.C. board and its chairman, Felix Rohatyn, will not make available unless confident the city will invest it in vital services and not give all of it to the unions.
M.A.C. wants to see a long-term restructuring of city government that would produce a leaner, more efficient, and therefore less costly work force. Productivity savings, work rule changes and a gradual shrinking of the work force -- instead of destructive layoffs all at once -- are crucial.
New York City's fiscal crisis is not labor's doing. But the municipal unions are now in a position to repeat their statesmanlike role during the last fiscal crisis by again recognizing that their fate and the city's are one.

HEADLINE: Much Too Soon to End South Africa Sanctions;
Reinvestment

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Even if the United States lifts South Africa sanctions, the economic gloom in South Africa will not correspondingly be lifted (news article, June 18). 
 The adverse effects of sanctions should compel Congress to adopt "reverse sanctions." Our new policy toward South Africa should be designed to enhance South Africa's Western-style capitalism, which in turn will insure the success of whatever new political system develops.
We should turn the sanctions legislation upside down. Why not reduce taxes, tariffs and quotas on banned South African products and legislate tax and other incentives for Americans to do business with South Africa? The unemployment rate in South Africa would go down, the economy would become more robust, and other African states would benefit.
We must bond ourselves to an economically strong, post-apartheid evolving democracy in South Africa and help develop a multiracial middle class there. However, business executives will not risk the boycotts and adverse publicity of years past unless they have assurances from South Africa that their investments will not be expropriated and assurances from our Government that sanctions will not be renewed.
Merely ending sanctions is not enough. Clear and irrevocable signals from our Government affirmatively encouraging our return to South Africa are needed.
Those most vocal in favor of sanctions should consider raising their voices loudest in support of reverse sanctions.
 
STEPHEN I. SILLER
New York, June 19, 1991

HEADLINE: Oil Drilling Weighed In Peru Nature Area

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
AN American oil company's plan to drill for oil in Peru's largest Amazon nature reserve is presenting this impoverished country with a cruel choice.
On one hand, oil revenues are desperately needed to revive an economy that shrank 30 percent in the last three years. With proven oil reserves down to about one-third the level of a decade ago, Peru this year became a net oil importer. 
 "Let's ask, 'What is good for the people of Peru?' " said Al Curry, operations manager for Texas Crude Oil Inc., the company that plans to produce oil in the Pacaya-Samiria reserve. "This goes above and beyond the right of someone in California, New York or Lima to say, 'Let's preserve the trees.' "
On the other hand, the Amazon reserve is a critical habitat for gray and pink river dolphins, black and speckled caiman, Amazonian manatees, giant South American river turtles and saddleback tamarins. A largely pristine stretch of rain forest the size of Massachusetts, the Pacaya-Samiria reserve contains more than 150 oxbow lakes and a wide variety of riverine forests.
"Because this is a flood zone with very slow-moving waters, an oil spill would cause a very serious pollution problem," said Antonio Brack, a Peruvian biologist with Asociacion Amazonia, a private group here that opposes the oil contract.
In April, Peru's official gazette published an executive decree granting Texas Crude exploration rights to a 2.4-million-acre tract in Peru's northern Amazon. Almost 75 percent of the exploration block is inside the Pacaya-Samiria, one of two reserves in Peru's Amazon.
 
Opponents Rally
 But recently Peruvians have rallied to urge Peru's state company, Petroperu, not to sign the contract. Last month, a protest strike supported by the regional government shut down Iquitos, the largest city in Peru's Amazon, for one day.
Opponents say the contract violates an environmental code signed into law last September by President Alberto Fujimori. Under this code, it is illegal to explore or to extract nonrenewable natural resources in natural reserves.
Noting that only 6 percent of Peru's 286,000-square-mile Amazon region is protected in parks, Mr. Brack said: "We are not against development. We conservationists only ask, 'Why do they have to explore in a reserve?' "
Demonstrating a growing cooperation between South American and North American environmental groups, an international coalition is now putting pressure on the Texas oil company.
In the first week of May, Rainforest Action Network, a group based in San Francisco, sent an "Action Alert" to 36,000 people on its mailing list. Asserting that American oil companies "can operate in the Amazon with almost none of the environmental controls imposed on them in the United States," the network calls for a letter-writing campaign against the contract. The alert suggests including the statement, "I am sure that Texas Crude does not want to develop a reputation as a company that destroys rain forests."
 
More Contracts, More Scrutiny
 Mr. Curry of Texas Crude rejected such criticism. "We think we are on solid legal ground," he said in a telephone interview from Houston. "We have worked around the world in some of the most environmentally sensitive areas, none the least of which is California. Contracts in Peru have requirements for environmental impact statements. They have set certain guidelines that are not going to allow people to rape and pillage the land."
Environmental scrutiny in increasing as more and more oil companies penetrate the Amazon.
In mid-May an international consortium announced the discovery of a one-billion-to-two-billion-barrel field in Colombia's Amazon. In early June, Bolivia signed a contract with an international consortium to explore and exploit a 5,700-square-mile tract of the Bolivian Amazon. Also in June, Petroperu started sending to 180 foreign companies maps and technical information on oil exploration areas in the Peruvian Amazon.
Last year Occidental Petroleum dropped talks with Petroperu after the discovering that the block under consideration was in Manu National Park, Peru's other Amazon reserve. "Once we checked it out and found out where the block was, we told them we were not interested," Philip Zander, an Occidental spokesman, said in a telephone interview.
To spotlight pollution caused by careless oil-drilling practices in the Amazon, the Natural Resources Defense Council in February published "Amazon Crude," a 130-page study of oil production in Ecuador's jungle.
 
Keeping Settlers Out
 A northern neighbor of Peru, Ecuador relies on oil exports for half of its foreign exchange and is actively seeking foreign investment to maintain oil production. In April, Donald Castillo, Ecuador's Energy Minister, said he expected to sign Amazon exploration contracts with three foreign companies.
"As a result of the Persian Gulf war, oil companies are going to be intensifying their search for oil in other parts of the world," predicted S. Jacob Scherr, a defense council lawyer who worked on the study. "The last frontier is the tropical forest."
Environmentalists fear that oil exploration will involve roads, opening protected areas to the slash-and-burn farming techniques of settlers.
On Thursday, an environmental group in Quito, Acion Ecologica, led demonstrations outside local offices of Texaco , Conoco and British Gas to protest drilling plans in the Amazon.
Largely because of this intense attention, Conoco Ecuador Ltda., a subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, has drawn up an elaborate program to minimize impact of oil production in the Huaoroni Indigenous Reserve and in the Yasuni National Park, Ecuador's largest park.
"Not one inch of the access road will be open to colonists," Edward J. Davies, president of Conoco Ecuador, said of a 90-mile road that the oil company plans to build into the fields.
 
Enter U.S. Environmentalists
 Even before the Texas Crude contract was announced, the Nature Conservancy, of Arlington, Va., made the Pacaya-Samiria reserve part of its "Parks in Peril" program.
Illustrative of growing efforts of United States environmental groups to make functioning parks out of Latin America's "paper parks," the Nature Conservancy plans next year to start training rangers and to provide boats, radios and control posts. Funds are to come from a $100,000 grant from the United States Agency for International Development and from a matching grant by the private conservation group.
Adding urgency to the effort is the desperate poverty in Peru's Amazon. This poverty was highlighted recently by two disasters. Since March, a cholera epidemic has preyed on the poor hygiene of slum dwellers in Iquitos, killing about 300. And in early May, an overloaded river ferry smashed into an empty Petroperu oil tanker, killing about 150 passengers.
Texas Crude maintains that the greatest economic aid to the Amazon would come from oil production. Mr. Curry noted that in the last decade only one foreign oil company, Mobil Oil, signed an exploration contract with Petroperu.
Last December, Maoists guerrillas attacked Mobil's exploration base in the Amazon, 250 miles southwest of where Texas Crude plans to work. The guerrillas, from the Shining Path movement, killed two people and destroyed millions of dollars worth of computers and communications systems. Mobil has returned and expects to drill its first exploratory wells in November.
But now the Shining Path guerrilla movement has turned its wrath on Texas Crude. Two weeks ago, the movement's newspaper, El Diario, threatened to apply "popular justice" against "the imperialists and their businesses like Texas Crude."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 4, 1991, Thursday

An article and a picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday about oil exploration in a nature reserve in Peru misidentified an animal species in the reserve. It is a spectacled caiman, not a speckled caiman.

HEADLINE: What Price Yugoslavia?

BYLINE: By Michael Scammell; Michael Scammell, professor of Russian literature at Cornell, is a frequent visitor to Yugoslavia.

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y.

 BODY:
How is it that whenever some small European nation seeks to establish freedom, democracy and independence for itself, the U.S. invariably backs away from these principles and turns a blind eye to its suppression by force? So Poland in 1953, Hungary in 1956, Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Poland again in 1980. The Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have hardly fared any better, and now it seems to be the turn of Croatia and Slovenia.
U.S. opposition to their aspirations is said to be motivated by a need to preserve Yugoslavia's "unity and territorial integrity." Secretary of State James Baker says he is convinced that "separation will lead to violence," and that we "will not reward unilateral actions." 
 The reasoning seems to be that if Slovenia and Croatia persist with their plans for more independence, the federal authorities in Yugoslavia will be justified in unleashing the army again, as they did this weekend. Dark hints are also being dropped about Greek and Bulgarian designs on Macedonia, Albanian claims on Kosovo and even Italian claims on Istria, while U.S. statesmen are fond of recalling, with divine irrelevance, that "World War I began in the Balkans."
These arguments are bogus. Talk of preserving the territorial integrity of Yugoslavia would make some sense if the country were threatened with invasion, which seemed to be the case after the break with the Soviets in 1948. But that threat has disappeared. As for Balkan irredentism, more or less democratic revolutions have taken place in every one of Yugoslavia's formerly Communist neighbors.
These small states, all with shattered economies and huge social problems, have neither the means nor the will for expansion or conquest. If Greece and Italy actually presented a problem, which is doubtful, they could easily be restrained through their membership in the European Community.
The situation in Yugoslavia offers a rare opportunity for the U.S. and the European Community to bring about constructive change. It is true that the Serbian Government is wedded to violence, as its brutal suppression of Albanians in Kosovo demonstrated. It has also manipulated the federal presidency to suit its own ends and is clearly behind the federal army's decision to invade Slovenia. But the present U.S. policy of insisting on federal unity at any price and rigidly refusing even to consider Slovenian and Croatian demands constitutes a submission to Serbian blackmail.
While the Soviet Union was in its expansionist phase, U.S. passivity toward Eastern Europe was understandable, if not forgivable. But in the Balkans, the Soviet Union is no longer a player, and Serbian power cannot be compared to that of the Soviets. The Serbian economy, also in ruins, depends on Western credits. In fact, Serbia is an anachronism -- an authoritarian island in a sea of nascent democracies.
All this presents the U.S. with a clear choice. We ought to tell the Yugoslav republics that we support efforts to introduce political pluralism, a market economy and legal safeguards for minorities. Not just in words but in deed. This would mean support for Slovenia and Croatia, where these principles are observed far more than in the rest of Yugoslavia, and unequivocal opposition to the violence, corruption and repression on the old Communist model, even if it is done in the name of a unitary state.
We can do this by placing conditions on further economic aid to Yugoslavia. The European Community made a start on Sunday by threatening to suspend up to $1 billion in aid unless the present hostilities ceased. But the U.S. can go further and exert greater leverage by discriminating between republics that honor democratic principles and those that don't.
Paradoxically, such a policy would be far more likely to preserve Yugoslavia in its present form than tacit support for armed force and invasion. The Slovenians and Croatians have bent over backward to avoid proclaiming outright independence, and even now are stopping short of secession. What they need is reasonable assurance that they can progress at least in step with the other countries of Eastern Europe. Strong U.S. support for a Yugoslavia in which democratic freedoms are prized above enforced unity would bring them back to the negotiating table.
Strong democratic forces have been gathering in Serbia, too, and are waiting in the wings for the fever to pass. We can either prolong their agony, and that of all the Yugoslav peoples, by encouraging violence, or we can shorten it by exerting pressure in the right places. Let's hope that we get it right this time.

HEADLINE: J. Clark Merritt; Lawyer, 87

 BODY:
J. Clark Merritt, a lawyer, died on June 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.
Mr. Merritt, a native of Bethany Center, N.Y., was a lawyer in Manhattan for many years and specialized in workmen's compensation cases. He retired in the late 1980's. 
 He was a graduate of the Rochester Business Institute and was manager of its Batavia branch from 1928 to 1931. In 1934, he received a B.S. degree from New York University and later received his law degree from Brooklyn Law School. Before entering private practice, he taught economics at Great Neck High School on Long Island.
Mr. Merritt is survived by a sister, Lillian Babbage of Batavia, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
AIDS Testing Doesn't Pay

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THIRTY-THREE state legislatures have decided it is bad social policy to permit discrimination against workers with the AIDS virus. Now, two economists at Columbia University have found that AIDS testing, the keystone to discrimination, is also bad business policy. The costs of screening prospective employees, say David Bloom and Sherry Glied, far exceed the likely savings on insurance.
Their research results, published last week in Science magazine, should be welcome news to people with a healthy respect for the power of the profit motive: If testing did indeed pay, it would put the interests of corporate America in direct conflict with those of society. 
 The numbers also suggest that involuntary screening for genetic diseases is likely to remain a hypothetical threat for years to come. Genetic screens, Ms. Glied notes, are more expensive than tests for the AIDS virus, while the potential rewards to employers are much smaller because the identifiable diseases are less common.
But the analysis leaves moral loose ends. While most employers apparently do not stand to gain from AIDS testing, they may still have an incentive to avoid hiring workers in high-risk groups. Thus the inability to test for the virus could increase discrimination against male workers who are (or might be) gay.
It is worth remembering, too, that employers worried about AIDS costs retain the option of paring the insurance of all employees against chronic illnesses. The only certain way to eliminate the incentives of companies to favor healthier workers is to get them out of the business of health insurance.
In a city with high medical costs like New York, the typical large company offering generous insurance benefits must pay out an extra $115,000 to cover the expenses of treating AIDS. Premature death reduces a company's pension liability. Moreover, just one-third of employees who test positive for the virus can be expected to come down with a serious illness during their tenure with the company.
But there is no way this calculus can be reworked to avoid an unpleasant truth: On average, it would save a large employer in a high-cost city about $32,000 to deny work to an HIV-positive job applicant. Even a small company with less comprehensive insurance coverage that is in a city with lower treatment costs can expect to save several thousand dollars just by saying no to HIV-positive applicants.
The redeeming catch, note Mr. Bloom and Ms. Glied, is that AIDS screening is expensive and few testing programs are likely to unearth a single worker who tests positive. For a small employer drawing from the same low-risk population pool that donates blood to the Red Cross, the typical cost of identifying one HIV-positive applicant would exceed $300,000.
The researchers concede that testing costs for large employers are lower, and that some may draw the bulk of their workers from groups with a higher than average incidence of the virus. But they argue that only a small minority of companies -- the fashion and entertainment industries, perhaps -- could make a case for mass screening.
The states with the highest concentrations of AIDS cases already bar discrimination against carriers of the virus. And last year Congress passed legislation prohibiting any form of medical screening by companies with more than 15 employees after July 1994. But this will not necessarily stop -- indeed, it may encourage -- employers to discriminate against workers whom they guess are at risk.
Happily, Mr. Bloom and Ms. Glied believe that would rarely be rational: The percentage of, say, never-married men over the age of 30 who are HIV-positive is very small. Thus an employer who burns time and money turning down an otherwise satisfactory job applicant on such crude demographic criteria is probably a dumb employer.
But there are dumb employers. And in any event, the AIDS-testing ban certainly could be felt in perverse ways, increasing the impulse to discriminate against openly gay males on the chance they might carry the virus.
Perhaps a more significant hazard in barring testing for AIDS (or any other expensive-to-treat disease) is that it reduces the incentive of employers to provide comprehensive health benefits. Some may drop insurance coverage altogether. More insidiously they may cap benefits, covering workers for the odd $12,000 appendectomy but leaving them vulnerable to catastrophically expensive illnesses.
The testing question is thus a tiny piece in the exasperatingly complex health insurance puzzle. Most Americans depend on their employers for insurance, and most employers have never doubted the logic of providing it. But with premiums representing an ever growing share of labor costs and screening soon to be barred by law, prospective medical bills are bound to affect decisions about who is hired and who is insured.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Handleman Deal Draws Praise

BYLINE: By Doron P. Levin

 BODY:
WHEN a movie becomes a successful home video or when Michael Jackson releases a hit recording there is rejoicing not just in Hollywood, but in Troy, Mich., home of the Handleman Corporation.
Handleman stocks videos, CD's, cassettes, computer software and other entertainment items on the shelves of mass merchandisers like K Mart and Wal-Mart. While most video fans are renters, the market for purchased videos is sizable and growing. 
 On June 25, Handleman, the entertainment industry's leading "rack jobber," said it had agreed in principle to buy the assets of Lieberman Enterprises Inc., a leading competitor. Lieberman is a subsidiary of Live Entertainment Inc. and is based in Bloomington, Minn. Carolco Pictures Inc. owns 54 percent of Live Entertainment. Both companies are based in Los Angeles.
Wall Street generally has applauded the acquisition, in the belief that antitrust regulators will approve the deal and that the reduced competition will help Handleman improve earnings.
Moreover, the sale should improve Live Entertainment's prospects, since the Lieberman division lost more than $12 million in its latest fiscal year. This also might mean a more expensive price tag for Carolco if it buys the shares of Live Entertainment it does not own.
Handleman's stock closed at $14 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, up from $12 on June 6, before the announcement that it was negotiating with Live Entertainment.
But in the longer term there may be dark clouds looming before Handleman. A rack jobber owns the merchandise, stocks store shelves, and keeps track of what's hot and what's not, acting as a distributor for the entertainment industry. But some retailers, notably Wal-Mart, are exploring the possibility of removing the extra layer of expense by buying or setting up rack-jobbing operations of their own. Last year, for example, Wal-Mart bought Western Merchandiser, another rack jobber.
The retailing industry's problems have had an impact on rack jobbers. For example, when Hills Department Stores filed for bankruptcy protection in February, Handleman was listed as the largest unsecured merchandise creditor, with accounts receivable of $7.1 million.
Michael Hamilton, a financial analyst with the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis, thinks the $100 million price is not much to pay for Lieberman's sales, since the sum includes inventory and fixtures. "This will help Handleman spread its fixed costs over a greater base," he said.
Lisbeth Barron, an analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company in New York, said, "Handleman paid a lot for Lieberman but it was a great acquisition." Warburg valued Lieberman at $88 million. Ms. Barron noted, however, that the acquisition would not include some small Lieberman units worth $10 million to $15 million.
But Warburg is putting a "hold" rather than a "buy" recommendation on Handleman because of concerns about retailing and entertainment, Ms. Barron said. "The music business in particular is so dependent on hits that there are dry spells," she said.
Louis A. Kircos, Handleman's senior vice president, declined to be interviewed because he was too busy with the details of the acquisition, an assistant said. It is understood that the company recently told analysts that it expected a number of big music and video hits in the coming year. It mentioned the artists Vanilla Ice, Michael Jackson, Aretha Franklin and Bob Seger, and the movies "Home Alone" and an animated version of "Robin Hood."
Handleman's 1991 fourth quarter, ended April 27, showed a 12 percent fall in sales and flat earnings. Weak retail sales because of the recession were one reason for the mediocre showing, but the company also complained that the quarter lacked "mega-hit videos" comparable to last year's "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade," "Honey I Shrunk the Kids," and "Lethal Weapons II."
David Katz, chief investment officer for Matrix Asset Management in New York, has owned about 100,000 of Handleman's 32 million shares outstanding for the last year and thinks the stock should reach the $19 to $20 level in the next year to 18 months.
Matrix's investment philosophy is to buy stocks with strong balance sheets that are selling at a one-third discount to what Matrix considers fair market value -- and then sell at that value. Using this method, Matrix bought Handleman after the stock market crash of 1987 and sold it six months later at a 60 percent profit. Mr. Katz estimates that Handleman is now worth $19 to $20 a share, which is why his company bought at $12.
"Basically they were able to buy a 25 percent to 30 percent increase in sales for a good price, and that makes them a stronger player," Mr. Katz said. "They won't hurt the balance sheet doing it either." Furthermore, he does not think that K Mart is going to buy its own rack jobber. "They've already got a lot on their plate revamping their stores," he said.

HEADLINE: Labor Dept. Outlines Job Skills Students Will Need in Future

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
As part of the Bush Administration's effort to promote education as a Republican initiative, Labor Secretary Lynn Martin today made public a report outlining what American students must learn in school to compete in the workplace of the future.
The report, "What Work Requires of Schools: A SCANS Report for America 2000," defines the skills young people must have "to hold a decent job and earn a decent living." 
 In an interview today, Ms. Martin said, "More than half of young people leaving high school won't have the knowledge or foundation required" to achieve either goal. Some 70 percent of students do not go on to college, she added, but enter the workforce.
The report also says that only with a skilled labor force can the United States be economically competitive in the global marketplace.
"Employers and educators must come together in a marriage of necessity if our youngsters are to be prepared for meeting the challenges of securing rewarding and well-paid work," Ms. Martin said. "The fact is the world's technological explosion has caught many of our students by surprise."
The report, the result of a year's work by the 31-member Secretary's Commission on Achieving Necessary Skills, is similar to one issued by the National Assessment of Education Progress, a federally supported testing group, and carries no legal obligation to be acted on. But the commission's document is based on interviews with employers, managers and workers, who described in detail the skills needed to perform their jobs.
Besides reading, writing and mathematics, the report outlines five areas of competency for students: resources, information, interpersonal abilities, social and organizational systems, and technology.
Resource competency, for example, involves knowing how to allocate time, money, materials and staff. Interpersonal abilities involves learning how to work on teams, teach others and negotiate.
 
No New Funds Recommended
 The report encourages parents, businesses and schools to give as much importance to the learning of these skills as is currently given to the acquisition of basic reading, writing and mathematics.
But schools would not be required to change their curriculums. Rather, Ms. Martin said, such decisions should be left to the local level. The commission did not recommend any new expenditures for the program.
William E. Brock, chairman of the commission and a former Labor Secretary, said the report outlines the "practical steps we need to take to achieve the National Education Goals," a reference to the goals for the year 2000 that President Bush and the nation's Governors agreed on in 1989. In April 1990, Elizabeth Dole, who was the Labor Secretary at that time, established the commission and charged it with developing a test to determine whether 16-year-olds had the appropriate skills to enter the work force.
Mr. Brock said that instead of using testing, students could be awarded "merit badges" at each stage of competency.
Ms. Martin, a former high school teacher and former Representative from Illinois, said that she was taking the program to the Labor Department's 10 regional offices so that it could be made available to state and local officials, to business executives and educators as well.
She noted that the Indiana would be using the report's five competency areas in a program, scheduled to begin next week, in which high school students survey employers about job skills and report back to junior high school students.
Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, with 750,000 members, praised the commission findings, but said that making changes in education requires "the money to implement it."
William Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, also praised the report, saying, "The realities of international business competition underline the need for highly skilled workers who have abilities well beyond the three R's."

HEADLINE: Sequent Computer Expects Loss in the Second Quarter

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2

 BODY:
Sequent Computer Systems Inc. said today that it would report a loss for the second quarter, citing the combined effect of the recession and a significant decline in orders from original equipment manufacturers -- companies that resell other manufacturers' machines under their own names.
Sequent's largest original equipment customer, the Unisys Corporation, has had severe financial problems because of the recession, which has limited its ability to resell Sequent computers. 
 Sequent said it would restructure to focus on direct sales. The company, based in Beaverton, Ore., added that it would maintain its original equipment manufacturers business with Unisys but would not initiate any new original equipment business.
Sequent's shares closed today at $9.75, down $2, in over-the-counter trading.
"While our primary business of selling computers directly to end-user commercial customers continues to grow significantly, the recession gripping this industry is not allowing us to grow fast enough to offset the decline in our sales to O.E.M. customers," said Scott Gibson, Sequent's president and co-chief executive.
Sequent said it expected revenues of $49 million to $51 million, down from $58.2 million in the second quarter of last year. It said it expected a loss substantially greater than the $7 million loss it had in the first quarter. In the 1990's second quarter, Sequent earned $5.7 million, or 24 cents a share.
Sequent said it planned significant cost-cutting measures, including a 7 to 9 percent reduction in its work force by July 15. The company will also restrict capital purchases, reduce travel costs and freeze salaries. The company said it expected these measures to be temporary.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Soars Against Mark; Level Highest in 20 Months

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed yesterday at its highest level against the German mark in 20 months, pushed up by turmoil in Yugoslavia and data indicating strength in the United States economy.
The dollar closed at 1.8345 marks, up from Monday's 1.8305 marks, but still shy of the 1.8415-mark close reached Nov. 17, 1989. 
 The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen, closng at 138.75 Japanese yen, up from 138.42 on Monday.
"It looks like the market likes the upside" for the dollar, said Frank Pusateri, vice president at the First National Bank of Boston.
Gold prices ended the day lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York gold closed at $367.90 an ounce, down 30 cents.
At least 10 Yugoslav soldiers were killed in fighting with Slovenian nationalists yesterday, as another fragile truce collapsed between the federal Government and the breakaway republic. Yugoslav warplanes bombed Slovenian fighters, after they fired on federal tanks.
"The situation has gotten quite a bit out of hand," said Belal Khan, corporate dealer for Fuji Bank. Because of Yugoslavia's proximity to Germany, the mark suffers from the unrest, traders said.
The dollar was also helped by a Commerce Department report that factory orders rose 2.9 percent in May. The increase was the largest since March 1990 and higher than economists had forecast.
Higher factory orders were seen as a sign of a rebounding economy, making the dollar more attractive.
The mark was also hampered by continued worries over Germany's investment rules. Although the German Government has said it is not considering reintroducing a withholding tax on investment earnings, it is considering a relaxation of bank secrecy rules to combat tax evasion.
Bankers said such a move could prompt capital flight. Investors are staying out of marks while they wait for a clearer idea of what the German Government will do.
The British pound closed at $1.6030, down from $1.6070 Monday. The dollar ended at 1.5825 Swiss francs, up from 1.5685, and, against the Canadian currency, at 1.1425 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1430 on Monday. Against the French franc, the dollar closed at 6.2125 francs, up from 6.1985 on Monday.

HEADLINE: American Air Pessimistic

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, July 2

 BODY:
American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said today that the recession and the Persian Gulf war had lowered air traffic and created an unsatisfactory second quarter.
If American's problems are mirrored by the industry, it would be the third straight quarter that weak traffic, higher fuel costs and the recession severely hurt airline earnings. 
 The AMR Corporation, American's parent, lost $195.6 million in the first quarter of the year and $215.1 million in the fourth quarter of last year.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, AMR's shares fell 87.5 cents, closing at $61.875.
Since late last year, four United States carriers have sought bankruptcy protection, seeking time to reorganize and pay their debts while they keep flying. They are Midway Airlines Inc., Pan American World Airways Inc., America West Airlines Inc. and Continental Airlines Inc.
Robert L. Crandall, chairman of AMR, said the economic downturn and effects of the war had severely reduced demand for air travel. "That is why we have lost substantial amounts of money in each of the previous two quarters and why the second quarter will not be a very satisfactory financial period for us, either," he added.
But Mr. Crandall, who made his remarks after American began its new service to London's Heathrow Airport, gave no specific projection of the company's second-quarter results.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed, With Dow Rising by 14.31

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
After Monday's big run-up, stock prices turned mixed yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 14.31, to 2,972.72. and the rest of the market giving ground.
Walt Disney and Alcoa accounted for almost 90 percent of the Dow's gain. 
 Activity was sluggish, with 157.3 million shares traded, down from 167.5 million on Monday.
The level of trading is particularly weak because it covers not just the normal trading day between 9:30 A.M. and 4 P.M. but also after-hours dealings between 4:15 and 5:15 P.M. in effect since June 13.
Even program trading subsided. Birinyi Associates, which monitors such activity, said it spotted only one 13-minute selling wave starting at 10:30 and that it lopped less than 3 points off the Dow.
Disney jumped 5 1/8, to 118 7/8, while Alcoa rose 1 7/8, to 68 5/8, both in heavy trading.
While there did not appear to be any news to account for the Alcoa rise, Alan S. Gould, entertainment analyst for Dean Witter Reynolds, recommended Disney yesterday after recommending it last week. He said it had had strong advance hotel reservations at Walt Disney World near Orlando, Fla.
Alan Kassan, media analyst for Morgan Stanley, said Disney's attendance had been "a little better" since the opening of its 3-D Muppet movie attraction at its Florida studio theme park. Moreover, he said, "its cold stretch in the movie business seems to have come to an end with "What About Bob?" and "Rocketeer," new movies that he said had "done reasonably well."
 
Mending of Economy Seen
 New data released yesterday showed that the economy was mending steadily but Wall Street seemingly paid little attention to the news.
Factory orders rose 2.9 percent in May for the biggest gain in over a year, while consumer confidence, as measured by the University of Michigan, rose last month to the highest point since the Persian Gulf war.
Traders, however, argued that the market had already had plenty of evidence that things were getting better.
"The market," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Brothers, "has had enough statistics showing the economy's turning upward; now it wants earnings."
"It believes the economy is going to improve," he said. "This is up and that's up. It's in the market; it no longer impresses the market. The market wants to see better earnings in the third and fourth quarters. And based on what it sees in the second quarter coming out now, it'll get a better feel on what's coming in the third and fourth quarter. So the market's on hold for the moment."
Asked why the Dow industrials were up and the rest of the market was down, the Shearson executive said that traders had become very selective in their buying, such as the concentration yesterday on Alcoa and Disney.
He argued that in a long market rise such as this one institutional buying tended to narrow, that is, "they go after fewer stocks and get more selective as the market rises or, as now, plateaus on top of a big rise."
The market, he said, "is trying to figure whether we go down on the other side of the plateau or go to a higher plateau."
Except for a bit of a decline at the start of trading yesterday, the blue chips tended to move ahead for most of the day. At 10:30, in spite of professional program selling, the Dow advanced a bit, fell a bit and zigzagged its way upward for the rest of the session.
In a weak insurance group, Conseco, the life insurer, rose 1 5/8, to 37 1/4. It split the stock 2 for 1 payable July 1.
Tenneco slid 4 3/8, to 35 1/2, on 1.9 million shares after Paul Milbauer of C. J. Lawrence dropped his "buy/ hold" rating on the oil company and cut his earnings estimate. Other oil stocks weakened, with two Dow stocks, Chevron and Exxon down, respectively, 1/2, to 71 1/8, and 1 1/8, to 58 3/4.
A. T. & T. led the New York Stock Exchange's active list, rising 5/8, to 39 1/4, on 2.2 million shares after Jack Grubman of Paine Webber recommended it. He pointed to strong second-quarter forecasts and expectations that it would be able to work out an accounting problem in its takeover of NCR.
Technology stocks had a bad day, with the Pacific Stock Exchange's high-tech index down slightly. Intel, the semiconductor producer, topped the Nasdaq active list, dropping 2 5/8, to 42 7/8, with 9.1 million shares changing hands. Drew D. Peck, semiconductor analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, cut his rating on Intel from moderately attractive to netural. Reuters said he had found that demand for its 386 chip had dropped "rather sharply."
I.B.M. rose 3/4, to 99 1/8, and Compaq Computer 1 1/8, to 32 1/2, but Microsoft fell 3 1/4, to 68 1/8.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
More optimistic news about the economy had only marginal impact on the credit markets yesterday, where prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in thin trading.
A sharp increase in factory orders in May, the largest monthly rise in more than a year, and an improvement in the consumer confidence survey conducted by the University of Michigan were both seen as signs that the economy is continuing to improve. 
William Melton, vice president and chief economist at IDS Financial Services Inc. in Minneapolis, said the rise in orders and shipments, the second straight monthly increase, "tell you about as loud and clear as they can that the production process is picking up."
The pickup in orders, however, will not necessarily produce a big rise in inventories, Mr. Melton added. The fact that orders and shipments have moved together for the last several months reflects the increasingly widespread use by business of "just in time" delivery methods.
"For a long time a lot of people have regarded factory orders as a leading indicator, but that is less and less true," he said.
"Because orders and shipments increasingly move in concert, you are not likely to get a big bulge in inventories as you have at the beginning of previous recoveries. In the past, the rebound in inventories has accounted for between one-quarter and one-third of total output. This time it will be more like 10 percent."
Yesterday's reports came on the heels of the release Monday of a survey from the nation's purchasing managers indicating that activity in the manufacturing sector was much improved during June.
"We have gotten a lot of very strong economic data over the last couple of days, but right now the market is paralyzed," one government bond trader said.
"The fundamental news has been a negative, but right now are not many securities with maturities of more than five years to trade. That lack of supply is allowing prices to stay higher than they otherwise would be."
Traders said the stronger than expected reports have given market participants little choice but to position themselves very conservatively in advance of the release Friday of June employment data.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 21/32 late yesterday, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.43 percent, the same level as late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 10/32, down 1/32, to yield 8.13 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 1/32, down 2/32, to yield 6.98 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were narrowly mixed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.55 percent late yesterday, down two basis points, or two one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 5.70 percent.
An announcement that the New Jersey Turnpike Authority intends to restructure more than $2 billion worth of outstanding debt obligations pushed up bids for some turnpike bonds by around 1/2 point in the secondary market for tax-exempt municpal securities.
The announcement did not come as a surprise, because the authority has made no secret of its desire to refund this debt, much of which was issued in 1984 and 1985. Details about the timing of the refinancing remain to be worked out.
Away from turnpike issues, municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted securities rose by about 1/8 point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most actively traded issues were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: Oil Exporters and Users Agree to Continue 'Dialogue'

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, July 2

 BODY:
Twenty-five oil-producing and consuming countries ended a two-day conference here today with an agreement to continue "a dialogue" that the United States has steadfastly opposed.
Six members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, including major producers like Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Iran, sent their oil ministers to the conference, called the Ministerial Seminar for Oil-Producing and Consuming Countries. 
 Energy and industry ministers from France, Norway, Britain and Germany also attended what is considered to be the first such contact since the "North-South dialogue" of the mid-1970's ended in failure, as the West resisted demands then from poor and socialist countries to share its wealth and technological advances with them.
 
'Informal, Frank and Direct'
 "It was informal, frank and direct," said Roland Dumas, the French Foreign Minister, at a news conference at the end of the meeting. France and Venezuela were the leading coordinators of the conference.
Many conferees said they had agreed to hold another meeting that would be sponsored jointly by Norway and Egypt and would be held in Oslo. No date was set for that conference.
The United States had steadfastly refused to endorse the idea of any dialogue between oil producers and oil consumers, asserting that it was totally opposed to any interference in the free-market mechanisms of the world's crude oil markets.
The United States agreed after the personal intervention of France's President, Francois Mitterrand, to send an "observer" to the meeting and insisted, at the end of the meeting, on stressing that it participated only as an observer.
 
Need for Stability Seen
 "The problem is that there is not now, and there was never, a free oil market," said Algeria's Energy Minister, Nordine Ait-Laoussine. "There has always been interference of one sort or another in the oil markets. What we advocate is stability. We can agree on at least that which is good for both consumers and producers so that we can do our economic planning on a sound basis."
Oil experts at the meeting said they agreed with the statement made at the end of the conference by Mr. Dumas, the French Foreign Minister, that "we are witnessing the birth of a tradition."
The desire to have a broad agreement to regulate oil markets is strongly supported within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, whose 13 members have suffered over the last few years from sudden and steep falls in oil prices.
 
Actions Taken by Consumers
 These falls were largely because of action taken by consuming countries in energy savings and seeking alternative sources to oil as an energy source and OPEC is now of a mind to reach a broad agreement with consumers about a general range of prices, something that the United States continues to resist fiercely.
Taking American concerns into consideration, Mr. Dumas said the dialogue did not mean that any of the industrialized countries at the conference endorsed any interference with free-market mechanisms.
Armando Duran, Venezuela's Foreign Minister, strongly endorsed the view that some interference in the market was possible without harming free-market mechanisms. "It is possible, and right, to insure perfect markets working by making them more transparent," he said.
OPEC officials said that what they were seeking was not an agreement on a specific price of oil but a control to be exercised on the free-wheeling energy markets of the West, where oil is traded without physical movements from one location to another.

HEADLINE: Yields Are Slightly Lower On Bank Funds and C.D.'s

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were down slightly for the week ended yesterday.
According to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest-rate publication, more savings institutions raised rates last week than in the previous few weeks. 
 At the Treasury Department's weekly auction held on Monday, average discount rates increased for the second consecutive auction to their highest levels since the beginning of June. The three-month bill rose a basis point, to 5.59 percent, with the six-month bill up 13 basis points, to 5.71 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Forecast on C.D. Yields
 Analysts at The Bank Rate Monitor said investors could expect further declines in short-term yields on certificates of deposit, with some rise in long-term accounts. A week ago the average annual yield on a two-and-a-half-year certificate rose by as much as 27 basis points, to 8.36 percent, at the Carver Federal Savings Bank in New York. The analysts said investors should not be taken in by some higher numbers and should refrain from buying a long-term C.D. too early, since odds favored a slow upward movement in rates later this month.
The analysts suggested a more prudent approach by savers would perhaps be to open a C.D. with a maturity of one year or less and wait for the numbers to go up.
The largest yield changes in New York-area banks this week were found at the Dollar Dry Dock Bank of New York, which cut the yield on its money market account by 26 basis points, to 5.39 percent, and the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, which reduced its three-month certificiate of deposit by 11 basis points, to 5.53 percent. People's Bank of Connecticut also lowered the yield on its six-month certificate by 11 basis points, to 5.60 percent.
 
Yields at Commercial Banks
 Among commercial banks, the average money-market yield rose 5 basis points, to 5.19 percent, while three-month certificates fell 2 basis points on average, to 5.46 percent, and six-month maturities fell a basis point, to 5.64 percent.
Depositors at savings institutions saw the average yield on a money-market account fall 2 basis points, to 5.54 percent, and on a three-month certificate 3 basis points, to 5.75 percent. Six-month maturities on average were off only a basis point, to 6 percent.
By comparison, at 20 large banks around the country, all of which are outside the New York market, the average money market yield fell by a basis point, to 5.24 percent, with no change in the average yield of a six-month certificate, at 5.74 percent.

HEADLINE: Eating Well

BYLINE: By Marian Burros

 BODY:
NOW that we have all learned how to pronounce salmonella (though we haven't learned what to do about it), it is time to add another kind of bacteria to our lexicon: campylobacter (that's CAM-pill-o-back-ter). As with salmonella, if you swallow enough of it, you can get very, very sick.
Dr. Mitchell Cohen, director of the division of bacterial and mycotic diseases at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, estimates that 30 to 70 percent of the poultry in this country is infected with campylobacter. 
 "Of the top four important enteric diseases -- salmonella, listera, e. coli 015787 and campylobacter," Dr. Cohen said, "I would list campylobacter as No. 4. But it probably causes more cases of disease than any of the other three. I think it's less serious than salmonella, and salmonella would probably have a higher death rate."
The C.D.C. estimate that there are two million cases of campylobacteriosis a year in the United States, and 200 to 800 deaths.
Campylobacter has been around for a long time. But it was not until the 1970's that scientists realized it could cause illness among humans as well as animals. Campylobacteriosis causes typical food-poisoning symptoms: fever, chills, diarrhea, abdominal pain. Sometimes there may be more serious and permanent consequences, like arthritis. Occasionally, someone dies.
Last week, Dr. Leonard Kapcala, an associate professor of medicine at the University of Maryland Medical School, testified before a Congressional committee about the effects of campylobacteriosis. He, his wife and one of his children were acutely sick with it for a week after eating chicken, and he continued to have chronic problems for months.
"I can never remember feeling so sick," he said in a telephone interview. "I felt as if I had been hit by a truck."
Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, the Ohio Democrat who held the hearings, has introduced a bill to revise the way the United States Agriculture Department inspects poultry. Currently, inspectors look, feel and smell poultry as it whizzes by on the line.
"This system was set up 80 years ago," said Tanya Roberts, a senior economist in the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service. "Today it isn't working because you can't see parasites and bacteria with the naked eye." And the bacteria does not cause a change in odor.
Stories about filthy chickens have become almost routine. The public has come to expect an expose a year, detailing the processing procedures that contaminate even those chickens that came to the slaughterhouse without any pathogens on them. If it isn't salmonella, it's campylobacter. Conditions never seem to improve.
Carole Tucker Foreman, who was an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture in the Carter Administration, thinks she knows why. "The industry has been growing very, very rapidly," she said. "Its production capacity and marketing capacity have outstripped its ability to produce a clean product. And there has been no incentive to produce a product with low bacteria count because the Government lets them sell the poultry with a seal on it that says 'wholesome.'
"All of the weight is on the side of make it fast and make a big profit, and there is no counterbalance from public or the Government saying we want it to be clean."
Ms. Foreman has suggested that one way to provide that counterbalance is "to have U.S.D.A. take the seal off the poultry and put some handling instructions on it." But that won't keep contaminated poultry off the market, she added.
Dr. Glen Morse, an associate professor of medicine and epidemiology at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, said there is no incentive for poultry producers to clean up their operations.
"So why should they do it?" he said. "Maybe if chickens had different grading depending on how much bacteria there is or if the label said how much bacteria the company's chickens had the previous month . . . ."
Dr. Morse served on a National Academy of Sciences panel that made recommendations to the Agriculture Department on how to reduce poultry contamination. But Dr. Morse said, "The Federal Government isn't doing much about it."
There are a lot of ways the production of chickens could be changed to reduce the amount of harmful bacteria they carry when they reach your kitchen counter, but the Agriculture Department is proceeding slowly, not only in looking for solutions but also in requiring the industry to make the changes.
"The U.S.D.A. is not a public health agency," said a scientist at a Government health agency who spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "The poultry industry wants to view the organisms as inevitable and nothing can be done about it."
Dr. Wilson S. Horne, Deputy Administrator for Inspection Operations at the Agriculture Department, disagrees. "Campylobacter is obviously something we are going to have to address," he said. "But you have to remember that raw products by nature contain pathogenic bacteria.
"One of our main thrusts is consumer education while we are working to reduce the numbers of campylobacter. Modern-day homemakers aren't nearly as knowledgable about safe food handling as they used to be."
Dr. Horne's view is shared by Dr. Douglas Archer, deputy director of the Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition at the Food and Drug Administration. "Some people eat dumb things, like raw animal-derived products," Dr. Archer said. "We don't think that's too bright a thing to do. Consumer education is the key thing. I think antibiotics lulled people into a sense of false security."
This blame-the-victim attitude makes Ms. Foreman and others angry. "I think the American public believes it our responsibility to use reasonable care in the preparation of food," Ms. Foreman said, "but I also think that when a package has a seal on it that says 'inspected for wholesomeness by U.S.D.A.' that it will be reasonably clean.
"They are asking us to treat chicken like it's toxic waste and to treat our kitchens like a surgical suite and I don't know anyone who does that."
No one wants to get sick the way the Kapcala family did. But for certain groups, whose numbers have been increasing in recent years, the problem is far more serious than for the general population. For the elderly and people whose immune systems are weak, like cancer patients and people with AIDS, campyllobacteriosis can mean death.
 
An Ounce of Prevention
 WHILE waiting for the Government and the poultry industry to reduce the danger from bacteria in poultry, there are ways to protect yourself.
Good cooking techniques and good sanitation improve your chances of avoiding campylobacter or most of the other bacteria on poultry that cause disease.
Above all, campylobacter is easily killed by thorough cooking.
If poultry is not to be used in one or two days, freeze it.
Thaw poultry in the refrigerator, never at room temperature.
Using hot soapy water, wash your hands and any surfaces or utensils touched by raw poultry, especially food that is to be eaten raw. Suppose, for example, that you slice tomatoes on the same countertop on which you placed the raw chicken. If it had any campylobacter, they would contaminate the tomatoes.
Do not leave uncooked poultry at room temperature for more than 30 minutes. If poultry has to be longer than that becasue it is being transported, pack it in an insulated container with ice.
Many chefs cook poultry to an internal temperature of 160 to 165 degrees. Scientists agree that all bacteria are destroyed at those temperatures. But the Agriculture Department, preferring to err on the side of safety, says poultry is done when the temperature reaches 180 degrees in the center of the inner thigh muscle. That temperature will probably result in an overdone bird, but the department has factored in a margin of safety for those who don't know how to use a meat thermometer. Cooking poultry to 170 degrees is a sensible compromise.
Cool cooked poultry rapidly, and after eating, refrigerate it; do not leave it out.
If you plan to use a marinade for dipping or basting, reserve some in the refrigerator before using on raw poultry. If you want to use a marinade that has held raw poultry, bring the marinade to a boil before serving.
Never use a dish that held raw poultry without washing it thoroughly.
When cooking poultry in a microwave oven, first cook it under cover; steam helps kill bacteria. Stir or rotate the dish during microwaving for even cooking and be sure to observe the "standing time" recommended in the microwave recipe.

HEADLINE: Time on Your Hands? It May Be Increasing

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
PEOPLE are always talking about how busy they are, how starved they feel for time. But do they really have less of it today? John P. Robinson, a University of Maryland professor of psychology who has been studying the way Americans spend their waking moments for 25 years, asserts that the perception does not match the reality. His findings show a steady increase in free time.
"I'm the guy with the odd data," said Professor Robinson, who directs the Americans' Use of Time Project at the university's Survey Research Center in College Park. He agrees with the widely held notion that people feel more harried. Surveys by poll takers like Louis Harris and Associates, for instance, say they have found that people believe that the work week has been increasing and leisure time has been decreasing. 
 But Professor Robinson, a man of diverse interests and multiple projects who seems perfectly confident that his numbers tell the real story, thinks people remember the past inaccurately. "The perception of a time crunch appears to have gone up in the period of time where free time has increased," said Professor Robinson, who, in those 25 years, has studied thousands of diaries that men and women around the country have kept on how they spent their time.
Since 1965, he said, men have gained seven hours of free time in a week, to 41 hours from 34 in a week. Women, he reports, have gained six hours of free time, to 40 from 34, in a week. He defines free time as any time when people don't have commitments to work, family, chores or personal needs like sleeping, eating and grooming.
Professor Robinson is considered one of the few experts on spending time who is able to make comparisons over decades. "Very few people actually study how we use time," said Prof. Geoffrey Godbey of the leisure studies department at Pennsylvania State University. He characterized Professor Robinson's work as "first rate," an evaluation echoed by colleagues in the field.
And Professor Godbey, too, reports that he has found that perceptions of how time is spent differ from reality. He said that in a study five years ago, he found, by comparing interviews with sign-in records, that people thought they had used a tennis and swim club 100 percent more than they really had. "People want to believe that they play tennis and swim," he said, "not that they watch TV and drink beer."
In a small office on the College Park campus decorated with family photos and souvenirs of trips to the Soviet Union, Professor Robinson studies the diaries, where groups of Americans around the country try to account for every minute of a day: what they did, who they were with, whether they were doing anything else at the same time. The diaries were filled out by 1,240 participants in the survey in 1965; by another 2,409 in 1975, and by 5,389 in 1985.
He became interested in the use of time when he was a graduate student at the University of Michigan. It seemed odd to him that much research had been conducted into how people spent their money, but little into how they spent their time.
Professor Robinson, who has a doctorate in mathematical psychology and social psychology, has written books on the use of time, including "The Rhythm of Everyday Life" ( Westview Press , 1988) and "How Americans Use Time: A Social-Psychological Analysis of Everyday Behavior" (Praeger Publishers, 1977). He is currently finishing a third, to be titled "Free Time in America," about his most recent studies.
In addition to the time diaries, financed by the National Science Foundation with some occasional backing from the Sloan Foundation and A.T.& T., Professor Robinson sometimes undertakes related projects. In his findings in a recent nationwide study for the Hilton Hotels Corporation, he reported that there was ample evidence that people felt starved for time. Almost half of 1,010 people interviewed by telephone in January said they would be willing to sacrifice a day's pay for an extra day off each week.
The answers indicated that women feel much more harried than men, especially if they have children. "We are at a point," said Professor Robinson, "when the value of time to most Americans is reaching parity with the value of money."
Although the feeling of time's pressure is real, he said, the findings of research, over time, indicate that women as a group have more free time than they did two decades ago, all of which has gone into watching television. He said further that although TV watching has declined very slightly in the last decade, it rose so much between 1965 and 1975 that it still consumes 37 percent of the free time of American women and 39 percent of the free time of American men.
Professor Robinson said that the perception that society as a whole has become short of time and is thus in dire need of things like instant food and instant shopping, may in part be a consequence of the large number of people who are in their 30's and 40's, a period when demands on time are greatest. People older than 65 have the most free time, Professor Robinson said, falling just slightly short of the amount they would like.
There has always been a large segment of the population that feels rushed. Professor Robinson estimates that a third of the population now feels rushed; about a quarter of the population felt that way 25 years ago. Then, as now, he said, women with jobs and with children have the least amount of leisure. Having a husband does not result in more leisure for women with children. Being married, he said, reduces the free time of a woman by an hour a week; being single increases her free time by four hours.
For those who do not actually have less free time today, the pressure for instant results and the technology that makes them possible, may help explain the feeling of a time crunch. "It could be because of the pace," Professor Robinson said, or the ever-expanding variety of life. "There are just more choices. Even the choice of doing nothing is a harried choice."
But using time as an excuse has become a valid explanation, making it a convenient cover-up. "People say they don't have time to read newspapers," the psychologist said, "but it's just another way of saying they'd rather be doing something else." Indeed, his research has indicated the truth in a very old truism: those with the most to do do the most.
When he conducted a survey of participation in the arts, he expected to find that certain people would be likely to attend cultural events while others would be likely to, say, fix their carburetors in their spare time. But it turned out that those who fixed their carburetors were also more likely to pursue cultural activities.
"The more you do one thing, the more you do another," he said. He calls such people "the omnivores," and says they are also likely to work long hours. "I've looked at it as an extension of Newton," he said. "Bodies in motion stay in motion."
Professor Robinson, who is divorced and has two children age 21 and 23, said he always finds time to do what he really wants to do, like going to jazz festivals, searching for old miniature golf courses and testing locally brewed beers. Like "the omnivores," he is always moving. Pointing to a man on Roller Blades, he said, "A friend says I should have been born on those."
No matter how many information on time he amasses, intriguing questions remain. Next year, he plans to tackle one. The time diaries show that people are working fewer hours. But official Bureau of Labor Statistics show that the work week has remained constant in the last two decades. Armed with a grant from the American Statistical Association, Professor Robinson hopes to reconcile those conflicting numbers.
He theorizes that people may say they work 40 hours a week, but when they actually account for each hour of their day it is clear that they do personal things during their workday, like going to the doctor, meeting children's needs, and the like. Their jobs may make it easier to do that. "As you move into a service economy," he said, "there is less monitoring of what goes on." Ideally, he said, he would like to broaden his studies to include actual observation of how people use time.
After the 1980's, when it was stylish to believe that everyone was frantically rushing to make money, it is now stylish to believe that the rat race is over and the simple life is back. But he doesn't believe that habits change for everyone, or that they change radically.
"Behavior," he said, "moves more slowly than perception."

HEADLINE: Her Fame Is Ruled His Too: Soprano Must Share Income

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
"The Marriage of Figaro" did not end like this.
A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade must share with her former husband money she made during their 17-year marriage. 
 The decision came in one of the more notable recent tests of the premise that a husband or wife who aids in a spouse's rise to fame is entitled to a share in the value of that celebrity. The unanimous ruling by the five-member court overturned a decision by Acting Justice Walter M. Schackman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.
Last year Justice Schackman denied a claim by Ms. von Stade's former husband, Peter Elkus. Having been her voice coach, adviser and photographer during Ms. von Stade's rise to stardom, Mr. Elkus asserted that he was entitled to a chunk of her star value under New York's equitable-distribution law.
 
What's Hers Is His
 Yesterday the appeals panel agreed, saying that his contributions to Ms. von Stade's career were marital property and must be taken into account in their divorce settlement.
The ruling is the latest in which judges in New York State have had to make a determination on what constitutes marital property and what contributions during marriage are compensable at the time of divorce.
Five years ago, New York's highest court ruled that a wife who had deferred her ca reer to send her husband to medical school effectively owned part of his medical license.
A Manhattan trial judge applied the same principle in the 1988 divorce case of the actress Marisa Berenson and A. Richard Golub. The judge held that the increased value of Ms. Berenson's acting and modeling career were marital property.
Since then, trial courts have held that degrees in law, medicine and accounting are marital assets. But yesterday's ruling recast the criteria for courts to use in deciding such cases.
"It is the nature and extent of the contribution by the spouse seeking equitable distribution, rather than the nature of the career, whether licensed or otherwise, that should determine the status of the enterprise as marital property," the appeals panel said.
Ms. von Stade was not yet a celebrity when she met Mr. Elkus, a bass-baritone, in music school. She went on to international acclaim.
The lower court decision referred to Ms. von Stade only as "F. Elkus," and the records of the case were sealed. But yesterday, the appeals court provided some details in its opinion, noting that Ms. von Stade earned $2,250 in 1973, the first year of her marriage to Mr. Elkus, and $621,878 in 1990, the last. They have two children.
"While it is true that the plaintiff was born with talent and, while she had already been hired by the Metropolitan Opera at the time of her marriage to the defendant, her career, at this time, was only in the initial stages of development," the appellate court said. "During the course of the marriage, the defendant's active involvement in the plaintiff's career, in teaching, coaching, and critiquing her, as well as caring for the children, clearly contributed to the increase in its value."
Mr. Elkus's lawyer, Alfred Ferrer 3d, said the ruling yesterday was significant because it extended the principle of equitable distribution beyond the realm of licensed professionals like doctors and lawyers to artists and others whose jobs are not.
 
Seeking Future Income, Too
 Mr. Ferrer said he would seek to have the ruling apply to the income Ms. von Stade has earned since her divorce from Mr. Elkus a year ago, as well as to her future income.
"What this ruling clearly means is that marriage is an economic partnership," he said.
Ms. von Stade's lawyer, Raul Lionel Felder, warned that the ruling would "open the floodgates to spouses who want equitable distribution from plumbers and shoeshine men."

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Up Sharp 2.9%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
In a compelling report of economic rebound, new orders to American factories surged 2.9 percent in May, the biggest increase in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today.
It was also the second straight substantial rise after five months in which factory orders declined. The April gain, moreover, was revised upward to 2.1 percent from the 1.8 percent initially reported. 
 Today's report seemed to extinguish any remaining hopes that the Federal Reserve would find it necessary to cut interest rates again to spur the economy, which is widely believed to be climbing out of the recession that began a year ago. The central bank's Open Market Committee began a two-day meeting today to set monetary targets for the balance of the year.
"I think we're in a classic recovery environment now," said Edward Yardeni, an economist at C. J. Lawrence Inc., a New York securities firm. He noted that not only have new orders turned up -- a predictive indicator -- but that shipments of factory goods have now advanced for two straight months.
 
Consumer Confidence Up
 In another report, the University of Michigan said its widely followed consumer survey showed a sharp jump in confidence in June. [Page D2.]
The report on factory orders covered the entire range of factory goods -- $120.1 billion of durables, which are designed to last a minimum of three years, and $117.9 billion of nondurables. A preliminary report on orders for durable goods last Tuesday showed these surging 3.8 percent in May, a gain trimmed today to 3.4 percent, mainly because of a lower order level for fabricated metals.
Orders for nondurables rose 2.5 percent, with all major industries except rubber and plastics posting increases, the department said. For nondurables, orders are generally filled so quickly as to be regarded essentially the same as shipments.
Shipments of food products rose 1.3 percent, textile mill products rose 2.2 percent, chemicals and allied products rose 1.9 percent and petroleum and coal products rose 3.6 percent.
Tobacco products, which are highly erratic for tax and other reasons, soared 22.6 percent. Rubber and plastics fell 1.5 percent while paper and related products edged down one-tenth of 1 percent, the report showed.
In all, shipments climbed 1.3 percent in May after a 2.7 percent April increase, but backlogs of unfilled orders were essentially unchanged at $521.1 billion, the lowest level since February 1990.
Declines in orders for durables offset increases in nondurables.
Inventories, meanwhile, fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $382 billion, declining for the fifth time in six months since reaching a November 1990 peak of $392.4 billion. It appeared that these inventory reductions were involuntary, as sales have outpaced production rather than representing deliberate retrenchment by anxious executives.
By the stage of fabrication, inventories of finished goods eased 1.6 percent for durables and five-tenths of 1 percent for nondurables. Work-in-process was down seven-tenths of 1 percent and five-tenths of 1 percent, respectively, for these categories while materials and supplies fell 1 percent and four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
Unfilled Orders Rise
 Unfilled orders for nondurables in May rose 4.1 percent, to $21.2 billion, the biggest increase since February 1987 and the highest level since May 1990, the Department reported.
Over all, the 2.9 percent gain in factory orders reflected a gain of $6.8 billion for the month. This followed a 2.1 percent gain in April and a 2.9 percent decline for March. Orders, however, remain 2.2 percent below the level of May 1990.
By market categories, orders were up 5.5 percent for automotive equipment, 3.2 percent for consumer, 3.7 percent for machinery and equipment, 1.9 percent for business supplies, 1.5 percent for construction materials and supplies, 3.7 percent for information technology industries and 6.1 percent for health care products.
Orders for military goods, on the other hand, tumbled 18.1 percent, and home goods and apparel eased nine-tenths of 1 percent.
