HEADLINE: Gains by Money Managers Proving to be Hard to Hold

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
For stock managers who were hot in early 1991, the challenge of the second quarter turned out to be holding on to the gains of the first quarter.
"It's more important to keep what you made," said Fred Astman, the chief investment officer of First Wilshire Securities Management of Los Angeles, which ranked second among investment advisers for the first half, according to estimates released yesterday by CDA Investment Technologies. 
 The CDA figures estimated that First Wilshire, which specializes in small stocks, gained 56.5 percent in the first half, with a gain of 51.2 percent in the first quarter and a much smaller rise of 3.5 percent in the second quarter.
 
No. 1 and No. 2 Trade Places
 First Wilshire had been the top manager in the first quarter, but it traded places for the half with Target Investors, a firm based in Wilton, Conn., which moved up from second place on the basis of an 11.1 percent second-quarter gain, which left the firm up 66.7 percent for the first six months.
Target, whose officials could not be reached last night, also specializes in small stocks, and seems to have benefited from holdings in Pacificare Health Systems and SciMed Life Systems, two companies that posted much-better-than-expected earnings and leaped more than 30 percent in the quarter.
For many small stock managers, however, the second quarter was disappointing. Typical was Dwight E. Lee of New York, which had ranked third at the end of the first quarter, with a gain of 42.6 percent, but which CDA estimated lost 13.9 percent in the second quarter. Many small technology stocks suffered in late May and June as a reaction set in to the explosive growth in prices earlier in the year.
 
Data Based on S.E.C. Filings
 Most money managers are not required to disclose performance data to the public, so the CDA figures are estimates based on the limited filings the managers do make with the Securities and Exchange Commission. CDA calculated the performance of the stocks each manager reported earning at the end of each quarter and assumed that no transactions took place in the second quarter.
Such an assumption is obviously incorrect and has the added disadvantage of ignoring cash and bonds that the manager might hold, as well as any short positions in stocks, which are not reported. But over time the estimates have proved generally accurate.
Because of the big growth in the first quarter, the average money manager, as calculated by CDA, showed a rise of 17.1 percent in the first half. That figure is probably overstated, because most managers hold at least some cash, but it nonetheless outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which rose 14.3 percent in the quarter. That rise reflects the fact that smaller stocks generally did better than their larger counterparts.
By the CDA calculation, none of the 528 firms for which it was able to make estimates lost money during the first half of 1991.
CDA did not publish a breakdown for the second quarter, so it is not possible to calculate how many of the firms lost money in that period, but the answer probably is close to half, as share prices gyrated but showed little overall movement in the period. An analysis of stocks in the S.& P. 500 by Shaw Data showed that the best performances generally were in the more economically sensitive industries, as investors grew to expect an economic recovery that could be stronger than had been forecast.
Mr. Astman said that he expected it would be more difficult to make money in stocks in the second half of the year. "The market is around 20 times earnings, and at that level we are nervous," he said. He added that in choosing stocks, he was paying a lot of attention not only to growth prospects, but also to a secure balance sheet.

HEADLINE: Foreign Investment in U.S. Decreased Last Year

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Foreigners invested much less in the United States last year than in previous years, according to Commerce Department figures released today.
Largely as a result, the excess of foreign investment in the United States over American investment abroad -- sometimes referred to as the nation's net debtor position -- barely widened last year and may actually have shrunk, the figures also showed. 
 Foreign direct investment in the United States, which includes purchases of land, factories, corporate subsidiaries and large stakes in companies, plummeted to $37.2 billion last year from $70.6 billion in 1989. Foreign companies and individuals bought fewer big stakes in American companies, reinvested less of their profits here and lent less money to their American subsidiaries, the department said.
 
Counters Popular Fear
 The report comes amid considerable concern in Congress and elsewhere about whether foreigners have been acquiring excessively large stakes in the industrial and technological base of the United States. "At the same time people were getting paranoid about foreigners coming in and buying up America, foreigners were beginning to disinvest in America, at least insofar as equities were concerned," said Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
The declining value of the dollar relative to other currencies prompted many foreigners to sell shares in American companies, Mr. Hormats said. Foreigners' sales of these shares, he added, actually exceeded their purchases by $5.9 billion in the fourth quarter of last year.
Foreigners have also been losing interest in American real estate, though precise figures are hard to find, said James A. Fetgatter, the membership director of the Association of Foreign Investors in U.S. Real Estate, a Washington-based trade group. Higher interest rates abroad, particularly in Japan, have made the returns from United States real estate and other investments seem less attractive.
And much like many American banks, foreign banks have cut back on lending for overseas real estate investment, making these deals more difficult to finance, Mr. Fetgatter said.
The weakness of the United States economy also contributed to the drop in foreign investment, the Commerce Department said. American interest rates dropped compared with interest rates elsewhere, so that United States bonds became less attractive to foreign investors. In addition, the United States subsidiaries of foreign companies earned less than in 1989, leaving them with smaller profits to repatriate.
 
Slowdown in Mergers Cited
 Part of the fall in direct foreign investment may be temporary because of the scarcity of very large international mergers last year, said Edward M. Graham, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Foreign purchases to acquire or enlarge large stakes in American companies fell to $47 billion from $51.9 billion, a drop that was smaller than the value of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company's $6.1 billion purchase of MCA, he said. "The equity coming into the U.S. tends to come in quite big chunks," he added.
The Commerce Department also issued varying estimates today of whether foreign holdings in the United States increased in value last year faster than American investments overseas. By the measurement that many economists prefer, the United States fell further behind. But by two other measures the United States gained ground.
The United States is sometimes described as the world's largest net debtor nation because foreign investment here exceeds American investment abroad, though much of the investment takes the form of equity rather than debt.
Using stock market indexes to calculate the value of direct investments made many years ago, total accumulated foreign investment in the United States as of last year exceeded American investment overseas by $360.6 billion, a deficit that widened from $267.7 billion in 1989. But using either the original purchase price or the replacement cost of these investments, the United States net investment position improved by about $25 billion, though it remained in a large deficit.
The deficit widened using the stock market measure because many foreign stock markets fell dramatically last autumn, more than the United States market fell, after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, so that the value of many American holdings abroad also fell.
Officials of the Reagan and Bush Administrations have contended that strong net foreign investment in the United States has been an expression of confidence in the nation's economic future rather than an indication of current economic weakness. But a senior Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, said weak foreign investment did not mean foreigners had lost confidence.

HEADLINE: Fighting It Out on TV, With Fists, Pies and Slime

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 2

 BODY:
Got a quarrel with a neighbor, friend, relative or mate that you want settled on national television? You don't have to take your case to Judge Wapner and "The People's Court" anymore. Now you can simply slug it out on "The Grudge Match."
In the latest twist in reality programming, people who might otherwise be in small claims or divorce court are entering a boxing ring and going three rounds against each other, cheered on by a studio audience that picks the winner. "It may not be PBS, but it's a real hoot," one production assistant said on Monday during taping of the program, which began production late last month. 
 "The Grudge Match," produced by Richmel Productions in association with Genesis Entertainment , is to go on the air in September in more than 100 cities around the country, mostly in late-night weekend slots. In New York, the program will be broadcast on WNBC.
Lisa London and Robert Branaman, though, did not seem particularly amused when they went at each other with the cameras rolling and the commentators Steve Albert, who is a sportscaster, and Jesse (The Body) Ventura, a former wrestler, describing their bout from ringside. Mr. Branaman and Ms. London once lived together, but parted ways when she insisted they marry and he refused; shortly thereafter, she moved in with his brother, sticking him with back rent. Then she wrecked his car.
 
From Fists to Food
 After knocking each other around the ring, Mr. Branaman, listed at 5 foot 11 and 170 pounds, and Ms. London, who at 5 foot 6 weighed in at 106 pounds, donned wedding veils and moved on to serious business: tossing wedding cakes, hors d'oeuvres and glasses of champagne at each other. Mr. Branaman got so much into the spirit of things that he rushed to Ms. London's side of the ring and creamed her with tiered cakes from her own arsenal.
"I hit her with tunafish, cake and eggs," Mr. Branaman crowed afterward. "She never even got me once."
Mr. Branaman and Ms. London were followed by Bryan Jardine and Sam Sloves, who were surfing buddies until Mr. Sloves' $800 surfboard was wrecked in a maneuver he blamed Mr. Jardine for and Mr. Jardine refused to pay the damages. Next up were Ann Greenfeld and her husband, Robert, a pair of transplanted New Yorkers who were soon wrestling in a sea of goop and pelting each other with matzoh balls. She thinks she might like to have a third child, but he is perfectly happy with two.
Among other contestants scheduled to appear on the program are a bride and groom who can't agree on what to do with the $10,000 wedding gift they received from her parents. There are also neighbors disputing a fence's position on their property line as well as two women whose friendship dissolved when one lent her wedding gown to the other, who promptly had it altered into a miniskirt.
 
An Effort to Avoid Injuries
 "The Grudge Match" is set up in such a way that the first round always consists of fisticuffs or something equally physical, as when the adversaries batter each other with inflated bats. Contestants then battle it out for two more rounds with implements chosen from the program's Gallery of Weapons, which include saws, bows and arrows (rubber-tipped), tennis rackets, rotten tomatoes, sauerkraut, baked beans, buckets of sludge, cat litter and cream pies. The adversaries wear costumes, starting out in tights and capes and then perhaps putting on giant chicken-head masks or other appropriate embellishments.
There are limits to the mayhem, of course. The boxing is done with oversize gloves, a referee is always on hand during the bout, and a paramedic examines the contestants afterward in case there are cuts, bruises or something worse.
"We don't want people getting hurt," Rich Melcombe, the program's executive producer, said. "We want them to vent their frustrations and settle their differences. But we do not want them to kill each other."
Lynette Klump and Peter Varvel, whose bout ended with them rolling around in the ketchup, mustard and mayonnaise they had been slinging at each other, said they had found their joint appearance to be therapeutic. The two are part of a group of college friends and co-workers who rent a house together in Riverside, Calif. Their relationship took a turn for the worse a year ago, when his car ran over her cat and he followed it up with a series of dead cat jokes she found offensive.
 
'Not Mad at Him Anymore'
 "I'm a very physical person, and this was a good way to release all the stress and tension that had built up between us," Ms. Klump said. "It was definitely better than going to the gym. I was really mad in the first round, because he was laughing, but when I got him, it felt so good. I'm over it now, I'm not mad at him anymore."
Mr. Varvel said that at first he had worried about treating Ms. Klump too roughly. "I thought I should hold back," he said. "But then I got into it, because I didn't want to lose." Nevertheless, the audience, recruited from tourists on the Universal Studios tour, voted Ms. Klump the winner.
Contestants on "The Grudge Match" have been recruited through advertisements like those in The Los Angeles Times, which read "Revenge!!! Get even with that certain someone on Nat'l TV Show." The program has also sent staff members to small-claims courts in Southern California and expects to receive a flood of solicitations from around the country once it begins broadcasting.
All contestants on the program receive a $250 "appearance fee," with an additional prize, custom-chosen for the contestants, going to the winner of the bout. Ms. London, for instance, would have received a set of satin sheets had she defeated Mr. Branaman, who as the victor walked away with a $700 cash award.
 
Rejected by Turner
 Mr. Melcombe said he came up with the idea for "The Grudge Match" in 1987, when he was working for Turner Broadcasting and the network's owner, Ted Turner, asked him to develop some sort of program that could run in tandem with the network's wrestling shows. But when Mr. Melcombe presented the idea to Mr. Turner, "Ted laughed and said, 'Rich, come on,' " Mr. Melcombe recalled.
Since then, however, both television economics and audience tastes have changed. "The Grudge Match" costs relatively little to make, thanks to a fixed set and low overhead, and is expected to appeal to the same viewers who have made solid succeses out of so-called reality-based cop and rescue programs on the Fox network.
Mr. and Mrs. Greenfeld said they had decided to appear on the program because they thought it would be a good way to end their deadlock over a third child: whoever won the bout would also win the argument. The audience sided with Mrs. Greenfeld by a margin of 2 to 1, and the $1,000 prize "that would have gone for a vasectomy or tubal, will now go into the kids' college fund," he said, graciously conceding defeat and kissing his wife.
"We wanted to have some fun and just get on TV so our friends and relatives back East could see us make fools of ourselves," Mrs. Greenfeld said. "But having done it, I'd say you should only do it if you really love each other. Otherwise, something could happen, and the next step is divorce court."

NAME: Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
Idealism With Gloves Off

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 2

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. did not create the budget problems in Connecticut; they arose from problems of falling tax revenues caused by the recession. But at every turn in the six months since he took office as the state's first independent third-party governor in a century, he has gone out of his way to make those problems indelibly his own -- in proposing and defending the kind of income-tax plan that residents and lawmakers have resisted for decades.
Through two budget vetoes -- and his order, issued early today, to begin shutting down nonessential state services until lawmakers pass a budget that he will sign -- Mr. Weicker has argued in ringing and righteous terms that he is defending residents from budget chicanery and long-term fiscal ruin. 
 Without insisting directly on the imposition of a deeply unpopular income tax as a requirement in the budget, he has said he cannot conceive of an honest budget without an income tax.
Mr. Weicker defends the income tax as the fairest system of taxation and the only one that would allow the cuts in business taxes that he argues are essential to stimulate the limping economy. But behnd his often elegant phrases, Mr. Weicker has not spared using political tools that are as tried and true as those of any ward heeler.
He has emerged as a bare-knuckled idealist willing to use all the maneuvers of traditional politics to achieve the individual idiosyncratic goals of a maverick.
The state employees unions provide a case in point. Mr. Weicker said today, for example, that he would veto any continuing budget resolution to temporarily finance the government for two weeks. He argued that doing so would formally dissolve a $340 million package of state employees' wage and benefit concessions negotiated this spring. His administration then declared a budget emergency and ordered about 7,000 of those employees in non-essential positions to stay home from work.
In both opposing the resolution and ordering the shutdown, Mr. Weicker said that political tactics to keep pressure on the legislature were not even given the slightest consideration.
 
'I Have No Alternative'
 "In the absence of a budget as required by law, I have no alternative but to do what I have done," he said at a news conference in his office. "It's up to me to harbor the resources of the state."
But a whole spectrum of factors make those decisions almost impossible to understand except in the context of old-fashioned politics.
Unlike many other states, Connecticut has no mechanism to furlough its workers, and state laws also require written notice for layoffs. That means that any labor savings resulting from the shutdown are questionable at best: according to the State Comptroller's office, the laws and contracts will probably require everyone to be paid. The written notices even said that all those "contractual obligations" would still be met.
What that means is that the state workers, ordered not to do any work for the state, but pointedly not laid off either, were simply footloose for the day. The Governor's press office politely notified reporters this morning that the workers would be rallying on behalf of the income tax on the Capitol grounds.
 
Supports His Tax, Not Him
 At least some of the state employees who showed up at the rally were torn between their support for the income tax that their unions had endorsed and their personal views about the Governor.
"It's totally counterproductive," said Vincent Diana Jr., a technical systems analyst for the Department of Education. Mr. Diana, who was wearing a T-shirt saying "Shut Weicker Down," said he supported the income tax but not the Governor.
By Wednesday the shutdown will include the closing of all state parks, beaches and campgrounds just in time for the beginning of the long Fourth of July weekend, was also based on the premise, Mr. Weicker said, that the lack of a budget is by definition a state emergency requiring executive action.
But the very lack of a budget resulted from Mr. Weicker's refusal to accept the temporary two-week budget resolution that both chambers of the General Assembly had already passed.
 
Says He Protects State
 Mr. Weicker said today that he was protecting the state because the resolution guaranteed current labor obligations -- which entitled workers to raises of up to 6 percent effective July 1. The $340 million concession package would postpone those raises, as well as putting off a large payment to the employee pension fund -- though both savings would untimately have to be made up in future budgets.
"An emergency is something that happens to you -- it's not something you create," said the Comptroller, William E. Curry Jr., who has urged Mr. Weicker to relent in accepting a temporary budget measure. "You can't cause an emergency, then certify its existence," Mr. Curry said.
But while some of the torments of lawmakers trying to pass a budget can be legitimately traced to Mr. Weicker's unbending ways, at times he has also apparently failed to communicate what was on his mind.
On Sunday, for example, the last day of the fiscal year, Mr. Weicker was invited into private caucus to address the majority Democrats in the House of Representatives. According to lawmakers who were there, Mr. Weicker for some reason danced around the question of whether he would veto a conventional tax plan, which would resolve the state's revenue shortfall through a traditional expansion of the state's 8 percent sales tax.
Even though Mr. Weicker's objections to a sales-tax expansion were well known, and even though he had already vetoed a similar plan in May, he said when asked that he would in fact sign a conventional plan "if it worked."
Lawmakers were apparently so confused by the answer that they pressed forward with a conventional budget, which passed both chambers before being smashed by another Weicker veto on Monday. All parties concerned lost at least a full day's work on the eve of the deadline. In his veto message, Mr. Weicker called the budget "shocking."

HEADLINE: Consumers' Survey Shows Sharp Jump in Confidence

 BODY:
Consumers' faith in the present and future health of the economy jumped sharply in June, the University of Michigan's widely followed survey on consumer sentiment showed.
Richard Curtin, who oversees the survey, said yesterday that the latest soundings showed that the "slow but steady improvement" in consumer confidence that began early this year continued strongly in June. "That is based on the expectation that the economy will improve, although the recovery is expected to be slow," he said. 
 Mr. Curtin said the weakest element of the survey was consumers' expectations about their personal finances. "That reflects the effects of the recession and the belief that income gains will be slow in the recovery," he said.
 
Provided in Confidence
 He declined to give specific details of the latest findings, which he said were provided in confidence yesterday to the survey's subscribers. But Reuters quoted economists who had seen copies of the report as having said that it showed confidence at its highest level since the euphoric period after the Persian Gulf war.
Reuters said the report showed that consumer sentiment rose to 82.1 percent in June from 78.3 percent in May. Consumer sentiment was the highest since March's 87.7 percent after the victory in the war. Excluding the March blip, the index was at its highest since August 1990 -- a month after the recession began.
"Confidence is now in a range where we can see a revival of consumer spending and a revival in the economy," said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill Inc.
Consumer spending alone buys two-thirds of all goods and services produced in the economy, so any sharp change could be an important factor in an overall rebound.
"The details of this report conform to the view that the economy is recovering, but the pace of recovery will likely be slow," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Confidence improved in all regions of the country except for the Northeast."
The Michigan survey works from a base of 100 percent in 1966 and is compiled through a telephone survey of 500 households. It is used by the Commerce Department in its monthly index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to predict the economy's direction six to nine months in the future. Consumer confidence is one of 11 factors in the report.
In addition to overall consumer sentiment, the Michigan study showed that an index on feelings about current economic conditions improved, rising to 91.9 percent in June from 89 percent in May.
A third index, based on expectations about the future, rose to 75.9 percent from 71.5 percent. That was the highest since March, when expectations surged to 84.5 percent.
The Conference Board, a business group in New York, also tracks the consumer. Its survey, released last week, showed confidence rose to 78 in June from 76.4 in May. It works from a base of 100 in 1985. The June rise was attributed to more optimistic expectations for the months ahead, the board said.
In contrast to the Michigan survey, it said consumer opinions of current economic conditions slid for the 10th straight month in June.

HEADLINE: With Jobs Scarce, Many Turn to Graduate School

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DEPALMA

 BODY:
From the beginning of the academic year, Dana M. Lew, a senior majoring in economics at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., knew that finding a job after graduation would be a nightmare. So she, like a record number of this year's seniors, kept her options open by applying to graduate school.
As the term progressed, iss Lew, who grew up in Metairie, La., regularly checked the job listings at Northwestern's placement office but did not come across anything hopeful. She spoke to several corporate recruiters who said they would be hiring half as many people as they had first expected. 
 "It got kind of discouraging," Miss Lew said. Finally, she received a letter of acceptance from the University of Illinois at Urbana, for its master's degree program in business administration. "I decided that this was the way to go," she said.
So many members of the class of '91 at colleges and universities around the country applied to graduate school this year that applications rose by as much as 20 percent at the 430 largest institutions, according to the Council of Graduate Schools, a national organization. Nearly 1 million foreign and American students applied to graduate school in the United States this year as against more than 830,000 last year, excluding law and medical schools and a few other specialized programs.
 
A Common Phenomenon
 Victor R. Lindquist, the director of placement at Northwestern, who wrote the Lindquist-Endicott Reports, an annual survey of employment trends for college graduates, said that in a bad economy it is common for applications to graduate school to increase.
"Graduate school is a socially acceptable place to hide," he said.
While applications at graduate schools nationwide have blossomed, enrollments are expected to inch up only about 2 percent, according to the Council of Graduate Schools, because most colleges and universities have not expanded their faculties to accept additional students.
The result is a double whammy for many students who, shut out of the job market, have also been rejected by the graduate programs of their choice.
But at least one school, George Washington University in Washington, is trying to help its own students by cutting in half graduate school tuition rates in 28 of its programs.
Nonetheless, some students say they cannot seem to get ahead, no matter what strategy they follow.
"I just got lost in the numbers," said Adam M. Goldstein of Fairfield, Conn., a chemistry major who graduated in May from George Washington and was rejected by several medical schools, despite decent scores on the entrance examination. He said college advisers had told him it was because so many others had applied.
Mr. Goldstein, who graduated with a minor concentration in business administration, said he then looked for a job as a salesman for a pharmaceutical company. He sent out 120 resumes, without getting a single job offer.
"I knew it was going to be bad, but I never expected it to be like this," said Mr. Goldstein, who plans to take the medical school entrance examination again in the fall and reapply for admission.
Because of his interest in medical school, Mr. Goldstein was not able to take advantage of George Washington's unusual plan, which offers its own graduates who meet admissions requirements the chance to pursue an advanced degree at half the cost of $490 per graduate credit hour.
Under the plan, the usual graduate tuition of $8,820 a year would be reduced to $4,410 each year for the two years it customarily takes to complete a master's degree.
 
'Sale' on Master's Programs
 The tuition "sale" applies to 28 of George Washington's 185 master's degree programs. Robert W. Kenny, acting dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, said the disciplines included in the program are under-enrolled and can accommodate additional students without increasing the faculty. They include standard programs like English, history and mathematics as well as some specialized ones like art therapy, neuroscience and women's studies.
"Giving students the credential of a master's degree may restore their competitive edge," Mr. Kenny said.
So far the response has been lukewarm. While about 15 seniors inquired about the program, none have enrolled. Part of the reason may be that it was not announced until May 10, just a few weeks before the end of the semester. Also, the most popular graduate programs, including the one in public administration, are not covered.
Stephen J. Trachtenberg, the president of George Washington, said he would decide next winter whether to extend the program for another year.
Paying for a graduate education appears to be a big impediment for many. As budget problems force public and private universities to trim expenses, there will generally be less financial aid available for graduate students.
Roy A. Koenigsknecht, dean of the graduate school at Ohio State University, said graduate applications there have increased 10 percent this year to some 20,000. But he said the university could assist just over 4,000 graduate students, roughly the same number as in 1990.
Mr. Koenigsknecht said the aid cutbacks hit particularly hard for women, who might need to pay for dependent child care, and minorities, many of whom have fewer alternatives for financial assistance.
"Over all we may see some gains in graduate enrollment," he said, "but it will be a net loss for women and minorities."

Ms. Lew's decision helped contribute to the 20 percent rise in such applications around the country, according to the Council of Graduate Schools. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gold-Stock Funds Win in Quarter

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
When it came to stock mutual fund performance in the second quarter of this year, it turned out that what glittered really was gold.
Gold-oriented mutual funds greatly outpaced the stock market from April to June, making them one of the few bright spots among mutual funds investing primarily in common stocks. Stock funds, in general, fell a bit more than the stock market did. 
 Lipper Analytical Services reported that, on average, general equity funds -- those that invest in a broad array of stocks -- fell in value by 0.86 percent in the quarter. That was a slightly greater decline than the 0.23 percent drop in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. When specialized funds are included, the average of all equity funds fell by 0.79 percent.
 
Gold-Oriented Funds Up 8.04%
 By contrast, funds with large holdings in gold-mining companies rose an average 8.04 percent in value. The biggest gainer, Strategic Investments, a Dallas-based fund that invests in South African gold-mining stocks, rose 34.39 percent. That was the largest rise among all of the 1,264 equity funds that Lipper tracks.
The biggest losers this time around were funds that invested in technology and environmental companies and those that invested in small businesses. These funds were hurt by poor earnings in high-technology companies, like I.B.M., as well as by a shift by investors toward larger, better-capitalized companies that are expected to fare better as the recession moves toward a recovery.
Gold shares are among the most volatile stocks traded, and it is not unusual for them to pop up temporarily to the top of hot-stock lists. Their recent strong showing followed a year in which they were big money losers. Gold mutual funds, which had slumped in value at the end of 1990, began to rise slowly in the first quarter and accelerated that pace in the second.
 
Lifting of Sanctions a Factor
 Leroy S. Brenna, founder and president of Strategic Investments, which has $38 million invested, said more favorable investor perception had helped lift South African gold mining stocks, particularly as many European and Asian countries ended their economic sanctions against that country, and the United States is expected to do the same.
Nearly 97 percent of Strategic Investments' holdings are in South African gold companies. American economic sanctions now prohibit Americans from investing in South African stocks issued after 1986. Strategic Investments buys only shares issued before that date. Many other gold funds invest primarily in gold mines in North America, and their shares did not rise as much.
Mr. Brenna said that the lifting of sanctions "has prompted Asians and Europeans to become big buyers of South African gold funds, and the stocks are rising in anticipation of our being able to own South African gold assets."
 
No. 2 Also Big in South Africa
 Another Texas-based gold fund, U.S. Gold Shares, a $300 million fund based in San Antonio, took the No. 2 position, rising 21.28 percent in the quarter. This fund is also fully invested in South African stocks.
"South African gold shares have traditionally had a certain amount of political discounting," said Edmund Serfaty, U.S. Gold Shares' portfolio manager. "Once the sanctions are lifted, it means that more people can invest in South Africa. We seem to be first out of the chute on this one."
The third-highest performer was another of Mr. Brenna's precious-metal funds, called Strategic Silver, which rose 18.95 percent. Mr. Brenna said its strong performance came from the increasing demand for silver from electronic and photographic users at a time when many American mines have been closed. Silver prices have risen recently on heavy buying by Japanese investors, he added.
 
Gains in Financial Services
 After precious metals, financial-services stocks rose the most, up an average of 3.51 percent. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, said stocks of regional banks helped lift these mutual funds.
"Financial-services stocks are benefiting from the recovery," he said, "and the regional banks have been in pretty good shape."
At the bottom end of performance were environmental funds, which fell in value by 7.13 percent, and science and technology funds, which fell by 6.49 percent.
The biggest loser was the Schield: Progressive Environment fund, a $4.1 million fund, which fell by 15.89 percent. "The story is simple," said Glenn S. Cutler, the fund's manager. "Environmental stocks got pounded during this quarter, and that's what we are."
 
Environmental Companies' Plight
 Mr. Cutler said his fund was hurt by disappointing earnings at many environmental companies, and by a switch by investors to other kinds of stocks better poised to benefit from an economic recovery. Among his big holdings are Sanifill, which operates non-hazardous landfills, and Harding Associations, an environmental engineering company.
Another big loser was the Fidelity Select: Computer fund, which was the second-worst performer, with a loss of 15.13 percent. Robert Chow, portfolio manager, said that the computer stocks his fund invested in were "sold off very heavily" and that there was "no place to hide."
Mr. Chow said his stocks were hurt especially by a decline in demand for computers by European buyers as a result of a downturn in demand there.
But for Mr. Chow, the poor showing of his computer fund was nearly offset by the performance of another fund he manages, the Fidelity Select: Paper and Forestry fund, which rose by 13.94 percent, making it the fifth-biggest gainer.
That fund benefited from investor interest in cyclical stocks, with paper companies considered to be well postioned to benefit from an economic upturn.
Mr. Chow added that forestry stocks had been helped by a sharp rise in wood prices because of heavy rainfalls and environmental issues that had limited logging at a time when demand for wood products was increasing.

HEADLINE: Fibreboard Names Chief

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 2

 BODY:
The Fibreboard Corporation said today that it had elected John D.C. Roach chairman, president and chief executive, effectively immediately. Based in Concord, Calif., Fibreboard manufactures lumber, plywood and other building materials, and also owns a ski resort. The company has been the defendant in a long-running series of asbestos suits.
Mr. Roach, 47 years old, succeeds Lawrence C. Hart, who had announced his intent to resign on April 11, and subsequently tendered his resignation on June 18. Mr. Roach joins Fibreboard from the Manville Corporation in Denver, where he was executive vice president as well as president of the mining and minerals group, the Manville Sales Corporation and the fiberglass and specialty products group. He had been chief financial officer. 
 Fibreboard "represents an excellent opportunity for imposing and increasing shareholder value," Mr. Roach said. He said that the company's insulation business was No. 1 in its market, that the wood products division should prosper as the country emerged from the recession, and that Fibreboard had handled a long series of asbestos liability suits well.
Fibreboard said that the experience with asbestos litigation Mr. Roach gained at Manville was a crucial factor in deciding to hire him. along with his experience in the insulation business and the wood products industry.
James F. Miller, one of Fibreboard's four directors, issued a statement that he vigorously opposed the selection of Mr. Roach. "In my opinion, I am the only director who truly represents the shareholders of this business," Mr. Miller said. He could not be reached for further comment and did not explain in the statement why he opposed the choice of Mr. Roach.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Orders to U.S. factories surged 2.9 percent in May, the biggest rise in more than a year, the Commerce Department said. The report seemed to extinguish any hopes that the Fed would cut interest rates again to spur the economy. [Page D1.] Consumers' faith in the present and future health of the economy jumped sharply in June, a survey on consumer sentiment showed. [D2.] 
 Telephone company officials and Federal investigators are befuddled by a string of nearly identical telephone breakdowns around the country. [A1.]
Gold-oriented mutual funds greatly outpaced the stock market from April to June, making them one of the few bright spots among mutual funds investing primarily in common stocks. [D1.]
For stock managers the challenge of the second quarter turned out to be holding on to the gains of the first quarter. [D2.]
Foreigners invested much less in the U.S. last year than in previous years, according to Commerce Department figures. [D3.]
 
Companies
G.M. and a United Automobile Workers union chapter have tentatively agreed to begin near-nonstop assembly operations at G.M.'s Lordstown, Ohio, plant starting next summer. The step would enable G.M. to effectively produce as many cars at one plant as the company can now assemble in two. [D1.]
Apple Computer and I.B.M. are expected as early as today to announce the formation of a strategic alliance. [D1.]
Miller Brewing has stopped debating whether its light beer tastes great or is less filling. A new advertising blitz asserts: "It's it. And that's that." [D1.]
Shell Oil has begun cutbacks that could reduce its work force by as many as 4,650, or 15 percent. [D4.]
Industry experts expressed surprise about A.T.&T.'s announcement stating that it will be allowed to use a favorable accounting method for its merger with NCR. [D17.]
 
International
Oil-producing and consuming countries agreed to continue "a dialogue" that the U.S. has steadfastly opposed. [D4.]
 
Markets
After Monday's big run-up, stock prices turned mixed. The Dow rose 14.31, to 2,972.72, and the rest of the market gave ground. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in thin trading. [D12.] Yields were down on certificates of deposit and money market accounts for the week. [D15.]
The dollar closed at its highest level against the German mark in 20 months. [D13.] A rally in grain and soybean futures prices stalled after rain fell in some parched areas. [D13.]
 
Technology
The development of a nationwide data network will allow personal computer users to tap sources as large as the Library of Congress or receive electronic newspapers. [D1.]
A simple silicon chip that could allow more auto makers to install air bags for passengers as well as the driver has been developed at Sandia National Laboratories. [D5.]
 
Today's Columns
The costs of screening prospective employees for AIDS exceed the likely savings by companies on insurance, two economists find. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Handleman's deal to buy the assets of a leading competitor has been applauded by Wall Street in the belief that the reduced competition will help the company's earnings. Market Place. [D6.]
The reorganization of the Time Inc. Magazine Company's advertising sales force is a hot topic for the advertising, marketing and media communities. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
New York City Budget Hardly Final

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
When it comes to New York City's bad-news budget, Yogi Berra was wrong: even when it's over, it's not over.
At least, that's what Mayor David N. Dinkins and millions of New Yorkers, who would suffer from service cuts and higher taxes, have to hope. What remains to be seen is whether the blueprint will get better or worse. 
 Most budgets are part wish-list, part worst-case warning. But more than usual, this one is built on uncertainty: revenue estimates that some monitors suggest may be too rosy, and pinched plans for spending that the Mayor hopes to improve. It was passed because it had to be by law and political reality in a city that skirted bankruptcy in 1975.
"I don't think all our decisions are decisions that we can live with over the long haul," said Councilwoman Mary Pinkett of Brooklyn as she voted for the $28.5 billion plan about 7:30 A.M. yesterday. But she said, "We have a responsibility to do that which we were elected to do."
 
Avoiding His Own Worst Ideas
 Just as Mr. Dinkins hoped never to adopt a budget that contained all the gloomy ideas he proposed in May -- and by the time it was finally passed, a bit of the gloom had lifted -- so he now hopes to avoid carrying out the worst of what remains, including 10,000 layoffs.
To do so, he will need concessions on wages or benefits by the municipal unions to which the Mayor granted recent raises, and help from the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was set up to help borrow money to bail the city out in the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. But there are no guarantees.
"Of course it's not over," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. This time, he has tied hundreds of millions of dollars in potential aid to proof by the city that it is willing to cut costs permanently.
For Mr. Rohatyn, and the Mayor, that proof means obtaining give-backs from the workers' unions that pounded the pavement for Mr. Dinkins's election. In some senses, Mr. Dinkins is not in a bad bargaining position, since the main city union, facing great pressure to restore whatever jobs it can, can do so through concessions.
But not all unions have equal incentive: for example, no police officers are being laid off, in keeping with the Mayor's big expansion plans for the force. And even if many workers return to the payroll, the cost would be tremendous disruption in the lives of some of the city's poorest-paid employees and the poorest people they are supposed to serve. Workers just keeping their heads above water in a civil service system that has been the route to middle-class life for generations of New Yorkers would find themselves back on welfare rolls.
In the end, it would be hard for the average citizen to understand why it could not have all been worked out sooner and more sensibly, through better planning, quicker cost-cutting, more aggressive attrition and smaller raises -- even in a collapsing economy.
"I don't think anybody wins in this budget," said Penelope W. Pi-Sunyer of the City Project, a nonprofit coalition of social-service and community groups. "I think the Mayor lost from the moment he put out his executive budget, because he lost union support and he lost advocate-group support." She said the attitude of protesters on the steps of City Hall during the negotiations was "one of despair."
In a budget so big -- the fourth largest in the nation after those of the Federal Government, California and New York State -- it is hard to remember that the pieces and the politics are often so small. Not everyone lost. The firefighters' union, which ran an open bar from the trunk of a car in the City Hall parking lot, plying Council members with food and drink, kept 245 chief's aides' jobs -- drivers who help coordinate operations at fire scenes -- that the Council had proposed to cut.
As Council members debated a point in the wee hours, an irate citizen stood up and shouted that they should be ashamed, that they had no business doing business in the middle of the night. Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan of Staten Island replied without a hint of irony: "This isn't business! This is legislation."
Whatever happens, Mr. Dinkins has vowed to avoid letting binding powers over the city's spending return to the State Financial Control Board. It has an oversight role since the recovery from the last crisis, but could resume control if the city's budget went out of balance.
The Mayor never misses a chance to note that the city remains the ward of a state government that is at least as fiscally frazzled but much less second-guessed. If the city's leaders needed any reminder of that legacy, they found one as City Council members wrangled over last-minute details Monday night. An aide found a 16-year-old memo, crumpled in a member's desk. It warned all members to stand by for a vote on the creation of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
To insure the city's independence and to try to fix some of the problems that contributed to the current crisis, the Mayor has proposed a joint city-state commission to recommend ways to realign their complex taxing and spending responsibilities.
As Manhattan Borough President, Mr. Dinkins produced a number of reports by special commissions, recommending thoughtful ways the city could better handle the needs of the homeless and children, reports he once cited constantly but whose prescriptions he mentions less often now.
The Mayor and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo are still warily reviewing just what form the new commission should take, or whether it should be a commission or a more informal effort. They might be thinking of a bit of British doggerel that ran decades ago in the magazine "Punch":
"If you're pestered by critics and hounded by faction
To take some precipitate, positive action
The proper procedure, to take my advice is
Appoint a commission and stave off the crisis."

HEADLINE: Back Manipulation Gains Respectability

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED by a lack of good treatments for back pain, doctors are turning to a therapy they have long dismissed as chiropractic quackery: spinal manipulation.
The American Association of Orthopedic Surgeons this year for the first time included a symposium on back manipulation at its meeting and, in a show of hands, almost a third of the 1,000-member audience bashfully admitted that they had referred patients for the technique. 
 "No question, manipulation is more accepted," said Dr. Scott Haldeman, a neurologist who is also a chiropractor. "Ten years ago if you practiced manipulation, you were a quack; you couldn't get published and were never invited to meetings. Now I can't keep up with the invitations."
This year's edition of the major textbook on backs, "The Adult Spine," contains its first chapter on manipulation therapy. But perhaps the most convincing sign that the therapy is moving center stage is that researchers at the Rand Corporation, who have studied the medical utility of coronary bypass surgery and hysterectomies, have recently turned their attention to spinal manipulation. And to their surprise, early studies indicate that the technique holds up well.
In a report being made public this week, a panel of medical experts assembled by Rand to review the medical literature concluded that manipulation was appropriate for patients with certain types of low back pain. The best candidates were patients whose pain had lasted less than three weeks, who had no signs of spinal nerve damage and whose spines appeared to be normal in X-rays. In studies, patients in this group had significant relief after manipulation and were able to return to work sooner than similar patients treated with conventional methods.
"I was surprised at how much agreement there was on when manipulation was appropriate and surprised at the interest on the part of the orthopedists," said Dr. Paul G. Shekelle, an internist, who is leading the Rand project. At one time, he said, he would never have sent a patient to a chiropractor, but he now does so on occasion.
Dr. John Frymoyer, director of the McClure Musculoskeletal Research Center at the University of Vermont, says that a growing number of doctors practice manipulation themselves or, more commonly, refer patients to other professionals who are skilled in the technique, from chiropractors to physical therapists.
Dr. Nortin Hadler, a professor of rheumatology at the University of North Carolina Medical School at Chapel Hill, describing himself as "a cantankerous doctor who would have never dealt with manipulation in the past," said, "It's not mainstream, but it has become acceptable to talk about because some of us establishment figures have become interested."
 
Restoring Normal Mobility
 Today, most hands-on back therapy is done by chiropractors, who believe that back pain and a number of other maladies can be treated by manipulation, the physical movement of joints past their normal range of motion. In their view, manipulation relieves aching backs because it restores normal mobility to vertebral joints that are abnormally stiff, altering the function of adjacent muscles and nerves.
While few doctors accept the whole of chiropractic doctrine and remain skeptical of chiropractic explanations, a growing number of physicians have turned to chiropractors for their hands-on skills.
"Chiropractors, who used to be ostracized, are now invited into major hospitals, H.M.O.'s and practices," Dr. Haldeman said.'
Dr. Louis Sportelli, past president of the American Chiropractic Association, said two decades ago he could not get doctors to accept his phone calls; today, he said, new surgeons in town invite him to lunch and he often "co-manages" patients with neurosurgeons or orthopedists.
"Until a few years ago they were still buying into the A.M.A. effort to eliminate chiropractors," he said. "Now, there's no stigma attached to referring people to us." Until recently, the American Medical Association held that it was unethical for a doctor to associate with a chiropractor.
As acceptance of manipulation has spread, physical therapists, osteopaths and even conventional doctors are offering a service once shunned. Traditional osteopathic doctors learned manipulation, but that waned in recent decades as they took on mainstream medical jobs.
When Dr. Stanley Paris, a physical therapist, joined the Boston University faculty two decades ago, the university forbade him to practice, teach or write about the manipulation technique he had learned in his native New Zealand.
He now lectures at major hospitals across the country, and at his private Institute of Graduate Physical Therapy in St. Augustine, Fla., he trains 2,000 physical therapists to manipulate backs each year.
 
An Ancient Therapy
 Spinal manipulation to treat back pain dates to Hippocrates and was widely practiced by American doctors until the last century, when, in the name of science, it fell out of favor. Overseas, some medical doctors continued the practice.
"Now after years of trying to discredit it, people in this country are saying maybe there's something there," Dr. Shekelle said.
The current spate of interest started 10 years ago when reports began to appear in conventional medical journals showing that manipulation held some promise. Four years ago, Dr. Hadler and Dr. Peter Curtis conducted a tightly controlled study "designed to prove it didn't work," said Dr. Hadler.
The researchers found that for patients with less than two weeks of pain, manipulation did not make a difference. But for people whose pain had persisted for two to four weeks, a single manipulation produced significant relief and allowed patients to return to activity four sooner on average. Their findings were reported in the journal Spine. Other studies have since confirmed and expanded the results.
"For acute back pain the general drift from all these trials is that there's a short-term benefit for people who get manipulation that lasts three to six weeks," said Dr. Shekelle. Although some of the studies have design problems, he added, "The control group never does better."
"There are a lot more good studies on this than on other things doctors accept and do all the time," said Dr. Robert Brook, a leader of the Rand group.
The mainstream doctors' interest is as much a sign of their frustration in treating backs as it is a tribute to the the chiropractors' success. Although a badly damaged spine can be diagnosed with magnetic resonance imaging and treated with surgery, most acute low back pain produces no detectable findings on X-rays or in traditional medical examinations. The patient just hurts.
Back rest, exercises and pain killers can generally get the patient through the acute episode, and about 80 percent of back pain goes away on its own in two weeks. But for some patients the pain lingers, and they miss work as they wait for their backs to recover. Back pain is the major cause of lost work days.
"If manipulation could be used for symptom control so the patient can be mobilized sooner that would be beneficial," said Dr. Stanley Bigos, an orthopedic surgeon at the University of Washington, who said he would wait for the results of more studies before recommending treatment.
But others are taking tentative steps. "Patients say it helps and there are a lot of thriving chiropractors out there, so obviously they are doing something patients like," said Dr. Vert Mooney a back specialist at the University of California at San Diego, who refers patients to physical therapists who incorporate manipulation into their care. In this country, twice as many patients suffering from back pain go to chiropractors as go to traditional physicians.
Experts emphasize that manipulation should be used as part of a program that includes back exercises and medicine, if needed.
Nonetheless, the truce between these formerly warring parties remains uneasy. Physicians are troubled by the lack of a scientific explanation for why the therapy helps.
At the Rand consensus panel, which included medical doctors, osteopaths and chiropractors, the group was able to agree on a number types of patients who could benefit from manipulation and a number of patients for whom manipulation would be fruitless or even dangerous. This latter group included patients with neurological symptoms, like weakness or numbness in a leg, and patients who had not had any radiological tests, like X-rays or scans of the bones of the spine.
But there was also a "a large gray area," of patients about whom the panel members could not agree. For example, the chiropractors felt that patients should continue maintenance manipulation after their symptoms had gone away, while the medical doctors felt there was no role for therapy once the pain had dispersed. The panel could also not reach a conclusion about whether chronic back pain was amenable to manipulation or how many treatments were necessary.
Most studies have looked only at the effect of a few treatments over a period of weeks, but new studies suggest that treatments may have long-term benefits.
Because of the divergent traditions, many medical doctors say they prefer to refer back patients to physical therapists or other physicians. "It's a fact of life that we have to cooperate with chiropractors and we're tolerating each other much better these days," Dr. Mooney said. "But there is still no great affection and trust."
At the orthopedists' symposium on manipulation, one back expert was loudly applauded after urging doctors to resist chiropractors who performed fake treatments to treat sham diagnoses. Many doctors have been comforted by the realization that "you can accept the laying on of hands without accepting the whole culture of this other profession," said Dr. Frymoyer, who was chairman of the meeting.
But Dr. Shekelle says chiropractors are a diverse group and that most today no longer make lavish claims about the curative potential of manipulation. "There are some chiropractors who never do X-rays and don't try to diagnose the cause of back pain, and I would be uncomfortable dealing with them," he said. "But there are others who I can sit down with and feel like I'm talking to another doctor."
Experts say the field of chiropractic has become more scientific in the past decade. "Chiropractic scientists are scrutinizing their own profession and finding they don't have the research to justify treatment of things like diabetes and cancer, which manipulation has never really been shown help," said Dr. Haldeman.
Many recent research on manipulation, including the Rand study, have been financed in part by chiropractic groups. "They took a big risk," said Dr. Shekelle. "It's turned out that some manipulations are worthwhile and some not, just like lots of medical practices."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A New Operating Head Of Sumitomo Trust Unit

 BODY:
Hiromasa Yakushiji, the new head of the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company's operations in North and South America, faces a double challenge: improving Sumitomo Trust's lowered credit ratings while contending with a sluggish real estate market.
Mr. Yakushiji, 47, has been named director and general manager of business planning for the Americas after 25 years with the Osaka-based commercial bank. Sumitomo Trust, one of the world's major banks, is separate from the Sumitomo Bank Ltd., which is even larger than Sumitomo Trust. 
 Mr. Yakushiji was also named chairman of the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company (U.S.A.), the company's New York-based trust banking subsidiary, and was elected to the parent company's board.
Mr. Yakushiji, who had been general manager of the bank's New York branch, replaces Kaneaki Hori, who has been named president of Sumitomo Trust's Sumishin Credit Card Company subsidiary.
Two months ago, Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered the senior debt rating of Sumitomo Trust to A-1, from Aa-2, and the Standard & Poor's Corporation in February lowered Sumitomo Trust's long-term debt rating to AA-, from AA. Mr. Yakushiji yesterday called the lowered ratings disappointing, but he added that Sumitomo Trust would not alter its business practices merely to please the ratings agencies.
"It is difficult to accept such a tough downgrade," Mr. Yakushiji said. "We lost some of our ratings even while we were showing stronger and stronger performances."
Those strong performances did not come from real estate lending problems, which have hurt Sumitomo Trust. Despite the difficulties, Mr. Yakushiji said, Sumitomo Trust remains committed to real estate.
"We have not stopped real estate transactions at all," he said. "If we can find good deals, we want to do them."
Mr. Yakushiji said that Sumitomo Trust would stay with its historic businesses, exercising caution because of the uncertain economic climate. "Being one of the foreign banks here, we have made it clear that we are not seeking any retail banking here," he said. "We are a wholesale bank."
A native of Tokyo, Mr. Yakushiji holds a degree in economics from Keio University. He said he joined Sumitomo Trust right after leaving college in 1966, adding with a laugh, "I haven't changed my job yet." He and his wife, Hiromi, live in Scarsdale, N.Y., and have two children.

HEADLINE: South Korean Leader Begins Visit to U.S. by Meeting Bush

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
President Bush met with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea today for talks on Seoul's role as an emerging Pacific economic power and the growing prospect of political and military changes in North Korea.
North Korea is said to be within a few years of producing nuclear weapons even as its estrangement from South Korea and the West shows signs of collapsing under the wave of changes sweeping the Communist world. 
 South Korean and American officials have sought for months to slow the nuclear program while speeding the diplomatic changes, and Mr. Roh's two-day stop here -- the first official state visit by a South Korean leader in 25 years -- will review that effort.
At a 40-minute meeting that was more ceremony than substance, Mr. Roh told Mr. Bush that he hopes that the two Koreas can be rejoined by the turn of the century. A senior Korean official, speaking on condition of anonymity, later asserted that that goal is "certainly" attainable in light of North Korea's growing economic problems and the prospect that the architect of the nation's hard-line policies, 79-year-old Kim Il Sung, is in poor health and could soon die.
 
'When Korea Is Made Whole'
 In welcoming remarks at the White House, Mr. Bush said that lasting peace will come to Korea "only when Korea is made whole."
Administration and Korean officials later said that the two men talked largely about South Korea's military and economic role in Asia and their concerns about North Korea's weapons programs.
The senior South Korean official later said the North's nuclear and chemical-weapons programs were matters of "grave concern" that must be remedied before relations can significantly improve.
North Korea said last month that it would allow international inspection of its nuclear sites, dropping a longstanding demand that the United States first remove all nuclear arms from South Korean soil. But it lagged in agreeing to an inspection schedule, saying the United States should simultaneously allow inspection of any nuclear arms it maintains in the South.
 
U.S. Rejects Arms Inspection
 The United States and South Korea have rejected that demand, and officially, the Pentagon neither confirms nor denies that any nuclear arms are in South Korea. But news accounts in Japan and elsewhere have said the South Koreans favor the withdrawal of American weapons if that will help stop North Korea's arms program.
Both Administration and South Korean officials refused today to say whether that issue arose in today's meetings. Mr. Roh and other South Korean officials are to have lengthy talks about the North Korean nuclear program and South Korean defense policy on Wednesday with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other Pentagon officials.
As part of an agreement for South Korea to assume greater responsibility for its own defense, the United States has begun a slow reduction of the 43,000 American troops stationed in the South, removing about 7,000 this year, with more scheduled to be withdrawn in the future. Pentagon officials said today that the command of forces in South Korea could be shifted next year from American officers to South Koreans.
 
Changes in U.S. Role
 Mr. Roh's visit comes amid major changes in Washington's old role as Seoul's military guardian and economic benefactor.
South Korea's economy has boomed in the last decade, growing at double-digit rates during much of the 1980's and achieving a $7-billion-a-year trade surplus with the United States.
Although most of today's talks were devoted to strategic issues, the restrictive trade policies that have helped amass that surplus remain a "serious concern," a senior Bush Administration official said this week, and were to be raised during Mr. Roh's visit.
The United States wants South Korea to lower barriers to the import of farm goods, protect the secrecy of foreign patents and allow American banks and other financial institutions to make larger investments.
Although no formal agreements were expected to emerge from this visit, President Roh told Mr. Bush today that he supports "as free a trading regime, as liberal terms for trade as possible," the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs, Richard Solomon, said today.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
Weicker Loses Again in His Bid For Income Tax for Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 2

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s attempt to impose the first income tax ever in Connecticut went down to defeat today -- again -- whn the Senate killed an exhaustively negotiated tax plan.
The rejection meant that the Governor, an independent, had come up short for now in his effort to force a restructuring of Connecticut's tax system through a legislature in which he has no natural political allies. He was thwarted even though, at dawn today, he had carried out his greatest threat: to begin shutting down state offices. 
 For a few hours, a tax plan that met with the Governor's approval had been alive. That plan, passed in the House at 4:15 A.M. by a vote of 76 to 72, balanced a budget for the fiscal year, which began on Monday, by adopting a tax on wages while reducing the state's high sales and corporate taxes.
 
Regret, Annoyance and Anger
 But in late afternoon the Senate, with a mixture of regret, annoyance and anger, voted 23 to 12 to kill an income tax plan that its own members had devised and that they accused the House of corrupting.
The Senate vote promised two consequences: It set off a scramble for vetoes and overrides aimed at reviving a resolution that would provide money to keep the government running temporarily and send nearly all state employees back to work. But the vote also left the General Assembly, controlled by Democrats in both houses, with almost no idea where to turn.
Across Connecticut, state workers awoke, like schoolchildren waking to news of snow, to radio broadcasts announcing that Mr. Weicker had acted at 5 A.M., issuing an order to close state offices deemed nonessential to the public's safety, health and welfare.
 
Closing Notices Posted

 The workers deluged an emergency telephone hot line to learn whether they should report for work or were among the 7,000 ordered to stay home.
Those who went directly to their offices found photocopied notices taped to locked doors, as at the Office of Policy and Management on Washington Avenue, two blocks from the Capitol:
"This notice will confirm that you have been told not to come to work today. This office is closed due to a lack of a state budget, in accordance with the Governor's Executive Order."
As the day went on the state prepared to close all its parks and beaches by sundown, and as many as 13,000 more employees were to be furloughed on Wednesday. Thousands of residents called the hot line, asking if Motor Vehicle Department offices were operating (today, but not Wednesday), if welfare checks were being mailed (yes), and if banks were open (yes, even if the Banking Department was closed.)
And so Connecticut found itself, for the first time this century, without a budget on the second day of its new fiscal year. Two budgets balanced without an income tax have been killed by Mr. Weicker, who insists the tax is needed to smooth the state's boom-and-bust budget cycles. Two budgets balanced with income taxes have been killed by legislators whose constituents, when it comes to taxes, still fancy themselves Connecticut Yankees.
Perhaps more important, a sense of betrayal stained the bipartisan cooperation that has marked this unusual year, when Mr. Weicker, as an independent governor, has had no party of his own.
Republicans, who wanted to beard a powerful income-tax with a constitutional amendment limiting the growth of state spending, were especially angry at Democrats' efforts in this tax bill to begin exempting various kinds of spending.
"We've spent a lot of time on how to raise taxes, and very little on how to cut spending," said Senator Louis C. Deluca, a Republican from Woodbury.
The budget and tax plan that died today was built around a 4.75 percent tax on all income over $12,000 a year for individuals and $24,000 for couples; the exemption would shrink for taxpayers with higher incomes, disappearing entirely for couples with incomes over $96,000. One percentage point of the tax was to go toward paying off this year's $940 million budget deficit and would be eliminated in 1995.
The plan also reduced the state's workhorse 8 percent sales tax to 6 percent in an effort to make Connecticut's tax system both less regressive and less dependent on the tax, and gradually eliminated a 20 percent surcharge on corporate taxes.
 
Aimed at Middle Class
 But Republicans complained that the plan also extended the sales tax to many previously untaxed goods and services and that the relatively flat nature of the income tax aimed it squarely at the middle class. For some wealthy investors whose income comes from dividends and interest, taxed now at a top rate of 14 percent, the income tax could amount to a tax cut.
To Mr. Weicker, however, the plan met his goals. And not following through in the Senate could cost taxpayers dearly, he said. If the tax were killed and both houses resorted to a temporary budget resolution, they would also kill $340 million in raises and pension payments that unions had agreed to defer in return for no-layoff pledges.
Hundreds of union members rallied around the back steps of the Capitol today and then filled the Senate galleries to support income-tax advocates, while union officials went to court to seek an injunction against the furloughs. The unions had offered the concessions in return for the state adopting a more recession-proof source of revenue: an income tax.
 
Need for Long-Term Solutions
 "I know the Governor has his reasons for sorting out this mess as quickly as possible," said Daniel Perry of Hartford, a supervisor at the Department of Labor whose department was closed today. "But if he can't do it without hurting substantial numbers of people, maybe he should consider more long-term solutions."
In a room deep within the state armory next to the Capitol, more than 20 volunteers answered telephones that rang steadily with calls from employees and residents.
 People needing welfare benefits were told to apply at their town offices, the first step in any case. Those who could not get to motor-vehicle offices before they closed this afternoon were assured that the state police were being asked to give a break to motorists with just-expired registrations.
With parks closing at sundown, two days before a long holiday weekend, campers were perplexed at being told to leave.
"Right at their moneymaking peak, they're going to close down?" asked Edward T. Buggie of Hebron after bicyling to the park offices at Rocky Neck State Park just before 8 A.M. "It seems like pure manipulation of the public."
At the Hamden branch of the Department of Motor Vehicles, a sense of panic grew in the long lines as employees began announcing that the office would close three hours early to prepare for a possible shutdown on Wednesday.
"If I don't have a license, I can't drive, and if I can't drive, I can't work," said 40-year-old Bob Sachse of Wallingford, a bus driver for Peter Pan Bus Lines.
At 12:45 P.M., when the state told branches that they would be closed, employees began letting people in only a few at a time, so they could close in plenty of time to count money that would have to be deposited in banks tonight.
"We usually do it tomorrow morning," said the Hamden branch manager, Jack Molia. "But we don't know if there is a tomorrow."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 4, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Connecticut budget crisis misidentified the manager of the Department of Motor Vehicles branch in Hamden. He is Jack Melia.

HEADLINE: Consumer Rates;
Yields of Money Market Funds Up Slightly

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up slightly for the week ended yesterday.
Tax-exempt money fund yields, up slighly for the week, show the average number of days to maturity of securities held in portfolios rising to 51, from 45. The large jump in average days underlines the efforts by fund managers to keep yields up by buying securities with longer maturities. 
 Analysts said total assets of tax-exempt funds fell $787.3 million, to $87.2 billion.
The seven-day average tax-exempt compounded yield was up 2 basis points, to 3.93 percent, while the simple yield rose a basis point, to 3.85 percent. During the same period the compounded and simple 30-day yields each rose by 2 basis points, to 3.85 percent and 3.78 percent, respectively. Some of the rise in yields is attributed to the supply of new issues, analysts said.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket the taxable equivalent of the current seven-day compounded yield is 5.45 percent, while the equivalent in the 31 percent tax bracket is 5.69 percent.
Of the funds monitored by IBC/ Donoghue's with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, which buys a fair amount of paper that for some investors is subject to the Federal alternative minimum tax, continues to be the best performer as it has for two months. The fund is distributed by Strong/Cornelison Capital Management Inc.; the return was 5.05 percent, unchanged from the previous week.
Assets of taxable funds fell by $5.03 billion, for a total of $444.4 billion. Institutional funds lost $2.9 billion, for a total of $106.9 billion, while assets of the consumer funds lost $2.4 billion, to a total of $337.6 billion. Since yields are still very low, there is some speculation that investors are going elsewhere in the money markets for higher yields.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield rose by 2 basis points, to 5.65 percent, and the seven-day simple yield was also up 2 basis points, to 5.50 percent. The 30-day compounded yield was unchanged at 5.64 percent as was the seven-day simple yield, which remained at 5.49 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return for the fourth consecutive week was Olde Premium Money Market Series, with a yield of 6.42 percent. The fund's distributor is the Olde Discount Corporation of Detroit.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds, were down a basis point, to 5.26 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.
