HEADLINE: 'Junk Bond' Funds Show Strength

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
A revival of the high-risk "junk bond" market pushed up the value of high-yield fixed-income funds in the second quarter of this year and made them the star performers among all bond mutual funds.
New figures by Lipper Analytical Services Inc. also show that a rise in interest rates from April to June lifted 93 percent of all bond funds.
The average return for all taxable bond funds was 2.05 percent. And junk-bond funds rose by 6.54 percent. 
 But at the other end of the spectrum, the rise in interest rates pushed down funds that invested in long-term securities, particularly target maturity funds, which invest in bonds that are redeemable up to 30 years from now. These funds fell in value by four-tenths of 1 percent. A rise in the dollar also pushed down the value of world income funds, which slipped by two-hundredths of 1 percent.
 
'Still Coming Back'
 After having nearly collapsed in the last several years, junk-bond prices have recently been rising, and this recovery was reflected in returns from mutual funds that invest only in these bonds.
Of the 25 top-performing bond funds last quarter, 24 were high-yield funds.
"High-yield funds were the best of all funds and they are still coming back in terms of price action," said A. Michael Lipper, the president of Lipper Analytical, the Summit, N.J. mutual-fund research firm.
The market is so strong partly because many companies that issued junk bonds have lightened their debt burdens, thus increasing their financial well-being. What is more, the improving economy has been easing fears that many companies with high debt in the form of junk bonds would default. And since few new junk bonds are being issued, there is a limited supply for investors seeking securities with high returns.
Lipper said the leading performer was the American Investors Income Fund, a $10 million mutual fund based in Greenwich, Conn. Warren K. Greene, the president of the fund, said many of his bonds that had been trading as low as 50 cents on the dollar as recently as December were now valued at par. And his fund, which rose by 12.76 percent, was also helped by the conversion of one of its convertible bonds into stock at a favorable price.
"One of the bullish things about this market is that the supply of bonds is limited," Mr. Greene said. But as a result of the turnaround in prices in the junk-bond market, yields have been falling somewhat -- from as much as 30 percent at the beginning of the year to about 13 percent to 15 percent today, he added.
Thomas O. Dial, the portfolio manager of the $370 million National Bond Fund, a junk-bond fund that came in second with a return of 11.58 percent, said the market perception had changed on bonds that six months ago were discounted to "really ridiculously cheap levels."
Among the larger holdings in Mr. Dial's fund are the bonds of Owens-Illinois, Dr Pepper/Seven Up, and the Hospital Corporation of America.
Mr. Dial warned, however, that too much euphoria might be seeping into the market. "Before, people were looking at everything that could go wrong" with junk bonds, he said. "Now, they are discounting risks that are really in the market."
Among the worst performers were funds that invest in long-term bonds, which tend to be more volatile and whose prices have fallen sharply as rates have climbed.
 
'Extremely Volatile'
 David Schroeder, the portfolio manager of the Benham 2020 fund, which has $93 million invested in fixed-maturity Government zero-coupon bonds, said that "when rates rise, our funds will be at the bottom, and when they fall, we're at the top."
Other Benham funds that fared poorly were similar funds but with different maturity dates -- the 2015 fund and the 2010 fund. Mr. Schoeder described these funds as "extremely volatile" because they are zero-coupon securities.

HEADLINE: End of Slump Forecast For Industrial World

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: PARIS, July 3

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicted today that the industrial world's economic slowdown would end in the second half of this year, led by a recovery in the United States.
The O.E.C.D., a group of 24 industrial nations that promotes economic growth, added that the rebound would be modest and would not be strong enough to reduce unemployment in most of the industrial world. 
 In its semiannual economic outlook, the Paris-based organization said it "expects a moderate pickup in the second half of the year, led by upturns in some of those countries now in recession, in particular the United States."
The group's economists said the American economy would grow by 2.7 percent in the second half of this year and 3.3 percent for all of 1992. That compares with a 1.8 percent drop in output in the first half of 1991.
 
Less Robust U.S. Recovery
 The O.E.C.D. said the American recovery would be less robust than previous ones because the nation's banks might not expand their lending enough to fuel a strong recovery.
According to the O.E.C.D., whose sophisticated computer models and economic projections are widely respected, the slowdown will end because of a rebound of confidence after the Persian Gulf war and lower interest rates in countries experiencing recession. The United States, Britain, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Finland and Sweden have all been in recession in recent months, the group said.
The O.E.C.D. report said the robust growth that Japan and Germany enjoyed last year would slow this year because of their tight monetary policies. The report added that the current-account imbalances of the United States, Japan and Germany were all decreasing.
The group said the American current-account deficit would fall from $99.3 billion last year to $8.7 billion this year, partly because of the financial aid that Japan, Germany and other countries have given Washington to pay for the gulf war. The O.E.C.D. expects America's current-account deficit to rise to $58 billion next year.
 
Risk in Dollar's Surge
 The report said the dollar's recent surge against other currencies carried a risk that the reduction of the American trade deficit "may stall or even be reversed through a deterioration of U.S. competitiveness."
In its first-ever projections for Eastern Europe, the group said that in the Soviet Union, output would fall by 8 percent this year and hyperinflation had "become a serious danger." It prediced that all of Eastern Europe, except Poland, would be in recession this year, projecting a 2 percent increase in output in Poland, a 9 percent drop in Czechoslovakia and a 3 percent drop in Hungary.
The unemployment rate for the O.E.C.D.'s 24 members would average 7 percent next year, with Western Europe's rate stabilizing at 9 percent. "Unemployment, which is high and rising in many countries, may not decline much in the coming recovery period," the report said.
 
U.S Unemployment Estimated
 The report projected that American unemployment would be 6.3 percent next year, down from the 6.7 percent expected in the second half of 1991, but up from last year's 5.5 percent.
Noting that the Federal Reserve has substantially relaxed monetary policy since late 1990, the O.E.C.D. said the American "expansion is expected to be led initially by consumer expenditure, but by the end of the year it should be sustained by the monetary stimulus that had been put in place."
Warning that inflationary pressures could again build up, the report said that given the shallowness of the recession, there would be only mild downward pressure on American inflation. It projected American inflation of 4 percent this year, compared with 4.1 percent last year. The O.E.C.D. sees the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in late 1992 to counter inflation.
"It is assumed that the Federal Reserve will begin to shift to a less accommodating stance late in 1992 in order to head off renewed inflationary pressures, although the macroeconomic effects of this would appear only in 1992," the report said.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Fell 3.3% in May

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
The Government today reported a surprising drop in new-home sales in May, raising questions about the strength of the housing recovery and sending builders and bankers scrambling for explanations.
The Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell 3.3 percent in May, contrary to economists' expectations of a 2.3 percent rise. Furthermore, April sales were revised downward to a drop of two-tenths of a percent, instead of the 1.2 percent gain originally reported. 
 Other recent economic reports, including higher factory orders, more construction starts and higher personal incomes in May, have indicated that the recession that began last July is ending.
 
Bottom Seen in January
 The building industry insists that the market for home sales bottomed out in January, when sales fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 414,000 units.
Sales bounced back in February, gaining 17.9 percent, and rose six-tenths of a percent in March before the back-to-back declines in April and May. Even so, sales in May reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 474,000 -- 14 percent higher than in January.
"I'm betting this is not a double-dip phenomenon for the housing market," said Dave Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, referring to the chance that sales might begin falling again, as they did during most of 1990.
"We believe that the low was in fact January, and we're moving along as expected in an erratic but upward-trending market," Mr. Seiders said, adding that he expected new-home sales to reach 520,000 in 1991. That would still be weaker than in 1990, when sales totaled 534,000.
Decline Was Widespread
The drop in May sales was widespread, led by a 13 percent decline in the South, to an annual rate of 187,000 units. In the Northeast, sales fell 6.7 percent, to a rate of 56,000. Sales in the West were down eight-tenths of a percent, to an annual rate of 125,000.
The only region where sales rose was in the Midwest. Sales there were up 21.6 percent, to an annual rate of 107,000 units.
The actual number of new homes sold in May was 44,000, down from 49,000 in April and 50,000 in May 1990.
The average price of a new home rose to $154,400 in May, from $149,400 in April, while the median sales price rose to $121,900, from $120,000.
Setback Called Temporary
Tom Holloway, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, whose members provide financing for home buyers, said the May sales dip was a temporary setback. Monthly increases should show up in the summer and fall, he said.
"The thing holding the housing market back is simply the sluggishness of the overall economy," Mr. Holloway said. With interest rates for 30-year mortgages at about 9.5 percent, "we believe there are a lot of buyers out there who would take the plunge if they had jobs."
By most measures, including more construction starts and building permits in May, as well as a 6 percent rise in sales of existing homes, housing has already begun to help the economy out of recession.
The National Association of Realtors conceded that it was surprised by the May decline and suggested that the drop stemmed from banks' tighter lending standards.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Modestly Higher

BYLINE: By By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher yesterday in thin trading before the Fourth of July holiday.
A report of a 3.3 percent decline in new home sales during May, the second straight monthly drop, was seen as a catalyst behind the price improvement. 
 The gains held as the session wore on, despite reports from the nation's major auto makers that sales in the last 10 days of June reached 7.4 million units at an adjusted annual rate, a figure that was well above market expectations and was the best 10-day rate since December.
"The car sales numbers should have upset the market, but they didn't," said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., research firm.
 
Employment Data Ahead
 With all American financial markets closed today, yesterday's activity mostly represented last-minute positioning before the Labor Department's scheduled release of June employment data tomorrow morning.
Reports released earlier this week, particularly the June survey of the nation's purchasing managers, have portrayed an economy that seems slightly stronger than anticipated.
But the latest statistics have not caused economists to massage their employment forecasts much. After a surprising increase of 25,000 jobs in May, most economists anticipate that non-farm payroll employment was unchanged to down slightly in June. Estimates range from a decline of 100,000 in payroll jobs to an increase of 75,000. Most analysts anticipate that the unemployment rate, which stood at 6.9 percent in May, will show a bit of an increase.
 
Delayed Reaction?
 Although the employment numbers often determine the tone for trading activity for the balance of each month, reaction to the June employment numbers may be delayed for a few days, traders and analysts said. Many credit market participants are taking Friday off, thereby creating a very long weekend out of the Fourth of July holiday.
"I wonder how many people will be willing to take positions on Friday," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at the Paine Webber Group Inc., "because ultimate buyers and sellers are not likely to be around."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday, the 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 7/8 late in the day, up 7/32, to yield 8.41 percent, down from 8.43 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 13/ 32, up 3/32, to yield 8.23 percent. And the 7 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 2/32, up 1/32, to yield 6.96 percent.
Late in the session, the Treasury announced that it would sell $9 billion worth of seven-year notes on July 10. The size of the offering was roughly in line with market expectations.
 
Movement Into Bills
 Yesterday's sharp slide in stock prices -- the Dow Jones industrial average lost 38.02 points -- helped to push down short-term Treasury bill rates, as investors left stocks and moved funds into more liquid and safe securities like bills.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.54 percent, down a basis point, or one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 4 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.66 percent. And one-year bill rates dipped by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.98 percent.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very light, traders said. Prices of most issues were unchanged to up 1/4 point.
Trading was also slow in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. Prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged, dealers said.

HEADLINE: For King Center in Atlanta, New Leader and New Focus

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 3

 BODY:
The center founded to carry on the work and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. today announced the hiring of a Harvard University administrator as its new executive director, a shift in focus and $1 million in new corporate financing.
Two years after Dr. King's son, Dexter Scott King, was installed amid great fanfare as executive director only to step down four months later, the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change Inc. here named Ronald L. Quincy, associate vice president and assistant to the president of Harvard, as its new executive director. 
 Mr. Quincy will handle daily operations and planning for the center while its founder, Coretta Scott King, Dr. King's widow, stays on as president and chief executive. Mr. Quincy said the move would free Mrs. King to spend more time developing international programs and good will for the center, which was founded in 1968.
The moves come after an 18-month re-examination of the center and its mission. Some critics have questioned whether the center is carrying on Dr. King's work or just preserving his memory.
Mrs. King and the center's chairman, Jesse Hill, stressed today that the center had never strayed from its goal of carrying on Dr. King's teachings and training leaders around the world in the techniques of what they call "Kingian nonviolence." Mrs. King said the center now plans to emphasize "international conflict resolution" and training of leaders around the world in Dr. King's philosophy.
Still, the announcement today reflected some of the fine lines walked by the center. Mrs. King spoke at a lectern adorned with the logos of the Coca-Cola Company and BP America, part of the international energy company, each of which donated $500,000 to the center for its expanded international focus. Both have been criticized by some blacks for maintaining economic activities in South Africa in recent years.
When asked if the shift in emphasis was appropriate at a time of growing despair in black America, Mrs. King said the emphasis on international concerns was in keeping with Dr. King's vision.
"We live more and more in a global village, people of all races and religion," she said. "Martin talked about how we can no longer be separated; we have to live together, find a way to live together as human beings who share so much. If we decided to ignore that, we are still being provincial."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Generally Lower; Concern on Recovery Cited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar retreated against most other major currencies yesterday as a thin pre-holiday market responded to overseas unrest and renewed doubts about the United States economic recovery.
Traders initially sold dollars in reaction to a report showing that United States housing starts were unexpectedly lower. The report said single-family home sales fell 3.3 percent in May, compared with expectations of a 2 percent to 3 percent rise. 
 But the market eventually recouped most of its losses as overseas developments battered the German mark and the Japanese yen.
The dollar strengthened as growing attacks by the Yugoslav Army led some European leaders to take a hard-line approach to the unrest in Yugoslavia.
"What we really see here is there is still a strong underlying sentiment toward the dollar," said Hillel Waxman, head of foreign currency trading for the Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York.
In New York, the dollar ended at 1.8286 German marks, down slightly from 1.8345 late Tuesday. Tuesday's level was the dollar's highest against the mark in 20 months.
In addition, traders sold yen as investor confidence was affected by the second scandal in two weeks involving major Japanese trading companies. On Tuesday, Tokyo prosecutors arrested four executives in connection with a $26 million swindle.
In New York, the dollar closed at 139.58 yen, up from 138.75 late Tuesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar rose by 0.82 yen, to 139.32, and in London, it was quoted at 139.50 yen.
Trading in New York slowed to an afternoon trickle as traders left early for the Fourth of July holiday. United States currency trading will resume tomorrow.
The British pound rose against the dollar, closing at $1.6070 in New York, up from $1.6025 late Tuesday. Earlier, in London, sterling rose to $1.6052, from $1.6020 late Tuesday.
Other dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, were: 1.5793 Swiss francs, down from 1.5815; 6.2015 French francs, down from 6.2125; 1,361.00 Italian lire, down from 1,362.75, and 1.14225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14255.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN YUGOSLAVIA;
WAR IN YUGOSLAVIA FEARED BY BAKER

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that Yugoslavia could be on the brink of "a full-fledged civil war," that its army appeared to be out of the central Government's control and that the United States and its allies were considering imposing an arms embargo on Yugoslavia and suspending all financial assistance.
Mr. Baker also acknowledged a subtle shift in United States policy on Yugoslavia. He spoke to reporters after a meeting on Yugoslavia at the State Department with Hans van den Broek, the Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, which is the current head of the European Community. 
 Mr. Baker emphasized that the United States was prepared to accept any new political configuration that the Yugoslav republics negotiated -- even if it meant changes in the internal and external borders of the country -- provided it was done peacefully through negotiations.
 
A Change of Emphasis
 American policy since May has been open to "any framework, federal, confederal or other" for Yugoslavia's six republics. But Washington had emphasized its preference for maintaining the basic Yugoslav federation and the territorial integrity of the country, while downplaying suggestions for any radical change.
In the last two days Washington has changed its emphasis, telling the Yugoslavs that while the United States still believes continued federation would be in the best long-term economic and political interest of their country, they can reshape however they want, including the creation of independent republics, so long as they do it peacefully.
Mr. Baker was asked if the United States had been too slow in shifting policy, thereby encouraging the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army and central government to believe that it had American backing to use excessive military force to prevent any form of separatism by the republics of Slovenia and Croatia.
"Of course, we categorically reject that," Mr. Baker said. "What we did was to make it very clear that we were concerned that something like this would happen and, indeed, it has. And we warned against unilateral actions which could pre-empt dialogue, pre-empt the opportunities for peaceful negotiations. It's only the Yugoslav people that are going to determine their own future. And our strongly held position is that should be determined through peaceful negotiation and through dialogue."
While the United States is signaling a greater willingness to consider alternatives to the old federal arrangement in Yugoslavia, Mr. Baker continued to stop short of signaling any readiness to recognize the declarations of independence by the republics of Slovenia and Croatia.
Mr. Baker spoke this morning by phone with German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, and officials said he told Mr. Genscher that Bonn was making a mistake in hinting at such recognition now.
Mr. Genscher said Tuesday that the Yugoslav army's effort "to keep its old position of power and to preserve old structures is bound to fail and merely brings bloodshed to the people of Yugoslavia."
Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, a former Ambassador to Yugoslavia, echoed Mr. Baker and Mr. Genscher's assessment that the Yugoslav army now appeared to be out of control.
 
Joint Statement Issued
 "My sense of it is that the Army is, if not out of control, at least not under control," Mr. Eagleburger said in an interview with CNN. "I think they are largely acting on their own. There are some Serbian generals who are basically in charge, and I think they have decided they're going to put this thing to an end. And they are probably acting without the consent of the central government. I think it's foolish, I think it's stupid, I think it's counterproductive, but I'm afraid that's where they are."
Mr. Baker and his guests from the European Community issued a joint statement calling for all military forces in Yugoslavia to return to their barracks, for an immediate cease-fire and an opening of negotiations "to decide their future political arrangements peacefully."
The European Community has internal disagreements on what to do about Yugoslavia, and so the declaration was limited to a simple call for a cease-fire. Germany and Italy have been hinting at supporting the breakaway republics unless the army crackdown ends, while other European Community members are being more cautious.
The Western allies also believe there is little they really can do to stop the fighting short of armed intervention themselves and that is not going to happen, since none of them yet believe that they have enough interests at stake to merit such a move.
 
Arms Embargo Considered
 Said Mr. Eagleburger: "In the last analysis, this is one of those cases, and there are so many of them in foreign policy, where if the parties themselves cannot bring themselves to sit at the negotiating table and find a peaceful solution to the problem, the outside world isn't going to be able to do it for them."
Mr. Baker said the United States and its allies nonethless "should give consideration to the suspending of aid and assistance to Yugoslavia" and mentioned the prospect of an arms embargo.
The United States sells no arms to Yugoslavia, so this would only apply to European countries. The Soviets have been Belgrade's traditional arms suppliers, providing mostly tanks. Slovenia is reported to have obtained weapons from Singapore and on the open market, while Hungary in recent months shipped weapons to the Croatians. Also the United States, which gives Yugoslavia $5 million a year, has already suspended the $1.5 million it has not already dispensed this fiscal year.

HEADLINE: At a Corner Near You: Fireworks

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
Considering that yesterday was the day before the Fourth of July, the sales pitch was hardly a shock. "Bottle rockets!" barked a street peddler named Rob, as he thumbed through a wad of cash, making change for a half-dozen customers. "Roman candles! Sparklers! I got the fireworks, folks! Check 'em out!"
Rob's location, though, was unusual: the corner of 46th Street and the Avenue of the Americas in midtown Manhattan, far from Chinatown, where New York's illegal fireworks dealers have congregated for decades. 
 "This is where the boss, the big boss, sent us," said a tanned young man named Richie, who worked as a lookout (a.k.a. "Hawk") on Rob's three-man fireworks sales team.
 
Dramatic Increase in Vendors
 Sergeant Michael T. Collins, the head of the Fifth Precinct Special Task Force, said the Chinatown area still accounted for 90 to 95 percent of the city's illegal fireworks traffic. But he also said that the number of sellers had been expanding and that, in some cases, vendors have been spotted in other parts of Manhattan.
By early last night, the city had made at least 33 arrests since early June for illegal sales of fireworks. They had also issued 178 summonses and confiscated six cars, $3,000 in cash and 450 cases of various pyrotechnic devices with a street value of more than $100,000.
"We're way over last year's figures," Sergeant Collins said.
But he added that he did not believe more people were buying illegal fireworks. He said increased police efforts, the recession and more competition between dealers had made a dent in the business, which is still predominantly run by Chinese and Italian organized-crime families.
Though the sale of illegal fireworks is generally not considered a serious crime, the devices are considered a significant public safety threat, particularly to minors and particularly when the more powerful explosives like M-80's and cherry bombs are used.
Last year, about 12,000 people nationally were treated for injuries caused by fireworks, according to the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission. About 2,000 of those injuries occurred in around the Fourth of July.

HEADLINE: Shearson Must Pay Investor

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Shearson Lehman Brothers and three stockbrokers were ordered to pay nearly $600,000 to an unemployed plumber's assistant whose account was depleted in risky trading.
A New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel ruled that, among other wrongdoing, a Shearson broker altered a document to make it appear that the customer was an experienced investor when he was not. 
 The panel ordered Shearson to pay $441,240 to the customer, William Tornquist of Staten Island. A broker and two Shearson branch managers were ordered to pay Mr. Tornquist a total of $134,760.
In addition to accusing the broker, Rudolf Dobutovich, of altering the trading questionnaire, Mr. Tornquist also said that Shearson failed to explain the risks of options trading and made numerous trades to generate commissions in a practice known as "churning."
In a statement, Shearson said: "The firm undertook a comprehensive investigation of the matter, and uncovered absolutely no evidence of any wrongdoing whatsoever by a Shearson employee."
Lawrence R. Sandak, Mr. Tornquist's lawyer, said his client had lost more than $634,000 of a $750,000 account. Mr. Tornquist opened the account with the proceeds from the sale of a building.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
Weicker Broadening Shutdowns In Pressing for Fiscal Compromise

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 3

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. expanded the shutdown of Connecticut's government today, turning up the gas still further under the pressure cooker that surrounds the search for a budget compromise with legislative leaders.
About 20,000 state employees were told to stay home, out of a total work force of 48,000. Every state park but three was ordered closed at sundown. 
 Then there was personal pressure: Mr. Weicker, whose ability to work his will with individual state lawmakers one on one has been demonstrated amply in his six months as Governor, began a series of what his office called summit meetings with the party leaders in the General Assembly.
 
The Big Question
 Conducted in Camp David-style seclusion at the Governor's mansion, the meetings were to extend through the holiday and into the weekend, presumably until a middle ground is found or one side or the other blinks on the question of an income tax. Through two budget vetoes and now through the third full day of a new fiscal year with no budget at all, Mr. Weicker has insisted on the tax just as hard as lawmakers have resisted.
It was a day of soft drinks and coats off at the Governor's back porch, according to the cryptic communique issued about the talks' progress, while, across the state, residents registered a mixture of bewilderment, anger and frustration about how and why things could have come to such a pass.
"I've had it," said David G. Benham, a Torrington resident who was evicted from his camping spot by rangers at Rocky Neck State Park on Tuesday, only to find out today that the park was reopening. He came back, even more in need of a vacation than before. "I figure the state owes me money for gas," he said. "And I'm not leaving again."
Mr. Weicker announced what he termed good news this morning at a Capitol news conference that Rocky Neck, in East Lyme, and two other heavily used shoreline parks -- Hammonasset Beach State Park in Madison and Sherwood Island in Westport -- would reain open, using $43,000 in corporate charity to pay for lifeguards and parking-booth clerks.
He had said on Tuesday that he would act immediately on a two-week temporary budget resolution that would set in motion events that could lead to a complete end to the shutdown. But a spokesman, Charles F. J. Morse, announced in a statement just before the news conference today that the decision had been deferred, and Mr. Weicker declined to take questions on it from reporters.
The resolution, already passed by both chambers of the General Assembly, has been on Mr. Weicker's desk since Tuesday. The resolution would put into place a temporary promise to meet all of the state's financial obligations.
 
Public Disagreement
 The Governor had said he would veto that bill, thus allowing the House and the Senate to proceed with an all but certain two-thirds override vote that would put the temporary budget in place over his objections. Under state law he could hold off that process until next Tuesday, five business days after passage, before it would become law without his signature. Or he could veto it any time before that.
In deferring the veto and prolonging the emergency shutdown, Mr. Weicker has publicly disagreed with two of the state's top elected officials -- the Attorney General and the State Comptroller -- both of whom argue that any budget authorization, even a temporary one, is better than the legal and economic limbo of having no budget at all.
Mr. Weicker said again today that a budget extension would be disastrous for the state because it would legally and formally eliminate a $340 million package of wage and benefit concessions negotiated with state employees. By promising to meet all state obligations, the extension would put the state in the position of promising the pay raises and pension payments that unions have said they would defer. It would also set a precedent of budget failure, he said.
But in a legislature that only seems to do anything at all under pressure, the vise that Mr. Weicker has applied to the process may not be entirely unwelcomed by the leaders now meeting with the Governor, some of whom are firm supporters of an income tax and could presumably use the continued shutdown as another means to lean on reluctant members of the rank and file.
And every player in the process seemed ready to raise the stakes today, or at least create that impression. The coalition representing unionized state employees announced, for example, in a terse news release that the state had "walked away" from the union concessions by failing to pass a budget and that "there is no agreement."
Earlier this year, Mr. Weicker presented the group with the choice of accepting either massive layoffs or the concessions. Today a spokesman for the group declined to say that "no agreement" really meant that all bets were entirely off.
"Our point was to clear the air," said the union spokesman, Robert Krzys. "We're still interested in trying to lead out of the crisis, but it's obviously more difficult now."
Within the General Assembly, the question of who might be willing to lead the way out of the crisis that hangs over the holiday "summit" remains something of a mystery. The House of Representatives, for example, has a strong contingent of income tax supporters, including the Speaker, Richard J. Balducci, a Democrat from Newington, and remains the only chamber to have passed an income tax plan.
 
Straddle Districts
 That proposal, a compromise package that featured a more modest income tax than Mr. Weicker had sought, and thus less of a drop in the sales tax, a main plank of the Governor's plan, was killed in the Senate Tuesday afternoon. The Senate has long been regarded as a sort of doomsday chamber for any income tax. The Senate minority leader, M. Adela Eads, Republican of Kent, has been a hard-line opponent, and many of the majority Democrats, including the Senate President John B. Larson, a Democrat from East Hartford, have not been far behind.
Lawmakers say many senators, representing large districts that take in both cities and suburbs, are more likely than House members to have at least some core community of constituents who are vocal against an income tax. In many such straddle districts, taking a position on such an uncomfortable and unpopular issue invariably means offending one group over the other.
But almost all groups will be affected by the park closings. The Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, Timothy R. E. Keeney, said about 250,000 people usually visit the three big seaside parks on a Fourth of July weekend. An additional 250,000 would typically visit the other parks that are being closed.
 
A Select Committee on the Budget
 Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. is meeting with Democratic and Republican leaders of the Connecticut Senate and House of Representatives to come up with a budget and tax plan that can be put to the General Assembly this weekend. Past positions on an income tax are not predictive; legislators who have vehemently opposed some income tax plans say they are willing to consider others.
 
Richard J. Balducci, Democrat, Newington. Speaker of the House. Business owner. Elected to House in 1975. Favors income tax to restructure tax system.
 
Robert F. Frankel, Democrat, Stratford. House majority leader. Lawyer. Elected to House in 1977. Favors income tax to restructure tax system.
 
Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., Republican, Bristol. House minority leader. Lawyer. Elected to House in 1979. Has opposed income-tax plans but does not rule one out.
 
John B. Larson, Democrat, East Hartford. Senate president pro tempore. Insurance agent. Elected to Senate in 1983. Opposes income tax.
 
Cornelius P. O'Leary, Democrat, Windsor Locks. Senate majority leader. Lawyer. Served in House 1973-77. Elected to Senate in 1977. Opposes broad-based income tax; favors tax on higher-income residents.
 
M. Adela Eads, Republican, Kent. Served in House 1977-81. Elected to Senate in 1981. Strongly opposes income tax.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Rescinds Approval of A Malt Liquor

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The Government ordered the G. Heileman Brewing Company yesterday to stop marketing its Power Master malt liquor, whose high alcohol content had brought protests. Heileman, which said it would comply, will be able to sell existing stocks of the beverage for four months.
Heileman had been told earlier in the day that it faced a potential boycott of its top-selling Colt 45 brand if it continued to market Power Master. The company announced that it was agreeing to discontinue the product because of the "economic burden a legal contest would entail." 
 Heileman, based in La Crosse, Wis., has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since January.
 
Alcohol Content of 5.9%
 The decision was viewed as a success by critics of Power Master, which has an alcohol content of 5.9 percent. They had contended that Power Master was aimed at blacks, who suffer disproportionately from alcohol-related illnesses.
The opponents, led by religious leaders from across the country, asserted that Heileman was using the name Power Master to covertly advertise the higher alcohol content in violation of Federal rules. Power Master has 31 percent more alcohol than Colt 45, which has an alcohol content of 4.5 percent.
In addition to the grass-roots campaign, whose leaders included the Rev. Calvin Butts of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, the product was criticized by Surgeon General Antonia Novello, who contended that Heileman was aiming Power Master at young black men.
The controversy reached a fever pitch yesterday, as Heileman executives met with protesters in Chicago and with officials of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. On Tuesday, the bureau ordered the company to stop using the Power Master name. Yesterday, it announced that it had officially withdrawn its earlier approval of the Power Master label and that the company could no longer market the beverage.
But because of the earlier approval, the brewer "will be able to sell existing stocks over the next four months," Stephen E. Higgins, the bureau's director, said in a statement.
 
Earlier Defiance
 The ruling came hours after Heileman executives pledged to continue to market Power Master in the face of a boycott. The Rev. Michael Pfleger, a Roman Catholic priest on the South Side of Chicago and a leader of the protest, met for two hours with Michael Evans, a Heileman vice president, and Randy Smith, the company's general counsel, who traveled to Chicago to answer criticism about the brewery's advertising.
The Heileman executives were told that a boycott of Colt 45 was scheduled to start Friday in 10 cities. After the Government issued its ruling, Heileman conceded.
Power Master is the second product aimed at black consumers to be pulled off the shelves in the last year because of protests about health risks. In 1990, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company abruptly canceled its marketing of Uptown cigarettes.
Opponents said the developments showed that companies could not disregard the concerns of blacks. "This demonstrates to corporations that the black community is taking an activist role in consumer and marketing issues," said Ken Smikle, president of the African American Marketing and Media Association, a trade group.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLES;
To the 'Nonessential,' Weicker's Shutdown Stings

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 3

 BODY:
Everyone in state government is essential, but some are more essential than others.
Connecticut's capital bowed to the Orwellian inevitable when government shut off every service save those deemed vital but not without bringing confusion and anger to its citizens -- and considerably wounded pride to its bureaucrats. Many of the latter, in fact, had trouble recognizing themselves in the unflattering description, "nonessential." 
 "That is a horrible word," said David Dearborn, an employee at the Department of Human Resources, whose services were deemed temporarily expendable on Wednesday. "I prefer to call myself 'not-as-essential.' "
State agencies were not immune from feeling slighted. The Election Enforcement Commission was one that lobbied strenuously to stay open late last week, arguing that its mandate to police voting procedure was absolutely essential. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s aides had to gently explain, "You would be if this were November, but this is July." Employees at the election commission were asked to stay home along with some 20,000 other state workers officially furloughed.
 
Almost Empty State Building
 The result on Wednesday was an antic State House teeming with absolutely essential legislative staffers, budget analysts and computer technicians, and, across Capitol Street in Hartford, an almost empty gray granite State Office Building where only a very few employees of the Consumer Protection Agency and the Environmental Protection Agency as well as other branches of government were needed.
The State Office Building's main doors were sealed shut with yellow "do not enter" ribbon similar to the tape the police use to block off homicide areas. Inside, door after door was shut, desk after desk vacant, while a few essential workers, those who process state revenue checks, huddled along darkened corridors that had the forlorn air of a school building during an epidemic of measles.
Those citizens who phoned in and were lucky enough to have their calls answered by volunteers who went into work, were greeted with the sing-song response, "That person has been furloughed and will be back in his office when the state has a budget."
For many state residents, at least those without Fourth of July plans in 25 closed state parks, or car registrations that expired on July 1, or a sudden yen for a fishing license, the government shutdown was barely noticed. "We can't issue a license today, but we could arrest you tomorrow," is how Wanda Rickerby, of the Environmental Protection Agency, explained the predicament.
 
Court and Lotto Continue
 Don Phee of New Haven went to his local Department of Motor Vehicles to register his car on Wednesday, blithely unaware that the department had been shut down. "I don't have a TV or a radio," he said. "I'm not normal."
State police patrolled the highways, courts stayed open and the lottery, lotto, jai-alai and the tracks, essential sources of revenue if not always matters of life and death, went on as usual. (Only Off-Track Betting was shut down.) Even those not directly affected by the shutdown, however, were disgusted.
"This is the true meaning of politics," said Robert Mattes, 38 years old, of Granby, Conn., who sells computer software to insurance companies. "Politicians push their policies, and shove their employees between a rock and a hard place."
The state's information hot line, a phone bank set up to answer questions about the shutdown, was deluged. Thousands of confused residents wanted to know the latest status of parks, banks, lotto, drivers licenses, welfare checks, unemployment compensation and even whether summer school homework was still due (it was).
 
Outraged Residents
 Many state employees called for more specific information, demanding to know who exactly in their department had judged them "nonessential."
"I just refer them to their commissioner or personnel department," Bruce Bockstael, an architect for the Department of Public Works who volunteered after he was furloughed, said weariliy.
The hot line also became a de facto consumer complaints department as outraged residents unable to get through to their Governor or local representative commandeered volunteers to listen to their indignation.
"I got a whole family yesterday," said Tom Moriarty, one of 24 state employees answering phones. "First the man yelled at me, then he got tired and put his son on, and then the mother took over." The family had been disappointed by the cancellation of a fireworks display.
"What the state considers an essential service, and what people consider essential isn't always the same," said Michele Sullivan, deputy press secretary to the Governor.
 
Government Choices
 Some government choices, however, were not always easy to fathom. The State Psychiatric Security Review Board, which oversees forensic mental patients, stayed open, while the Board of Parole, did not. In that case, as in others, the state's legal liability was as much a part of the decision as the service provided. "The Psychiatric Security Review Board has legal custody of those patients," the Governor's press secretary, Avis Meehan, said. "They are ultimately responsible."
The entire welfare department known in Connecticut as the Department of Income Maintenance, and which had mailed out monthly checks before the shutdown, was closed until next Tuesday. Yet the Bureau of Rehabilitation Services, a branch of the Human Services Department, was able to hold its weekly job training seminar on Tuesday for the handicapped, because 80 percent of its funding is Federal and the state was in danger of losing that support if it shut down that program.
There were other odd twists of administrative fate.
Vincent Diana Jr., a technical systems analyst for the Department of Education who was also furloughed, attended a union rally held in support of an income tax increase on Monday at the Capitol, where, inevitably, the conversation turned to who was essential and who was not. Mr. Diana was surprised to run into a female accountant from his division who was deemed "essential" and remained on the payroll. He recalled that only last spring she had been given a pink slip during a mass layoff plan, which had been forestalled at the last minute by union concessions.
Not all of it makes sense, said Donald Morton, a Labor Department employee who learned he was being furloughed on Tuesday, and noticed that some Department of Transportation maintenance workers were still on the payroll.
"Is cutting grass more essential than what I did?" he asked.
He added pensively, "At least not with all the rain we've been having."

HEADLINE: Records Indicate Company Ignored Warning on Drug

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
The Swiss maker of a widely used sedative was warned by its American affiliate six years before the drug was marketed in the United States that in certain circumstances it could cause life-threatening side-effects, according to internal company documents.
Yet the company, F. Hoffmann-La Roche, went ahead with what the affiliate correctly predicted would be a dangerously concentrated formulation, and more than 40 deaths and about as many injuries resulted. 
 The drug, known as Versed, was designed to replace injectable Valium as its patent expired. The documents, made available to The New York Times by a person who said he was outraged at the company's conduct, include a memorandum from the company's own legal advisers stating that it might have disregarded safety concerns for economic reasons.
 
Company Cites Clinic Trials
 The company denied that it had acted improperly or ignored warnings from its own employees about safety problems. It characterized the initial recognition of safety problems as a preliminary concern that was allayed by additional data. It stated that safety was a concern from the beginning and that the drug passed all its safety and clinical trials without adverse effects.
Max W. Gurtner, the director of corporate information for the company at its headquarters in Basel, Switzerland, and Carolyn R. Glynn, a spokeswoman at the headquarter's of the company's United States affiliate, Hoffman-La Roche Inc., in Nutley, N.J., declined to allow executives to be interviewed but responded with written answers to questions about Versed's development.
Versed (it is pronounced VER-sed) was promoted as a drug to produce conscious sedation, a twilight sleep in which patients are conscious during minor operations, like oral surgery or colonoscopies, but have no memory of the procedure. It could also be used before and during general anesthesia.
 
Problems From Beginning
 But from the time it came on the market in March 1986, doctors had problems with the drug. They wrote to the company and testified at a 1988 Congressional hearing about problems with Versed that it was so concentrated that they could easily give too much. The doctors, as they dripped the drug into patients' veins, said they could quickly overshoot conscious sedation and go straight to unconsciousness or even death.
The company wanted Versed to look like injectable Valium, which meant marketing it in the same concentration as Valium and in the same sort of ampuls, the internal company documents indicated. But Versed was up to four times as potent as Valium, and it left doctors small room for error.
The company documents show that the potential dangers of the concentrated Versed were no surprise to Hoffman-La Roche executives. In 1979 and 1980, Dr. Ronald Kuntzman, a vice president for pharmaceutical research and development at Hoffman-La Roche in Nutley, supported by a group of researchers and administrators, urged officials at the concern's headquarters in Basel to use a less concentrated form of the drug. But his concerns were overruled.
In a letter on Feb. 21, 1980, Dr. Roman Amrein, head of clinical research for central nervous system substances at Hoffman-La Roche in Basel, laid out the company's reasoning. He noted certain safety factors in favor of the higher-dose version of Versed, like the fact that it required less of the chemical to dissolve the drug. He went on to discuss various marketing considerations, including the desirability of presenting the drug in the ampuls used for Valium and not the larger vials required by the low-concentration version of Versed.
 
Scientific Problem Takes a Back Seat
 He concluded by stating that the economic concerns outweighed the scientific. "The scientific problem is, at present, less significant," he wrote. "For the commercial exploitation, it is, however, under the circumstances decisive with regard to the price. It has to be taken into consideration that the cost price for the vial form is around three to five times that of the ampul which we have proposed."
After receiving this letter, Dr. Kuntzman made one more effort to persuade Roche headquarters in Basel to use the lower concentration.
In a letter to Dr. Amrein on April 1, 1980, Dr. Kuntzman explained his group's fears that the drug would be particularly problematic when used for conscious sedation in doctors' offices. He expressed particular concern about apnea, a temporary cessation of breathing, and cardiovascular collapse.
Referring to Versed by its chemical name, Dr. Kuntzman wrote, "The safety issue is expected to be of greatest concern when midazolam becomes available for direct intravenous administration for minor medical and dental procedures in situations in which there usually is neither resuscitation equipment available nor personnel trained in the use of these measures."
But three weeks later, Dr. Kuntzman changed his mind. He wrote to Basel saying that new data from the use of Versed for inducing unconsciousness before general anesthesia had led him to change his position.
In 1988, on the eve of a Food and Drug Administation investigation into the marketing of Versed, Hoffman-La Roche asked its law firm, Arnold & Porter, to review its internal documents. In a confidential memorandum to the company, Arnold & Porter lawyers expressed surprise at Dr. Kuntzman's sudden change of heart.
"Within three weeks of this detailed exposition of the Nutley position which had previously been articulated many times during the preceding year, new data were presented to completely reverse Nutley's position," the memo said. The memo went on to question Dr. Kuntzman's conversion to the Basel point of view. It pointed out that the new data were from the use of the drug to induce anesthesia, but Dr. Kuntzman had been primarily concerned about its use for conscious sedation.
 
Pressure From Top Cited in Document
 The Arnold & Porter memo concluded, "One interpretation possible from these documents is that Roche/Nutley disregarded its own concerns for safety of the drug in favor of marketing and political pressure from Roche/ Basel."
Stuart Land, a senior lawyer at Arnold & Porter, said he could not comment on the documents or the memorandum because of client confidentiality.
Dr. Kuntzman, reached at his home, said he had nothing to add to the written statements by Hoffman-La Roche.
From 1980 to 1985, Hoffman-La Roche tested the drug in clinical trials, which took place in settings where resuscitative equipment was available. Mr. Gurtner, the director of corporate information, said, "There were no deaths -- indeed, there were no unexpected problems -- in those American clinical trials."
Within 18 months after Versed went on the market in the United States, the F.D.A. received reports of 86 serious adverse reactions, including 46 deaths. Some experts say that other deaths may not have been reported. One anesthesiologist, Dr. Robert M. Julien of Portland, Ore., said he knew of seven deaths in Portland alone. "There were thousands and thousands of very close calls" throughout the country, he said, adding, "It was a real fiasco."
Dr. Julien, a former professor of anesthesiology at Oregon Health Sciences University and who is an author of anestheiology textbooks, wrote to Hoffman-La Roche in 1987 complaining about the concentrated formulation. He wrote that in a typical situation, he would have to drip in 0.056 cubic centimeter of drug a minute, an amount that is much less than a drop.
"I would state to any jury that 56/1,000 cc. is virtually impossible for any physician to accurately inject by any known human technology," he wrote. "In other words, the presentation of Versed is not only impractical, it is dangerous and any indication on your part that drug overdose is the sole responsibility of the physician is blatantly wrong."
Ms. Glynn, the Roche spokeswoman, said in a written response that at the time Dr. Julien sent his letter, the company had already submitted an application to the F.D.A. to market a less concentrated formulation "because we believed that some physicians preferred that formulation."
 
Doctors Distraught Over Patient Deaths
 Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of Public Citizen Health Research Group in Washington, said he had been called by several doctors who were distraught at their experience with Versed. This was the only time in his 20 years of consumer advocacy work that doctors called him to report deaths, Dr. Wolfe said. "These were conscientious doctors who had bought the Roche line that Versed is the greatest thing since sliced Valium," Dr. Wolfe said. When their patients died, the doctors felt terrible, he added. "They were practically crying on the phone." he said.
At the Congressional hearing held in 1988 by the House Subcommittee on Human Resourches and Intergovernmental Relations, officials of the Food and Drug Administration testified that they had not been informed of deaths and adverse reactions that had been reported in Europe before the drug was approved in the United States. They said they were also unaware that the British counterpart of their agency had forced Hoffman-La Roche to lower the concentration and dose of Versed 10 months before the F.D.A. approved the concentrated formulation.
Hoffman-La Roche said that it obeyed all the F.D.A.'s legal reporting requirements.
Company officials refused to testify at the committee hearing, but Mr. Gurtner questioned whether the deaths that occurred after Versed was marketed should be attributed solely to the drug. Mr. Gurtner said that some were ascribed to incidental events like suicides and medication errors, while those receiving the drug "included high-risk patients with severe systemic life-threatening diseases."
Representative Ted Weiss, the New York Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee, has said he would ask for a criminal investigation into whether Hoffmann-La Roche withheld data about the drug Versed before or after its approval by the Government.
 
Company Is Selling Less Potent Version
 In July 1987 Hoffman-La Roche introduced a less concentrated formulation of Versed that it recommends for conscious sedation, and it recommended a lower maximum dose. It continues to market the original concentrated formulation.
The company sent two warning letters to doctors in 1987. One, in February, cautioned that there had been reports of deaths among patients who took the drug and that doctors should be particularly vigilant in monitoring patients who received it. In November, the company warned that Versed was three to four times as potent as Valium.
The F.D.A. would not comment on the results of its investigation or say when it forwarded its report to the Justice Department. The agency usually forwards reports "for prosecution or with a recommendation for submission to a grand jury to see if a prosecution is warranted," said Peter Barton Hutt, a Washington lawyer and former chief counsel for the F.D.A. "Otherwise, it would not be forwarded at all."
Dan Sigelman, an Atlanta lawyer who was counsel for Mr. Weiss's committee, noted the pressures that accumulate in a company as a drug nears the market.
"At some point, the executives have a very strong investment in successfully marketing it," Mr. Sigelman said. "This is not only a dollar investment, but also a career investment. It is often the case that people's entire careers become principally tied to a single product. There are tremendous incentives to speed a compound through to successful marketing. In that environment, one is much more likely to have marketing concerns take precedence over safety concerns."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

COMPANIES
Apple Computer and I.B.M. have signed a letter of intent to work together to create advanced software and powerful computers in a deal that, despite being rumored for weeks, still had the industry abuzz when it was officially announced. [Page A1.] 
 Security Pacific forecast recession-related earnings trouble and said it expected its second-quarter profit to be down 75 percent. BankAmerica said its earnings for the quarter would be flat. [D1.]
 The chairman of Tyco Toys and his two sons have agreed to sever all ties to the company. And in the stock market's opinion, Tyco is worth $27 million more without them. [D1.]
 A memorandum from F. Hoffmann-La Roche's legal advisers stating that the company might have disregarded safety concern about its drug, Versed, has been disclosed. The company responded by saying the drug had passed safety and clinical trials. [A1.]
 A.T.&T. modified the terms of its merger deal with NCR to settle questions about the accounting method to be used. [D2.]
 Great Republic Insurance has been seized by the California Department of Insurance. [D2.]
 Hughes Aircraft won an $837 million contract to help build an air-defense system for Saudi Arabia. [D3.]
 LTV intends to raise prices on some products by about 5 percent, beginning Sept. 29. USX and Wheeling-Pittsburgh said they would match the proposed increase. [D5.]
 The Government ordered G. Heileman Brewing to stop marketing its Power Master malt liquor. Heileman will comply. [D3.]
 
THE ECONOMY
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 10.1 percent in late June. On a seasonally adjusted basis, however, the results provided new evidence that the sluggish American automotive market is gaining strength. [D1.]
 New-home sales fell 3.3 percent in May, raising questions about the strength of the housing recovery. [D6.]
 The New York and American stock exchanges will soon open for trading 30 minutes earlier, at 9 A.M. Eastern time, beginning on Sept. 9. [D1.]
 A revival of the "junk bond" market pushed up the value of high-yield fixed-income funds in the second quarter. [D1.]
 Sabotage or a basic design flaw in computer systems did not cause several major service disruptions in the last week, said John O'Rourke, who is leading the investigation of the disruptions. [A10.]
 Standard & Poor's lowered New Jersey's bond rating to AAA plus, from AAA. [B5.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
The O.E.C.D. predicted that the industrial world's economic slowdown would end in the second half of this year, led by a recovery in the U.S. [D7.]
 
MARKETS
 Stocks tumbled in light trading as investors grew jittery over the possibility that a widening stock scandal in Tokyo could touch off heavy selling that could spread to Wall Street. The Dow slumped 38.02, or 1.3 percent, to 2,934.70. [D6.]
 Prices of Treasury securities moved modestly higher in thin trading. [D5.] Yields rose on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report. [D4.]
 The dollar retreated against most other currencies as the market responded to overseas unrest and renewed doubts about the U.S. economic recovery. [D12.] Precious metals futures prices jumped late in the session. [D12.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 When Time Warner announced its $3 billion rights offering in early June, both the size and structure surprised many. But the company has already scaled back its plans. Talking Deals. [D2.]

LENGTH: 1302 words

HEADLINE: Sardi Offers Long View Of Theater And Close

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

 BODY:
When Vincent Sardi looks out from the theater district restaurant his parents founded in 1921, this is what he sees:
*The Shubert Theater, dark since "Buddy" closed in May. 
 *The Minskoff Theater, dark since "Black and Blue" closed in January.
*The Helen Hayes, dark since "Prelude to a Kiss" closed in May.
*The Broadhurst, dark since Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Aspects of Love" closed in March.
Not a pretty sight. But Mr. Sardi, 76 years old, says he has seen worse and is not prepared to roll over and die. He skips the rosy, out-of-touch press-release chat favored by Broadway producers, and pinpoints exactly those areas he thinks need help. He's watched Broadway flirt with dying before, and each time it changed its mind he was there to greet it, martini in hand.
Mr. Sardi came out of retirement to take Sardi's back from the producers Ivan Bloch and Harvey Klaris, and the restaurateur Stuart Lichtenstein, who bought it from him in 1985 and declared bankruptcy last year.
He has wasted no time catching up. Weary of the bad reviews his kitchen has received over the years -- in The New York Times, Bryan Miller called the menu antediluvian -- he has hired a new chef, Robert McGowan, who has worked at Le Cirque and "21." He has started publishing a Sardi's newsletter, is printing his menus in Japanese and accepts J.C.B., the Japanese equivalent of an American Express card. He hails the influx of new hotels in the Times Square area as "the biggest boom we've ever had here," and unlike most of Broadway's old guard, he is a major proponent of combining Broadway and Off Broadway "into one New York theater."
"The day of divorcing the two is over," he says. "Broadway producers just have to take a realistic point of view, to make the theatergoing public aware of Off Broadway. Take 'The World Goes 'Round,' the Kander and Ebb revue. That's a terrific show and it's playing on 43d Street. Not an Off Broadway theater, a New York theater. And I think the unions will have to make adjustments not just so the theater will survive, but flourish."
 
He Knows the Neighborhood
 This is the point where most Broadway producers would tell Mr. Sardi to stick to his cannelloni, but if anyone knows this neighborhood and what's good for it, he does.
He grew up on 56th Street, on the edge of Hell's Kitchen, in a railroad flat where his parents took in boarders in show business. When his parents started Sardi's, the family moved in above it. Mr. Sardi went to school at Holy Cross, on 43d Street, and at the age of 10 joined one of those boarders, an acrobat in vaudeville, "on tour."
In those days, Mr. Sardi says, on tour meant to Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx. He also had a part in a 1925 Broadway show called "The Master of the Inn." "I played a street urchin," he recalls, "and I was billed as the Little Wop. Can you imagine that happening now? I never got the acting bug, though. I used to lose my voice."
He concentrated on school and graduated from Columbia University in 1937. He then joined his parents in the restaurant, after it moved to its current site on 44th Street, down the street from its first home in a brownstone, long gone, between the Helen Hayes and St. James Theaters. "Lee Shubert put this building up for Dad in 1926," Mr. Sardi recalls. "It used to be apartments." He adds that he has "a few customers from back then, all theatergoers, who still come in," including Helen Hayes.
 
Flattering the Clientele
 And if Miss Hayes was not there during a recent lunch hour, some of her contemporaries were, along with a few local businessmen and more than a few tourists dressed in shorts, toting cameras. Mr. Sardi took a table at the restaurant's rear.
He is dressed elegantly, though he worries that his tie might not match his shirt since his wife of nine years, June Keller, the graphic artist, is in Vermont and did not check him. He looks physically fit, after years of polo playing, but he credits the restaurant's lighting with making him look better. "I've met women on the street I haven't recognized because they look so much more attractive in the restaurant," he says.
The burgundy banquettes and the famous caricatures crowded on the walls add to the room's romance. And Sardi's smells like a good time -- food, Scotch, women's perfume. It's the way your mother's coat smelled when she came home on a Saturday night. The waiters and bus boys service their tables dutifully, but when it comes to Mr. Sardi, each has eyes in the back of his head. There is no question who the star is in this Broadway house.
"The whole audience has changed," he says while a waiter pours coffee. "You would open a play on Broadway, it would run one season, then go on the road. It didn't run five, six years like they do now. So your whole audience was from New York. After New York they used to go to the hinterlands for an audience. Now the hinterlands come here."
 
The Words Not Used
 "But I resent the word tourist," he continues. "You cater to whatever audience you have. In the winter you get the business traveler, and that's why this area will improve, because these new hotels are geared for business people on expense accounts, which is definitely a theater audience. In July and August it will basically be foreign visitors to the city. Maybe New York has lost glamour for the American tourist, but all over Europe and the Far East we're considered very reasonable. I don't like the word cheap."
Still, Sardi's is not exempt from the recession. The groups that used to number 60 or 70 have been coming in at 30 or 35, Mr. Sardi says. Theater parties promise the restaurant, say, 150 people, and "I'm lucky if I get 110," Mr. Sardi says. But he adds: "We're ahead of our projections for this season. Of course we made very modest projections."
And Sardi's is still very much part of the theater community. Opening-night parties this season ran the gamut from "The Speed of Darkness" -- the first play produced under the Broadway Alliance, a plan to bring serious drama back to Broadway at prices affordable to the audience and the producers -- to "Miss Saigon."
Philip J. Smith, executive vice president of the Shubert Organization, which owns the Sardi's building, says: "Everybody in the theater loves Vincent. You see him on the floor at 12 noon, and if you look back in there at 11 at night, he's still at the door greeting people."
 
To Feel at Home
 Mr. Sardi says he does it because the most important thing, especially in these troubled times, is for customers to feel at home. He wants everyone to be as excited as he is by the prospect of going out to dinner and seeing a show. It is a ritual that remains as compelling and exotic now as it was to the child growing up in Hell's Kitchen.
His maitre d'hotel, Mitchell Albert, recalls an example of Mr. Sardi's dedication to his customers. "A few weeks ago," he says, "we had a family eating here who asked directions to the Nederlander Theater. It turned out they had tickets for "Our Country's Good," which had closed."
Mr. Sardi picks up the story: "They were a nice couple with two young girls. So I told them to eat while I went down to the box office at 'The Secret Garden' and explained what happened. It was a Saturday night so I couldn't get them four seats together, but I got two pairs. I put it on my American Express card, came back and told the man, 'When you get home, send me a check.' I thought he'd forget, but he didn't. It turns out he's president of a big oil company. You see, you never know about people."
That's for sure. Whatever made him go to such lengths for people he didn't even know? He looks genuinely taken aback. "Those kids were all dressed up to go to the theater," he says. "It would have been terrible to disappoint them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vincent Sardi outside his restaurant on West 44th Street. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
The Rising Sun on Plymouth Rock

 BODY:
Plymouth, Mass. -- "America's home town" -- has had Fourth of July band music as long as anyone remembers. But the recession made it harder to find sponsors this year. Enter Kao Infosystems, which makes floppy disks for computers -- and friends for Japan. 
 Kao landed in Plymouth in 1989 from Tokyo, and claims to be at least as American as those who landed in 1620. As evidence, it is paying for six hours of bluegrass, country-and-western and old-fashioned band music today just a stone's throw from the famous rock. It also has a float in the parade, offering out balloons and candy.
East may be east and west may be west, but today the twain meet in Plymouth.

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Riding the Quota Wave

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER;

 BODY:
Starting this week, Tom Wicker's column will appear on Thursdays and Sundays. 
It used to be said down South that the only way to get a mule's attention was to hit it over the head with a two-by-four. If anyone doubted that "quotas" and the Democrats' alleged partiality to them will be a Republican theme in 1992, Jesse Helms got out his lumber last week and gave them a good lick.
Mr. Helms, the well-known "Senator No" from North Carolina, is not a man to let the voters wonder where he stands. In 1989, when some optimists doubted he would run again, he dashed their hopes by taking up arms against the Mapplethorpe show -- as good as an announcement of his candidacy. 
 In 1990, it appeared for a time that Senator No might be beaten by a strong black candidate, Harvey Gantt. Close students of the Senator's brand of politics never accepted this shining vision; sure enough, he turned the tide with a TV spot depicting a white man losing a job due to "quotas" for blacks.
Now Mr. Helms has introduced an amendment to civil rights legislation that would bar employers from granting any kind of preferential treatment whatever, in hiring, compensation or promotion, if based on race, color, religion, national origin or sex.
This, after centuries of the most blatant preferences in every aspect of American economic life -- preferences for whites, males, usually for those of Western European stock, almost always for English-speakers, all too often for Protestants. What blatant hypocrisy it would be for the Senate to say, after such a record, that preferences were no longer permissible.
Now, of course, some preferences are called quotas, whether they are or not, and are extended to blacks, Hispanics, Asians, women. Admittedly, they might once in a while inconvenience or disadvantage a white, Protestant male. But in the face of a history of discrimination, is rigid evenhandedness to be the test of a candidate's or party's devotion to American values?
If so, it's as distorted a view of history and reality as the argument that any deviation from the idea of a "colorblind" America must be denounced. Since when was America colorblind? When is it ever likely to be? Colorblindness is an ideal, not a fair standard of current action or employment rules.
The Helms amendment is less a serious proposal than a typically shifty Helms device to insure that those who dare to vote against it can be pilloried next year for "favoring quotas." Even before its introduction, President Bush had branded the civil rights bill a "quota bill." He has stuck to this indictment against all arguments -- not just by Democrats and black leaders but also the pleas of Republicans like Senator John Danforth of Missouri, who tried hard to get Mr. Bush to accept a compromise and now describes the adamant White House position as fostering job discrimination.

Mr. Bush is regarded as sure to veto the legislation as a "quota bill." With the aid of the Helms amendment, he can seek to establish himself and his party in 1992 as defenders, against quota-wielding Democrats, of an evenhanded, colorblind, non-preferential American working life. In such an America, the actuality soon would be pervasive preference for white males, as it always was in the past.
Besides, as Representative Howard Wolpe of Michigan recently said in a notable speech: "The real enemy of beleaguered workers today is not affirmative-action programs designed to overcome a legacy of race prejudice and discrimination, but an economy that does not provide secure employment for all Americans. The solution is not to fight over who gets the limited number of jobs available, but to create more jobs and to train people to fill them."
Education, unfortunately, could be another testing ground for the quota theme. Lamar Alexander, the Secretary of Education, told a House subcommittee the other day that he feared cultural-diversity policies and multicultural curriculums in higher education might lead "to race-based hiring quotas at educational institutions receiving Federal funds."
That might happen in some cases. But even if it did, those cases could be dealt with individually; the possibility is insufficient reason to ban or even to discourage cultural diversity in higher education. That would be like taking up a two-by-four to get a mule's attention -- or escalating the quota theme into a national crisis in order to win an election.

HEADLINE: The Bank Bill: More Profit, Less Loss

 BODY:
Radical bank reform could still be tampered with, even torpedoed in coming days, but the story so far can be told in four happy words: good and getting better. The House Banking Committee has now voted to reshape the banking system, improving on an already wise proposal by the Bush Administration.
The bill must snake through the House energy and Senate banking committees; members have expressed opposition to various provisions. The bill can and should be improved. But its two main provisions are essential -- to close failed banks early and to let banks increase profits. Meddling here would doom effective reform. 
 Though the bill is dizzyingly complex, its logic is simple. Regulators would be required to close troubled banks quickly, before they ran out of reserves, thereby protecting taxpayers. And banks would be empowered to diversify their investments, making it easier to earn reasonable profits.
Shareholders would be required to keep a substantial amount of money in the bank. If bank losses mounted and shareholder capital fell below preset targets, regulators would halt dividends and restrict new loans. If losses continued, regulators would be required to close the bank while there were still reserves to pay depositors.
These rules would prevent a replay of the savings and loan debacle. Then, regulators were under extreme political pressure to let crippled savings institutions lend money in desperate gambles for salvation.
The bank bill would thus protect taxpayers from having to pay for vast amounts of deposit insurance. Meanwhile, it would permit banks to earn more. They could set up branches throughout the country and, if well capitalized, sell insurance, mutual funds and securities.
Yet, there are grounds for criticizing the bill. Capital standards are too low; regulators still retain too much discretion. And the provision that would permit -- in an attempt to attract new capital -- commercial businesses to buy banks raises serious doubts.
Opponents argue that commercial ownership is dangerous and unnecessary, because capital will flow once banking is profitable. The provision would, they say, invite financial self-dealing and force the Federal Reserve to bail out parent companies to save banks.
The bill adequately addresses these fears. But if Congress remains jittery, it could strip commercial ownership from the bill without compromising the integrity of the other provisions.
Another challenge will come from Representative Charles Schumer of New York and other proponents of "core bank" proposals. The idea is to wall off insured deposits from other funds. Interest rates paid on them would be capped, tied to market rates on government securities. And restrictions would be placed on loans from insured deposits.
Core banks would provide appealing protection. But the cap on interest rates is a fatal flaw. During crises, private rates can rise well above government rates. If private rates were capped, depositors would withdraw their money, just when the economy would be most vulnerable.
Over the next several weeks, House and Senate committees will take hefty whacks at the banking bill. But if they spare the two key provisions, everybody will benefit: depositors, investors -- and taxpayers.
