HEADLINE: Hold on, Here Comes The Next Bank Fiasco

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"New Finance Woes: F.D.I.C. Loss Worse; S.& L. Crisis Deeper" (front page, June 11). "Court Backs Banks' Sales of Insurance" (Business Day, June 11). There is a connection here. 
 This is the same Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and Government that promised in 1988 that the cost of the savings and loan institutions bailout would not exceed $50 billion, right? Has not the same F.D.I.C. assured us that banks would not follow the savings and loans into a financial black hole?
Is this not the same banking industry that, with Washington's blessing, lent money to nonperforming oil-producing countries in the 1970's on the ground that oil producers cannot go broke, and sank billions into the late Eastern bloc, arguing that the Soviet Union must back these loans to save its own credit? Are the insurance companies now complaining about new competition the same ones that sank policyholder dollars into the same junk bonds and overpriced real estate as the S.& L.'s did?
Do the banks that have yet to find the bottom of the savings and loan-banking crisis really need another abyss into which to throw a trillion or so taxpayer-guaranteed dollars? They seem to think a Washington that is functioning beyond its intellectual capacity is willing to overlook prior sins. Must taxpayers conclude that, within a decade or so, our funds will be used to honor policies for lives and homes because the banks, like the insurers before them, threw policyholder premiums into bad investments? What assurances can Washington give that we can expect a more optimistic scenario?
Our "protectors" in Washington now wish to reduce the deposit insurance for small taxpayers to cover the bad guesses and demonstrated incompetence of large campaign contributors.
 
NORMAN HIGBY
Menlo Park, Calif., June 19, 1991
 
The writer publishes a newsletter on the energy industry.

HEADLINE: Egypt's Arms Control Plan for Region

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, July 4

 BODY:
The Egyptian Foreign Minister unveiled new proposals today for Middle East arms control, including the demand that Israel be subject to the same restrictions as Arab countries on weapons of mass destruction.
Announcing the plan at a news conference for foreign journalists, Foreign Minister Amr Moussa declined to respond directly to a question about a report on British television last week that an Egyptian-based company, jointly owned by Arab and British interests, was cooperating with North Korea to develop and manufacture an extended-range version of the Scud-B missile. 
 Since the report was broadcast on the British Broadcasting Corp's investigative program Panorama, Defense Ministry and other officials here have declined to respond to repeated invitations to either confirm or deny it.
The Scud-B, originally designed by the Soviet Union with a range of around 200 miles, was deployed by Iraq during the Gulf war in a version Baghdad had developed that increased the range and lightened the pay-load. The missile is said to be capable of delivering chemical weapons, but Iraq, in attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia, fired only conventional warheads.
 
Regional Disarmament Plan
 Mr. Moussa said President Hosni Mubarak had proposed that the Middle East be made a region free of nuclear weapons and other weapons of mass destruction.
But in a response to the Bush Administration's call for the Middle East arms race to be slowed after the Gulf War, Mr. Moussa said the Egyptian suggestions had been expanded to include a role for the United Nations in Middle East arms control, the adherence of all Middle East countries to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and a variety of other steps to secure formal commitments by all Middle Eastern countries to renounce nuclear, chemical or biological arms.
Israel is the only Middle Eastern country that is understood to possess functioning nuclear weapons.
Mr. Moussa made clear that the thrust of the Egyptian ideas was to have Israel included in any new arms control program. His comments reflected widespread Arab suspicion that the United States wants to use Middle East arms control to shelter Israel's military supremacy while further weakening Arab nations. after the decimation of Iraq's military power in the Gulf War.
"Precarious asymmetries cannot continue to prevail in a region striving for a just and comprehensive peace," he said.
In his summary of the Egyptian ideas, Mr. Moussa said Egypt urged Middle Eastern countries "to deal effectively and equitably with the issue of means of delivery of weapons of mass destruction in all their different forms."
Mr. Moussa said he would not respond directly to a question about how this proposal affected the program described by the BBC report to develop an improved Scud-B missile.
According to the Panorama report, an Egyptian-based consortium jointly owned by an Arab consortium and British Aerospace P.L.C. -- Britain's leading weapons manufacturer -- were involved in a project with the North Koreans to develop improved Scud-B's.
Panorama identified the joint venture as the Arab-British Dynamics Company, based in Heliopolis on the outskirts of Cairo. A British Aerospace spokeswoman, Irene Dodgson, said 30 per cent of the concern was owned by British Aerospace and 70 per cent by the Cairo-based Arab Organization for Industrialization, an arms manufacturer owned by Saudi Arabia, Abu Dhabi, Qatar and Egypt.
 
Reports of Missile Project
 Ms. Dodgson and British Government spokesmen would neither confirm nor deny that Arab-British Dynamics was involved in a program to develop an upgraded Scud.
The television report, which cited unnamed "intelligence sources," said the program with the North Koreans was nearing the production stage.
Before Iraq invaded Kuwait last Aug. 2, Egypt, along with Jordan and North Yemen, was grouped with Iraq in an economic body called the Arab Cooperation Council, which Baghdad had sought to transform into a military alliance strengthening previous military cooperation between the four nations in Iraq's war with Iran.
At that time Egypt was said by diplomats to be selling Iraq up to $1 billion worth of ammunition and other arms supplies a year. Retired Egyptian officers were loaned to the Iraqi military as advisers and officials here said privately that Cairo had shared rudimentary chemical weapons technology with Baghdad.

HEADLINE: Guyana Marxist, Mellowed, Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GEORGETOWN, Guyana

 BODY:
Surrounded by plaques and medals struck with likenesses of Marx and Lenin and other political mementos that seem almost quaint after Communism's collapse, Cheddi Jagan, a 73-year-old leftist crusader, lacks no enthusiasm for explaining why his time has finally come.
His face lit beneath a wispy halo of white hair, Dr. Jagan proclaims his rebirth, calling himself a "Gorbachev before Gorbachev," 27 years after the United States and Britain helped maneuver him from power for fear of seeing a Communist beachhead on the South American mainland. 
 Now, after decades of this continent's most orthodox authoritarian socialism under one of his rivals, Dr. Jagan is making a comeback. Foreign diplomats and the leaders of a cluster of smaller opposition parties describe him as the favorite in elections expected this year in this nation of 650,000 wedged between Venezuela and Suriname on South America's northern coast.
In 1953, with a strong base among this country's downtrodden East Indian sugar plantation workers, Dr. Jagan's People's Progressive Party won an overwhelming victory in colonially administered elections. The fiery young Marxist held the prime ministership for 153 days, before the British suspended the Constitution out of fear of "Communist subversion" and removed him from office.
 
Two Decades of Socialism
 Despite succeeding election victories, American opposition and a new proportional representation system helped insure that Dr. Jagan's longtime rival, Forbes Burnham, would eventually lead South America's only English-speaking nation out of colonial rule in 1966.
Under the control of President Burnham's black-based People's National Congress, Guyana underwent two decades of socialism that drove this country, the former British Guiana, into poverty. Since Mr. Burnham's death in 1985, his successor, Desmond Hoyte, a longtime official of the People's National Congress, has moved gradually to undo much of his predecessor's socialist legacy.
With the Government promising that this fall it will hold what international human rights monitors say would be the first free and fair election in Guyana since 1964, Dr. Jagan, long the Moscow-inspired purist, is competing with his rivals on questions like who can best attract foreign investment and safeguard political liberties.
That he is the front-runner after all these years is partly a testament, his supporters say, to the personal integrity widely attributed to him. Another factor is the ethnic tension that continues to divide this nation into two main groups: the offspring of East Indian indentured servants, like Dr. Jagan himself, and the descendants of African slaves, giving Dr. Jagan a near-captive racial base that makes up about 50 percent of the electorate.
 
'Nothing Works Here'
 But perhaps most responsible for making Dr. Jagan the election favorite, Guyanese and foreign diplomats say, is the condition of this nation itself. In 27 years of rule by the People's National Congress, Guyana has been driven from breadbasket of the Caribbean to contender for the title of the hemisphere's poorest country.
Even in predominantly black Georgetown, long a stronghold of the People's National Congress, years of perceived electoral fraud and severe economic decay seem to have taken their toll on the Government's core supporters.
"We never had to vote for them in the past because we knew the vote was going to be rigged anyway," said an unemployed Afro-Guyanese professional. "Now even many black people are willing to vote for a change. Nothing works here and there is no reason to stay."
On average, diplomats estimate, every flight that leaves here these days carries away 20 Guyanese emigrants, part of an estimated 5 percent of the population that is now thought to be leaving each year.
 
A Fillip of Leftism
 To fight this, Dr. Jagan looks to foreign investment -- with a fillip of the leftism of old.
"Foreign capital must be given incentives," he said in an interview, criticizing the Government's newborn economic conservatism. "We agree on the basic goals. But we must start the development process from the local level, involving the people's organizations, the farmers' organizations and trade unions in the decision making."
When asked how he felt about the United States, three decades after it worked to keep him out of power, Dr. Jagan said: "What happened to us was part and parcel of the cold war. It wasn't that we were charged with suppressing the people or doing anything wrong." Professing no bitterness, he added, "We appreciate the help of those in Congress who are supporting fair elections."
 
Still a Goal
 While support for Dr. Jagan seems to be growing among the disinherited, others here wonder how much his Marxist prescriptions have changed.
After years of competing for the image of true champion of the left, the Government now criticizes Dr. Jagan as being too socialist. "Many people may perceive that voting for Cheddi is jumping from the frying pan into the fire," said one Government official, Kit Nascimento, chairman of the Guyana Public Communications Agency.
For his part, Dr. Jagan, who spoke wistfully of his socialist dream, seemed to acknowledge it would have to await another era. "We feel that in this stage of our struggle we want what we call a national democratic program, not a socialist program," he said. "We maintain that as a goal for the end of the road."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Cheddi Jagan, the consensus favorite in the coming elections in Guyana, is a leftist crusader who was removed as Prime Minister of British Guiana in 1953 when the British suspended the Constitution out of fear of "Communist subversion." "What happened to us was part and parcel of the cold war," Mr. Jagan said. "It wasn't that we were charged with suppressinng the people or doing anything wrong." (Howard W. French/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Fed, a New Set of Tea Leaves

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
From corporate offices to the headquarters of the Federal Reserve, economists are always looking out for new indicators that will give them clues to where things are headed. David W. Mullins Jr., a governor of the Federal Reserve and its vice chairman-designate, is betting that an experimental indicator of bond market jitters will help tell him whether investors expect inflation to flare.
The index's current calm readings suggest that the Fed has some latitude to ease its monetary policy if other conditions warrant -- though Mr. Mullins and other Fed officials have made it clear that they see no reason for easing right now. 
 Many economists look to the Fed itself to divine where interest rates and the economy are heading. Fed officials can directly influence short-term rates, but they are often uncertain about how their actions will affect long-term rates. Will an easing by the Fed result in lower long-term rates by making more money available for lending, or raise rates as investors question the Fed's commitment to fighting inflation?
 
Possible Answers
 Mr. Mullins said his indicator, which uses the prices of Treasury bond options to measure investor uncertainty, could help answer such questions.
Mr. Mullins, said by some at the Fed to exert significant influence already, has been talking up this measure with other members of the Fed's policy-setting Open Market Committee. He has also asked Fed staffers in Washington to begin the basic research that, he said, could result in the indicator's formal inclusion in policy deliberations. "There is a lot of groundwork that has to be done," he said.
Some Wall Street economists doubt that the indicator will prove as useful as Mr. Mullins expects, or as reliable as, say, exchange rates or commodity prices. "It's a reach," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The U.S. options market isn't sufficiently well developed nor is it truly international."
But the New York Fed, the most powerful of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks because it carries out the directives of the Open Market Committee, already follows the indicator closely.
"We pay a lot of attention to options markets," said Charles M. Lucas, the senior vice president for international capital markets at the New York Fed. "Our view is that they reveal the market's expectations of future variability of the price of bonds." Bond prices vary inversely with interest rates.
The inventor of Treasury bond options, Richard L. Sandor, an executive managing director at Kidder, Peabody & Company, also favors the Fed's use of the indicator. "The market, unlike some economists' model, does reveal participants' expectations," he said.
Mr. Mullins readily agrees that the indicator has been far more popular among bond traders than economists. Traders have used the measure for years to forecast options prices. "Normally, macroeconomists don't look at this number, and market-oriented people don't think about how to use it in a macroeconomic context," Mr. Mullins said.
 
An Intimidating Name
 Underlying the indicator's intimidating name -- the implied volatility of options prices on Treasury bonds -- and its complex mathematical derivation is a simple concept: Options are a kind of insurance, with their costs reflecting both the prices of underlying assets and the perceived risks.
"When the environment gets riskier, the price of insurance goes up," said Steven P. Feinstein, an economist at Boston University and a former Fed staffer in Atlanta.
Options are rights to buy or sell assets, like 30-year Treasury bonds, at a specified price within a certain time. Corporations and financial institutions use them to hedge their risks, locking in a price or protecting against an unfavorable price change.
Two University of Chicago finance professors, Fischer Black and Myron S. Scholes, invented a formula in 1973 for how much this insurance, the option, should cost, based on how much volatility investors foresee. The greater the expected volatility, the more the option costs.
 
Inferring Market Risks
 "Anyone equipped with that formula can infer how risky the market thinks investing in a given asset is at a given point in time," Mr. Feinstein explained.
The implied volatility can be calculated primarily from the prices of an option and the underlying asset. The Chicago Board of Trade, where options on Treasury bonds are traded, publishes a chart of implied volatilities in its monthly newsletter. A 10 percent reading for an option on a bond worth $1,000 means that investors expect the price to vary between $900 and $1,100 over the year ahead.
Mr. Mullins said that as a guide to inflation fears, implied volatility could help the Fed gauge how investors might respond to its actions: for example, when steps meant to lower long-term interest rates might backfire and instead raise them.
Mr. Mullins said he was already making use of the volatility index. He has watched yields on long-term Treasury bonds rise from 7.98 percent in late February to about 8.4 percent, even as the Fed has eased. Should the Fed conclude that investors are becoming more fearful of inflation?
 
Less Uncertainty Is Seen
 Not according to recent readings of the implied volatility measure, just 8.1 on July 3, about half the rates recorded during the Persian Gulf war. "We don't see a lot of uncertainty out there," Mr. Mullins said. "Maybe investors really aren't that worried about inflation. They may simply be forecasting higher rates because worldwide saving hasn't risen enough to take care of new investment demands."
Economists say the volatility measure, like most other indicators, must be viewed in the context of other statistics. While a steep yield curve -- with long-term rates much higher than shorter rates -- suggests inflation fears, other statistics point the other way. The dollar has been appreciating and commodity prices have remained weak.
Last August, after Iraq invaded Kuwait, implied volatility surged and stayed high for weeks. "The fact that volatility went up and the dollar went down made me think that markets were more concerned about inflation then than now," Mr. Mullins said.
An internal memorandum from the New York Fed said that loosening monetary policy then "might have confirmed pessimistic views of inflation." Despite strong pressure from the White House, the Fed, for a variety of reasons, refused to ease even as the economy slowed.
 
Intellectual Tradition
 Mr. Mullin's interest in implied volatility continues a tradition by which Fed governors establish their intellectual credentials and leave their marks. Manuel Johnson, the last vice chairman, promoted the exchange rate of the dollar as a crucial indicator.
In the Fed's university seminar atmosphere, governors pride themselves especially on contributions that reflect their unique knowledge and experience. Wayne Angell, one of the governors, has brought more attention to commodity prices, implying that his experience as a Kansas farmer and banker is as pertinent to policy-making as a bushel of Ivy League degrees.
Mr. Mullins brings a background in markets and finance. One of Professor Scholes's star students, Mr. Mullins taught options theory at the Harvard Business School and was the associate director of the Brady commission on stock market reform.
But Mr. Mullin's indicator might have some homespun uses far from the Fed's marble halls. Mr. Feinstein, the Boston University economist, is trying to decide whether to protect against higher interest rates with a 30-year fixed mortgage, or go for an adjustable rate. He is scanning the financial pages to see how options on 30-year Treasury bonds are behaving. "I can't predict interest rates." he said, "but I can look at implied volatility to see whether the market expects a lot of fluctuations."

HEADLINE: California Tax Plan Loses, Returning State to Turmoil

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 4

 BODY:
California was thrown back into fiscal turmoil today after the Legislature failed to approve more taxes to balance the state budget in a chaotic session that ended minutes before a Wednesday midnight deadline.
But unlike Connecticut and Maine, California faces no immediate shutdown of services. A spokesman for Gov. Pete Wilson said the state had enough cash reserves to carry it until about July 15, the next payday for state employees. 
The breakdown in negotiations was a political setback for Governor Wilson, a moderate Republican who has repeatedly set deadlines in the lengthy budget battle and then backed off.
The Governor had threatened to veto the $56.4 billion budget passed on June 20 by Wednesday midnight unless the Legislature passed a measure sought by business interests to cut workers' compensation claims for psychological stress. He characterized this as a "modest" change that was the price for his agreeing to increase income tax rates for the wealthy.
But he was unable to get his fellow Republicans in the State Assembly, the lower house of the Legislature, to accept the tax increase. Nor was he able to get the Democrats to agree to changes in workers' compensation.
By beating a tactical retreat Mr. Wilson bought more time. He used a parliamentary device in which he returned the budget bill to the Legislature, which then sent it back to him intact today, starting the clock again for 12 days.
The failure was foreordained on Wednesday evening when, with the temperature outside at 112 degrees, the Assembly Speaker, Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco, left the baking Capitol to see the new Arnold Schwarzenegger movie "Terminator 2."
While he was waiting in the ticket line, Mr. Brown was paged by the Governor to return for a leadership meeting, a meeting that produced no miracles.
The budget crisis underscored the dramatic reversal of economic fortunes in the nation's most populous state. As recently as 1988 California had a $1 billion surplus and returned $75 to every taxpayer. But the recession and troubles in the aerospace industry have deflated the state's economy.
 
A $14.3 Billion Gap
 For the fiscal year that began Monday, the state government faced a $14.3 billion gap between spending and expected revenue, the largest such shortage ever faced by any state in the Union.
On Wednesday the State Controller, Gray Davis, reported that tax revenue for the just-completed fiscal year dropped by $462 million from last year -- the first decline resulting from economic conditions since the Depression.
In recent weeks the Legislature has closed most of the $14.3 billion gap mainly by raising and broadening the sales tax, increasing fees for vehicle registration and other services, and by cutting welfare grants. Four days ago the Governor signed the tax increases, amounting to more than $5 billion, the largest in California history.
But the budget, which state law requires to be balanced, still remains more than $2 billion short. On Wednesday afternoon a new tax package was offered by the State Senate Republican leader, Kenneth L. Maddy of Fresno.
Among other things, the plan would have raised the personal income tax to 10.3 percent from 9 percent for taxpayers making more than $200,000 a year or $400,000 for married couples filing jointly. It also would have reduced the tax credit for renters, imposed a 2 percent tax on telecommunication services and raised various business levies.
"This is a budget balancer," Mr. Maddy said. "It is the best we can do."
The Senate passed the package at about 10 P.M. amid a chorus of complaints against the more contentious Assembly and against Mr. Wilson for being unable to get his fellow Republicans in the Assembly to cooperate. Both houses are controlled by the Democrats, but a two-thirds majority is required for budget matters, meaning that the votes of at least 9 of the 31 Republicans in the Assembly are needed.
"I guess the Governor cannot get the votes just by enforcing party discipline," said State Senator David A. Roberti of Los Angeles, the President pro tem. Mr. Roberti also complained that he had delivered the earlier tax increases and painful welfare cuts that the Governor had sought, and said he resented Mr. Wilson's raising the workers' compensation matter at the last minute.
Across the hall in the Assembly, all hope was lost. The workers' compensation bill was stuck in the Insurance Committee, and voting on the taxes, which began only 15 minutes before midnight, produced nowhere near the two-thirds margin.
"If this budget blows up it will not be because the Democrats did not do the job," said Mr. Brown. At 11:57 P.M. he announced that Mr. Wilson had agreed to his suggestion to return the budget bill. "We did not go off the deep end," the Assembly Speaker said.
Eight minutes later the drawn-looking Governor met with reporters and said the action "allows the opportunity for negotiations to compromise."
Despite the night's failure, he added, much progress had been achieved. "We have come a long way on this budget," he said. "There is more reform than I have ever seen in the state of California."
 
Excessive Claims Blamed
 He strongly defended the workers' compensation revisions, saying excessive claims for psychological stress had driven up the cost of doing business in California and were driving companies out of state.
In essense, the proposed revisions would prohibit payment for psychiatric injury on the job unless the employee could demonstrate that at least 50 percent of the injury was job-related, instead of the current 10 percent. They would also bar compensation for demotions, layoffs or transfers made in the normal course of business.
Businesses complain of thousands of unfounded stress claims, but unions and lawyers' groups contend that workers with legitimate claims may be excluded by the stricter standards.
Governor Wilson defended his tying the workers' compensation issue to the budget, saying it was the only way to get leverage over a Legislature "as corrupted as it has been by applicants' attorneys."
The Legislature is scheduled to resume its budget deliberations Monday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Though California remains without a budget, it does not face immediate service shutdowns, according to Gov. Pete Wilson. Willie Brown, the Assembly Speaker, received the budget returned by Mr. Wilson shortly before the midnight Wednesday deadline, but the move was only a parliamentary device intended to buy the Governor more time. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
U.S. Will Press Plan for Growth In London Talks

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IN an interview on Wednesday, the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, said that at the London economic summit conference of the seven major industrial countries later this month, the United States would press for a "three-pronged strategy" to lift the world economy out of stagnation and help rescue the economies of the fledgling democracies of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
At the end of the meeting of the rich industrial countries, Mikhail S. Gorbachev will arrive for talks on reconstruction, trade and aid, first with President Bush and then with the other Western leaders. 
 These are three elements in the United States strategy for the meeting that Mr. Brady described:
* A more dynamic monetary policy aimed at bringing down real interest rates -- what money really costs borrowers after allowing for inflation -- to stimulate economic growth and yield more employment, income and a higher rate of capital formation for a world desperately short of capital.
* An international trade policy focused on the successful completion of the current round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The talks are aimed at opening markets in all countries and breaking down regional barriers to the flow of goods, including agricultural products and textiles, as well as services and intellectual property.
* The elimination of structural rigidities hampering job creation and productivity growth within countries, whether capitalist, socialist or still struggling in the transition from Communism to a market economy.
In describing his overall strategy, Mr. Brady said, "When I first raised it last April, I was cast as a Johnny one-note." The "one note" heard by his critics in the United States and abroad was his call for lower interest rates. Foreign governments and publications said the United States had shown itself to be, as The Economist put it, "incapable of wise leaderhip." Many blamed Mr. Brady for trying to force monetary expansion at the risk of reigniting inflation.
Now Mr. Brady is seeking to put his quest for lower interest rates in a broader context and to reply to the charge that he is soft on inflation. "The economists always insist that we must have non-inflationary growth," he said, while he prefers to talk in terms of low-inflationary growth.
Mr. Brady is doubtful, as was the late Prof. Sumner Slichter of Harvard in the early post-World War II period, that zero inflation and vigorous growth are compatible. Like Professor Slichter's position, Mr. Brady's is regarded by many conservatives as not just heretical but, far worse, undeliverable and unstable. The acceptance of even low inflation is likely to lead to a much higher rate of inflation, the critics say.
In the 1950's and early 1960's, however, low inflation -- by Professor Slichter's definition, 2 percent a year -- did prove consistent with strong economic growth in the United States. In the 15 years from 1950 through 1964, real economic growth in the United States averaged 4 percent a year. With the escalation of the Vietnam War in the mid-1960's and the failure of the Johnson Administration to cut domestic spending or raise taxes to pay for the war and the Great Society, the compatibility of low inflation with high growth was shattered.
Mr. Brady believes that the world's economic leaders need greater confidence and should concentrate on positive goals, like growth and open world trade, rather than being hamstrung by negatives like fear of inflation and unemployment.
He did not try to defend all the policies that had produced economic growth and financial boom in the 1980's. On the contrary, he was highly critical of the wave of leveraged buyouts of corporations in the United States and excessive debt creation.
"The banking system is less strong," he said. "Are certain banks in trouble? Of course. Bigger banks? Yes!" But the mistakes of the 1980's, he said, should not deter us from moving ahead, "so that we're creating jobs, increasing investment."
Affirming that "a strategy of hope is important," Mr. Brady drew a comparison with what he is proposing for the world economy and with the policy taken vis-a-vis Mexico, which, he said, is moving ahead economically "by marrying the Brady Plan for reducing Mexico's foreign debt with President Salinas's progress in opening up markets."
He said that in convincing Mexicans, including expatriates as well as foreigners, that Mexico meant business and that debt reduction would work, what critics regarded as the missing element in the formulation of the plan -- money -- was flowing into the country. Mr. Brady said the inflow to Mexico of expatriate capital would rise this year to $14 billion from $4 billion last year.
Mr. Brady said he believed other governments were "getting the message" that he has been trying to deliver for a comprehensive growth-oriented strategy, including reductions in interest rates. He called attention to the Bank of Japan's half-point cut in its discount rate, its benchmark rate of interest, to 5.5 percent on Monday. Japan had been holding interest rates high to wring inflation out of the economy.
Mr. Brady said he also saw evidence that Britain, Italy, Spain and Denmark were moving to lower-rate policies. He was more equivocal about Germany, where Karl-Otto Pohl has resigned as head of the Bundesbank to be replaced by another monetary hard-liner, Helmut Schlesinger. Timothy Deal, a member of the National Security Council who is helping to prepare the United States position for the London summit meeting, said he thought the Germans were still adamant about their rate policies.
Mr. Brady's line on the urgency of growth appears to be gaining international support. This week, the United Nations World Economic Survey for 1991 predicted that global economic growth this year would be zero and would rise in 1992 to only 2 percent -- barely enough to keep pace with population growth. And the U.N. declared: "In various industrialized countries, the monetary authorities feel that output growth over 2 or 3 percent a year would be inflationary and must be restrained. As long as this view prevails, these nations cannot serve their historic role as an engine of world economic growth."
The survey concluded that the present mix of monetary and fiscal policy seems to express political priorities in which unemployment is an acceptable price for containing inflation, "and high real interest rates are welcomed even at the expense of growth, at least in the short term." If such policies continue, the report said, "the more dynamic international economic environment needed for a shorter adjustment in the developing countries and a less costly transition in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union will not materialize."
This will be not only the United Nations' but the United States' line at the summit meeting in London. Mr. Brady said that as he saw it, a strategy for regenerating growth is the most important item on the summit's agenda.

HEADLINE: Flea Markets Pit School Against Merchants

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERGENFIELD, N.J., July 4

 BODY:
The fund-raising flea markets at the high school -- source of scholarships, gifts for schools and students, and angst -- have embroiled just about everyone in town in a nasty fight.
Local merchants are mad at the Board of Education for opening the high school to out-of-town vendors and bargain-basement prices that, they complain, undercut their stores. The parents and teachers who sponsor the flea markets and return their earnings to the school system are angry at the merchants and are threatening to boycott their stores on South Washington Avenue. 
 And the five-member school board is caught in the cross-fire.
"This town is being ripped apart," the school board president, Michael Mullarkey, said after the board listened to an hour of appeals on Monday night about how many flea markets was the right number. "We're not saying anybody's right and anybody's wrong. We're just trying to ameliorate a real bad problem and make it a harmonious town again."
Flea markets have become more commonplace in the suburbs of the New York region in recent years, with wholesalers, suppliers and manufacturers' representatives, offering, at deep discount, the same clothing, cosmetics, jewelry, records, sporting equipment and other goods available in local stores and highway malls.
Most create little commotion. But Bergenfield's, which began in 1978, has become fractious, primarily because of its size.
The parents' club at the high school sponsors a two-day flea market on the weekend after Thanksgiving and the teachers' union another two-day affair just before Christmas. They're are the year's biggest, each drawing about 10,000 shoppers -- and the biggest complaints from merchants who say they cut into their peak sales season. Each class at the high school has its own market between January and April and the parents' club has another in May., near Mother's Day.
Net earnings from the seven average about $51,000, with the two holiday markets alone generating about $37,000, said Rich Catoggio, chairman of a coalition of parents and teachers now fighting to keep all seven. Earnings come from the $25 rental of sales tables to the vendors, sale of hot dogs, hamburgers and soda, and a 50-50 raffle, Mr. Catoggio said.
"That money gets dispersed through every kid in the high school," Mr. Catoggio said.
The parents' club annually spends $6,000 on scholarships and $10,000 buying items from a "wish list" submitted by teachers and administrators, he said. Over the years, he said, they have included a $10,000 refreshment stand at the football field, a $3,000 scoreboard in the gym, a $6,000 laser printer for the high school paper, Bear Facts, a $2,500 copying machine for the library, and assorted maps, microscopes and computers.
The teachers' union spends all its earnings each year on scholarships, said Charles Bruen, a union vice president. This year it awarded three four-year scholarships of $750 totaling $9,000. and set aside $3,000 for next year.
Each class's money goes for gifts for the school and class members and to help defray costs of prom tickets and yearbooks, Mr. Bruen said.
The merchants begrudge the students none of this money.
They are angry, they say, because the flea markets hurt their businesses and provide vendors a gold mine in exchange for the $25 rental of a sales table.
"What the students get is a pittance in terms of what the vendors make," said Matthew Connell, owner of Betty Lee Drugs on South Washington. He estimated vendors' earnings at about $1.5 million and $2 million a year since the markets started 13 years ago.
"That money spent at the flea markets wasn't spent in Bergenfield; it wasn't spent in Teaneck, it wasn't spent in New Milford, and it wasn't spent in any of the surrounding towns," Mr. Connell said. "And we don't know if they pay the state any sales tax."
Mr. Catoggio, head of the parents-teachers group, said all vendors must sign a contract agreeing to pay state sales tax. He also disputed Mr. Connell's earnings estimate of $1 million, telling the school board on Monday he believed the vendors made about from $4500,000 to $500,000 a year.
 
'Compete on an Equal Level'
 "The merchants have yet to prove the flea markets take $1 from them," Mr. Catoggio said.
The merchants counter that their customer flows shrink on flea-market weekends. And, they argue, the flea markets, on top of the recession, have doomed three stores in recent months -- Brass Roots, a gift shop; The Baby Carriage, and Victor's Men's Shop.
They The merchants also complain that competition from the flea markets is unfair and inequitable because they pay property taxes, rent and utilities.
"If someone is going to compete with me, compete on an equal level," said Harold Kriegsman, owner of a home accessories store. "I pay $7,000 in real-estate taxes and if I go out of business, the people in town have to make up that difference. Multiply that situation by the 100 merchants in town and you have a ghost town. When the business part of a town goes down, the whole town goes down."
The merchants, through the Chamber of Commerce, have been fighting the flea markets since 1987 -- before the Town Council, before the Board of Adjustment and in the courts.
The issue has twisted and turned back to the school board, which has been debating whether to drop the November and December flea markets, leaving the other five. The meeting on Monday ended with a 2-to-2 tie in favor of the five-market agreement with one member abstaining. On Monday, the board then agreed to bring the merchants and parents together for talks seeking a solution.
Mr. Catoggio, in the meantime, is threatening a residents' boycott of stores unless his side prevails.
Not all merchants are intimidated.
"This boycotting works both ways," said Russ Dermond, owner of the local hardware store. "If all the merchants stopped donating to civic groups and stopped giving to the Little League and the PAL and the Boy Scouts, a lot of people would be hurt."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Cuomo's Tax Shift Reflects Fiscal Squeeze

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 4

 BODY:
As a leader whose power flows from his mastery of words, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is often careful to leave himself plenty of linguistic wiggle room.
Rather than making a Shermanesque statement of disinterest in the Presidency, for instance, Mr. Cuomo prefers to say that he has "no plans and no plans to make plans" to run. The implicit suggestion, of course, is that plans can change. 
 That is why it was so striking that Mr. Cuomo, from the beginning of this year's legislative session, sounded so categorical in ruling out an increase this year in the personal income tax. The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, seemed equally firm.
"We will not consider any P.I.T.," Mr. Cuomo said at an April 5 news conference. "Not a smidgen, not a big one, not a little one, not a medium-sized one, not a last-minute deal."
On Wednesday, as part of a last-minute deal, the Governor and the state's legislative leaders signed off on a smidgen of an income-tax increase to raise $100 million and put the state budget to rest. That Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Marino were willing to break their pledges testified to the severity of New York's fiscal crisis and to the potential for an endless summer of destructive politics.
 
'We've Put Together the Pieces'
 The resolution demonstrated the truism that political jockeying in Albany inevitably expands to fill available time, no matter how dire the consequences.
And that a $100 million tax plan ultimately would close the $52 billion budget -- but not until three months after the start of the fiscal year -- also showed how intractable positions had become.
"This year, like in a labor negotiation, compromise didn't work," Assembly Speaker Mel Miller said today at a 3:30 A.M. news conference shortly after his house had recessed. "We had to go on strike."
Now, he said, "we've put together the pieces and we've learned to compromise again -- we look a lot worse when we don't compromise."
Neither Mr. Cuomo, a Democrat, nor Mr. Marino, a Republican, was happy about dining on a meal of their own oratory. But faced with the continuation of a fiscal firefight that was scorching all parties, they decided to negotiate a deal with Mr. Miller, who had been calling for a much larger income-tax increase.
The Assembly Speaker believed that a significant income-tax increase was a more progressive way to solve the state's fiscal problems than the deep cuts in state programs and local aid proposed by Mr. Cuomo.
Mr. Miller and his Democratic colleagues in the Assembly could affect a modicum of smugness on Wednesday night as the final budget bills were being passed. But they conceded that the tax increase was too little and far too late to be declared much of a victory.
 
Containing the Damage
 The agreement succeeded in containing the political damage, but everyone involved in this year's budget process is likely to be tainted by its touch. More than one lobbyist mused that the Legislature had stretched its business into the wee hours of Independence Day so that lawmakers would not have to return home to face constituents at picnics and parades.
The income-tax deal was born of political desperation. With the clock ticking toward the close of the legislative session -- it ended when the Senate recessed at 6:34 A.M. -- the leaders concluded that backtracking on a pledge was preferable to prolonged chaos.
If an agreement was not reached before the end of the session, the legislative leaders said they were prepared to restore most of the spending that Mr. Cuomo had vetoed from the budget passed by the Legislature last month. The Governor, who maintained that the Legislature's budget was out of balance by $900 million, said he would use the veto again.
"You just got to the point where everybody had exhausted alternatives and we were down to a grim choice between the devastating prospect of another round of vetoes, which were inevitable, and a constitutional struggle, which was going to come, or a compromise," Mr. Cuomo said. "And a compromise was better."
Pressure was also building from business leaders who wanted the abolition of energy taxes in the Legislature's budget as well as from New York City and other municipal governments that needed to know how much state aid to expect.
The Business Council of New York State had been lobbying for a month to kill the new taxes paid by producers and importers of petroleum and natural gas.
On June 25, the council published a report estimating that the taxes would cost New York 32,000 jobs by 1994. Late last week, it called formally for the Legislature to swap the energy taxes for an income-tax increase on the wealthy.
Mr. Cuomo said today that the Business Council's position helped persuade the Republican-majority Senate to accept an income-tax increase in exchange for elimination of the natural gas tax and restrictions on the petroleum tax.
But it also helped undermine the Governor's stance that an income-tax increase would hinder the state's economic competitiveness in attracting and keeping businesses.
The Governor said today that he continued to believe that income-tax increases were damaging to the state economy. But he said this year's increase was not large enough to hurt the state's competitiveness. "Everything is degrees," he said.
The increase would apply higher tax rates to the first $26,000 of income earned by the 225,000 New York taxpayers -- both single and joint filers -- with incomes above $100,000 a year.
Taxpayers who earn $150,000 or more would pay an additional $720 in state income taxes.
Mr. Cuomo stressed today that the focus of his pledge against raising income taxes had been to maintain existing tax rates and to avoid surcharges.
"This is not a rate increase or a surcharge," he said. "But those are words. The fact is you pay more in personal income."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Legislature recessed early yesterday after passing a budget that included an income-tax increase. Assemblywoman Helen M. Marshall and Assemblyman Paul A. Tokasz reviewed budget documents during the all-night session in Albany on Wednesday. (David Jennings for The New York Times) (pg. B2)

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Gain in London; Dollar and Gold Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks rose in London and were mixed in Frankfurt yesterday, while the dollar advanced against most major currencies. Gold prices were also higher.
Trading on some overseas markets was light and uneventful. American exchanges were closed for the Independence Day holiday. 
 Prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange yesterday as investors continued to worry that Japan's stock market scandals would widen.
In Toyko, the 225-issue Nikkei stock average fell 237.86 points, or 1.02 percent, closing at 23,135.61. The index has fallen 973.15 points in three trading days since rising 817.80 points on Monday.
"The environment surrounding the stock market still remains very gloomy," said Isao Okada, head of the stock department of the Taiheiyo Securities Company.
 
Discouraged by Scandal
 Investors have been discouraged by a scandal in which major brokerages are said to have compensated large clients for investment losses and arranged loans for a company linked to gangsters. Hitachi Ltd. acknowledged yesterday that it had been compensated by Nomura Securities for losses in its account.
On the Tokyo exchange today, stock prices opened higher, but closed with a loss. The Nikkei index fell 237.27 points, to 22,898.34, a decline of 1.03 percent.
Prices advanced on the London Stock Exchange amid speculation there would be a cut in British interest rates next week. Dealers said trading was quiet because of the holiday in the United States.
The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index rose 22 points, to close at 2,470.2. Volume was 352.8 million shares, well below Wednesday's total of 459 million.
In Frankfurt, stocks ended the day mixed in lackluster trading. The DAX index of 30 blue-chip stocks inched higher, to close at 1,616.11, up from Wednesday's finish of 1,614.41.
The dollar was mostly higher on foreign exchange markets. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 139.40 yen, up 0.08 yen from Wednesday's close but below its overnight New York finish of 139.58 yen.
Nobuyoshi Okada, a dealer with the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, said many market participants refrained from big moves with the New York market closed.
In London, the pound fell to $1.6030 from $1.6052 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included 1.8343 German marks, up from 1.8315; 1.5825 Swiss francs, unchanged; 6.2210 French francs, up from 6.2090; 2.0655 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0623; 1,365.25 Italian lire, up from 1,362.25; and 1.1423 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $369.25 an ounce, from $369 on Wednesday. In Zurich, gold closed at a bid of $369.25, up from $369. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.19, to close at a bid of $369.40.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
An Exhibition About Art Exhibitions

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
To see the latest theories of art history squeezed and prodded into exhibition format, there's no place in Manhattan quite like the Whitney Museum's downtown branch at Federal Reserve Plaza. Several times a year, a group of graduate students from the museum's independent study program are given the run of this sleek exhibition space, whose gleaming metal accouterments can bring to mind scenes from Charlie Chaplin's "Modern Times." These students are well-read, conscientious and almost terminally up to date, and they tend to orchestrate shows that stand out in one way or another, even if they're not completely outstanding in the visual sense.
This summer's offering, "Constructing American Identity," organized by Elizabeth Bingham, Eric Miles, Andrew Perchuk and Ellen Tepfer, is no exception. The exhibition, which includes more than 60 paintings dating from the late 1920's to the late 60's, is a show that nourishes the mind while frequently starving the eye. It outlines an ambitious subject but often treats it too skimpily. It also commits some glaring curatorial errors, the most prominent of which is too much required reading. A nearly one-to-one ratio of text panels to actual artworks is not a good idea. 
 "Constructing American Identity" is an exhibition about art exhibitions, specifically about how they mirror society as well as its art. It sets out to examine the ways three prominent exhibitions of contemporary art, each from a different decade, reflected America's changing sense of national identity and the role of its culture in the formation of that identity.
The shows under scrutiny are "American Art Today," held at the 1939-40 New York World's Fair; "The New American Painting," a 1958-59 traveling exhibition of Abstract Expressionist painting organized by the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art, and a selection of new artworks, mostly Pop, that was displayed on the exterior of the New York State Pavilion of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair. One of the current exhibition's goals is to demonstrate that both national identity and the idea of a national art are not consistent or linear in development; rather they are fluid, changing as the times -- and the sponsoring institutions -- require.
On a purely visual level, the separate sections devoted to the three shows contrast vividly with one another, each reflecting a distinct period look and national mood. (That the sections are also divided by walls of red, white and blue is heavy-handed.) From the isolationist, Depression-torn 1930's that was encapsulated in "American Art Today," which was organized by the Federal Art Project of the W.P.A., comes the idealistic Regionalism of Grant Wood and John Steuart Curry, with their back-to-the-earth images of Midwestern farmers. This section also includes the less than utopian Social Realism of Phillip Evergood and William Gropper, who focus on urban workers and the unemployed, and the Cubist-inspired abstraction of Stuart Davis, Byron Browne and Ad Reinhardt, who strove for a universal abstract language.
The show's second section focuses on the expansionist postwar 1950's, when artists were less politically involved than in earlier decades, and when personal isolation and existential doubt fueled large-scale, gestural abstractions. Here there are works by Willem de Kooning, Franz Kline and other artists represented in "The New American Painting," which toured under the auspices of the United States Information Agency and introduced Abstract Expressionism, the first American art style of international stature, to Europe. Finally, from the tumultuous 1960's, a time when both American life and art took a turn for the materialistic, are Pop Art works by Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and Robert Indiana, as well as a crushed-metal sculpture by John Chamberlain and a serene abstraction by Ellsworth Kelly.
This exhibition often looks like another excuse to trot out a succession of well-known American art chestnuts. In fact, until you start reading the myriad wall texts, the visual evidence seems to confirm the impression of "inexorable linear progression" and the ultimate "triumph of American art" that the exhibition's organizers hope to dispel. For better and for worse, it is the words and the accompanying documentation that make the issues of the show come alive. In each section, various art reviews and news accounts, as well as polemical quotations from artists, critics and occasionally disgruntled Congressmen, provide glimpses of the ways these shows were presented and received, and of the debates they stirred up.
Beyond its extremely didactic slant, one of the exhibition's biggest problems is that its organizers simply could not borrow the artworks necessary to do their ideas justice. The resulting skimpiness tends to reduce art to the level of visual aid, or stand-in for more important artworks by more important artists. The meager selection of six examples of Abstract Expressionism does not include anything by Jackson Pollock, whose work was most representative of the new American painting. The Pop Art section is pumped up with portfolios of prints by Warhol, Mr. Oldenburg and Mr. Rauschenberg, which are arranged in clusters so repetitious that the quotations, weighing the relative merits of Pop Art, become the primary points of interest.
Like many other exhibitions today, this one might make a better book. Its lack of visual life reminds one that the curator's art -- that mysterious ability to to arrange art objects in space so that they speak to one another and to the viewer in their own language -- is fragile and highly susceptible to the winds of fashion.
 "Constructing American Identity" remains at the Whitney Museum of American Art Downtown at Federal Reserve Plaza, 33 Maiden Lane, at Nassau Street, through Aug. 30.

GRAPHIC: Photo: An untitled work by Ad Reinhardt, part of the "Constructing American Identity" exhibition at Whitney Museum of American Art Downtown. (Whitney Museum of American Art)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
The Truth Is Self-Evident: The Yankees Are Doing Dandy

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
The Kelly on second base stole third. The Kelly at bat poked a grounder through the drawn-in infield to win another game.
So elemental, these Yankee victories. There is an economy of motion, of deeds, of words. 
 "I got a really good jump," said Pat Kelly, the base-stealer, who scored the tie-breaking run in the eighth inning of the Yankees' 3-2 victory yesterday over Baltimore.
"I was just trying to put the ball in play somewhere," said Roberto Kelly, the batter, whose single up the middle scored Pat.
 
One Game From .500
 The Kellys completed their assigned tasks. The rookie starting pitcher, Jeff Johnson, got the Yankees into the eighth, tied 2-2, with 89 thoughtful pitches. The bullpen closed out the Orioles.
The i's were dotted. The t's were crossed. The Yankees won their sixth straight game, their ninth in the last 10. They moved to within one game of that elusive .500 mark, and six and one-half games of the first-place Toronto Blue Jays. With the All-Star break and a pennant race both clearly in sight, life is good off the Major Deegan rampway.
"You don't know who's gonna do the job around here, but you know someone's gonna do it," Manager Stump Merrill said. "It's nice to see."
The Yankees fell behind again yesterday, 1-0, then managed to blow a 2-1 lead on a homer by Baltimore catcher Chris Hoiles to lead off the seventh. All game long, the Yanks had put up with the unorthodox slow curves and floaters of Orioles starter Roy Smith. Pat Kelly finally chased Smith with a double to left-center to lead off the eighth, only to bring on an even odder reliever -- submariner Todd Frohwirth.
Merrill gave Pat Kelly the green light to steal, and the rookie measured Frohwirth's weird delivery for several pitches. Meanwhile, Steve Sax, who had homered off Smith in the sixth, tried to bunt against Frohwirth but popped out to third. That brought up Roberto Kelly. On the first pitch, Pat Kelly took off for third. The pitch bounced out of Hoiles's mitt. The runner would have been safe, anyway.
 
Don't Annoy The Fans
"With a sidearmer like that, you can get a pretty good jump," Pat Kelly said. "I had to get the best jump of the season. You get caught in that situation, the Yankee fans come out and get you."
There was no summary execution necessary at third base. Now, facing a 2-1 count and the realigned defense, Roberto Kelly put wood on ball, which was all he was trying to do. "I was trying to make contact, maybe hit the ball in the outfield," he said. "I got jammed a little bit."
One Kelly ended up at first with a run batted in. Another scored. Lee Guetterman went in for Eric Plunk in the ninth to nail down his fifth save, to hand the Orioles their third straight defeat.
Plunk (1-2) got the victory, but Johnson's performance was equally encouraging. The 24-year-old left-hander had his sinker ball working until late in the game. He has just one victory in six outings since joining the Yankees on June 5, but has deserved better. He said yesterday he can wait.
"Every time I face a hitter up here, it's a new experience," Johnson said. "I've got to figure out what I got that they can't hit."

 
 
INSIDE PITCH

 DON MATTINGLY'S 16-game hitting streak ended as the first baseman flied out to center three times and struck out in the eighth. "We won, and there's a good feeling in the clubhouse," Mattingly said. "That's all I care about." . . . It can happen to anyone, at any time: Old pro ROBERT MERRILL finally blew the national anthem, on the Fourth of July, no less. One stanza of the always-tricky, never-melodious "Star Spangled Banner" came out, "O'er the ramparts we hailed . . ." . . . STEVE SAX , who homered leading off the Yankee first in the 3-2 victory over Cleveland on Wednesday night, last homered in consecutive games in 1986, playing for the Los Angeles Dodgers against the Chicago Cubs at Wrigley Field. The Yankees have homered five times to lead off innings in their last three games.

HEADLINE: South African Sanctions: Go Slow

 BODY:
The anti-apartheid sanctions imposed by Congress in 1986 have fostered change in South Africa. What made them credible was Washington's ability to speak with a bipartisan voice. Yet a big foreign policy success is now threatened by domestic politics as President Bush and the Democratic Congress square off for a needless row on when to lift the sanctions.
Mr. Bush impatiently hints that Pretoria has fulfilled all but one of five conditions for ending sanctions, which is debatable. Prodded by a black caucus deeply suspicious of White House racial politics, Democratic leaders claim that South Africa has barely met a single condition, which is more debatable. 
 That change has occurred in South Africa is not in dispute; whether reforms meet U.S. legislative tests is open to argument. If Mr. Bush hastily lifts sanctions, with Congress in recess, the U.S. will lose credibility and leverage at a critical moment in South Africa. If Democrats resist acknowledging compliance, it will be just as damaging.
The responsible solution is to review the law -- and fairly stipulate which conditions must still be satisfied.
Releasing all political prisoners. Though Nelson Mandela and many other prisoners have been released, hundreds remain in jail. Pretoria asserts that it will release all genuine political prisoners, and that none are now being detained without trial; this surely can be independently verified.
Ending the state of emergency. The emergency laws have been repealed, and Pretoria's critics concede minimal compliance.
Unbanning political parties. Change has been substantial but incomplete. Previously illegal parties now operate freely, and debate is unfettered. But some leaders are still in exile, and negotiations for their return are still under way. It would be stretching the language of the law, however, to insist -- as some Democrats do -- that blacks must be enfranchised before sanctions are lifted.
Repealing apartheid laws. With the repeal of the Population Registration Act and the Group Areas Act, the main legal pillars of apartheid have fallen. Critics assert that 59 other laws are still on the books, and that repeal has left untouched the evils of segregation. But these charges are in factual dispute, and an item-by-item reckoning is needed.
Opening a negotiation track. The law stipulates that Pretoria must "agree to enter good faith negotiations with truly representative members of the black majority without preconditions." By any fair reading, this condition has been met.
For Mr. Bush to lift sanctions before reasonable doubts are resolved would be as indefensible as stretching the law's language to prolong sanctions. America's good faith and South Africa's struggle for a new democratic order would both suffer if this debate soured into a partisan brawl.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 294 words

HEADLINE: Connecticut Adrift

 BODY:
Connecticut has no budget for the fiscal year that began Monday -- and, alas, no leadership. Gov. Lowell Weicker and the Legislature's Democrats and Republicans are in a three-way standoff, mainly over adopting an income tax. It is time to end the brinksmanship.
The Legislature, under Democratic control, has passed two no-income-tax budgets in recent days. Mr. Weicker, an independent, wants an income tax and vetoed both. The House then passed a budget with an income tax, but Senate supporters couldn't muster a majority. The key holdout is the Democratic leader, Senator John Larson, who aspires to be governor himself someday. 
 The need for an income tax is clear. Connecticut depends unwisely on an 8 percent state sales tax, the highest in the nation. Sales taxes unfairly tax the poor proportionately more than the rich. And the yield is undependable, fluctuating erratically with economic ups and downs. But for Republicans and some Democrats, opposing an income tax is an article of faith, no matter that faith in the sales tax undermines their state's future.
Connecticut also needs to brake its spending binge. Spending soared in the 1980's when the Northeast was flush with prosperity and rising revenues. It couldn't last, and now comes the torture of sharp cutbacks. If good sense prevails, the state will follow the Republicans' lead on reining in future increases. But Democrats are maneuvering for loopholes to make any ceiling less binding.
Meanwhile, Governor Weicker, true to his reputation for bluff and bluster, has shut most government offices -- a move more symbolic than sensible. While saving little or no money, he sows confusion and much resentment.
In Connecticut this weekend, politics reigns while policy suffers.

HEADLINE: Don't Forget Inflation in Corporate Tax Figures

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Business Helps Schools" (letter, June 6), Richard W. Rahn of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce would have us believe: "Corporate taxes have increased dramatically in the last decade. Total corporate taxes have increased 60 percent while profits rose 19 percent." Mr. Rahn seems to be misusing statistics. 
 Mr. Rahn probably used the same figures I took from the 1990 Statistical Abstract of the United States in computing the rise in taxes and profit, but he forgot to correct for inflation. Between 1980 and 1990, the increase in corporate taxes (from $84.8 billion to $132.1 billion) was about 56 percent in current dollars. But the increase in the Consumer Price Index (from 86.3 to 133.8) over this period was about the same: 55 percent. Thus, there was no dramatic real increase in corporate taxes.
In fact, total corporate taxes rose only .05 percentage points a year more than inflation during that decade. Since the inflation-adjusted per year gross national product increased by about 3 percent a year during that period, the data indicate that corporate taxes have proportionally decreased. According to the Statistical Abstract, the increase in corporate profits for the decade was 103 percent, more than 7 percent a year, which exceeded the rate of inflation by about 3 percent, and so did the G.N.P.
 
HERBERT F. SPIRER
Professor, Business Administration
University of Connecticut
Stamford, Conn., June 15, 1991

HEADLINE: No Progress On Tax Plan In Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 4

 BODY:
After agreeing on how much Connecticut should spend in the fiscal year that is now four days old, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and legislative leaders met for more than seven hours today without settling on a tax plan to raise that money.
On a holiday when all but three of the state's parks and beaches were closed because there is no budget, Mr. Weicker and six Senate and House leaders did reach a consensus on one issue: what goods and services should be subject to the state's sales tax. But they did not disclose which goods and services those were. 
 Today's talks ended at 4:30 P.M. with continued division over what has brought the budget process to an impasse: whether to continue to rely on the work-horse sales tax or restructure the tax system by adopting Connecticut's first tax on wages.
The talks began on Wednesday, their goal a budget and tax plan that could be brought to legislators this weekend and so end the partial shutdown of the state government that the Governor began on Tuesday.
 
'Every Tax Known to Mankind'
 On Wednesday, when talks ended at 11 P.M., a gubernatorial spokesman said general agreement had been reached on the spending side, though he would not say how it differed from the most recent budget proposal of $7.8 billion. Income-tax opponents have said that the Legislature has not tried hard enough to cut the budget.
The only progress today, said the spokesman, Charles F. J. Morse, the Governor's speech writer, was general agreement on what to apply the sales tax to.
Mr. Morse said one legislative leader had described today's talks as including consideration of "every tax known to mankind."
After a week of day-and-night politics that produced one budget vetoed by Mr. Weicker and one killed by the Senate, the Capitol was deserted today, its doors locked and only a handful of cars in front.
The talks had begun at 9 A.M. in a conference room of the Supreme Court building across Capitol Avenue. But the only activity on the nearly empty streets was crews preparing for Hartford's Fourth of July Riverfest celebration.
In its stillness, the Capitol resembled a principal victim of Mr. Weicker's shutdown -- the state's parks, which normally are jammed with picnickers on this holiday.
Contributions from corporations allowed the state to keep open three beaches along Long Island Sound: Rocky Neck in East Lyme, Hammonasset in Madison and Sherwood Island in Westport. But through the rest of Connecticut, park gates were swung shut and beaches, campgrounds and picnic areas were silent.
Parks that were open were not jammed. The largest, Hammonasset, with parking for 7,000 cars, had a rush when it opened as families and groups staked out tables. But the beach parking lots were slow to fill, and none of the three parks reached capacity.
 
Oil From a 'Happy Taxpayer'
 Most of the closed parks, meanwhile, were empty under the bright July sun.
Wharton Brook in North Haven often reaches capacity by noon on the Fourth of July, and it is not uncommon for some picnickers to arrive as early as 5 or 6 A.M., said Hammonasset's supervisor, Mark Rickert.
Today its parking lots along Route 5 were empty and one of the few people in sight was a sunbather asleep on a chaise next to his car beside the gate. Cars pulled up every few minutes, only to drive off slowly as their occupants realized the park was closed.
One act of vandalism was reported, at Wadsworth Falls State Park in Middlefield. Wanda Rickerby, spokeswoman for the Department of Environmental Protection, said someone dumped used motor oil from a 55-gallon drum into Wadsworth Pond during the night. Scrawled in the sand nearby, she said, was a message that the oil was from "another happy taxpayer."
 
40 Percent of the Work Force Off
 Governor Weicker began shutting down state services judged nonessential on Tuesday, saying he had no choice under laws that require Connecticut to have a balanced budget. Seven thousand state workers were told to stay home that day, and on Wednesday the number grew to 20,000, or 40 percent of the work force.
The Governor, an independent, is without a budget in part because he has vetoed two, neither of which included an income tax. They relied instead on expanding existing taxes, especially the state's 8 percent sales tax.
Mr. Weicker has demanded a budget that was balanced without fiscal gimmicks and that would stimulate the state's stalled economy. With the recession, he says he does not see how that can be accomplished without imposing a tax on wages for the first time and cutting the other taxes.
Opposition to an income tax, however, has long been a political badge of honor in Connecticut, and a budget that included an income tax approved by Mr. Weicker was killed by a bipartisan vote in the Senate on Tuesday.
 
Separate Meetings
 That night Democratic leaders of the Senate appealed to Mr. Weicker to meet with them on taxes, and the next day three senators, three representatives and Mr. Weicker began reviewing budget plans together.
Mr. Morse said Republicans plan to meet in party caucuses with their members in the House and Senate on Friday afternoon to review the tax discussions before they are resumed at the Governor's Residence at 6 P.M.
This afternoon, Mr. Morse said, the Senate president, John B. Larson, suggested that Governor Weicker and his staff leave the conference room so that the legislative leaders could discuss issues among themselves.
Afterward the two Republicans, M. Adela Eads, the Senate minority leader, and Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., the House minority leader, caucused alone, as did the four Democrats: Mr. Larson; Cornelius P. O'Leary, the Senate majority leader; Richard J. Balducci, Speaker of the House, and Robert F. Frankel, the House majority leader.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 6, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday and a short article on Tuesday, both about the New York State Legislature, misstated the sales tax rate for Westchester County. The rate currently is 5 3/4 percent; the Legislature on Thursday authorized an increase to 6 3/4 percent.

HEADLINE: Waiting for Darkness Puts a Glow on Hawaii

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KAILUA-KONA, Hawaii, July 3

 BODY:
The last time Dr. Donald Hall chased a total eclipse of the Sun he was in a Concorde jet, flying under the shadow of the moon for an hour at 70,000 feet.
"It produced tantalizing but inconclusive results," said Dr. Hall, director of the Institute of Astronomy at the University of Hawaii. 
This time around the solar eclipse is coming to him. At 7:28 A.M. next Thursday the Moon will slide in front of the Sun and park itself for four minutes directly over Dr. Hall's open window on the universe: an observatory on the 13,796-foot summit of Mauna Kea.
 
A Clear View of Space
 It will be the first time since the observatories were built that a total blockout of the Sun will take place over the dormant volcano, a site so far removed from the visual clutter of the rest of the world that it presents astronomers with an unusally clear view of the heavens.
Nine experiments, most of them measuring the extended atmosphere of the Sun, will be done atop Mauna Kea, which has the largest and most powerful collection of telescopes in the world.
But scientists are hardly the only ones here thrilled at the prospect of seeing the day dawn twice. The saying that the Sun in the tropics does things to people seems doubly true when the Moon is in front of it: the frenzy surrounding the spectacle is already being called ecliptomania.
When the sky darkens and the birds quiet, up to 60,000 tourists will be here on this island, where the population is usually about 100,000, gazing at the Sun's halo through Mylar-covered glasses.
For the Hawaiian tourism industry, which had been somewhat staggered by the recession and by travel jitters over the war in the Persian Gulf, the eclipse could not come at a better time.
"This is the biggest thing ever to happen to this island," said Debbie Baker, head of the Eclipse Information Center here on the big island of Hawaii, the largest of the eight major islands that make up the state. "It's a made-to-order eclipse: we get it in the middle of the resort area, one week after the Fourth of July, in a soft tourism year."
A battle between the ancient countries of Lydia and Media in Asia Minor was halted by a total solar eclipse in 585 B.C., but merchants in Hawaii have not shown similar restraint.
 
Homes Rent for $4,000
 They are selling eclipse golf balls (half black, half white) as well as offering eclipse haircuts (the halo effect, bald on top, fringe on the outside), and people are renting their houses for up to $4,000 on the day of the big event.
Most of the 9,000 hotel rooms on this largely rural and remote volcanic island are sold out for July 11. The airlines have added extra flights here from Honolulu; from midnight to 7 A.M. on July 11, one plane every few minutes will disgorge a new load of tourists on the island of Hawaii.
For $340 on the day of the eclipse, a visitor can swim with dolphins and sit in on a session with a man billed as a "shaman-drummer-flutist-artist."
"I was born during a lunar eclipse but that was in Ohio, which is different," said Kathleen Toepker, who has set up shop selling eclipse kitsch here in Kailua-Kona (pronounced ky-LOO-a CO-nah).
Her father, a nuclear physicist, suggested a T-shirt, "I Got Mooned in Hawaii," and it is selling faster than her tape of eclipse music, "Canned Hawaiian Dark."
 
A Very Bright Full Moon
 Although the island will not be as dark as night on the morning of the eclipse, the effect will be like that of a very bright full moon, scientists say.
"A lot of people think this is going to be like a drive-in movie," Miss Baker said. "But anywhere on the island you'll be under the full shadow. You don't have to drive up to it."
The next closest island, Maui, will be just outside the full shadow of the eclipse. "We're on the edge of totality, staying in Maui," said Nathan Johnson, a visitor from Mountainview, Calif., who is on a waiting list to get a room here in Kailua-Kona.
The path of the eclipse, which casts an oval-shaped shadow that covers only one-half of 1 percent of Earth's surface at any given time and moves at 7,600 miles an hour, will touch much more than Hawaii, of course. The blackballed Sun will also cross the peninsula of Baja California and Mexico City, all of Central America and parts of South America. But because this is the rainy season in many of those areas, the eclipse may be obscured.
A partial eclipse will be visible over much of the United States; in Los Angeles, 80 percent of the Sun will be covered; in Dallas, 60 percent, and in New York less than 20 percent.
The duration of the eclipse in Mexico, nearly seven minutes, will not be exceeded for more than 150 years, scientists say. The next total solar eclipse visible from the United States will happen in the year 2017.
Atop Mauna Kea, where the air is thin and the cloud cover rare, scientists from around the world will be viewing the eclipse through telescopes so powerful they can spot the design label on a bathing suit 200 miles away.
"The light-measuring equipment inside the observatories are a billion times better than what we had 20 years ago," Dr. Hall said.
The eclipse comes at a time of high solar activity -- sun spots, solar flares and magnetic storms -- making it an added bonus for scientists.
"For the first time we will be able to measure some very fine detail on the outer edge of the Sun, the corona dust," Dr. Hall said. "These experiments could very well produce some significant finds on the heat source of the sun's outer layer."
Many scientists, he said, have waited a lifetime for the four minutes they will have atop the highest vocano in Hawaii on July 11. "An eclipse of this magnitude brings with it enormous pressure," Dr. Hall said.
As the Sun begins to re-emerge at 7:32 A.M. Hawaiian time, some viewers will probably have an emotional letdown. Others will rejoice at the gift from above and its commercial spinoff on the ground.
"This event is supposed to change a lot of lives," said Manny Martinez, creator of the eclipse haircut, which cost $100 until Tuesday, when the price fell to $50. "I know it's already changed mine."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 11, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A map on Friday with an article about the solar eclipse today misstated its timing. The shadow of the moon strikes the earth early today over the Pacific Ocean and moves eastward through Central America to Brazil, where it will be late afternoon.
