HEADLINE: BANKERS EXPECTED TO STAY HESITANT TO LEND FOR YEARS

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Just as the bank failures in the Depression years bred a generation of conservative bankers, the new banking crisis is creating a cautiousness among lenders that bankers themselves say may slow the flow of loans long after the recession ends.
 Many factors affect a bank's willingness to lend, from the health of the bank to the size of its underlying capital base. But none are as important as the mindset of the bankers themselves. And there is widespread evidence that that mindset has changed in a way that may transform banking for months or years to come. 
There has been a trauma, and that trauma will make bankers cautious for a period of time," said Robert Hawkins, president of the Southern Commercial Bank of St. Louis.
 
Wary of Loose Lending
 The caution in banking circles represents a shift away from the free-lending approach of the heady 1980's and a return to more traditional banking standards.
 What had loosened banking standards was partly deregulation, and partly the increased tendency of the most creditworthy corporations to borrow directly from the credit markets, bypassing the banks. Pressed for business, the banks looked elsewhere for customers, competing to make higher-risk loans, including many in real estate -- a strategy that cost the banks dearly in loan defaults.
 The new caution among lenders showed up repeatedly in 25 interviews with bankers, corporate finance officers and Government officials. It is a caution that goes far beyond the credit tightening of the last year that the banks have often attributed to Government regulators.
 
Even Big Banks Change
 Even large, healthy banks say they are changing their ways. "In all types of lending, the price -- the interest rate -- is not only higher, but the terms of the transactions are becoming tougher and will remain so," said Lewis Coleman, vice chairman of the Bank of America in San Francisco.
 For consumers, the new caution shows itself in such things as slightly higher rates on bank credit cards -- they have already risen by nearly a percentage point in the last year, to an average of 19.6 percent -- smaller lines of credit and a growing reluctance to issue new credit cards to people who already hold one or two others.
 "They are target marketing to those with higher incomes and good credit records," said Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America. "In terms of ZIP codes, instead of mailing down 80 percent of the income ladder, as they used to do, they mail down 50 percent or 40 percent."
 Lenders are also requiring higher incomes from home buyers seeking mortgages, and often larger down payments. They are declaring that any borrower, consumer or corporate, will have to show higher levels of income in the 1990's to qualify for loans than in the 1980's. And bankers increasingly are putting limits on how much they will lend to even the most creditworthy corporations.
 "If someone wants $50 million from us, they have a tough sell on their hands," said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at the First Interstate Bank Corporation in California, where lending officers once could make such loans without higher management's approval. "We are trying to limit how much exposure we have to any borrower."
 
Outgrowing Fear
 How long might this caution last? The estimates run from two or three years to the end of the decade. "Once there are enough new faces in banking who did not experience the current crisis, lending will ease up again," said Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow and banking specialist at the Brookings Institution.
 Many experts argue that not only the nation's banks, but also two other major sources of loans, insurance companies and private finance companies, are simply returning to the lending standards that prevailed before the 1980's -- forced into doing so by the numerous loan defaults that threaten the survival of many banks. As Mr. Coleman put it, "I am making loans today with a feeling of deja vu."
 
Low Inflation a Factor
 The earlier cutback in lending had largely been a result of Government rules that in effect limited lending at banks with insufficient capital or labeled as risky many loans that in the 1980's went unchallenged by bank regulators.
 These obstacles still exist. But other forces are also kicking in to prolong the lending cutback, chief among them the defensive reaction to the trauma of bad loans and bank failures. The failures have occurred in a more concentrated fashion than at any time since the Great Depression.
 Low inflation, expected to endure well into the decade, is also playing a major role, especially in real estate lending. Property is not appreciating the way it did in the late 70's and early 80's. High inflation made real estate loans low risks and masked any mistakes a lender might have made in granting the loans. Now weaker prices have often made homes and machinery worth less than the loans floated a year or two ago to purchase them.
 The greater care in lending probably will dampen the economic recovery, once it materializes, because of less credit for corporate operations and consumer spending. For the longer term, the result is likely to be weaker economic growth in the early 1990's than in the 1980's.
 
Growth of Debt Reduced
 The credit shortage has already helped to reduce the growth of all outstanding debt in the United States, except that owed by the Federal Government and the lenders themselves, to an annual rate of less than 4 percent, according to Federal Reserve data. That is less than half the growth rate for debt in the late 1980's.
 The slowdown is partly a result of the scramble by many banks to raise cash to reimburse depositors whose money has been lent out and lost in unrepaid loans. Citibank is engaged in this scramble, and the experience is changing its long-term lending standards, said Michael Callen, a senior executive in corporate lending. "The mistake the banks made in the 1980's was to move downscale and lend to less creditworthy companies," he said. "The banks were not recognizing the level of risks and appropriately pricing for it."
 To recognize the risks, Citibank has increased interest rates for many commercial loans, with some companies whose credit ratings are of less than top quality paying two to four percentage points more than the bank once offered, Mr. Callen said.
 Such caution is similarly in vogue for healthy lenders. Many institutions, for example, are trying to keep down the levels of unpaid debt on bank credit cards, in part by trying to issue the cards to higher-income people likely to pay their bills every month, said Diane Casey, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association, which represents 10,000 midsized banks. "You try to issue cards to people who don't really need them," she said.
 Similarly, General Electric Capital, a healthy lending company whose activities include financing charge-card operations for retailers like Montgomery Ward, is monitoring income levels of card holders and limiting credit to low-income households, said James A. Park, G.E. Capital's senior vice president of finance.
 Many banks are no longer lending out as big a proportion of their deposits as they did in the 1980's, a cutback that allows them to be more selective. Deposits instead are often invested in Government securities. First Interstate is in this category, and so is Southern Commercial in St. Louis. Southern Commercial once lent 90 percent of its deposits, which total $180 million today. Now the proportion is 80 percent.
 "We don't have the loan demand today and even if we did, I would be nervous about getting back up to that level," said Mr. Hawkins, who is also president-elect of the Independent Bankers Association.
 
The 'Club Loan'
 The multibillion-dollar bank loan, once common for corporate takeovers and huge commercial real estate projects, is also more difficult to obtain, although big sums can still be raised by creditworthy companies through new bond issues. In the 1980's, a major bank would underwrite a multibillion-dollar loan and then quickly syndicate it, selling off shares to other institutions. Now the syndicated loan has become what Mr. Coleman of Bank of America describes as the "club loan."
 "The banks all sit down with the borrower and decide how much each will take, before the loan is made," Mr. Coleman said. And the amounts involved are much smaller. In the late 80's, there were syndicated loans put together in excess of $5 billion, and now the top is about $2 billion, he said.
 Even the nation's most creditworthy companies, among them the Colgate-Palmolive Corporation, are feeling the pinch. They often raise money on their own, by selling i.o.u.'s known as commercial paper, which currently total more than $550 billion.
 Colgate-Palmolive's i.o.u.'s are in such demand that the consumer products giant is paying less than 6 percent interest annually on $100 million in borrowings, said Brian Heidtke, the company's treasurer. By comparison, the banking industry's prime rate for loans to good corporate customers is 8.5 percent and many companies say they now have to pay above that level.
 But any corporation, no matter how creditworthy, traditionally lines up a bank guarantee to assure holders of commercial paper that they will be repaid should disaster strike the company. Lately the banks are making these guarantees more expensive and publicly warning that they will not pay off under certain conditions. Mr. Heidtke, for example, says that when Colgate-Palmolive renews its current $460 million standby credit, the nearly $600,000 annual fee will probably double.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Equities Surging In Latin America

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
ON the economic ropes several years ago, Latin America is beginning to show real success in opening its economies, and one of the strongest signs is the flourishing of its stock markets.
 As a group, stock markets in these developing countries have been the best performers of the year, outdoing both their competitors in the world's developed economies and their rivals in developing countries in Asia. "They have replaced the Pacific Rim emerging markets as the flavor of the month," said Gary Kleiman of Kleiman International Consultants. The problem for investors is figuring out how much higher some markets, like those in Mexico and Brazil, can go before a large correction occurs. 
Most of this year's leading markets, like those in Brazil and Argentina, and in the Philippines and Taiwan, were last year's losers. Only Mexico has been a consistent performer.
 Before this revival, these markets had suffered severely with the debt crisis of the 1980's. In 1981, according to the International Finance Corporation, which follows emerging economies, stock markets in Latin America made up 46 percent of the capitalization of the world's emerging markets. At the end of 1990, that share had shrunk to 17 percent.
 But now the International Finance Corporation indexes show that Latin American markets rose 75 percent in the first half of this year in dollar terms. In comparison, the Standard & Poor's 500 was up 12.9 percent, the Financial Times Stock Index in London was down 5.7 percent and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo was off 4.3 percent.
 According to Lipper Analytical Services, which follows the many closed-end funds that invest in Latin American stock markets, the total return, including dividends, of these funds was 69 percent in the first half of the year, based on preliminary data. In comparison, funds in Europe and the Mideast were off 27 percent and all emerging-market funds fell slightly less than 18 percent.
 Two forces behind the revival are the selling of state-owned companies and the promise of structural changes in the countries themselves. A third force has been the preliminary success of the Bush Administration's third world debt policy, which has led to agreements with Mexico and Venezuela that reduce their debt and to negotiations with Brazil and Argentina toward the same goal.
 The dollar has also played a role. Some currencies in Latin America, like the Mexican peso, are tied to the dollar. So while the dollar rally this year has cut the earnings of dollar investors in Europe, it has had much less of an effect in Latin America. And even in markets like Brazil's, where the dollar has hurt, the market has jumped so much -- more than 360 percent in local terms -- that its dollar rise is still nearly 140 percent, according to I.F.C.
 "I think that as the world has seen the economic miracles that have taken place in Chile and Mexico there has been a new acceptance on the part of investors who want to gain an advantage in the market," said Emilio Bassini, a managing director of BEA Associaties and president of the Chile Fund and the Latin American Investment Fund, two closed-end funds. Mr. Bassini has put 15 percent of his global institutional portfolios into Mexico.
 He said one important force in the markets is the shortage of stock. Although the tilt in many portfolios toward Latin America is small, he said there was still not enough stock around to satisfy the growing demand.
 In addition, heavy local buying in anticipation of profits when foreigners buy has pushed prices higher, especially in Brazil, said Edward B. Games Jr., vice president of the Brazil Fund, managed by Scudder, Stevens & Clark.
 This does not mean the story is all rosy. As the markets have become more popular the once-low price-earnings ratios are beginning to look expensive. In Venezuela, the ratio jumped from 6.44 at the end of 1989 to 29.31 at the end of last year, the I.F.C. found. Mr. Games said: "I lament what happened in Mexico; the charm was a lot of companies that were very cheap. I do not think that there is much left in Mexico that anyone could say is woefully underpriced."
 Brazil, Mr. Bassini said, still needs sweeping tax reform and a huge shrinking of the size of its Government to make the economy and market more attractive. And he says Venezuela, which has what he regards as unfavoravble tax laws, has made no earnest attempt to open the market and encourage foreign investment.
 "An awful lot of the opportunity has been nailed down in a short period of time," Mr. Games said of Brazil, a comment that could apply to the rest of Latin America. He added, "There is a lot of opportunity left but it will be longer in coming, and there will be a lot of volatility."

HEADLINE: Despite Furor Over Research Fees, Stanford Plans Similar Rate Again

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: STANFORD, Calif., July 3

 BODY:
Stanford University has proposed a research overhead rate for the next fiscal year that is almost as high as the one that got it into trouble with the Federal Government earlier this year.
 "It shows a lot of chutzpah," James Collman, a chemistry professor at Stanford, said Tuesday. "It certainly would appear to be a little bit arrogant. It's politically impossible." 
Robert Dean, the university's dean of research, said that Stanford did not expect the Government to approve the rate it proposed, but that Federal regulators required the university to give an accurate projection of costs.
 At issue is how much the university charges for indirect costs of federally sponsored research. Auditors have accused Stanford of overcharging the Federal Government millions of dollars and including as research-related costs personal extravagances for the university's president, Donald Kennedy, like cedar-line closets and a 72-foot yacht. While he has not been directly accused of wrongdoing, his critics say he did nothing to stop the improper practices.
 Federal research grants consist of two components: direct costs for a specific project, like laboratory equipment and professors' salaries, and indirect costs, for items like use of buildings, utilities, libraries and administrative services.
 
Rate is Well Above Average
 Since indirect costs are not easily attributed to specific research, universities charge the Government a percentage of the grant for all costs related to the research. Each university sets or negotiates its rate; the national average is 49 percent. For example, if a university receives a $1 million Federal grant, the Government is billed about $490,000 in indirect costs, making the total cost of the grant $1.49 million.
 Stanford's rate had hit 78 percent by the time Federal auditors began investigating the university last year. After scrutinizing Stanford's records, the auditors determined that the university overbilled the Government as much as $200 million in the 1980's.
 In April, the Government cut Stanford's overhead rate to 55.5 percent and made it retroactive to Sept. 1, 1990.
 
Heated Debate Insured
 The high opening bid announced Tuesday insures heated negotiations between the university and the Office of Naval Research, the agency that oversees Federal research grants at Stanford.
 Speaking of the 76 percent proposal, Paul Biddle, the Navy contract negotiator who uncovered the overbilling, said, "I think the opinion of most people I've spoken to in government today is that this is an outlandish proposition."
 Mr. Byer said the university did not expect approval of the 76 percent rate. "We have gotten the message loud and clear," he said in a statement. "We know that changing standards and upcoming negotiations are unlikely to produce a rate that fully reimburses our costs.
 "Nevertheless, Federal regulators require us to submit our best projection of our indicrect costs and, under today's conditions, this is it."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 6, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article by The Associated Press on July 5 about Stanford University's billing of the Federal Government for indirect costs related to Government research described past overcharges incorrectly. The figure $200 million was not a determination by auditors; it was an estimate by a representative of the Office of Naval Research. This correction was delayed through an editing error.
 Because of other editing errors, the article also misidentified the university's dean of research and referred incorrectly to a yacht for which expenses were in question. The dean is Robert Byer. The yacht was not a "personal extravagance" of Stanford's president, Donald Kennedy; it had been donated to the Stanford sailing club.

HEADLINE: Whose Park Is This Anyway?Chris Angus writes the "Canoe Country" column for The Advance News in St. Lawrence County, N.Y.

BYLINE: By Chris Angus

DATELINE: POTSDAM, N.Y.

 BODY:
When most New Yorkers think of the Adirondacks, they imagine a vast land of mountains, rivers and chain lakes held in a public trust for their use and enjoyment. Sadly, they're mistaken.
Most of the rivers and lakes of the Adirondack Park are locked away -- posted and often patrolled by private landholders. Of the 21 historic waterways that have been declared public since 1812, 18 are closed: two-thirds of New York State's wild, scenic and recreational rivers system is off-limits. 
 In the last two years, the State Assembly passed the Public Rights of Passage in Navigable Waterways Bill, which would have opened all such waterways in the state. Unfortunately, the bill has never made it out of committee in the Senate. This year, budget problems have delayed action yet again. There is still hope, though, that the bill will come up for a vote when the Senate meets to address its unfinished business later this year.
In the spring of 1986, I was cited for trespassing along with two friends after we used a bridge to gain access to the South Branch of the Grass River in the northwestern part of the Adirondack Park. Our case dragged on for more than a year and through two courts before being thrown out for lack of evidence.
The laws concerning river navigability are murky at best. Over the years, courts have interpreted common law in many cases. Together, these legal decisions form the basis for an uncertain situation that has played into the hands of landowners who want to keep the public out. What remains for the recreationist is the distinct possibility that he will be harassed and even prosecuted for enjoying what was one of the premiere canoe destinations in the U.S. in the 1800's.
Throughout most of the rest of New York and New England, waterways have remained open. Under common law, the public can claim property as a result of continued use over many years. From the time New York was a Dutch province, citizens were able to travel on any river.
But within the Adirondack Park, established in 1892 for "the free use of all the people," this open use of the waterways has been allowed to slip, largely as a result of a decision by a New York Court of Appeals, which in 1883 ruled against the idea that perennial streams were considered in the public domain.
There is much to be gained from a return to open navigability. Increasingly, corporations and individuals have sold their land to developers, who have then built houses and condominiums along miles of pristine lakes, rivers and streams.
Because of budget restraints and fierce bidding from developers, the state has been unable to act quickly enough to purchase and protect these lands. And because many beautiful rivers like the South Branch of the Grass have rarely been seen by the public, there is a limited constituency for their protection.
Many developers and game clubs claim that opening up the rivers and chain lakes for public use will destroy the wilderness. This doesn't make sense. Free access will let the public to act as watchdogs not only against quick sales to developers but against vandalism and illegal logging.
The Public Rights of Passage in Navigable Waterways Bill may well be the last chance for many rivers and lakes to be discovered by the boating public in time to save them from a gallery of waiting developers. With the defeat of the Environmental Bond Act of 1990, the state has no money to buy back the waterways. In this time of economic instability, the bill would open vast areas for public recreation while offering increased protection.
Declaring the Adirondacks the rival of Switzerland in scenic beauty, William H. H. "Adirondack" Murray, author of "Adventures in the Wilderness," wrote in 1869: "What luxury it is . . . to glide down the winding reaches of these rivers, overhung by the outlying pines and fringed with water lilies, mingling their fragrance with the odors of cedar and balsam!" What luxury indeed! But only if our legislators agree to make it possible for everyone.

HEADLINE: Drug Maker Assails an Article Critical of a Sedative's Safety

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BASEL, Switzerland, July 5

 BODY:
The Swiss drug concern F. Hoffmann-La Roche today rejected as false a report in The New York Times suggesting that a concentrated sedative marketed by the company is dangerous.
Hoffmann-La Roche accused the newspaper of spreading "incorrect allegations" about the sedative Versed in an article on Thursday. 
 Versed's safety "can in no way be called into question" if it is administered according to instructions included in the package, a company statement said.
The Times said the Food and Drug Administration received 46 reports of deaths linked to the drug within 18 months of its going on the market in the United States in 1986.
But the chief spokesman for Hoffmann-La Roche, Max W. Gurtner, called it "absolutely absurd to portray this as a causal relationship."
 
Disputing Cause of Death
 He said all deaths associated with the use of an approved drug in the United States must be reported to the drug agency, but that reporting them did not automatically pinpoint the drug as the cause of death.
The Times also said internal company documents indicated that a group of researchers and administrator at the company's United States affiliate, Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. in Nutley, N.J., twice urged Swiss executives to market the drug in a less concentrated form.
But the company pressed ahead with marketing plans, citing economic objectives, The Times reported. Three weeks after its second objection, the dissenting group said new data from the use of Versed led the group to change its objection, the newspaper said, citing internal documents.
Versed is used to sedate patients during minor surgery or before and during general anesthesia. It is chemically close to Valium, a hugely successful sedative also marketed by Hoffmann-La Roche.
At a Congressional hearing in 1988, it was reported that Hoffman-La Roche's Swiss operation knew higher concentrations of Versed were difficult for some doctors to administer and could cause over-sedation of patients.
Mr. Gurtner said that clinical trials in the United States and Europe of a 5-to-1 concentration of Versed showed it is safe in that formulation.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Tax Rule Benefits Night Workers

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
For thousands of urban workers, commuting late at night will become less worrisome, thanks to a regulation the Internal Revenue Service put into effect this week.
When an employer pays for a taxi or car service to take employees to or from work because it would be unsafe to walk or take public transportation, employees will have to report only $1.50 a ride, not the actual value, as taxable income. 
 The tax-forgiveness rule previously applied to people who occasionally worked late; it has now been extended to those who are assigned to the graveyard shift and are regularly given rides.
"The service has done a fantastic job in taking some action to recognize the realities of urban life," said Avery E. Neumark, chairman of the fringe benefits subcommittee of the American Bar Association's section on taxation, which helped to persuade the I.R.S. to change its position. "This can be tremendously beneficial, because usually people who work at these hours don't make much."
Law and accounting firms often employ word processers to transcribe documents overnight. Utilities have repair people and technicians who work late, as do broadcasters. People in a variety of service industries also work through the night.
Some law and accounting firms paid employees extra, to cover the taxes on the taxi rides they had to report as income, said Mr. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie, a New York accounting firm. But some did not, and many workers were afraid to accept a night job or risked using public transportation in high-crime areas to avoid the tax liability.
A taxi ride to the New York suburbs or the outer parts of the Bronx or Queens could easily cost $30, Mr. Neumark said. That would equal $7,200 a year; Federal, state and city income taxes on that amount, plus Social Security taxes, could be $2,900.
To be eligible for the tax forgiveness, a worker has to meet two tests: he or she must be paid $60,535 or less in 1991 (the number is indexed for inflation and will rise in future years) and be eligible for overtime pay of at least time and a half for working more than 40 hours a week.
In testimony before the I.R.S. this week, Mr. Neumark asked that only the first test be used. "The mugger doesn't ask, 'Are you an hourly or salaried employee?' " he said.
That and a further recommendation to extend the regulations to cover transportation in employer-owned cars are being considered. In the meantime, the rules already adopted should help to raise the morale of urban workers fearful of crime, Mr. Neumark said, and "it puts them on a parity with workers elsewhere, who are not taxed on employer-provided parking."
 
 Home Ownership
 When Americans start to look for new homes -- as many are doing this time of year -- the vast majority think first about the mortgage. How big and desirable a home they can buy is determined by how big a mortgage they can receive. Indeed, the conventional wisdom is that over the years the home's value will rise and its owner will receive tax deductions.
But William J. Goldberg, who is in charge of personal financial planning for KPMG Peat Marwick, rejects that view. He is advising home owners to take a conservative stance and hold down their mortgage costs.
"Back when there was high inflation, generally leverage worked in your favor," he said. "Fix your cost today, stretch, and pay it off with cheaper dollars." But since home values have declined in many regions, the opposite approach is now best, said Mr. Goldberg, a partner in KPMG's Houston office. With many economists expecting low inflation to continue, the situation may not change.
In addition, tax deductions were more attractive when they meant the Federal Government was picking up half of the cost of real estate taxes and mortgage interest. Now a taxpayer in the top Federal bracket of 31 percent is still paying 69 cents on the dollar, he noted.
"Vocational insecurity is also a factor," he said. With layoffs widespread, many employees are anxious about their jobs, he said, and many professionals like doctors, lawyers and accountants are finding their income is 20 to 30 percent lower than a year ago. People with relatively low monthly payments are in better shape to weather any storms.
Mr. Goldberg advises people who are selling one home and buying another to put the equity from the first into the second, rather than make a minimal down payment. "Not many people can pay cash," he said, "unless they are moving from Los Angeles to Houston," or are selling a big home to buy a retirement home. But many can make a large down payment and limit the size of the mortgage.
He also advises those who already have big mortgages to pay them down ahead of schedule, if possible. "The less your loan is, the better off you're going to be in the long run, barring fabulous inflation," he said.
But he added one caveat: "Don't do it if you are going to need the money for tuition next year. Don't think of the house as a piggy bank, where you put the money in and get it back out."

HEADLINE: About New York

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
So here we are mired in a recession at a time when doomsayers see the lights dimming on the Great White Way, and we run across an absolute novice -- a waiter, in fact -- starting his own theater company and being the producer of an avant-garde Russian drama.
All on the strength of little more than a nice smile and a Visa card in the name of Keith Gilroy. 
 "He's doing everything wrong," Arthur Cantor sighed. "It's an absolutely foolhardy thing."
Mr. Cantor is an old lion of the theater world, having staged better than 100 shows, some quite classy. Eileen Atkins's recent one-woman performance as Virginia Woolf, for instance. And some not quite so classy. "Vampire Lesbians of Sodom" comes to mind.
He worships the histrionic art, but has also come to know Broadway for what it often is: a fool's-gold paradise where brazen compromise is revered as genius, where exquisite talent is brutally replaceable and where every dream carries a price tag.
"I'm so cynical about this business," he said.
Then, last Monday, a 26-year-old dreamer waltzed into the old schemer's cluttered office and sold him a deal almost certain to lose money. On the strength of Mr. Gilroy's "divine insanity" -- and a few phone calls to check his credentials -- Mr. Cantor agreed to rent the Provincetown Playhouse, a 175-seat theater he manages in Greenwich Village, to the young man for $1,000 next Friday through Monday. Maybe just enough to cover expenses.
Mr. Gilroy convinced the impresario -- or landlord in this case -- that Tverboul, a Russian dramatic troupe that had wowed him at a theater festival in Scotland last summer, just had to be seen by Manhattan audiences. Its eclectic approach, he said, can be described as "collages of street scenes."
Tverbol had planned only two American engagements, on Long Island and in Chicago. Mr. Gilroy took in the Long Island show, then offered the Russians a chance to pick up a couple thousand extra dollars, though they might have to sleep on his floor.
Their immediate "Da!" and Mr. Cantor's generosity were just two pieces of the puzzle: a friend who works for an ad agency is making fliers; another friend is using a personal computer to print tickets, and the Marriott Marquis Hotel on Times Square, where Mr. Gilroy is a waiter, is supplying free rooms. Actor friends, most of whom are also waiters, have written checks for as much as $1,500.
We caught up with Mr. Gilroy in the spinning rooftop restaurant where he usually works but where on this day he was complaining about the service. He sat at a window table with his girlfriend, Lisa Bobonis, 26, a former ballerina whose bad ankle has led to jobs like spritzing perfume on Bloomingdale's customers.
Sitting in such bubbly company, we had the distinct feeling that young dreams still might come true in this battered old burg. Just as a psychic had predicted, it was love at first sight for these two. They met at a "surrealistic fashion show" replete with mermaids munching shrimp. They live in a spacious apartment in a dilapidated Lower East Side building that was once home to the jazz legend Charlie Parker. The decor includes a horse's head from "Equus."
Since he played Winthrop -- the kid who lisps in "The Music Man" -- at a dinner theater, Mr. Gilroy's ambition has been the stage. He has drifted into directing.
An early effort was directing a friend's play produced in a small theater called Synchronicity Space in SoHo. They got a bargain-basement rental on the theater, provided they put up their set overnight. Hey, no problem for dreamers. That led to being invited to form a resident theater company at Synchronicity. Barebones Productions was born.
Mr. Gilroy made it a limited partnership, through which 21 members agreed to invest $125 a month for 15 months. They were guaranteed acting lessons with first-rate teachers; one comes from the Royal Shakespeare Company. They are also given a chance to participate in four productions a year. And who knows? The explicitly for-profit troupe might even make money.
Their first production, Viki Boyle's "The Whole Truth," was recently a winner at the Short Play Festival at the Double Image Theater in SoHo.
Mr. Gilroy hopes that the Russians can be persuaded to stay a week or two longer, but that may be precluded by an engagement in the Netherlands.
As is, it is too late to properly publicize next week's performance. Even free listings, including those in the Sunday New York Times, had unmeetable deadlines.
Well, shucks. Keith Gilroy Productions will present Tverboul, described as a "collage of striking scenes and beautiful, haunting songs," at the Provincetown Playhouse at 133 MacDougal Street, July 12-15. Ticket price is $20. For more information, call 212-279-4200.

HEADLINE: Ray of Hope for Homeless Penetrates Meager Walls of Miami Shantytown

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 5

 BODY:
From the elevated expressways that lace this city, Miami seems all glitter. But below the main ramp that leads downtown lies a shadowy shantytown, swirling with smoke and mosquitoes, where people like Andrew Johnson struggle to live in a city that has long refused to care adequately for its homeless.
"We're just trying to survive," said Mr. Johnson, who calls himself A.J. and has initialled gold caps on his front teeth to prove it. He said he got the teeth when times were good and when, as a Coast Guard veteran and long-haul truck driver, he was doing all right. 
 Now the slim 45-year-old man lives in an eight-square-foot hutch of old plywood and cardboard under the Interstate 395 overpass a few yards from Miami's showcase, Biscayne Boulevard. "Miami doesn't make it easy for us."
 
Plan for a Large Program
 But this week, under persistent prodding by a Federal court, city officials tentatively agreed to a plan intended to establish Miami's first large-scale program to help the homeless.
The plan, which still must be approved by the city commissioners, would provide accommodations for 30 days for as many as 500 homeless people at Bobby Maduro Stadium, an open-air baseball stadium, about a mile from the overpass, that a few years ago housed Nicaraguan refugees. The plan is seen as a first step toward a permanent program.
City officials said the state had committed as much as $300,000 for the project, which, along with city and county involvement, would provide shelter, showers, food, medical care and counseling to help the homeless find jobs and a place to live.
Until now, Miami has done almost nothing for its 6,000 homeless but arrest them for violating various city ordinances. The only city shelter program, run with Dade County, operates 100 beds. The city provides less than $400,000 a year to private organizations that help the homeless, and advocates say this does not amount to much compared to the efforts of nearly every other major city in the nation.
Mayor Xavier Suarez acknowledged that it was unlikely the city would have agreed to do anything without the pressures brought by a 1988 suit and a rising outrage among downtown merchants worried that the homeless are scaring away business. But in the city's defense, he said Miami has been hampered by a split in government responsibilities between the city and Dade County that has made it impossible to get a consensus on how to deal with the homeless.
In one way, the city backed itself into a corner. By sweeping the homeless from its parks last February, the city forced them to find a new place to stay, which turned out to be beneath the overpass, where they are more visible to thousands of commuters and shoppers.
"At this point," said Andrew L. Cherry, a professor of social work at Barry University, who has studied the homeless camps for four years, "the city is either going to really start helping the homeless or roust them out of here for good."
Around the country, there is a growing impatience with the homeless. New York moved aggressively last month to roust homeless people from encampments at Tompkins Square Park and Columbus Circle in Manhattan. Santa Barbara, Calif., has passed no-sleeping and no-camping ordinances. Cincinnati has taken to giving tickets carrying a $114 fine tohomeless beggars for aggressive panhandling. Atlanta, Chicago and Columbus, Ohio, are among cities that have recently shown a backlash toward street people.
But Miami stands apart.
"Miami is in a different league from other cities because it never had a positive response toward helping the homeless," said Fred G. Karnas Jr., executive director of the National Coalition for the Homeless, based in Washington. The head of the Miami Coalition for the Homeless, a local advocacy group that is loosely affiliated with the national organization, said Miami's attitude has changed for the worse.
"Miami seems to have jumped right from apathy to anger," said Christine M. Hildner, executive director of the organization.
That anger was most tragically displayed last May when someone jumped from a van and clubbed to death a homeless man sleeping under I-95, not far from the downtown shanties. The police said the attack was apparently unprovoked, and Ms. Hildner said she considered it an isolated incident.
 
Other Signs of Rejection
 But there have been other less violent expressions of rejection. "No windshield washing" signs have sprouted downtown to deter street-corner entrepreneurs with squeegees, and more than 100 homeless people have been arrested for violating the ordinance over the last year. Some merchants on Biscayne Boulevard have fenced their properties to keep the homeless away at night. Yacht owners who dock at the Bayside Marina put up a fence to keep the homeless from using their tap water.
With its easy climate and the traces of a frontier attitude, where thousands of immigrants have successfully started over, Miami never has had much sympathy for the homeless. The city relies on a sunny, carefree image to attract tourists and conventions, the region's lifeblood. Community leaders do not want to do anything to attract even more homeless people.
Concern for the city's image is one reason the encampment under the overpass has inflamed emotions. It lies in sight of Miami's fleet of bleached white cruise ships and just blocks from the city's new downtown shopping mall.
In recent months the encampment has become a focus of even greater frustration and concern as it has spread to cover an area as wide as a six-lane highway and as long as about four city blocks. The basic building materials are shopping carts, called buggies, discarded plywood and cardboard. Landscape sprinklers broken by the homeless provide water for cooking and washing. Men and women wearing swimsuits use the sprinklers to shower, and they use the bathroom at a local Burger King or in nearby bushes.
The highway about 16 feet above them provides shade all day and generates a steady hum that helps the homeless tune out the traffic whizzing by them on all sides. Arthur Harris, a 38-year-old unemployed construction worker, said the worst part of living under the overpass right now is fighting off the swarms of newly hatched mosquitoes.
 
A Precarious Existence
 Mr. Harris said he used to sleep in a city park until the police swept through it one night last February. He was not able to grab any of his possessions before he was carried off in a paddy wagon to be dropped off about half a mile away. By the time he walked back, he said, all his things were gone.
A Federal judge later fined the city $2,500 for those actions and others that violate an injunction against harassing the homeless. The court proceedings have been going on since 1988, when lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida brought a lawsuit against Miami, claiming the city tried to sweep the homeless from sight before events like the Orange Bowl football game or the 1987 visit of Pope John Paul II. A trial is scheduled to begin in September.
As controversy swirls around them, many people living under the overpass focus on their own needs, some with surprising success.
Chelly Bulnes, a 31-year-old Miami native who has been on the streets with her husband, Salvador, for two years, lives in one of the most elaborate hutches. It is a triumph of inventiveness, made from cloth-covered office dividers that she said she salvaged from the trash. In one room she has a pull-out sofa lined with plush toy animals, a plastic foam cooler containing soda and chicken parts and a table on which she keeps her coloring books and crayons. In a plywood extension, she has a black leather sofa that was thrown out in a downtown office renovation and a twin-sized mattress.
"I think the city is really trying," Mrs. Bulnes said. "I know Suarez has us on his mind, but it's not easy. There's just too many people on the street."
 
'That Was Foolish'
 Mr. Suarez concedes that until recently Miami deserved its reputation as a city that refused to care for its homeless. He blamed the city's inability to act partly on the ineffectiveness of the form of government.
The government of Miami is split between the city, which provides physical services, including the police, and Metro-Dade County, which takes care of social services.
"For years the city said, 'We don't have responsibility for social services,' and the county said, 'We don't have the funds,' " Mr. Suarez said. "That was foolish because the homeless were everywhere."
The plan to accommodate 500 homeless people in the stadium is described as a temporary response but one based on the city's experience this year of forcing the homeless from one location only to find them in another. Mr. Suarez said that he realizes the city must come up with a permanent solution and that with the current climate of soul-searching, the time is right.
Many people under the overpass welcomed the plan and said they would gladly move. "All I want to do," said Mr. Johnson, sweeping outside his plywood hutch with a broken-handled broom, "is get myself out of a jam."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Up But Pay Is, Too, In Mixed Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
More signs of an incipient economic recovery emerged today even as the Government's first comprehensive report for June showed a decline in business payrolls and a rise of one-tenth of a point in the unemployment rate, to 7 percent.
The latest data, although mixed, sent a shudder through the bond market, pushing up interest rates as traders contemplated, among other things, a six-tenths of 1 percent increase in average hourly earnings that hinted at a stepped-up pace of inflation. [Page 33.] 
 At the White House, Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, found "a variety of mixed messages" and interpretive difficulties in the new figures but said they did not change the Administration's basic assessment. "The economy, we believe, has begun to recover," Mr. Boskin said at a briefing for reporters.
 
Lagging Current Conditions
 The jobless rate is considered a lagging economic indicator, which means that it tends to keep rising, for example, even after business recoveries get under way. A principal reason is that to be counted as unemployed, one must be actively seeking work, and in an improved economy people who were not previously looking for work are now looking, therefore increasing the unemployment rate.
Private economists as well as the Bureau of Labor Statistics tended to dismiss the rise in the unemployment rate as both unsurprising and, because the change was less than two-tenths of a point, statistically insignificant.
But Democrats seized on the figures to assail the Bush Administration. The unemployment rate was the highest since late 1986 and there was a sharp increase in the number of people who had been jobless for at least 15 weeks.
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, and Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat who is chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, wrote President Bush to urge action to provide additional weeks of unemployment compensation for those whose normal 26 weeks of benefits have expired.
In a separate report today, the Labor Department said initial claims for jobless benefits during the third week of June declined 8,000 from the preceding week, to a total of 423,000, well below the 500,000-plus peaks recorded in March.
Among the most striking positive factors in today's data were a 12-minute extension of the private-sector workweek, a 24-minute extension of factory hours and an 18-minute extension of factory overtime.
This was also seen as typical of the early stages of recovery when employers, many of whom are not yet convinced that the turn has come, tend to work their employees longer rather than hire new workers.
The longer factory hours, now at their highest levels since last fall, helped raise the index of aggregate weekly hours, a major determinant of industrial production, to 121.7 in June from 121.1 in May.
Other favorable elements in today's data were a second straight decline in the number of people working fewer hours than they would like, and a decline of 227,000 in the ranks of the newly unemployed, those looking for work for less than five weeks.
The quarterly survey of discouraged workers -- those who have given up looking for a job because they think they cannot find one -- found that the number fell slightly in the April-June period, to 981,000 from 997,000.
Among the report's negatives, one of the most disappointing was a decline of 50,000 in payroll jobs when a modest increase was widely anticipated. Factory jobs were down 59,000, with the hardest-hit industries being those making military and transportation equipment. Auto makers have for some time been managing their inventories of cars by altering employment levels.
 
Health Sector Keeps Growing
 But jobs in the service industry rose 69,000, the biggest gain since August, as recession-resistant health services gained another 40,000 and business services, an industry closely tied to overall economic conditions, gained 12,000.
Analysts also took some comfort from the fact that growth of payroll jobs for May was revised upward to a gain of 119,000 instead of the 59,000 initially reported.
During transition periods, the data are usually mixed, observed Donald H. Straszheim, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "These don't indicate to me we're going back into recession," he said.
The survey of households, on which the official unemployment figure is calculated, showd that employment rose 293,000 in June after two months of unexplained gyrations that saw a jump in April of 644,000 and a drop in May of 807,000.
There were no significant changes in unemployment among the various population groups last month, but large swings were posted by some of the 11 major states for which June data are available. The jobless rate in Illinois soared 1.3 points, to 7.3 percent, while Pennsylvania's fell 1 point, to 6.7 percent. The rates for New York and New Jersey moved marginally, with New York at 7.7 percent, up three-tenths of a percentage point, and New Jersey at 6.6 percent, down two-tenths.
In all, 397,000 people were added to the labor force last month, with the 104,000 who failed to find work swelling the joblesss ranks to 8,745,000. The 7 percent unemployment rate was the highest since October 1986. Of the jobless, the nearly 2.6 million out of work for more than 15 weeks now account for 29 percent.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed In Slow Day; Dow Off 2.23

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Wall Street mostly took a holiday yesterday. Stocks turned mixed and activity sank to the lowest level of the year as hundreds of traders stayed home for a long Fourth of July weekend.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell to 2,932.47, off 2.23 for the day but ahead 25.72 for the week. 
 Activity on both the New York and American stock exchanges and in the over-the-counter market fell to the lowest levels of the year.
"It was just a post-July Fourth day," said Eugene E. Peroni, chief technical analyst for Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia.
Monday's 51.66-point surge in the Dow in the wake of a big run-up in Japan's Nikkei stock index helped the Dow stay in the black for the week.
 
 Earnings More of a Factor
 Since then, however, the Nikkei has been losing ground, dropping another 1 percent yesterday. Even so, the few traders around yesterday on Wall Street looked more to earnings than either the Nikkei or another piece of news on the economy.
New employment data came out yesterday showing that while payrolls dropped in June they apparently did not decline enough to prompt the Fed to trim interest rates. The news toppled bond prices but had little impact on stocks.
Along with the Dow blue chips, the Nasdaq composite fell a little, with high-technology stocks leading the way. The Standard & Poor's 500, peppered with the big stocks, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index, loaded with smaller stocks, both rose a bit. But the changes were far less than even 1 percent and in any case meant little because many traders were elsewhere yesterday.
Except for a brief 12-point slide in the Dow at the start of trading, the blue chips jumped 28 points from their low by 10:30 but then began dropping. In a decline that lasted for the rest of the day, the Dow lost most of its gain by 1:30, moving aimlessly until the closing bell.
Trading on the Big Board hit a new low for the year yesterday of 69.9 million shares, down sharply from 140.6 million on Wednesday. Volume was also down sharply from the previous 1991 low of 109.5 million on May 20, a quiet Monday, and was the lowest since Dec. 24, 1990, when 57.2 million shares were traded.
The Nasdaq hit a 1991 low of 56.3 million shares, down from its previous low for the year of 92.02 million. Trading on the Amex hit a new low yesterday of 5.4 million shares, down from the previous 1991 low of 6.99 million shares.
Mr. Peroni, the Philadelphia market watcher, pointed, though, to the market's "relative firmness."
"Compared to the bonds' sharp selloff," he said, "this relative firmness in stocks indicates that investors who were in the market today are looking for quality growth plays in anticipation of a focused earnings turnaround in the second half."
With Wall Street's attention fixed on I.B.M. and a few other technology stocks as one of the best ways to forecast the direction of stock prices, Mr. Peroni argued that the market was "apt to remain unsettled for several weeks -- until it becomes clear whether investors have fully discounted lower earnings expectations for I.B.M. and other recently depressed tech stocks."
I.B.M. made the Big Board list of the 10 most active stocks, rising 1/2, to 98 5/8, in what appeared to be a reaction to its announcement with Apple Computer that the two would join forces to make personal computers easier to use.
Apple led Nasdaq's active list, rising 2 1/2, to 45 5/8, with nearly three million shares changing hands. A big competitor, Microsoft, stood in third place on the list, sinking 2 1/4, to 61 3/4, with volume of 1.6 million shares.
BankAmerica, which was down by 2 on Wednesday amid uncertainty over earnings, rose by 1, to 34 1/2, yesterday following its announcement after Wednesday's close of trading that it expected second-quarter earnings to be close to the $267 million it earned in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: BLACKS IN DECLINE IN NORTHERN CITIES

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
Blacks are moving away from metropolitan areas in the industrial North and toward metropolitan areas of the South and West, census figures show.
The trend, which counters old migration patterns, was underscored by declines in the black populations of the Pittsburgh-Beaver Valley area, by 1.5 percent, and in the Chicago-Gary-Lake County area, by 0.6 percent. Those were among many northern cities that were magnets for blacks escaping poverty and racial discrimination in the South in the 1950's and 1960's. 
 The Census Bureau tables from the 1990 count, made public on Thursday, showed that blacks are joining whites in moving to the Sun Belt and Far West, apparently seeking economic opportunities and better living conditions.
While black populations rose in some northern cities, the rates of increase were far lower than elsewhere and often were below the national increase of 13 percent in the number of blacks in the decade.
But the black population rose 65.5 percent in Sacramento, Calif., 52.5 percent in San Diego, 50.1 percent in the Miami-Fort Lauderdale area and 40 percent in Atlanta and the Seattle-Tacoma area.
 
Rises in the North
 In the North, the New York-Northern New Jersey-Long Island area showed a 16.4 percent increase in black population, that in the Philadelphia-Wilmington-Trenton area was up 6.5 percent and the Detroit-Ann Arbor area grew by 5.9 percent.
The Boston-Lawrence-Salem area was one of the few in the North in which the black populations showed substantial growth, rising 35.6 percent. In the Washington D.C. area, the black population went up 19.7 percent.
The Census Bureau also reported that the Hispanic population in the Los Angeles-Anaheim-Riverside area grew more than 2 million, or 73.4 percent . At least 100,000 Hispanics were added to the rolls in 12 other cities and metropolitan areas, most of them in the border states of Texas, California and Arizona.
Proportionately, the biggest changes were in Orlando, Fla., up 271.2 percent; Washington, up 136.7 percent, and Las Vegas, Nev., up 136.3 percent.
The Los Angeles metropolitan area had the largest Hispanic population, with 4.78 million, followed by the New York metropolitan area, with 2.78 million, the Miami metropolitan area, with 1.06 million, and the San Francisco-Oakland-San Jose area, with 970,000.

HEADLINE: Frictions Haunt Rights Hero of Past

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 5

 BODY:
He left his blood on the streets of Selma, Rock Hill and Montgomery for the landmark civil rights bills of the 1960's, and John Lewis believes the moral issues that resonated then must resonate again.
"It is a shame and a disgrace that, in 1991, we are still debating whether or not we should protect our fellow American citizens from discrimination," Mr. Lewis, now a United States Representative from Atlanta, said last month as he called on the House to pass the latest civil rights bill. 
 Mr. Lewis, whose balding head bears the scars from beatings he received while being arrested about 40 times in the South in the 1960's, represents as much as any living American the heart and soul of the civil rights battles that changed the nation three decades ago. And as Congress lurches along in its struggle over the civil rights bill, which the House passed last month, he is also a symbol of the frustrations and contradictions surrounding civil rights issues today.
For Mr. Lewis, civil rights is still an issue of morality. When he attended dedication ceremonies this week for the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis, he marked a continuity of vision that goes from the streets of the South to the halls of Congress.
 
Some Difficult Questions
 But the dissension brought out in the debate over the civil rights bill has posed difficult questions even for Mr. Lewis: Does civil rights address the core problems facing minority groups today? Have the bill's proponents erred tactically and philosophically in putting it at the top of the Congressional agenda this year? What is the best way to build broad-based support for addressing the problems of the poor?
The questions come quicker than the answers.
Time has rounded out the slender frame that Mr. Lewis had in the days of the Freedom Rides. But, at the age of 51, his voice is still rich with the slow cadences of rural Alabama, and he still has the same dogged commitment he has had ever since he first heard the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preach a scratchy radio sermon in 1955.
The story of Mr. Lewis, who was born the son of a sharecropper in Troy, Ala., on Feb. 21, 1940, has become a staple of civil rights lore -- from his beginning as a shy farm boy who preached to the barnyard chickens to his service on the front lines of the Freedom Rides and sit-ins that changed the South.
Some, like Dr. King or Ralph Abernathy, were more dynamic leaders. Others, like Julian Bond, were more eloquent speakers or compelling tacticians. But Mr. Lewis's penchant for putting his body on the line and his almost spiritual commitment to the philosophy of nonviolence inspired extraordinary respect from his peers in the civil rights movement. Over the years he has emerged as one of the most unambiguously heroic figures of the 1960's.
"There were a lot of people who pretended they were civil rights heroes," said Roger Wilkins, a professor of history and American culture at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va. "John was a true hero, an absolute hero, a man of absolute fearlessness and total and utter integrity."
That sense of integrity is his main attribute in Congress, where he is serving his third term after winning a bruising election in 1986 that essentially shattered his longterm friendship with the man he defeated, Mr. Bond.
Mr. Lewis has no major legislation to his credit and is not regarded as an insider in Congress. But last year he became one of 31 members of the influential House Democratic Policy and Steering Committee. He has also become one of the best-liked men in Congress and is something of a celebrity, frequently stopped and praised by tourists and passers-by.
But the esteem in which Mr. Lewis is held for his role in the 1960's does not necessarily translate into an ability to change people's minds on civil rights in the 1990's.
 
A One-Man Lobbying Effort
 In the civil rights debate Mr. Lewis worked almost nonstop in an effort to convince vacillating members, including some of his best friends in Congress, to support the bill. Some, he says, simply dodged his phone calls. Others, like Representatives Marty Russo of Illinois and George (Buddy) Darden of Georgia, listened long and hard and then voted the other way.
Mr. Russo said that when he finally made up his mind on his vote Mr. Lewis was the first person he told.
"John Lewis is a living hero who, along with Martin Luther King, changed the course of history," Mr. Russo said. "It's important I have his respect and friendship. But I had to tell him I think this bill just leads to an enormous legal quagmire. I think it's just contributing to more polarization of the races."
Mr. Russo, a Democrat who is usually aligned with House liberals, added: "Instead of working on a civil rights bill, we should be working on an economic rights bill. I view this as a bill that helps a small minority of the minority."
Mr. Lewis well understands the difficulties the bill poses for Mr. Russo, many of whose constituents are working-class whites in the suburbs south of Chicago and who are most sensitive to allegations of racial quotas, the main argument used by opponents of the bill.
 
An Unsettling Familiarity
 What he has a harder time coming to terms with, Mr. Lewis said in an interview, is the unsettling familiarity in the nation's racial politics. In the Southern politics of his youth, pitting whites against blacks was standard fare. Now, he believes, the same process has become a staple of national politics.
He says he finds the tenor of the current debate profoundly troubling, and places the blame squarely on President Bush, whose public comments he compared on the House floor to that of former Gov. George Wallace of Alabama, who had Presidential aspirations before being crippled by a gunman in a Maryland parking lot, and Eugene (Bull) Connor, the former Birmingham police commissioner.
"There was not much difference really to what George Wallace did in his campaign and what President Bush has done, or some of the people in his Administration," Mr. Lewis said. "No President in modern times, not in the past 40 or 50 years, has ever used the issue of civil rights, the issue of race, the way this President has used it."
Mr. Lewis said he was also aware that the debate over the civil rights bill so far had aroused more passion on the part of its critics than its supporters.
"There's been no groundswell of support for it," he said. "We're probably getting at least a hundred letters a day dealing with triple-decker trucks. That's more of an issue in the district than this civil rights bill."
Indeed, Mr. Lewis acknowledges a broader lack of passion among civil rights advocates. He says he knows it may be naive to expect the drama and passion of Selma and Birmingham. But he says he also knows that civil rights is doomed unless it connects to a mass of people.
"During the 1960's the movement was from the bottom up," he said. "In 1965 it was people from the black belt of Alabama or the Mississippi Delta literally writing the bill with their feet. In 1990 and 1991, it's the professionals, the people within the Beltway, and you need more than that."
To some critics, including some Democrats, who believe the civil rights debate is doing more harm than good, the problem is deeper than tactics and strategy. They say Mr. Lewis represents the degree to which civil rights leaders are fighting old battles with old issues, while the plight of the poor grows ever worse.
"John is truly misguided," said Bob Woodson, a black conservative who heads the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, which has pioneered some of the low-income housing strategies favored by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp. "People like him continue to press this as the quintessential issue for black Americans today, and it's not; it's really a middle-class access bill."
 
Dr. King's Ability to Change
 Mr. Woodson added: "Martin Luther King is always held up as a model, but no one seems to have emulated King in his ability to change with the times and to regroup and refocus his energies. Remember, King died helping those garbage workers in Memphis. Martin Luther King would not have been hung up on civil rights today."
Mr. Lewis readily agrees that what is needed is not just civil rights legislation, but also a comprehensive program to address the needs of the poor. But he has few specific strategies for revitalizing the movement.
Still, if he does not have a blueprint, Mr. Lewis does have a sense of what is missing in the civil rights debate: a sense of shared purpose, of basic morality, that speaks to blacks and whites alike.
In Memphis this week he spoke of today's environment for civil rights, including Justice Thurgood Marshall's departure from the Supreme Court and the President's nomination of Clarence Thomas, a black conservative hostile to much of the civil rights agenda, to replace him.
"A lot of young people who came to Mississippi or Selma or the Freedom Rides thought you could come for a summer, a semester, a year, and create something new," Mr. Lewis said. "But most of us knew this is not a struggle that lasts one day or one week or one month or one lifetime."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative John Lewis in his Washington office. "It is a shame and a disgrace that, in 1991, we are still debating whether or not we should protect our fellow American citizens from discrimination," he said last month on behalf of the civil rights bill. (Andrea Mohin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Depressed By Job Data

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds plunged and interest rates soared yesterday as the fixed-income market reacted negatively to indications of growing economic strength in an otherwise mixed Government report on employment in June.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell more than three-quarters of a point, or close to $8 per $1,000 face value, pushing its yield up to almost 8.5 percent. 
 Any hint of economic improvement is generally taken badly by bondholders and investors in other fixed-income securities because increasing strength raises fears of inflation and higher interest rates. Both erode the value of existing fixed-interest securities.
 
 Gains in Hours and Wages

The Government said the nation's unemployment rate rose to 7 percent in June, from 6.9 percent, as 50,000 non-farm jobs were lost last month. But it also revised growth in May payroll jobs to a gain of 119,000, up from 59,000 originally reported. And it reported gains in both the number of hours worked by employees and wages paid to them. When employers find business improving but are still unconvinced that a recession is coming to an end, they often prefer to pay for overtime rather than hire new workers.
"While the overall numbers were more or less neutral, the bond market chose to focs on the numbers of hours worked and wages paid last month and the bond market did not like what it saw," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Mr. Sullivan said that two other lesser but significant factors also weighed on the bond market. One was a shortened trading session. The Treasury securities market, which normally does not observe fixed trading hours, closed at 2 P. M., Eastern time, to enable traders and their staffs to have a longer Fourth of July weekend. A shortened session tends to reduce the number of market participants, and this, in turn, often causes wider gaps in quotes and thus exaggerates price movements.
"We will have to wait until early next week to really see how hard the market is taking the employment data," Mr. Sullivan said.
 
More Than $30 Billion
 The other factor is the impending increase in the supply of Treasury paper scheduled for auction in the next few weeks. Not only will the auctions of roughly $42 billion of seven-, five- and two-year notes and one-year bills add to the supply of Treasury debt issues, but the market also faces the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions the first week in August. The refunding should increase the supply of Treasury notes and bonds by more than $30 billion.
At yesterday's early close, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in May 2021, were offered at 96 2/32, down 26/32, while the yield climbed to 8.49 percent, from 8.41 percent the day before and 8.40 percent at the end of last week.
On the Chicago Board of Trade's Treasury bond futures market, the spot September delivery closed down 30/32, at 92 25/32. Brokers there said traders were also influenced by the pockets of strength in the jobs data.
Treasury note prices were also battered. The 8's of 2001 dropped 19/32, to 97 26/32, for a yield of 8.32 percent; the 7 7/8's of 1996 lost 10/32, at 99 17/32, for a yield of 7.99 percent, and the 7's of 1993 fell 3/32, to 99 31/32, for a yield of 7.01 percent.
On Wednesday, the Treasury plans to hold its quarterly auction of seven-year notes. The amount to be sold is $9 billion. The notes traded yesterday on a when-issued basis to yield 8.21 percent. Terms of the regular monthly auctions of two- and five-year notes will be announced the next week.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on the 90-day bills rose 2 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.58 percent. Six-month bills rose 3 basis points, to 5.71 percent. One-year bills rose 2 basis points, to 6.02 percent.
The Federal Reserve did not intervene in the market. The key funds rate that banks charge each other for temporary loans traded at 5 5/8 percent most of the day, and the Fed's perceived target for the rate, from which most other interest rates are scaled upward, is 5 3/4 percent.

HEADLINE: In New South, Old Crop Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: COTTONPORT, La., June 26

 BODY:
After the last farmers stopped growing it in the early 1970's, a lot of people never expected cotton to return to Cottonport.
But when Filmore Bordelon 3d resumed growing the crop that gave this town its name, he was taking part in a quiet revolution over the last few years that resonates with the enduring mythology of the South and irrevocable evidence of change. 
 The mythic element is the return of King Cotton to hundreds of Southern farming communities from Cottonport to Snow Hill, N.C., that abandoned it decades ago. In dollar value, the $5 billion cotton crop last year was the country's largest in history.
But cotton is returning to a changed world of declining rural areas where it is harvested not by slaves or sharecroppers but by expensive machines that often are run by crews of Hispanic migrant workers. And its resurgence means more to the few mechanized farms big enough to grow it -- with fewer employees -- than it does to the declining small town, which once lived or died with cotton.
Few miss the harsh economics of the day when cotton was king, but its return is a reminder that nothing has replaced it as an employer -- particularly as an employer of large numbers of rural blacks -- in much of the South.
"The revival of cotton in the South is not going to bring back the small towns," said Charles S. Aiken, a professor of geography at the University of Tennessee, who has studied cotton's decline. "You can go to the areas where cotton is still viable, and most of the towns are losing population and businesses are still going out."
For Mr. Bordelon, whose grandfather grew cotton on the family's "Old Boy" plantation at the beginning of the century and whose grandmother may have been one of the last growers to farm cotton with mules and hand hoes, the crop's resurgence is first and foremost an economic decision. But it is a sentimental one as well.
"Sure it's nostalgic," said Mr. Bordelon, 35 years old, who farms the rich Red River alluvial soil in central Louisiana, about 80 miles northwest of Baton Rouge. "I was the first one to grow cotton in Cottonport in maybe 20 years last year," he said. "You had people coming by to watch us pick it, people showing their grandkids how they used to pick some cotton themselves. That may not mean much to people in the city, but it does to me."
 
Cotton as a Way of Life
 For most of its history in the South, cotton has been more than a crop. It has been, for better or worse, a way of life.
Cotton provided the underpinnings for slavery before the Civil War and for sharecropping after it. When cotton picking was mechanized after World War II, the change led to the migration of Southern blacks to the North that changed both regions forever.
Cotton, of course, never disappeared from the South. For years, Texas has been the largest cotton producer, followed by California. Total production in the United States last year was 15.5 million bales, up 27 percent over the previous year. In 1937, the peak year for cotton production, 18.9 million bales were produced.
In parts of the South, including northern Louisiana and the Mississippi Delta, cotton never relinquished its role as the backbone of the farming economy, and it played some part in the economies of most Southern states.
But in the late 1930's, low prices, infestations of pests like the boll weevil, competition from artificial fibers and high production costs relegated cotton to a marginal status in many parts of the South and wiped it out in others.
Despite fluctuations over the years, cotton production continued on a downward trend that accelerated in the 1970's when many farmers deserted cotton for soybeans, corn and wheat -- plants that were less evocative for the South but more profitable. In the 1960's and 1970's, cotton production in the South, from Arkansas and Louisiana to Florida and Virginia, declined by half.
 
Popularity Helps Comeback
 But in more recent years, cotton production has surged, spurred by higher prices, a resurgence in popularity, as opposed to synthetic fibers, and advances in pest eradication as well as Government farm policies that have helped cotton farmers. And while the production of cotton in California has been slowed by water shortages, it has seen a sharp comeback in the South.
From 1983 to 1990, acreage devoted to cotton growing in five southeastern states increased to 1.1 million acres from 481,000. In five mid-South states, it grew to 3.5 million acres from 1.7 million.
In Louisiana, where the acres devoted to cotton fell to a low of 300,000 from a peak of 1.1 million, cotton acreage is back up to 770,000.
 
New Gins Are Sign of Resurgence
 Cottonport began as just that, a cotton port visited by paddle-wheelers that came down the Mississippi to what was then a flooded bayou. But cotton production had generally died out in the area by the early 1970's and all the old cotton gins were closed.
In the last few years, though, cotton acreage in Avoyelles Parish jumped to about 14,000 acres from a few thousand. The number of acres would have risen to 20,000 this year, but unrelenting rains held down the crop. More important, two gins are going up -- signs of a commitment to the crop.
"We're probably the only area in America that has two brand new gins being constructed," Mr. Bordelon said. "All people have talked about for the last 18 months is planting cotton."
Cotton's legacy for the South has always been a mixed one. It produced the wealth that built the South, providing much of the economic and cultural coherence that gave rise to the Confederacy. But cotton's rise, predicated on cheap labor, created not just a dependence on slavery, but a history of economic and political domination by a few large planters.
 
Small Farmers Paid Dearly
 Over time, many small independent farmers paid dearly for their flirtation with cotton.
"The great ideal of the yeoman farmer, the Jeffersonian ideal, is that you're independent farmers; you grow what you need and you rely on yourself," said Charles Reagan Wilson, a professor of history and Southern studies at the University of Mississippi. "When the plain folk started losing that independence was when they turned to cotton, because it made them dependent on the world market price. It seemed at first an easy way to make easy profits, but, in effect, it was kind of a seduction, and increasingly, they lost their land."
Any profitable crop will have some benefits for the rural South, and cotton may still provide more than most crops will.
"It doesn't take a lot of people to grow soybeans or wheat and harvest it," said J. Walker Clarke, a cotton merchant in Columbia, S.C. "Cotton spreads into the community better because you have cotton gins that have to be put up and run. You have cotton storage facilities. You have trucking. You have merchants, such as myself."
 
Big Farm Operations Required
 But the effects on the communities now do not approach what they once were. Because of the high costs of chemicals and machinery, like a $100,000 cotton picker, there are no small cotton farmers. And because of mechanization, cotton no longer provides nearly as many jobs.
Mr. Bordelon's house is decorated with colorful folk-art plantation scenes of blacks working in cotton fields. But most of the contract workers who run the cotton pickers or work at the gins in the fall harvest season are Mexican-Americans and aliens who work with crews that come from Texas.
"Cotton doesn't provide the jobs it used to, and nothing has replaced it," said Carlos Smith, the local extension agent here. "But then I don't think most people miss those kind of jobs. I certainly don't."
Cotton will always have its cycles, and some experts like Professor Aiken are skeptical about how long-lived and significant cotton's comeback will be. But some industry figures say the popularity of natural fibers bodes well for cotton's long-term prospects.
"Until they change the name of polyester, it's going to be a bad word," said Mr. Clarke, the South Carolina cotton merchant.
Still, economists agree cotton will never be king in the South the way it was in the past.
"Now growing cotton is an economic decision; it's not tied in with all the other social and cultural factors," said Professor Wilson. "When the market is bad, farmers will give up cotton, where in the past that didn't happen. Cotton is not going to energize the rural areas. We've already abandoned them to a large degree."
