HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Quiet Trading After Unemployment Report

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed lower in quiet trading yesterday as dealers digested the latest Government report on jobs.
The Labor Department report showed unemployment in June climbing to 7.0 percent but also included indications of economic strength. As such, it carried mixed implications for the dollar, and "after the numbers, the dollar was just sold out," said Joe Cambria, foreign exchange manager for Banque Paribas. 
 The dollar also fell under pressure by traders squaring their books ahead of the weekend. The United States market was closed Thursday for the Fourth of July holiday.
The dollar ended at 1.8250 German marks, down from 1.8343 marks on Thursday in Europe and 1.8286 marks on Wednesday in New York. It closed at 138.35 Japanese yen, down from 139.15 on Thursday in Europe and 139.58 on Wednesday in New York.
The dollar initially fell because of employment statistics that showed June non-farm payrolls fell by 50,000, compared with economists' average forecast of an 11,000 gain.
But May payrolls were revised to a rise of 119,000 from a previously reported increase of 59,000. In addition, the statistics said hourly earnings and hours worked rose in June.
Dealers said market sentiment remained cautiously bullish toward the dollar after the data, but some said they were skeptical about a sharp rebound in the United States.
"I think it will be a long and slow recovery," said Kevin Weir, vice president of Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce in New York.
Sales of yen for marks also helped push the dollar lower against the German currency, traders said. Traders said the dollar was likely to test higher levels against the mark next week, but they did not anticipate huge gains for the United States currency.
The turmoil in Yugoslavia also improved sentiment for the dollar against the mark, said Belal Khan, a corporate dealer for Fuji Bank. Slovenia freed Yugoslav Army prisoners under a truce yesterday and said it had demobilized thousands of its own troops. The European Community agreed to send ministers back to Yugoslavia to reactivate a peace mission.
The British pound closed at $1.6155, up from $1.6030 on Thursday in London and 1.6070 on Wednesday in New York. The dollar ended at 1.5745 Swiss francs, down from 1.5825 on Thursday in Europe and 1.5793 on Wednesday in New York.
Precious metals futures were not traded yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York in an extension of the Fourth of July holiday.

HEADLINE: Federal Express in Pact To Buy Jets From Airbus

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, July 5

 BODY:
The Federal Express Corporation announced today that it would buy up to 75 wide-body cargo jets from Europe's Airbus Industrie consortium in a deal that could be worth as much as $6 billion.
The package-delivery company said the new planes, to be delivered at a rate of six per year, will have 40 percent greater capacity than the current Boeing 727s that dominate its 416-plane fleet. 
 In addition, the Airbus jets can be flown by two pilots, compared with three for the Boeings, analysts said.
Federal Express said it placed 25 firm orders for Airbus Industrie A300-600 aircraft, 25 reconfirmable orders subject to cancellation and options for an additional 25 planes.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but industry sources, noting that the Airbus planes cost about $80 million each, said the order would be worth $6 billion if all options were exercised.
The announcement of a deal had been expected since last month, when Federal Express said during the Paris Air Show that it was negotiating with the European manufacturer, a consortium of Aerospatiale of France, British Aerospace P.L.C., Daimler Benz AG's Deutsche Airbus and CASA of Spain.
The order was the first for Airbus's A-300 wide-body jet to be built in a freighter configuration. Earlier versions have been passenger planes that were later converted for use as freighters.
Federal Express said the planes will be powered by CF6-80C2 engines made by the General Electric Company. Deliveries are scheduled to begin in early 1994.
The planes will be used on United States domestic routes, the company said.
Craig Kloner, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said that Federal Express's focus in the last several years has been on international growth, noting that the planes on order have the potential to fly international routes as well.
The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation have complained that state subsidies to Airbus have given the consortium an unfair advantage in the highly competitive market for new aircraft. American and European Community officials have been negotiating the dispute.
Spokesmen for Boeing and McDonnell Douglas said they had not competed for Federal Express's freighter aircraft orders.
"We do not have a freighter model with the specifications that Fedex requested," a Boeing spokesman said. A spokesman at McDonnell Douglas's Long Beach, Calif. division said the company was not participating in the competition.
Federal Express shares closed up 87.5 cents at $40.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Tourist in Car Killed as She Chances Upon Chinatown Gunfight

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
It was a reunion that drew Rhona Lantin to the New York area, a chance to mix with old high school friends from the Philippines, trade memories, catch up on too many years apart. It was also a chance to see the town, take in the theater, watch the fireworks explode over New York Harbor on a warm, beautiful night -- the best kind of things the area has to offer.
But a bullet ended that. It just happened. At 11:30 P.M. Thursday, as Ms. Lantin and friends were driving north on a Chinatown street, headed for a late-night snack after the mammoth fireworks display, members of a notorious Chinatown gang, the Ghost Shadows, began to fight, the police say. 
 By the time the car reached the crowded intersection, the dispute had become a gun battle. Gunfire erupted and a bullet hit Ms. Lantin, sitting in the passenger seat, in the head. She died yesterday morning at 8:53 at St. Vincent's Hospital.
Yesterday, friends of Ms. Lantin were left to contemplate the fate that linked their 26-year-old friend, a Government economist known for her gentleness, her devotion to her family and her fondness for Filipino handicrafts, to the brutality of a Chinatown gunfight.
"When tragedy strikes, you always hear people say, 'It couldn't have happened to a nicer, gentler person,' " said Hallis Seitz, a neighbor of Ms. Lantin's in Silver Spring, Md. "Well, in this case it really does apply."
The randomness of the shooting was unusual for Chinatown, where violent gangs like the Ghost Shadows usually choose their victims carefully, then stalk them on foot on narrow, winding streets that are almost always congested. The killers are usually precise, walking up to the targets and striking them at close range.
But the police were at a loss yesterday to explain what led to the chance killing of Ms. Lantin at the intersection of Mulberry and Bayard Streets, in the part of Chinatown that the Ghost Shadows call their turf. The police say the gang terrorizes storeowners and people in the neighborhood through extortion, robbery and a constant threat of violence.
There were no suspects last night. Chief Joseph G. DeMartino said he did not know what the dispute was about.
"We've been talking to people in the Chinese community about this," he said.
This was a particularly happy time for Ms. Lantin, who as an economist studied environmental and natural resources for the Department of Agriculture in Washington. She had traveled to a friend's home in Jersey City for a reunion of alumni of the Rural High School at the University of the Philippines in Los Banos. On Sunday, friends say, she was to return home to Maryland and then fly out to join her fiance, who had already started on a cross-country pleasure trip. They were to be married next spring.
Mr. Seitz said Ms. Lantin had met her fiance, 29-year-old Patrick Canning, two years ago at the University of Maryland, where they were doing graduate work. Mr. Canning had recently moved to Maryland from a rough neighborhood on 14th Street in Washington because Ms. Lantin was afraid of being shot there, Mr. Seitz said.
Ms. Lantin lived with her twin cousins, two women in their early 20's, on the third floor of a condominium complex, the brown-brick Americana Finnmark in Silver Spring.
"She was absolutely nice," Mr. Seitz said. "She was a really intelligent girl, really smart. She was a devout Catholic. Her family was a really close family. They did a lot of stuff together, like have barbeques and gatherings."
"It's just tragic," Mr. Seitz said. "It doesn't make any sense. She was just at the wrong place at the time, I guess."
A family friend, Tom Schruben, said that although she was born in the United States, Ms. Lantin had lived much of her life in the Philippines and had returned to this country only in 1987. In choosing the field of agricultural economics, she was following the footsteps of her parents, both of whom were agricultural researchers in the Philippines, where they still live.
 
'Always Wore a Smile'
 Mr. Schruben described Ms. Lantin as a woman who "always wore a smile."
"She was always making traditional Filipino handicrafts," he said. "She made dolls and baskets and was always knitting."
On Thursday night, she joined five of her classmates at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, where they watched a fireworks display, Chief DeMartino said. All six of the friends then piled into a friend's 1991 Ford Explorer and headed for Chinatown, the chief said.
The police believe that at 11:30 P.M., as the car passed through the intersection, one member of the Ghost Shadows pulled out a gun and fired at least two shots at several other gang members. Though the shots missed their targets, one bullet pierced the front passenger window on the right side of the car and struck Ms. Lantin in the head, Chief DeMartino said.
The driver, seeing Ms. Lantin slump forward, steered the car onto Canal Street and called the police. No one else in the car was injured, Chief DeMartino said.
 
No One Arrested
 None of the suspects in the shooting had been identified or arrested yesterday, Chief DeMartino said. Detectives were canvassing Chinatown but no witnesses had come forward, he said.
Though the police have questioned some members of the Ghost Shadows, witnesses had fled from the intersection by the time the police arrived late Thursday evening, Chief DeMartino said.
In the past, it has been nearly impossible to persuade Chinese witnesses to testify in court against the gangs, law-enforcement officials have said.
Chinatown has increasingly become a hotbed of gang warfare as its neighborhoods have continued to swell with Chinese and Southeast Asian immigrants, law-enforcement officials say.
Members of the Ghost Shadows, who often congregate on Mulberry, Bayard and Mott Streets, have been routinely linked to a number of crimes in the area, including extortion, robbery, the protection of illegal gambling establishments and the sale of fireworks, Chief DeMartino said. It was not known if the dispute on Thursday evening had any connection to the sale of fireworks, he said.
"They're just another Chinese gang," Sgt. Michael Wagner, who has spent more than five years monitoring Asian gangs, said of the Ghost Shadows. "They do the same things as other gangs."
The authorities have had some success prosecuting the Ghost Shadows. Five years ago, the Federal attorney's office overcame a lack of witnesses by using the flexible Federal racketeering conspiracy laws to convict 21 of the gang's members.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Financial regulators in seven countries seized control of a private banking empire rooted in the Middle East whose network includes 69 countries and two American banks. The seizure of Bank of Credit and Commerce Group, whose $20 billion in assets were regulated chiefly in Europe, came after what the Bank of England described as "widespread fraud" over a period of years. None of the alleged fraud affects the American banks controlled by B.C.C.I. [Page 1.] When the financial regulators swooped down on the B.C.C.I., they caught a very big bank, but one largely unfamiliar to much of the banking world and its public. [33.]
The Economy 
 The unemployment rate rose to 7 per cent in June, a gain of one-tenth of a point. Private economists as well as the Bureau of Labor Statistics tended to dismiss the rise in the unemployment rate as both unsurprising and, because the change was less than two- tenths of a point, statistically insignificant. There was a decline of 50,000 in payroll jobs, when a modest increase was widely antici pated. Factory jobs were down 59,000 but service industry jobs rose by 69,000. [1.]
The strength in the high-risk "junk bond" market in the last quarter spread into tax-free funds, with the high-yield municipal bond funds outperforming the general municipal bond funds for the three months ended June 30. [33.]
President Bush authorized a large increase in this year's peanut import quota. The limit has been raised to 100 million pounds of peanuts, up from 1.7 million. [9.]
New York City's assessors are not accurately measuring the market value of homes, a study shows. [1.]
 
 Companies
Lewis Galoob Toys said it had been told by a Federal judge that a district court had ruled in its favor in a copyright-infringement case brought by Nintendo of America to prevent the sale of the Galoob product Game Genie. [35.]
 Delta Air Lines has made an offer for parts of Pan American World Airways Inc., offering to buy a package including the Northeast shuttle, the carrier's trans-Atlantic routes and 45 planes. [35.]
Federal Express has ordered up to 75 wide-body cargo jets from Airbus Industrie, the European aerospace consortium. [35.]
Southeast Banking has held talks with several parties about a merger or capital infusion with some Federal assistance. [36.]
 
 Markets
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds plunged and interest rates soared as the fixed-income market reacted negatively to indications of growing economic strength in the otherwise mixed Government report on employment in June. [33.]
Stocks turned mixed and activity sank to the lowest level of the year as hundreds of traders stayed home for a long Fourth of July weekend. The Dow fell to 2,932.47, down 2.23 for the day but ahead 25.72 for the week. [37.]
The dollar closed lower in quiet trading as dealers digested the latest Government employment report. [41.]
Prices of corn and soybean futures ended sharply lower after forecasts called for mostly wet weather in key growing regions. Prices of wheat futures also plummeted. [41.]
 
 Today's Columns
A new I.R.S. regulation will benefit people who work late-night jobs. Now employees will have to report only $1.50 for car service not the actual value, as taxable income. Your Money. [34.]
Contraceptives for cats? A small biotechnology company outside Houston has patented what it contends is a permanent vaccine against pregnancy that can replace surgical sterilization in dogs, cats and even rabbits. Patents. [35.]

HEADLINE: Workers Protesting Budget Delays Rally in Pennsylvania and Maine

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Angered by the failure of state leaders to adopt budgets on time, workers in Pennsylvania and Maine held rallies at their state capitols yesterday to demand quick action.
In Pennsylvania, where workers did not receive their regular paychecks yesterday, more than 100 protesters stood on the stairway of the Capitol rotunda holding union banners, chanting "Paycheck! Paycheck!" and waving signs. 
 In Augusta, Me., an estimated 600 state workers and their supporters rallied on the Statehouse steps to urge an end to the budget impasse that has halted the government since Monday.
Budget negotiations also continued in Illinois, while California lawmakers took a break for the holiday weekend before making a renewed attempt to balance the state's $55 billion budget. Gov. Pete Wilson of California has given lawmakers an extra 12 days to approve additional taxes or find more cuts to close a budget gap of $2.5 billion. Because the state has enough money to operate until July 15, the next payday for state workers, state services have not yet been affected.
In Pennsylvania, Fred Davis, a public employees' union leader said at the rally outside the Capitol in Harrisburg, "We want a budget and we want our paychecks."
More than 10,000 Pennsylvania state workers, or about 9 percent of the state's employees, did not get paychecks because lawmakers failed to meet the June 30 budget deadline. Legislators planned no further negotiations until Sunday. The 10,000 employees did not receive paychecks because of a change in the state's payroll system several years ago which lengthened the lag in issuing paychecks.
In Maine, demonstrators sang, chanted and carried signs with messages like "End the lockout," "We want a budget" and "Free the Maine 10,000."
"It's the first time in the 171-year history of Maine that any governor has had the heartless audacity to shut down the state in order to pander to the interests of the rich and powerful," John J. Sweeney, a union leader, said.
The Legislature continued efforts to balance the state's $3.2 billion, two-year budget.
 
State Liquor Stores Close
 The partial government shutdown ordered by Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. has forced the closing of state parks and liquor stores and delayed the mailing of unemployment benefit checks.
The closing of state liquor stores has been a boon for private liquor sellers but is beginning to hurt restaurants, which must buy liquor from state stores.
In Illinois, the Senate President, Philip Rock, a Democrat, accused Gov. Jim Edgar, a Republican, of stalling budget negotiations, and said Democrats were prepared to seek a vote on their own version of the budget. But he acknowledged that Democrats might not be able to muster the three-fifths majority needed for passage.

HEADLINE: Transportation on the High Road

 BODY:
"We have poured enough concrete," says Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. The New York Democrat deserves much credit for the innovative transportation bill the Senate adopted last month by a resounding 91 to 8. After 35 years of focusing Federal aid on interstate highways, the Senate offers clear and welcome new directions.
President Bush calls the bill too costly, which it may be, and he still clings to old priorities; he advocates more for highways and less for mass transit. The House hasn't acted yet, but seems to be headed along the Senate's sensible course -- except for a not-so-sensible hike in the gas tax. 
 The Senate bill's main virtues are a new emphasis on improving the efficiency of highways, bridges and bus and subway systems already in place, and new flexibility in letting states decide how to spend Federal money. Broadly supported by rural as well as urban states, the bill also gives big metropolitan areas more power over the money. That's overdue recognition that clogged city and suburban arteries impede the national economy; they're not just local headaches.
In contrast, the Administration's proposals were routine, stressing money for new construction and aid formulas that favor road-building. Its bill gives less flexibility to the states and provides no money at all for mass-transit operating costs.
Mr. Bush objects to the Senate's 80/20 aid formula -- $80 for every $20 the states put up. But his formulas were absurd. Defying public concern about the environment and fuel consumption, he would have allocated money on the basis of how much gas a state's drivers guzzled, and would have aided roads more generously than transit systems.
The House Public Works Committee is shaping a bill of its own. It would cost even more than the Senate's bill but, like it, puts new emphasis on mass transit and flexibility. The package, to be introduced soon, includes a 5-cent hike in the Federal gas tax. Given its members' diligence in ladling gravy to constituents, the House's public-works bills tend to be overstuffed with dubious "demonstration projects." More revenue from a higher gas tax would surely lead to more overstuffing.
With constraints on spending, and resistance to higher taxes, this is no time for mandated waste. Rather, it is time to rethink Federal transportation policy. The Senate bill does so, with admirable intelligence and veto-proof, bipartisan conviction.

HEADLINE: To Curb China's Arms Trade

 BODY:
Despite pledges to curb sales of advanced arms, China now confirms it has begun delivering new missiles to Pakistan. And it's about to ship others to Syria. Understandably, the news fuels Congressional fervor to deny China trade privileges. A Democratic-sponsored bill would cancel China's most-favored-nation trade status for making such sales.
But economic sanctions have failed to restrain Chinese arms merchants in the past. A new strategy combining carrot and stick might be worth a try -- provided the Bush Administration is willing to curb its own arms sales. 
 In a depressing ritual, the U.S. gets assurances from China that it won't sell advanced arms and then learns that it has. The gap between word and deed stems from internal divisions in China. The assurances that arms won't be sold come from the Foreign and Defense Ministries, as a timely article in International Security by John W. Lewis, Hua Di and Xue Litai at Stanford's Center for International Security and Arms Control explains. But the sales are made by an army commission that has considerable autonomy and substantial inducement to sell as much as it can.
As China's leader, Deng Xiaoping, accelerated modernization in the 1980's, the commission became China's engine for technological development. It's as if the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers ran the Manhattan Project, NASA, the National Science Foundation and Silicon Valley combined.
At the same time Mr. Deng slashed the military budget. That led the commission to promote sales in order to raise revenues and import advanced technology. Administrators of its two main arms export firms, who stand to profit personally from sales, have family ties to China's leaders.
One of those firms signed a contract in 1988 to sell medium-range M-9 missiles to Syria and has received some proceeds, but has yet to deliver any missiles. And it sent "a very small number" of shorter-range M-11 missiles to Pakistan.
The deals can still be killed. But discriminating against China's trade with the U.S. might spur its arms sales. And sanctions, by denying contact and technology, come down hardest on the modernizers who back liberalization and opposed the Tiananmen crackdown. A threat of sanctions may be more effective than their actual imposition.
A different strategy is worth a try -- cooperating with China in arms suppliers' groups while holding out a threat of trade sanctions by the U.S., Japan and other nations that want the missile sales curbed. Beijing has now told Washington it may join the 16-nation Missile Technology Control Regime, which seeks to halt the spread of medium-range missiles. And the world's five leading arms suppliers, China included, will meet soon in Paris to draw up guidelines for Mideast arms sales. China can be pressed in these forums to curb its sales -- but is not likely to comply unless the Bush Administration shows some sales restraint of its own.
Congress could facilitate that by renewing most-favored-nation status for one year, requiring Mr. Bush to report within the year on China's arms sales practices and imposing its own temporary moratorium on U.S. sales by year's end if Mr. Bush fails to exercise restraint.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 22; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 842 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
GET SHORTY, by Elmore Leonard. (Dell, $5.99.) Forced out of the loan-sharking business, a Miami hoodlum moves to Hollywood, where he finds himself feeling perfectly at home in his new job in the film industry. Last year our reviewer, Nora Ephron, praised this novel for its "great, punchy, pitch-perfect Elmore Leonard dialogue and great Elmore Leonard sentences, long looping twisting strings of words that turn around and back up and go the other way, managing somehow (but how?) to avoid all the accouterments of punctuation like colons, semicolons and parentheses."
A MIDWIFE'S TALE: The Life of Martha Ballard, Based on Her Diary, 1785-1812, by Laurel Thatcher Ulrich. (Vintage, $13.) Reconstructed from town records and elliptical, sometimes incoherent journal entries, this book tells about the people of Hallowell, Me., from the viewpoint of a woman who delivered as many as 50 babies a year. "Thanks to Mrs. Ulrich's imaginative talent, Martha Ballard's diary becomes a major source through which we can vicariously experience the rural life of early New England and reimagine the character of men's and women's economic and family existence," Carl N. Degler said in The Book Review last year. "Laurel Thatcher Ulrich wears her learning lightly and her prose sings." The book won the Bancroft Prize and the Pulitzer Prize. 
 ONLY BEGOTTEN DAUGHTER, by James Morrow. (Ace, $4.50.) In Atlantic City, Christ makes a second coming in the form of a girl named Julie, the daughter of a lighthouse keeper who supports himself by donating to a sperm bank. Last year our reviewer, Jack Butler, called the novel "a rich, intelligent tour de force."
AN UNCERTAIN HOUR: The French, the Germans, the Jews, the Klaus Barbie Trial, and the City of Lyon, 1940-1945, by Ted Morgan. (Arbor House/Morrow, $13.) Interweaving the story of Klaus Barbie, the "butcher of Lyons," with family reminiscences, a French-born journalist reflects on the bravery and the cowardice his compatriots showed in World War II. "This eloquent book of personal and public history is a dreamlike and, alas, at times also nightmarish account," Patrice Higonnet said here in 1989.
THE BODY AND ITS DANGERS: And Other Stories, by Allen Barnett. (St. Martin's, $8.95.) When these short stories, some about people with AIDS, were published in 1990 our reviewer, Meg Wolitzer, said Allen Barnett portrays his characters' "awareness of fragility with such candor and melancholy that they almost seem to be holding their own hearts in their hands."
DON'T KNOW MUCH ABOUT HISTORY: Everything You Need to Know About American History but Never Learned, by Kenneth C. Davis. (Avon, $10.95.) This crash course shows that Kenneth C. Davis is "a diligent researcher whose prose is light on the eyes," James M. Cornelius said here last year.
SWEET TALK, by Stephanie Vaughn. (Penguin, $7.95.) One night, while they're all cooking dinner, a woman discovers that her husband is the father of her best friend's unborn child. Last year our reviewer, Joseph Olshan, said the writing in this and Stephanie Vaughn's other short stories is "pure and elegiac, as though it were piped in directly from the soul."
THE LIFE AND DEATH OF A DRUID PRINCE: The Story of Lindow Man, an Archaeological Sensation, by Anne Ross and Don Robins. (Touchtone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) A historian and a chemist join forces to reconstruct the life of Lindow Man, the 2,000-year-old druid whose body was found in an English peat bog. Last year our reviewer, Malcolm W. Browne, called this "a plausible speculative history. . . . Right or wrong, it is a story that satisfies."
THE TONGUES OF ANGELS, by Reynolds Price. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Looking back 34 years to when he was an art counselor at a camp in the Smoky Mountains, a painter blames himself for the death of one of his charges. Last year our reviewer, Paul West, called this a "chastely visionary novel."
EXPATS: Travels in Arabia, From Tripoli to Teheran, by Christopher Dickey. (Atlantic Monthly, $9.95.) A journalist finds that foreign entrepreneurs have lent corners of the Arab desert the bizarre ambience of a shopping mall. "In his engaging book, laced with humor, pathos and sensitivity, Mr. Dickey unveils this new Arabia, shaped by the sometimes creative, always skeptical, tension between the Arab and the expatriate," Sandra Mackey said in The Book Review in 1990.
FLOATING IN MY MOTHER'S PALM, by Ursula Hegi. (Vintage Contemporaries, $9.) This novel about a girl growing up in the 1950's on the banks of the Rhine "is wholly convincing . . . absolutely successful and a delight," our reviewer, Edward Hoagland, said last year.
THE UNIVERSITY: An Owner's Manual, by Henry Rosovsky. (Norton, $10.95.) A former Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard tells how to play academic politics. "This is the real skinny," Linda Bradley Salamon said in The Book Review last year. The book is "the work of a scholar (the footnotes alone are a delight and the index looks like an arcane academic joke), a wit and an economist."

LENGTH: 902 words

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Dicey Times In Moscow And Berlin

BYLINE: By John Rockwell

 BODY:
Contrary to popular conviction, most critics prefer celebration to condemnation. So it was disappointing to confront two legendary European musical institutions, the Berlin Philharmonic early last month at Carnegie Hall and the Bolshoi Opera over the last two weeks at the Metropolitan Opera, and find them suffering through perilous transitions.
Both the Berliners and the Bolshoi came here with big reputations honorably earned, and both were marketed with a panache reminiscent of the late Sol Hurok's, with ticket prices to match (a $135 top for the Bolshoi). When people pay top ruble, they not only expect to have a good time, they resent being told they shouldn't have had one. 
 The Bolshoi's troubles seem more dangerous than those of the Berliners, who just need stability to insure their future as the gleaming orchestral symbol of the new Germany's new capital. The Bolshoi mirrors almost eerily the current crises in the Soviet Union itself.
Like the nation it so grandly represents, the Moscow company seeks to slough off old ways but seems unsure about the proper path to modernization. It wants to borrow from the West, but not at the expense of the best Russian and Soviet tradition. In short, it's confused, and at least the first two productions of its New York stand, which ended last night, exposed that confusion all too well. (There will be further dates this week at Wolf Trap, near Washington.)
Until recently, the Bolshoi looked like a curious throwback to 19th-century practice. Before recordings and fast international travel, each country's operatic style reflected its national attributes. Most Russian singers couldn't be expected to sing German or French or Italian roles, at least in those languages, but they did sing Russian opera more idiomatically than anyone else.
They still can, and one reason is that for all its modernist ideology, Communism prized old-fashioned aristocratic and bourgeois opera as a symbol of its commitment to the arts. With political restrictions and economic disparity blocking free interchange between East and West, the Bolshoi remained a haven for Russian style and talent.
But an increasingly moribund, enervated haven. The stale repertory, the plodding literalism of the productions and the ludicrous infrequency with which star singers and dancers were parceled out all bespoke a tradition in dire need of revitalization.
The current Bolshoi leadership, although it contains some veterans, has been in place for only three years. All three productions seen here were the work of Aleksandr Lazarev, the company's artistic director and chief conductor; Boris Pokrovsky, director, and Valery Levental, designer. Their stagings of Tchaikovsky's "Yevgeny Onegin" and Rimsky-Korsakov's "Mlada" (the third was of Tchaikovsky's "Maid of Orleans") showed them eager to break with dogged realism. But they also revealed a disregard for basic practicalities (the "Onegin" set that banished the chorus and a gratuitous instrumental ensemble backstage, requiring tinny amplification), a yearning for change for change's sake (Tatyana and Olga's offstage duet sung onstage) and a muddled lack of faith in the works they revived ("Mlada" as vaudeville instead of mythic spectacle).
The quality of the Bolshoi chorus and orchestra remains high, although Mr. Lazarev's absence during the first week left the conducting in presumably weaker hands. No one sounded as authoritative as Yuri Simonov did during the company's last New York appearance in 1975.
Vocally, the opening-night "Onegin" revealed a brightly penetrating young soprano in Nina Rautio and a handsome if bland baritone in Vladimir Redkin. But the squalling top notes of the company's leading soprano, Makvala Kasrashvili, were a trial in "Mlada," and except for the veteran Yevgeny Nesterenko in "Onegin," there was little of the grand sonority that once seemed to define Russian male singing.
In Berlin, the problem is less political and economic than personal and institutional. The Berlin Philharmonic long ago joined the ranks of top international orchestras, forswearing most of its specifically central European attributes but gaining a sumptuous polish. Herbert von Karajan's performances, especially late in life, were often criticized for substituting surface sheen for expressive depth (except in his always magisterial Bruckner). But my, did that surface shine!
It didn't last month. That may have been partly because Bernard Haitink, the conductor for these performances, sometimes favors stolid musical discourse over tonal beauty. But the indifferent music-making also suggested that this great ensemble is essentially rudderless: Karajan withdrew from Philharmonic affairs a decade ago, and Claudio Abbado, the new chief conductor, can still give the orchestra only limited time.
The Bolshoi's problems run deeper. Quite apart from the taste and talent of its current leadership, the company seems torn between ossified Eastern tradition and Western influences that hold the promise of revitalization at the peril of a leveling of Russian character. And it faces this momentous transition in a time of national unrest and economic privation. May the next Bolshoi visit to these shores come sooner than another 16 years. And may it reveal that this noble institution, along with the nation it epitomizes, has overcome the formidable challenges it now faces.

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Nightly News Looks Beyond the Headlines

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
Under pressure from cable news and local news and in hopes of stemming a ratings erosion, for some time now the main network news programs have been edging away from the day's headlines toward features and themes. That means, to get the disheartening aspect out of the way, that the number of soft stories, particularly about show business, have gone up markedly. In the first half of 1990, according to the Tyndall Report, a newsletter that monitors the evening newscasts, the programs gave an average of 68 minutes a month to arts and entertainment coverage, compared to 38 minutes in 1989 and 1988.
More emphasis on entertainers in a celebrity-saturated medium may not seem strictly necessary, but in their more sober moods, "ABC World News Tonight," "The NBC Nightly News" and "The CBS Evening News" have also been paying more sustained attention to such subjects as the jobless and the homeless, health care and education. To be sure, features on serious matters have long found a place on the tube, but not always in such a sustained way. (CNN is also pitching in, but the networks still have the big audiences.) But those of us who have criticized network news for soft or superficial coverage must welcome any indication of greater seriousness. One week last month offered an unusual opportunity to inspect the sorts of efforts that may signal a new direction for the nightly news. 
 For most of the week of June 17, "World News Tonight" led off with a report on what being poor means these days to children in Ohio. "The NBC Nightly News" carried a five-part series about middle-class America. And "The CBS Evening News" devoted its regular feature, "Eye on America," to such subjects as workers and retirees in danger of losing their pensions, a dispute over whether an 86-year-old woman in a vegetative state should be kept alive and the way tenants in a New York apartment building are helping their neighbors who have AIDS.
"Eye on America" (the title and format seem to owe something to ABC's "American Agenda") consists of nightly segments of about five minutes each on matters of moment. In the batch I monitored, five minutes -- though a sizable allocation by evening news standards -- could not do justice to the issue of political correctness now roiling America's campuses, but they were enough to catch people's feelings in the stories about pensions, AIDS and that comatose woman.
All the segments were well produced, making smart use of pictures to bring out issues and emotions. By following Carol Beck, the principal of Thomas Jefferson High School in Brooklyn, on her tireless patrols of the school's hallways, the camera affirmed what the reporter was saying about her reputation as "an equal-opportunity enforcer." This short-form journalism is of course no substitute for a full-fledged documentary, but in hands as professional as those of the CBS producers, it can explore manageable pieces of significant issues, one this week, another next week, another the week after, steadily broadening the viewer's perspective.
 By contrast, in the weeklong series "Caught in the Middle," NBC took on more than it could chew, much less digest in three-minute segments. The subjects included the economic pains of three families with little in common except "a fear of falling back"; a return to religion; the punishing costs of medical care; the expense inflicted on small business by shoplifters and crooked employees, and a tribute to family values. It was a random agglomeration that told less about the middle class than about the propensities of television news. Each of the subjects might have warranted a program of its own, but as presented here, they were like sideshows in a theme park, aimed more at grabbing an audience than informing it.
 The final segment, a success story, was merely a pass at an upbeat ending, and the piece about small businesses resembled a real-life crime show. The more interesting story on religion was in fact a look at the Second Baptist Church in Houston, which has 18,000 members to whom it offers aerobics, weight lifting, bowling and all manner of support groups as well as more traditional forms of worship. It might have served as an entry point for a sharp look at religion's attractions to young families today, but this try never got much past the starting line.
 The three-minute bites on joblessness and medical care focus on desperate cases: a child whose chronic illness has exhausted the lifetime insurance limit of $500,000 and a family that has to pay almost $500 a month for private insurance because a teen-age son has epilepsy. The program seemed to be competing mainly to up the stakes on the sort of sad stories that have already been heavily treated by television documentaries and discussions and the evening news programs themselves.
"Caught in the Middle" confirmed that a timely subject does not guarantee a fresh or significant report. If NBC News hopes to offer something more than viewers can get from the headlines, it might do better to forgo pretentions to take on all of middle-class angst in less than 15 minutes and concentrate on a slice of the subject it can dig into instead of exploit in passing.
The most ambitious of the week's efforts, ABC's "Children in Crisis," which was timed to coincide with the recent recommendations by the National Commission on Children on ways to help low-income families, did some digging. When Peter Jennings, who stayed at his desk in New York during the war in the Persian Gulf, spends a week in Ohio, and when "World News Tonight" leads off three evenings in a row with a report on a single subject that takes up from a third to a half of the broadcast, the audience is on notice that attention must be paid.
By focusing on the economic tribulations of parents and children in one area, the producers were able to shape a comprehensible and sometimes moving picture. The series reporters, Carol Simpson, Jim Wooten and Chris Bury, took their cameras into trailer homes, day-care centers and hospitals to show the grim legacy of generation after generation with little money, no education and babies being raised by one young parent.
The pictures of premature and underweight infants, of youngsters growing up without a book or adult guidance, of parents who seem unable to manage their own lives, much less those of their children, or who are battling the odds just to scrape by, brought home what Mr. Jennings said is the situation in which 12 million American children are trapped.
In the week following these extended reports, ABC News returned to the subject on its regular "American Agenda" series. It was advocacy journalism in a more explicit form than the networks usually permit themselves, but most viewers are likely to grant that it was justified by the sorry statistics that Mr. Jennings dropped in along the way.
 Strong though the series was, it demonstrated yet again that television is not a particularly good instrument for analysis; recommendations for action and where the money might be found were left vague. And Mr. Jennings's editorial asides tended to take the form of rhetorical gestures to fit every problem: If Washington can save Kuwait, why can't it try to save American children?
Caveats notwithstanding, "Children in Crisis" was an innovative effort to direct the nation's fitful attention and stir its conscience. If "World News Tonight" stays with the subject, and goes on to address other troubling conditions with comparable time and resources, it could be showing the way for network news of tomorrow.

HEADLINE: PRINTMAKERS;
Upstairs, Downstairs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Museum of Modern Art's exhibition "Seven Master Printmakers: Innovations in the 80's" and Roberta Smith's criticisms of it are ironically timely ["Narrow Notions of Greatness at the Modern," June 23]. In his retrospective downstairs at the Modern, Ad Reinhardt posthumously skewers art-world hype (and slick, salable images as a manifestation) through a series of hilarious and irreverent cartoons, then bathes the viewers in a real genius glow with his reductive "black" paintings. 
 After experiencing that and then utter deflation upstairs at the sight of the pretty printmakers Rosenquist, Stella, etc., one might keep one's artistic sensibilities intact only by pausing for air at Ellsworth Kelly's elegant and dynamic lithograph in the lobby -- a truly great print. It owes so much to the tradition downstairs and so little to the so-called masters of the last decade.
 
STEVE NIKITAS
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: Postings: SoHo Renovation;
A Business Pied-a-Terre

 BODY:
A home away from home is being built for out-of-town companies that need temporary quarters in New York City.
Under the name of Walden House, the project involves the renovation of a 119-year-old structure at 49 Mercer Street, between Grand and Broome Streets, in the SoHo-Cast Iron Historic District. Until recently, the six-story building was home to a textile company. 
 Its developer, Kari Walden, identifies himself as an artist and economist who has lived in the neighborhood for six years. The building, which is to reopen in September, will not have tenants as much as clients: corporations that use the space and services Mr. Walden provides.
"The space is part of the service," Mr. Walden said. "We can design a package for a company from the West Coast or Scandinavia or England or Germany. You come into our building for three months and we provide all consulting services. We construct a marketing event for you, do basic market research, do a search for business partners and devise the advertising program for you. Whatever we cannot produce ourselves in house, we subcontract -- for instance, legal services or accounting."
Mr. Walden bought the building last year for $3 million and expects to spend about $7 million on the project, which will yield not only new office space but a ground-floor gallery and 74-seat screening room. He said he was the sole investor in the project and had raised the money by selling "everything I have -- or had" in the way of real estate and securities, as well as obtaining financing from an international bank. Kapell & Kostow of Manhattan are the renovation architects. The original architect was Joseph M. Dunn.

HEADLINE: Talking: Gardening;
Sharing The Land In Condos

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AS midsummer approaches, many residents of suburban condominums are gazing longingly at their neighbors in one-family houses who are beginning to harvest produce from lush vegetable gardens.
 Though they may have been only too willing to give up backyard chores when they moved into a condo, they now feel a sense of loss. Ruth Price, for example, who moved four years ago from a one-family house in Guilford, Conn., to a condominium about 30 miles away, suffered such withdrawal symptoms that she now helps tend a friend's vegetable garden in the next town. 
 It does not have to be so. Any condominium or homeowner association can create a community garden by setting aside land in the common area and dividing it into individual gardening plots.
 "We've had one at Rowayton Woods for 10 years and the people love it," said Edward Nardella, president of Corporate Property Management of Norwalk, Conn., which manages some 43 associations. Rowayton Woods is a 206-unit town-house condominium near the center of Rowayton, Conn.
Some 34 million households tended vegetable gardens in 1990, up from 30 million in 1989, according to the National Gardening Association, and many community ownership residents were among them.
"This year we have a waiting list of about 40 people for garden plots," said Claudia Thompson-Deahl, environmental manager at Reston, Va., a planned community of 20,000 units where a community garden has been maintained for 20 years.
Among the growing number of gardeners, she added, are the community's Asian and Indian residents, who are eager to grow exotic vegetables and herbs that they cannot easily find in stores.
 Fairfield Glade, a homeowner association of some 3,000 year-round and time-share units on 12,500 acres near Nashville, Tenn., now has 66 garden plots, having added eight this year to keep pace with requests. "We just keep expanding," said Rick Dowswell, the recreation director.
 Nevertheless, a sampling of managers nationwide suggests that condominium or co-op community gardens are still relatively uncommon. One reason could be the mistaken notion that it is illegal -- or at least very complicated -- to set aside common lands for individual gardening plots.
 Not so, said Gurdon Buck of Hartford, supervisory council member of the American Bar Association's Committee on Housing and a leading authority on community association law.
The legal status of the plots is much the same as that of individual parking places, he said. Both are taken from common ground and may be assigned on a temporary basis according to rules set by the board of directors -- provided those rules are applied in a nondiscriminatory way and offer a reasonable method of access for any applicant. But plots cannot be permanently assigned to any individual or unit.
 A community garden can therefore be established at any time by the board without modifying the basic documents of the association or getting a two-thirds majority vote, Mr. Buck said.
A compelling argument for a community garden is to prevent illegal gardening in other areas. An alternative is to create a garden club and let members landscape and beautify parts of the grounds as a community project.
This was done four years ago at Sudden Valley, a 4,500-unit homeowner association in Bellingham, Wash. "Each year it's looking better and better," said Billie Thoreson, the general manager. Although this method limits gardening to flowers and shrubs, it also helps the association save on landscaping costs.
IF a complex is not yet complete it might be possible to persuade the developer to let part of the unused land be temporarily set aside for gardening, a technique appropriate in a recession when new construction is often placed on hold.
 This idea was used successfully by Carol Levey, a resident of the 180-unit River Walk homeowner association in Chesapeake, Va. Earlier this year, Ms. Levey obtained about a quarter of an acre for gardening on a sunny piece of adjacent land that the River Walk developer owned and planned to use for a strip shopping center.
 The best place for a community garden is a secluded area that is visible neither from the units nor the roadway so it does not mar the overall appearance of the development, said Doug Kleine, president of Professional Association Services of Reston, a consultant to community associations.
 Rowayton Woods, for example, has its garden tucked between a copse and a pond on the edge of the complex. At Reston the garden is on a strip of land that would have otherwise remained unused because of a gas pipeline easement.
Other good spots could be wetlands, open space that cannot be built upon or buffer zones between the complex and an unsightly neighbor, like a commercial complex, said Mr. Kleine.
 The most common method of assigning plots is first come first served, with prior garden-plot renters given preference. Seasonal rents range from $10 to $40. Some, like Rowayton Woods, give rebates to owners who clean out their plots in the fall.
 The rent normally covers the cost to the association of fencing the area (to keep out wildlife and vandals) and providing water.
 Areas are often divided into those where chemical fertilizers can be used and those restricted to organic gardening, "so as not to affect everyone else," said Cynthia Yee, who coordinates the community garden at Farmington Woods, a 969-unit condominium in Farmington, Conn.
 Community gardens can also provide a social opportunity and a chance for pooling resources for bulk purchases of seed and equipment. At Fairfield Glade, gardeners find new friends as they give away excess produce to their nongardening neighbors.
At Heritage Village, a 2,580-unit retirement condominium in Southbury, Conn., the end-of-season festival at which the vegetables and flowers are professionally judged has become "one of the most popular events of its type in the state," said Jack Lewis, senior vice president of the River Garden Club, which operates the Village's 750 plots.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Retail Condominiums;
For the Premier Locations, The Price Is Commensurate

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
TO put into perspective the price paid by Mitsui Real Estate Sales for a retail condominium at Madison Avenue and 66th Street, consider the amount of space taken by this paragraph. Had it been part of the recent deal, it would be worth $38.
Mitsui, the Manhattan-based subsidiary of Mitsui Real Estate Development Company of Tokyo, has paid $14.75 million for five stores at the base of a 10-story landmark apartment house at 45 East 66th Street. The stores, numbered 773 to 781 Madison Avenue, amount in all to 5,167 square feet. 
 That works out to $2,854.65 a square foot, which may work out to some kind of record.
"It's a vote of confidence in prime Manhattan real estate," said Lawrence A. Russo, a vice president of the Trump Organization, who represented the seller, Classic Properties of Manhattan. "There are other retail condominiums on Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue, but this is a first, in that no deal has been closed at this level.
"It's a world-class location and they paid a world-class price," he said.
Mr. Russo said he believed the only retail deal that might come close was one done last year, also by Mitsui, also on Madison Avenue. It involved a five-store, 6,000-square-foot retail condominium in the Leonori apartment building, at 63d Street.
"While it is an astonishing price, it's a shrewd investment," said Peter Melnikoff, of Oval Grove Properties of Manhattan, who was the other broker in the deal. "As opposed to the office sector, you have a real constraint on supply. You have a limited area where upscale retail exists."
"The limited supply is creating a healthier situation, compared with office, hotel or condominium properties," said Masahiko Kawakami, executive vice president of Mitsui.
"I am not worrying about the future of New York City," he said. "You still have a great residential stock on Park Avenue and Fifth Avenue. A lot of the richest people are living there and they prefer to buy on Madison Avenue. A lot of tourists are coming to New York and they prefer to go to shop on Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue. And other international retailers want to have some kind of showcase on Madison Avenue."
He said his confidence was bolstered by such impending developments as the Barneys store, at Madison Avenue and 61st Street; the Mitsukoshi store at Park Avenue and 57th Street and the Galeries Lafayette store, at 57th Street, near Fifth Avenue.
"We recognized that the high price per square foot might stir a lot of attention," said Christopher G. McManus, president of Offshore Asset Management of Westport, Conn., who advised Mitsui. "I hope it does. I hope other owners of premier properties will anxiously contact us and give us the opportunity to acquire other retail condominiums."
Not everyone was impressed by the magnitude of the Mitsui deal. "It's probably a record, but so what," said Benjamin Fox, executive vice president of New Spectrum Realty Services. "It doesn't mean anything -- dollars per square foot. That has meaning in midtown, where what happens at Third and 54th has a direct bearing on what happens at Lexington and 56th. But on Madison Avenue, these deals are so few and far between as to have no basis for comparison.
"Madison just defies what's going on," he said. "People who have a lot of money simply love shopping on Madison."
Remarkable as the price is, it may seem a little less breathtaking when considered as a factor of income rather than space.
"You can't look at retail space as '$2,800 a foot,' " said C. Bradley Mendelson, a managing director of the Edward S. Gordon Company and a specialist in retail real estate. "No one would pay that for land. No one would pay that for an office building. But if you're getting $275 a square foot in rent, you're buying at about 10 times rental. That's a 10 percent return. Would you buy a bond that yielded 10 percent? Of course. This is like buying a bond. It's not like buying real estate.
"When you're dealing with multi-use properties, you're looking at a major maintenance and repair investment that will fluctuate in value," he said. "But the buying of a retail condominium, which gets its service from the building, is very much protected. If the roof leaks, you're going to be the last to know it. You're not going to have a major maintenance nightmare on your hands."
BUT Mr. Fox pointed out that retail condominiums have their problems. "A lot of these deals have gone sour," he said. "The rent projections have not borne out the investment."
Indeed, no matter how the brokers tout the Madison Avenue site, the final price was about 18 percent lower than the deal that had been negotiated only five months earlier, reflecting the fact that no location is recession proof or trouble free.
Completed in 1908 to designs by Harde & Short, 45 East 66th Street was declared a landmark in 1977. From 1928 to 1973 and again from 1977 to 1987, it was owned by the Bing & Bing real-estate company. Along with numerous other Bing holdings, it was purchased in 1987 by a partnership controlled by Martin J. Raynes.
The Executive Life Insurance Company of Los Angeles was a limited partner in the transaction. Mr. Raynes, who gave up vast holdings to avoid financial collapse, "left the deal" last summer, said Gary Glatter, president of Classic Properties, which is now the sponsor of the co-operative conversion of the 33 apartments upstairs. Classic still owns about 15 of those apartments, Mr. Glatter said.
Taken together, the apartments compose a single residential condominium. There are also two professional-office condominiums in the building, which are to be combined as an art gallery.
CLASSIC also owned the retail condominium, whose tenants included the Fred Leighton jewelry store (No. 773), the Christian de Castelnau boutique (No. 775), the Alexon boutique (No. 777), the Bernardaud china shop (No. 779) and the Berk of Burlington Arcade cashmere store (No. 781).
Although Classic had not considered selling the retail condominium, it had been under scrutiny by Mitsui. "We have studied almost all the Madison Avenue properties," Mr. Kawakami said. "We pointed at that property."
"Some brokers said there were Japanese buyers who might pay a price that would interest us," Mr. Glatter recalled.
The first approach was in June. A contract was signed in November for $18 million. The closing was scheduled for Jan. 14. But that turned out to be the day before the deadline set by the United Nations Security Council for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. The closing was postponed to Feb. 14.
"Unfortunately," Mr. Glatter said, "as luck would have it, between mid-January and mid-February, Christian de Castelnau decided to bolt in a midnight run. That's rather uncharacteristic for a Madison Avenue tenant, but that's what he did."
"The past year was not profitable," Mr. de Castelnau said, from his office in Los Angeles. "I had been talking to the landlord since December. We did not know what we were going to do. I was trying to get them to reduce the rent to where it would make sense to keep the store." He was paying between $225 and $250 a square foot.
That left Classic without one of its tenants. Since the deal with Mitsui was predicated on full tenancy, the agreement was opened for for renegotiation. In that process, the price dropped about $3.25 million.
Another closing was scheduled in mid-April but that was when California regulators seized control of Executive Life, saying the company was in a hazardous condition. The prospective sale then had to be reviewed by the California insurance commissioner and Superior Court. "Mitsui wanted to get comfortable that all the T's were crosses and all the I's were dotted," Mr. Glatter said.
The deal finally closed June 19.
As to the future, Mr. Kawakami said Mitsui would probably form a partnership and sell shares to other Japanese investors.
"Some" part of the proceeds "could find its way to Executive Life," Mr. Glatter said.
Mr. Russo said "major European retailers" had expressed interest in the retail space that Mr. de Castelnau vacated at No. 775 and had made offers ranging from $250 to $285 a square foot.
"We are basically investors," Mr. Kawakami said. "We are expecting to have long-term appreciation of the properties."

HEADLINE: Postings: 20 Stories Off Third;
Pension Fund Plans Addition

 BODY:
The world's largest pension fund will be expanding its Manhattan headquarters to keep up with the size of its portfolio. TIAA-CREF, the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association-College Retirement Equities Fund, has seen its assets multiply five times, to $95 billion, over the past decade, requiring more space for its headquarters staff.
Accordingly, the pension fund will build a 20-story, 160,000-square-foot addition to its present headquarters at 730 Third Avenue on an adjacent lot on 45th Street that the fund owns. Demolition on the lot begins this month and construction will start in September, with completion planned for mid-1993.
The addition will match the current building's gray brick style. As part of the project, the present lobby entrance on Third Avenue will be renovated and given a two-story atrium partially clad in granite. 
 Besides creating space for the fund's growing staff of 3,800, the $30 million project also will permit the fund to take advantage of the slower pace of construction in the city, said Tom Fjellman, assistant vice president of the fund and the project manager.
"Because of the current recession," Mr. Fjellman said, "high quality workmanship is available at lower costs, making this an opportune time to build."
The Manhattan firm of Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron are the architects.

HEADLINE: Budget Said to Set Stage for Future Battles

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
BY relying on some one-time revenue sources to help balance the state's new $14.7 billion budget, Gov. Jim Florio and the Democratic-controlled Legislature may have made balancing next year's budget an even greater challenge.
The new budget includes between $500 million and $700 million in revenue that will not be counted on a year from now, and Dr. William C. Freund, a professor of economics at Pace University, said, "That reeks of a quick fix that can do some permanent harm." 
 Dr. Freund, who served on the Governor's Economic Policy Council under four governors, said, "If the New Jersey economy suddenly picked up and roared ahead, then the loss of the one-time revenues could be offset, but it doesn't look like that kind of a turnaround is in prospect."
Interviews with economists, lawmakers, state officials and fiscal watchdogs showed that most believe that the budget just enacted sets the stage for another round of fights over further job cuts, reductions in employee benefits, service rollbacks or new tax increases.
"What they did was politically expedient, but not economically sound or smart," Dr. Freund said. "And they know that in Trenton."
The final agreement on the budget for the fiscal year that started last Monday did not come until about noon the day before, when Senator Laurence S. Weiss, Democrat of Woodbridge and chairman of the Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee, said that "an intense and tumultuous week of hard work, negotiations and compromise" was over.
But the compromise included about 3,000 layoffs of state employees and the one-time revenue raisers -- $400 million from the sale of a portion of Interstate 95 in Bergen County to the New Jersey Turnpike Authority; an acceleration of utility taxes that will yield $620 million this year but about $100 million less in the next fiscal year, and a change in Medicaid eligibility planned to attract $250 million in additional Federal Medicaid funds.
The sale of the 4.4 miles of highway to the toll road authority was not very popular with many lawmakers, and no one expects the state to continue to cannibalize its road system, even to stave off future budget shortfalls.
Although Mr. Weiss said he and others were uncomfortable with this "unorthodox" budget item, he said it was the best anyone could come up with to avoid even tougher choices, including more layoffs.
"With a budget that incorporates conservative revenue figures and is structurally sound, it is safe to include the roadway transfer to bridge the fiscal gap," he said.
Douglas C. Berman, the State Treasurer, said the national recession was the chief reason that the state's tax base, which was broadened by changes in both the state sales and income taxes last year, was unable to produce the revenue needed to keep pace with the costs of government. When the recession lifts, the underlying strength of the budget, which spends less for direct state operations and $2 billion more in state aid for schools and property tax relief, will become apparent, he said.
Mr. Berman is also relying on some $200 million in savings and productivity gains claimed for the current budget to grow next year and help offset the loss of the nonrepeatable revenue.
He said the budget departed from the recent past when state spending began outdistancing revenue growth, even during the economic boom of the 1980's.
 
Education Tied to Income Tax
 From now on, increases in state aid for education, for example, will be tied to the increase in income tax revenue, he said, which will prevent this aid program from consuming revenue needed for other parts of the budget.
A job freeze begun last December has resulted in a reduction of 1,900 state jobs, before the state begins to effect the layoffs required by the budget. An attrition program and early retirement offers are also expected to realize savings. In all, Mr. Berman said, the administration hopes to reduce the 76,000-member state work force by 10 percent in another year.
Assemblyman Robert D. Franks of New w Providence, the State Republican chairman, said he believed that the economies being claimed by the administration were overstated and that the one-shot revenue used to balance the current budget would spell trouble very soon.
"We face a big crisis next spring," he said, when the time rolls around to begin planning the 1993 budget. Mr. Franks predicts that his party will control one or both houses of the Legislature after this November's election, and he said the Republicans would have to clean up the budget mess created by the Democrats.
 
Increased Fees as 'Savings'
 Mr. Franks said the Florio administration was counting on raising fees charged by various state departments and has been picturing the increased fees as "savings" generated by the departments.
"These aren't savings but new taxes that are again being placed on the shoulders of the New Jersey taxpayer," he said.
Dr. Joseph J. Seneca, professor of economics at Rutgers University and another former economic adviser to New Jersey governors, said that relying on one-shot revenue to balance the current budget insured that revenue would continue to be a problem when the next budget rolled around.
Unless there is a "significant turnaround" in the economy in the near future, he said, the state will have to consider program cutbacks or find new revenue. That does not always mean new taxes, as the highway sale indicates. "In the genre of one-time revenue raisers, there may be a large number of clever and imaginitive sources to tap," Dr. Seneca said.
David Kehler, president of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey in Princeton, said, "It looks to me like we'll be dealing with a budget crisis for Florio's entire term."
 
Savings Depend on Unfilled Jobs
 Mr. Kehler said that even as the budget was being approved, not enough was known about the costs associated with some important programs. There is an early retirement program, but no one knows how many people are expected to participate, he said, or how long their jobs will be unfilled. "The real savings turns on the idea that the jobs remain vacant," Mr. Kehler said.
He said that in testimony before the appropriations committee Mr. Berman could only give estimates of the cost of the state's new homeowners' rebate program to assist those whose property taxes eat up a large part of their income.
"Some people may miss their first year of eligibility, and that could be another factor driving up costs in subsequent years," Mr. Kehler said.
 
$55 Million From Early Retirement
 Mr. Berman said the state hoped to realize $55 million from the early retirement program and had appropriated $710 million for the rebate program in the current budget.
He said the number of people eligible for the rebates could decrease in the future if the administration's efforts to curb the rise in property taxes were successful.
Mr. Kehler said he did not believe that it was realistic to expect an economic turnaround to solve the state budget woes in the near future, and he said the administration would have to aggressively pursue the economies identified by the Governor's Management Review Commission. The commission has identified more than $900 million in cost savings, productivity increases and other economies over the next two years.
Mr. Kehler also said public-interest organizations and the press would have to do a better job to keep the public informed on budget issues. He said there had been insufficient review of the last Kean administration budget, "which created problems that Florio had to address as soon as he took office."
"Those of us interested in this issue will have to delve deeply to see where we stand," he said. "And to see to it that the public isn't being blind sided."

Reduce number of state garages to 29 from 71: $16.5 million.

HEADLINE: Recession Inspires Innovative Approaches to Business

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AS businesses, individuals and state and local governments struggle to weather the recession that has gripped the economy since the end of the 1980's, economic survival for some has been accompanied by employee layoffs, a paring down of personal and household budgets and cutbacks in services in the public sector, economists say.
And though recent statistics offer a glimmer of hope for recovery, they say, a rebound is likely to be gradual, with those groups hurt the most by the recession -- developers, contractors and bankers -- facing a particularly arduous climb. 
 But even in the worst of times, innovators prosper.
In West New York, for example, along a stretch of Hudson River waterfront unofficially dubbed the Gold Coast in the optimistic 1980's, a new enterprise has arisen from the ashes of scrapped plans for an ultra-luxurious multimillion-dollar residential development. In its place, people happily pay for the privilege of whacking golf balls by the basketful onto a grassy expanse in the shadow of the Manhattan skyline. Business is so good, the owner says, he is thinking of expanding.
 
Paying Rent by Selling Shrubs
 Two miles south in Hoboken, a contractor who ran a thriving construction business just a few short years ago now spends a good part of his time cultivating plants for his 7,500-square-foot nursery and garden center. While not quite as profitable as contracting, the owner says, selling shrubs pays the rent and at the same time provides him with some peace of mind.
And in Somerville, a modestly sized savings bank that had husbanded its resources during the good times of the late 1980's virtually doubled in size overnight by purchasing six branches of a prominent savings and loan that failed to survive the savings and loan crisis.
"There are always people around who can sail through anything," said Dr. Marilyn Marks Rubin, associate professor of economics and public administration at the City University of New York. "Even during the Depression, if you tried hard enough, you would find success stories," she said.
The current recession, she said, despite its depth and breadth, holds within it the seeds of success for those who are determined, either through necessity or desire, to find a niche and fill it.
"It's a matter of insight and luck," Dr. Rubin said. "Being in the right place at the right time."
For example, she said, because of the recession people are forgoing exotic vacations for activities closer to home.
 "The nearby-travel industry is doing extraordinarily well," she said, citing renewed interest in inexpensive outdoors activities and an increase in short-term rentals at the Jersey Shore and in the Poconos.
 
Fun Without a Lot of Money
 "People want to go out and do something that's fun and doesn't cost a lot of money," Dr. Rubin said. Businessmen who can capitalize on that, she said, will prosper.
Arthur E. Imperatore, the North Jersey trucking magnate and real-estate developer, is perhaps one such example.
Mr. Imperatore, who has systematically acquired hundreds of acres of Hudson River waterfront property, said he had spent "two years and millions of dollars" obtaining approvals to build an ultra-luxurious residential development along the waterfront in West New York just north of his restaurant, marina and Manhattan ferry service in Weehawken.
The project was shelved indefinitely, however, with the onset of the recession and the realization by Mr. Imperatore that the development would very likely be "too audacious for the American public." But undeveloped land costs money to keep.
 
Searching for Alternatives
 "If you have assets that are nonproductive, and if there are alternatives to utilizing those assets, you've got to be timely, imaginative and sometimes somewhat courageous," he said.
Searching for a way to make his unproductive land at least partly productive, Mr. Imperatore struck upon the idea of a golf driving range and miniature golf course -- uses that would generate income and cost relatively little to build. The idea worked.
"If we continue to generate the cash flow that seems indicated from the present results," he said, "then we can sit on this land indefinitely." Indeed, Mr. Imperatore said, the driving range is so successful that he is now considering expansion of the range to include a "pitch and putt" course and possibly a professional golf school.
At the same time, he said, he is also exploring the feasibility of increased recreational use of much of his waterfront land, as opposed to, or perhaps in conjunction with, the office and residential development he had originally envisioned.
"Once you start down the road of alternative uses, one's mind opens up very imaginatively and inventively," he said.
 
A Common Practice
 Finding interim uses for undeveloped land is a common practice among successful developers, said Edele Hovnanian, vice president of H. Hovnanian Industries, a Tinton Falls developer. Ms. Hovnanian, whose company has built more than 14,000 residential units in Ocean County alone, said that H. Hovnanian Industries owned property in Manchester Township that was currently being mined for zircon.
 "If you want to buy at the right price, you have to recognize that the right time to buy land is not always the right time to develop it," she said. Her company, she said, typically buys land years before it is "mature" for development.
Ms. Hovnanian said her company was using the slowdown in construction to move projects through the time-consuming process of applying for municipal and state land use approvals.
 
Best Time to Buy
 "My projects are very rarely ripe for development immediately," she said. "If they were, that means that I would have to pay market price for my land, and that would be very expensive."
Some savings banks have also found that the best time to buy is when everyone else is selling.
The New Jersey Savings Bank, a subsidiary of Bancorp New Jersey, a Somerville-based savings bank, for instance, recently doubled in size when it acquired six branches of the failed City Federal Savings and Loan Association from the Resolution Trust Corporation.
 Beatrice D'Agostino, chairwoman and president of both the New Jersey Savings Bank and Bancorp New Jersey, said the New Jersey Savings Bank was converted to a public company in 1987, when the economy was thriving.
"We raised an enormous amount of capital," Mrs. D'Agostino said. "We felt that capital would be king in the future."
 
Decline Yields Opportunities
 Mrs. D'Agostino said that by properly managing that capital, the bank was in the enviable position of being cash-rich at the right time.
"When there is a decline in the economy, there are more opportunities out there than you can look at," she said. One opportunity that was too good to miss, she said, was the Resolution Trust Corporation's sale of failed savings and loans institutions.
Another kind of of asset management is illustrated by Joe Taglieri, a Hoboken contractor.
"I'm squeezing every nickel out of every asset I've got," Mr. Taglieri said. "I'm going back to the basics."
Mr. Taglieri, who has been in the construction business for 20 years, said that the last couple of years were the most dismal he could remember. "A few years ago, I had 70 people working for me and more work than I knew what to do with," he said. But as the recession set in, he said, business fell off dramatically.
As a result, Mr. Taglieri decided to capitalize on his assets, the most prominent of which was his sprawling warehouse on Clinton Street.
"I found other ways of making money," he said.
Mr. Taglieri, who had never before considered horticulture as a vocation, found that residents were eager customers for the plants and shrubs he started selling on the sidewalk and in back of his warehouse. In fact, business was so good that Mr. Taglieri moved his construction equipment out of the way and created an open-air nursery to sell his plants.
In addition, he also rented out nearly 50 parking spaces in his garage and provided storage areas for space-starved neighbors.
 
'I Sleep Better Now'
 "I sleep better now," he said. "There used to be nights when I couldn't get to sleep because I owed out as much as $200,000. Now, if I owe somebody $2,000 over a weekend, it's a lot. I'm working real close to the bone."
Dr. Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said people like Mr. Taglieri were responding appropriately and cleverly to difficult economic times.
"Rather than try to sell the business, you are forced to innovate," Dr. Seneca said. "That's sort of natural in the economic process. In weak markets, alternatives are developed to keep costs under control."
Mr. Taglieri has another explanation for his ability to weather the economic doldrums of the recession.
"I'm following the advice my Uncle Louis gave me," he said. "He told me, 'Joe, if you're going to do something, you've got to do something that doesn't cost you anything.' "
