HEADLINE: Telling the Story of Ethiopian Jews

BYLINE: By Roberta Hershenson

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
AMONG those greeting Ethiopian Jews at Ben Gurion International Airport in Israel last month was a woman from Scarsdale, Susan K. Stern. Mrs. Stern, the new chairwoman of the Women's Young Leadership Cabinet of the United Jewish Appeal, had been sent by the organization to witness Operation Solomon, the two-day emergency airlift of 14,000 Ethiopian Jews to Tel Aviv.
Within hours of returning home, even before catching up on the sleep she lost while aiding a stream of bewildered refugees, Mrs. Stern began telling the story of what she had seen. Storytelling is her job, an almost sacred responsibility, she said. 
 In the coming months, she will travel widely to share her impressions of "people from the 17th century coming off a plane into the 20th century." People with "beautiful, stunned black faces" who were "home now after 2,000 years of waiting."
According to legend, Ethiopia's first king was the son of Solomon and the Queen of Sheba, and the country's small Jewish population is descended from one of Israel's lost tribes. In 1984, 20,000 Ethiopian Jews were airlifted to Israel. More than 1,500 Jews are thought to remain in Ethiopia and face persecution there, said Mrs. Stern, who added that their rescue is also being planned.
She was back in Israel last week, attending a leadership conference sponsored by U.J.A., which raises funds nationally for Israel and for mostly Jewish causes in 34 other countries. Its Women's Young Leadership Cabinet, which Mrs. Stern heads, is composed of 225 women under the age of 40 from all over the United States.
 
'Privilege of Watching a Miracle'
 The U.J.A.-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, one of the largest local philanthropic groups in the world, sponsored Mrs. Stern's visit to observe Operation Solomon. The U.J.A.-Federation provides funds and services to 130 agencies in eight New York counties; some of its money is disbursed in Israel.
Mrs. Stern receives no salary for her two-year appointment. She said the rewards for traveling and lecturing for the group were "the privilege of watching a miracle" -- the airlift -- as well as such experiences as "watching Russians take their first steps of freedom, kiss the ground and pop the first bottle of champagne" upon arriving in Israel.
Her involvement with U.J.A. began after she and her husband, Jeffrey M. Stern, an investment banker, moved here from Chicago nine years ago. "I was just looking for friends and trying to meet people" by attending local U.J.A. meetings with a friend, she recalled. Then, one day the group visited a social center for Russian immigrants in Brooklyn that was financed by U.J.A.-Federation.
"A woman who came from the same part of Russia as my grandmother took my hand and said 'thank you' " for the center's activities, Mrs. Stern said. "She could have been part of my own family." She added that the visit had helped her understand where the organization's money was spent.
 
Focus on Human Needs
 Moved to participate further, Mrs. Stern headed the first $1 million fund-raising effort of the Scarsdale Women's Campaign for U.J.A.-Federation in 1988. Mrs. Stern now personally solicits for gifts up to $25,000. The work consists of "having a conversation," she said, and the contributions come.
In a daunting economic and political climate, the U.J.A. leader focuses on human needs. Her job is not to judge Israel, she noted, although she conceded that "some of what they do makes my fund-raising harder that day." She cited the "Who Is a Jew?" debate and Israel's activities in the occupied territories as issues that "all of us wrestle with."
Despite the fact that "Israel does lots of things we don't agree with," its collective people are "my hero," Mrs. Stern said. "They keep pulling off these miracles," she said. "The whole country mobilized for 14,000 people from another world."
Current U.J.A. fund-raising efforts are directed largely at absorbing the Ethiopians as well as the one million Soviet Jews expected to settle in Israel by 1993. Mrs. Stern said more than $1 billion had been raised in the United States this year to help pay for immigration costs and for other projects.
 
'Taking Care of Our Own'
 This is money that many people, including many Jews, would also like to see going to local causes. When asked why people should pay for housing in Israel when many Westchester families are homeless, Mrs. Stern answered that "no one else is going to help the Jewish people."
In that light, she added, the money contributed to U.J.A. is "not seen as charity but as taking care of our own," a tradition that developed since the Holocaust.
U.J.A. finances some nonsectarian projects abroad through the American Joint Distribution Committee, which has helped the Kurds in Iraq and victims of the Chernobyl disaster. U.J.A. fund-raising in Westchester benefits such institutions as Blythedale Children's Hospital in Valhalla, the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School and the Pleasantville Cottage School, residential-treatment centers for emotionally disturbed children.
Some local U.J.A. funds are also used to support "Connections," a telephone program linking the homebound that is run by Westchester Jewish Community Services.

HEADLINE: Why So Many Children Need Extra Help

 BODY:
It was with dismay that I read the article on preschool programming for handicapped children. This article presented a somewhat negative, one-sided view of preschool for the handicapped. As an educator with 30 years' experience working with handicapped children, 15 of which are as a teacher-facilitator of a local school-district-based preschool program, I must take exception to the tone and content of the article.
For many years educators have been aware that when a child is diagnosed as having a handicap or to be at high risk for developmental disabilities, early intervention is indicated. Research has revealed that early experiences have a positive influence on functioning and that influence affects all areas of functioning. 
 As with any large, bureaucratic system there is no doubt that the system that delivers services to preschoolers has some drawbacks and/ or abusers. I would like to think that for the most part all parties involved are acting responsibly.
I can only speak for the practices of my school-district program. We do not provide services to preschoolers with lisps. Children that are recommended for a classification of speech-impaired have moderate to severe communication problems. This would include children with little or no language, unintelligible speech or a combination of delayed language and articulation deficits. Children with mild articulation problems or mild delays in language development are recommended for itinerant speech services, usually two times a week.
Our overall goal of the early intervention program is the smooth transition of all children into traditional kindergartens, with the realization that this is not always possible. While the child is enrolled in the preschool, service levels are reviewed approximately every 10 weeks.
We have brought both 3- and 4-year-old children back to the Committee on Preschool Special Education at the end of these 10-week periods, sometimes to reduce service levels, other times to declassify. Over the last 15 years it has been our experience that 40 percent of our preschoolers need continued special-education services in kindergarten, usually with speech as a related service.
We have further found that approximately 95 percent of these children are fully declassified by the time they reach second grade.
We have also found that those preschoolers who are recommended for the transition class, a special-education kindergarten, generally require an additional year in a full-time special-education class and are then declassified or receive a related service for another year or two.
The bottom line is does preschool make a difference in the lives of children? The empirical evidence points to long-lasting gains. If we examine the Perry Preschool Program in Ypsilanti, Mich., for its investment return and convert all costs and benefits into current values based on a 3 percent real rate of interest, one year of the program is an extraordinary economic buy.
It would be hard to imagine that society could find a higher yield for a dollar of investment than found in preschool programs for its at-risk children.
I would agree that cost-cutting measures are in order. One area that needs to be looked at is the cost of transportation. At the present time there are several other cost-cutting alternatives being considered, one of them being the use of parental insurance to help defray costs.
Another saving could be realized by eliminating the Committee on Preschool Special Education. There is no reason why the Committee on Special Education, which was already in place, cannot assume responsibility for preschoolers.
Let's not use the excuse of fiscal crisis to deny children educational programs. There are other ways to reduce spending. Park county and state cars and let the administration join the Civil Service workers on unpaid furlough.
 
MARIAN LORENZ
Islip

HEADLINE: A Look at the City;
Holiday Haranguers

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
The other night my wife and I went to see "The Will Rogers Follies," a tedious Broadway musical about the great comedian's life. After the umpteenth playing of "Never Met a Man I Didn't Like," after the dog act and a leggy chorus line led by an unhappily bare-breasted young lady, Will's life came to the confluence of the Ziegfeld Follies and the Great Depression.
 Will noted the irony and expressed abundant sympathy for the millions of unemployed and starving, before the chorus line reappeared. The plumpish woman sitting behind us took umbrage at the sermon. 
 "This is ridiculous," she harrumphed to all. "This talk has no business being in this play, etc., etc."
 The power of the insight -- that Americans don't want social preachments intruding on their determination to think they're having a good time -- suggested that the harrumpher was a member of Congress or, more likely, a high-ranking official in the Bush Administration. On reflection, we agreed that she could not be a Washingtonian. No Washingtonian would have responded to a harangue with a harrumphing harangue.
 If Will had dared to speak of depressing things to a Washingtonian, the pros there would have neutralized him in no time. It's all technique.
 Liberals harangue President Bush about his nomination of Clarence Thomas to be a Justice of the Supreme Court. They hint that Mr. Bush selected Judge Thomas because he was black and not because he was the best man. Under the Kennebunkport sun, Mr. Anti-Quota stared into the cameras and said: "I resent that." (And who wouldn't?)
 Jack Kemp, the Housing Secretary, bothers the White House with ideas to combat poverty. He proposes to bypass the Washington bureaucracy with market incentives that don't require bundles of Federal money. He, too, has been easy prey. The White House unsheathed its bureaucratic scalpel and said: "We'll study your idea, Jack." (A trifle intellectual, but fail-safe.)
 Senator Jay Rockefeller harangues colleagues about 20 percent of America's children living in poverty and puts the repair bill at $50 billion yearly. From practiced lips flows a devastating riposte: "There's no money." (This technique can be used at home.)
 Then come the pests who yammer that there is money. They argue that we do not have to spend almost $300 billion annually on the Pentagon when the Soviet Union is in shambles and smaller forces can readily defeat the next Saddam Hussein. Others chime in that $7 billion yearly might be excessive to build nuclear warheads when we are presently halving our nuclear stockpile. To these nags, the pros give the unkindest cut of all: Silence. (That nailed me, too.)
 Then inevitably the let's-increase-taxes crowd resurfaces with its witches' brew of facts and logic. These tax hikers note that the industrialized world taxes gasoline at many times the American rate. They point to the fact that the tax burden in Germany and Japan is greater than here, and that their economic growth far exceeds ours. The winning Bushian counterthrust, unencumbered by reason, lives for all to revere: "Read my lips." (The classic mingling of scholarship and sex.)
 Vital morals can be learned here. First, harangues about foreign policy (like the Kurds) fare far better than domestic ones (like children). The foreign stuff, mostly words and an occasional war, is easier to understand. Domestic issues are too close to home.
 Second, nobody likes negative haranguers and problem-mongers. Everybody knows problems are a New York fetish and can't be solved anyway.
 Third, if negative haranguing can't be avoided, it has to embrace opponents tenderly as "baby killers" or "fat cats." Negative harangues laden with facts and complex arguments have no public place.
 Fourth, the shorter the harangue the better.
 Fending off legions of haranguers is hard work, but that's what political responsibility is all about. So Washingtonians need their July 4th vacation. Perhaps some came to New York City and took in "The Will Rogers Follies." And when Will interrupted the chorus line with his sentimentality about unemployed and needy Americans, Washingtonians surely disposed of him as they do all us haranguers. Final moral: Even astute haranguers can hope for little until the show is over.

HEADLINE: None of an Employer's Business

 BODY:
Imagine being fired from your job for smoking a cigarette or taking a drink in your own living room. Janice Bone and Daniel Winn don't have to imagine it.
Ms. Bone was fired from the Ford Meter Box Company in Wabash, Ind., when nicotine was found in her urine. The company policy: No smoking, ever. Mr. Winn was dismissed from the Best Lock Corporation of Indianapolis for admitting that he had had drinks several years earlier. Best Lock's policy: No drinking, ever. 
 Both are instances of life-style discrimination, a term rapidly entering the public vocabulary. Desperate to cap rising health care costs, employers are seeking greater control over employees' private lives. The least onerous of these interventions are economic incentives offered to those who lose weight, lower their cholesterol levels or quit smoking. More troubling are the penalties, puritanical and discriminatory, imposed on those who fail to meet company standards.
The pariah status of smokers provides a worrisome example. The cancer risks associated with smoking justify making public places smoke free. Yet those who wish to risk disease should be allowed to do so privately without fear of repercussion -- except, perhaps, the added insurance cost of belonging to a higher risk group.
It hasn't worked that way. At least 6,000 companies now refuse to hire smokers; some dismiss smokers they discover on the payroll. The Indiana Legislature, angered by what happened to Ms. Bone, passed legislation that protects the employment rights of smokers. A dozen states have such legislation. A dozen more are considering it.
The city of Athens, Ga., experimented briefly with discrimination on the basis of cholesterol level. In an effort to decrease the number of heart-related health claims, Athens declined for a time to hire even qualified employees with cholesterol levels that exceeded the city standard.
The program was junked under pressure from the American Civil Liberties Union, which argued that the law prevented recipients of Federal funds from discriminating on the basis of health. Private companies are free to do as they wish -- though, as in the Bone case, wary state legislatures are beginning to set some limits.
The Indiana Court of Appeals recently ruled in favor of Mr. Winn, who had sought unemployment benefits because, he claimed, his firing had been unjust. The unanimous decision said that the company had failed to demonstrate that its rule had a reasonable connection to business interests.
Companies are justified in providing employees with economic incentives to eat more healthily and to drink and smoke less. They may even be justified in assigning those who live less healthily to risk groups that pay more for their health insurance. But employers would do well to refrain from invading an employee's personal life with edicts that do not bear on fitness for work.

HEADLINE: The Best Little Bank in America

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio

 BODY:
From the troubled landscape of American banking, burdened with bad loans and falling profits, a new elite is emerging. A group of surprisingly vigorous banks, little-known outside their multistate bailiwicks, these so-called superregional banks are seen as the likely winners in the Darwinian winnowing that is now underway in the industry. They could eclipse the money-center banks like Citicorp and Chase Manhattan as the new powers of American banking.
When industry experts look for the best-run bank among these regional powerhouses, and perhaps the best bank in America, they usually end up here in Columbus at the 24-story mirrored-glass headquarters of the Banc One Corporation. Banc One has combined conservative lending, innovative technology, remarkable customer service and an uncanny ability to smoothly absorb a steady stream of acquired banks. Today, it is the nation's 22d-largest bank, but it ranks first in several key measures of financial performance like return on assets. 
 Banc One executives almost brag that they do little business with the nation's biggest 1,000 or so corporations, preferring higher-margin loans to smaller companies that their vast army of community bankers know so well. Eighty percent of the bank's commercial loans are to companies with sales of $50 million a year or less. "Our corporate lending ends about where Citibank's starts," noted George Meiling, Banc One's treasurer. The conservatism even extends to a few odd rules at the head office. Employees, for instance, are not permitted to drink coffee at their desks.
Yet Banc One has also been a pioneer in introducing new products and services, from one of the first automated teller machines in 1970 to an A.T.M. installed last week in a McDonald's restaurant in Mansfield, Ohio. Many of its branches are open on Saturdays and Sundays. "That's
when most people do much of their purchasing -- it only makes sense," explained John B. McCoy, Banc One's 48-year-old chairman.
Banc One even has branches that look more like mini-shopping malls than banks, with glass atriums, "boutiques" offering special services, signs of blue neon, comfortable seating areas and fresh coffee. One in a Columbus suburb, the Sawmill Financial Marketplace, was designed with advice from a Banc One director, Leslie H. Wexner, the founder of The Limited Inc.
"Anyone who doubts that you can make money in basic banking need look no further than Banc One," said Lowell Bryan, a director of McKinsey & Company. "It's a terrific bank. We need more like Banc One."
Since 1984, when Mr. McCoy succeeded his father as chief executive, Banc One has quadrupled in size, to $30.3 billion in assets by the end of last year. When its Federally assisted purchases of Texas banks are consolidated on the balance sheet, probably next year, Banc One's assets will total roughly $44 billion.
Buying other banks has been a big part of the Banc One formula and its success in bringing them into the corporate fold is being scrutinized by others in banking as economic logic and regulatory reform accelerate the concentration of the industry. Fewer, stronger banks would be better for the American economy and cheaper for the taxpayers, who have had to ante up to protect depositors at failed banks. The Treasury's proposed banking bill, which would allow banks to freely open branches anywhere in the nation, seems certain to speed the consolidation.
And the big regional players -- NCNB, Banc One, Fleet Financial, Norwest, PNC Financial, Wachovia and others -- will be the likely buyers. They avoided the once-trendy fields that proved so damaging to many of their banking peers -- loans to developing nations and those to finance corporate takeovers and to bankroll the 80's real-estate boom. Rather, they have moved into new markets as state laws against outsiders eased one by one. Today, they are the ones with the profits and the high-priced shares needed to buy other banks.
Two weeks ago, for example, NCNB Corporation offered to buy the C&S/Sovran Financial Corporation in a $4 billion stock swap that, if completed, would create the nation's second-largest bank, behind Citicorp. And just three days earlier, the Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem agreed to buy South Carolina National Bank for $800 million.
But making acquisitions work will be the key to which of the superregionals emerge as the industry leaders over the next several years. The Bank of New England, for one, was among the most ambitious superregionals before falling victim to bad acquisitions and reckless lending. Management skill displayed in handling growth, technology, product innovation and people will be more important than size alone.
At Banc One, there are clear-cut rules governing acquisitions -- rules that would presumably prevent it from trying a deal like the NCNB-C&S/Sovran Financial merger. Banc One will not buy a bank larger than one-third its size. "I don't believe in a merger of equals," the 48-year-old chairman explained. "We want to be sure that it is the Banc One culture that survives."
 
High-Quality Assets
 Banc One has moved beyond its Ohio stronghold to build up branch networks in Indiana, Wisconsin, Michigan, Kentucky, Texas and Illinois by making scores of smaller acquisitions, all friendly. It moved into Texas in 1989 with a $500 million deal with a failed bank, MCorp, but only after the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation agreed to take the bad loans. Banc One then fashioned a retail network with additional purchases of troubled savings and loans in Texas.
Banc One has two purchases pending in Illinois: the $190 million acquisition of the Marine Corporation of Springfield, announced last March, and the $347 million purchase of the First Illinois Corporation of Evanston, announced last month. Counting the pending acquisitions, Banc One has 858 branches in seven states.
Despite rapid growth, the quality of Banc One's earnings has not slipped. Last year, it had by far the highest return on assets, at 1.53 percent, of the country's 50 largest banks. That performance has been appreciated on Wall Street. The market value of its shares outstanding, roughly $6.1 billion, ranks third among all banks. Only J. P. Morgan's and BankAmerica's are larger. Investors place a value on Banc One, for example, that is more than $1 billion greater than that of Citicorp, the nation's largest bank. Growth and high-quality earnings are crucial to Banc One because that buoys the price of its stock, which is the currency it uses to buy other banks.
Banking experts familiar with Banc One are hard pressed to find shortcomings. Even the move into Texas, which some viewed as a risky foray, appears to be turning out well. Thomas Hanley of Salomon Brothers Inc., who has been quite critical of major banks recently, admitted a bit sheepishly that the report he wrote on Banc One two months ago, entitled "Banc One -- A Dominant Competitor," was probably the most positive research report he had written in 23 years as a bank analyst. "I tried to find weaknesses, chinks in the armor, but I couldn't," Mr. Hanley said.
 
Casting Its Nets
 Banc One's management is constantly scouting for banks to buy. "One of the businesses we're in is the acquisition business," Mr. McCoy said. The point man in the hunt is William Boardman, an executive vice president, who was recruited from a Columbus law practice in 1984. Mr. Boardman glances at six deals a day, many of them from the inventory of failed institutions held by the F.D.I.C. or the Resolution Trust Company.
Mr. Boardman travels to one merger candidate a week. In fact, the Ohio company's reputation as a buyer is so well known today that news of one of its two corporate jets landing on a local airport can prompt a jump in the stock price of a community bank.
Mr. Boardman has just one full-time staff member, but he freely calls on experts from banks within the group. For big deals, the "due diligence teams" can be large and on assignment for weeks, with specialists poring over a prospective bank's retail lending and data processing, and interviewing senior executives and branch managers. The team in the MCorp deal was 22 people, who went to Dallas for two weeks in 1989.
Buying the MCorp banks was a departure for Banc One. The Texas banks did mainly corporate lending and had no retail branch system, Banc One's forte. Mr. McCoy was skeptical, despite the Federal assistance to make the deal financially attractive. But over dinner with his 22 colleagues, he was won over. "We liked the people," explained Mr. Meiling, who was part of the Texas team. "They were motivated. There had been no brain drain." And today, the senior people at the acquired MCorp banks are mostly still in place.
The atmosphere was very different when a second Banc One team of 55 people had cocktails and dinner at the hotel in Boston last February to discuss whether the bank should bid for the Bank of New England. Banc One chose not to bid, scared off by the state of the bank and the prospect that the Northeast economy would not rebound soon.
Banc One pursues good banks and makes them better in states where it can build a strong market position. The neighboring state of Pennsylvania, for instance, might seem a natural place to expand, but already has three large companies -- PNC Financial, Mellon Bank and CoreStates Financial. "We'd be a pimple there," Mr. McCoy explained.
It leaves existing management in place. Banc One is structured as a multibank holding company, with each affiliate bank having its own chief executive and board of directors. The local management makes its own decisions, from salaries to charitable donations. "The power is where the money is made -- at the banks, not at headquarters," said John Russell, a corporate vice president.
But all 51 affiliate banks have standardized products, the same technology and prepare similar monthly reports. The standardization is designed to cut costs by creating companywide economies of scale for functions like data processing. New conscripts to Banc One are often impressed by the rigor of the monthly reports, which track hundreds of categories of revenue and expenses, measuring performance against monthly forecasts made by the managements of each bank. "Banc One has the best management reporting system I've ever seen in the banking industry," said Harvey Mitchell, a veteran Dallas banker who is now chairman of Bank One, Texas.
The reporting system is less a means of corporate control than a management tool. Each bank's performance is measured alongside comparable institutions in the Banc One system. These "peer" banks then share tips to improve profitability. For example, Chuck Sulerzyski recalled that as head of retail banking for 40 branches in the Columbus area a couple of years ago, his expenses were much higher than at the Dayton affiliate. Mr. Sulerzyski and a group of his managers inspected the Dayton office and found the difference: they used a higher proportion of part-time tellers and had streamlined the handling of some transactions. Those techniques were copied in Columbus at a savings of $3 million a year, explained Mr. Sulerzyski, who is now the vice president for Banc One's retail banking throughout Ohio.
Why do healthy banks sell out to Banc One? Because they see the industry concentrating into fewer hands and want to combine with a winner to protect and expand their grip on local markets. The Marine Corporation of Illinois is a Springfield-based holding company with four banks, 16 branches and $1.2 billion in assets. It wants to buy smaller banks with the valued and liquid currency of Banc One stock. "We want to put Banc One's muscle behind us," said John Staudt, Marine's president. (The affiliate banks typically hunt for smaller banks, with less than $1 billion in assets.)
 
Distinctive Touch
 Banc One's distinctive approach to consumer banking is on display at its branch in Dublin, a Columbus suburb. In the Sawmill district of Dublin, it is not called a bank but a "financial marketplace." It is a prototype, but several others have been built since it opened in the winter of 1988.
Walk into the red-brick building with a peaked glass atrium and a woman seated behind a curved counter asks, "Hi, can I help you?" Along the sides are the bank's service areas, set off by partitions and glass, boutique-style, and labeled overhead with signs in blue neon script -- Home Equity, New Accounts and so on. The boutiques include a travel agency and relocation service, both run by Banc One personnel, and an outside realtor.
The center of the branch has low, modern couches for customers. Magazines are neatly stacked on a glass table, with fresh coffee nearby. Just below the glass atrium is a border of color pictures of local scenes, a high-school graduation, a business meeting, a Cub Scout and the best local golfer, Jack Nicklaus.
Michael Bradley, manager of the Sawmill Financial Marketplace, speaks like a marketing specialist. The average age of customers is 31.2 years old, 80 percent of his customers come from within a four-and-a-half-mile radius, there are 18 nearby competitors, and none of them come close to matching his volume. His branch has accumulated deposits of roughly $50 million and handles 50,000 transactions a month, unusually high figures in the banking industry.
There are no banker's hours here. The branch is open from 9 A.M. to 7 P.M. Monday through Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday, and noon to 5 P.M. on Sunday. The late hours clearly appeal to Mr. Bradley's busy suburban customers; 37 percent of the branch's new accounts are opened from 5 P.M. to 7 P.M.
On July 27, the Sawmill branch will hold its third annual "sidewalk sale." The bank moves outside. Mr. Bradley grills hot dogs and hamburgers. Some animals are rented from the local zoo. And there are one-day bargains like a quarter percent added to the prevailing rate on six-month certificates of deposit. "Is that innovative?" Mr. Bradley asks rhetorically. "No. Hell, retailers have been holding sidewalk sales and midnight madness sales for decades. It's just unusual for the banking industry."
 
 
 
BOOT CAMP FOR BANKERS
 The management culture at Banc One is constantly and carefully nurtured. Senior officers of acquired banks are sent to "Bank One College," a two-week, 18-hour-a-day indoctrination, with speeches, small group meetings, dawn aerobics sessions and Outward Bound-like excursions. John McCoy, a Stanford M.B.A., and his team of young executives are constantly sampling the latest in management thinking with well-known practitioners, from the consultant Tom Peters to the Harvard Business School's Rosabeth Moss Kanter, who are brought in for lectures.
But there is another vital ingredient in the Banc One culture: cash. More than 600 officers are in the "key manager incentive compensation" program, intended to give senior managers an incentive to push for earnings growth -- and high-quality earnings. "It's a real strong part of the culture," said John Westman, Banc One's chief financial officer.
It means that the president of a smallish bank with $300 million in assets might get a salary of, say, $100,000. Yet he could make $175,000 if he exceeded his profit targets for the year. But should a bank's return on assets fall below 1.1 percent, the executive gets no bonus at all. Only five of America's 50 largest banking companies had returns above 1.1 percent last year, according to Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a banking research firm.

 
 
Targeting Gets Personal
 Behind Banc One's retail banking stands an impressive array of technology. For example, most Banc One tellers in the Columbus area have computers linked into a master file with information like age and income of customers. When a customer steps up to the counter, the employee can hit a button and pull up a list of the four products -- C.D.'s or I.R.A.'s, say, -- that person is most likely to buy. Banc One is working on a system that would add far more data. A new customer might be asked about his or her family, for example. "And when your daughter turns 6, you might receive a letter saying you should think about saving for her college education, " explained David Van Lear, president of Banc One's $220 million-a-year services subsidiary.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Showdown in the Gas Patch

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
In the San Juan basin of northwest New Mexico, a handful of energy companies have sold natural gas from an unlikely source, underground coal deposits, for $1.50 or more per 1,000 cubic feet in the last few years.
Spot prices routinely vary widely depending on the heating season, but an unusually warm winter and recession sent prices tumbling to their lowest levels in 20 years this spring, below $1.20. When big gas buyers in southern California bargained last week for a deeper cut, to 95 cents, J. Larry Nichols balked. 
 Mr. Nichols, operator of the region's biggest coal gas alliance, which includes Amoco, Burlington Northern's Meridian Oil, Conoco, Texaco and his own Devon Energy Corporation, cut daily production of the partnership nearly in half, to 65 million cubic feet a day for the month of July.
The maneuver meant stopping or curtailing production at 50 wells of the group's Northeast Blanco unit.
Many gas buyers had believed coal gas producers like Devon were in a bind and would have to produce at any price because of potential problems with water draining back into inactive well bores in the coal layers. Mr. Nichols, Devon's 49-year-old president and chief executive, said the shutdowns ordered last week sent a message that those buyers were wrong: wells in the region can be water-proofed.
Meanwhile, he said, Devon and its partners have the financial strength to wait for higher prices in the winter.
Low prices forced Devon to take a $25 million writedown in the first quarter, resulting in a loss of $17.8 million. But Devon has staying power, Mr. Nichols said, adding that its debt was a moderate 32 percent of equity at the end of March, and production costs were cut to 60 cents a 1,000 cubic feet from $1 two years ago.
"We needed to draw the line somewhere to tell buyers that we weren't going to be traded down forever," Mr. Nichols said.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The French Market as a Temptress

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The sudden decline in the French stock market is making it attractive again -- at least for the investor who has a tolerance for the political risk that arrived with Edith Cresson, France's new Prime Minister, and the patience to wait for a hoped-for interest rate cut.
The market's fall has been quick. From a 1991 high of 1,874.81 on June 11, the CAC-40 index of leading blue chip French stocks has dropped more than 8 percent in three weeks, closing at 1,723.14 on Friday, This is the lowest it has been in four months. The decline is now eating into the spectacular gains made in the rally that began in January when the Persian Gulf War started. 
 Taking their toll on the market have been worries about Mrs. Cresson, whose popularity has declined since her appointment May 15, signs of a further slowing of the French economy and the growing expectations that any interest rate cut will be delayed.
Just a few weeks ago, summer was expected to bring good news for the French market, which has been the favorite of many European analysts this year, especially as an alternative to Germany.
The July inflation figures are expected to show prices rising in France at a slower rate than in Germany for the first time in years. This reversal should give some lift to the French franc, which is one of the weakest currencies in the European Monetary System. And in the way things work in monetary policy, this lift from the bottom for the franc is supposed to give the French central bank the leaway it needs to lower interest rates without damaging the currency.
But other things have not gone as they should.
For example, Japan's unexpected interest rate cut last week is not likely to have a salutary effect in Europe, where Germany sets the pace on interest rates and monetary policy.
In fact, the dollar rally this year makes it more likely that the Germans will raise their interest rates to fight inflation and defend the mark, which is at its lowest level since October of 1989. This will likely limit the French Government's maneuverability regarding rates. Analysts like Stephane B. Michel, president of Bertrand Michel Securities in New York, and Nicola Mann at Salomon Brothers in London now think the French rate cut will be delayed until the fall when German intentions might be more clear.
In recent months, Acadian Asset Management in Boston has found the stock markets in Belgium and Italy to be preferable to France's. Ronald D. Frashure, the firm's executive vice president, said Italy and Belgium were better values because the ratios of prices to cash flow and other measures of reltive cost and value have been more attractive.
The firm has had no investment in France in some of its global portfolios that include stocks, bonds and cash, and a lower than normal French investment level in its all-equity portfolios for institutional investors. These include state pension funds, including that of Massachusetts; universities, including Harvard, and companies like International Paper.
But Mr. Frashure had said that a drop in the market or a further slowdown in the economy would make France more attractive. Both those shifts are now underway.
At Salomon Brothers, Ms. Mann and Danielle Kadeyen have just come around to a more favorable view of France -- but with caveats. "Spain and Italy still look cheaper," said Ms. Mann. "But we are beginning to tell investors to take some advantage of weakness but not to take an aggressive stand."
Mr. Michel said that the worst news on France may not have been heard yet, that it will come if the Germans raise interest rates. "That will be a good time to buy," he said, adding that eventually with both the German and French economies slowing, some easing of interest rates will follow.
With Salomon Brothers predicting a rise in the CAC-40 to 2,000 by year end and Bertrand Michel looking for a jump to 1,950 if there is an interest rate cut, there is a potential gain of 14 percent to 17 percent. So the French slump, especially if it deepens a little more, could make the wait for the interest rate cut worth the price. "France may not be the best bet but it is a reasonable bet today," said Mr. Michel.
Elsewhere, the Bank of Japan surprised most analysts last week by suddenly cutting its official discount rate to 5.5 percent from 6 percent. But instead of providing a hoped-for boost, it gave the Tokyo market just a one-day rally. And if it was an attempt to bolster a market hurt by the latest scandal involving the top brokerage firms, it did not work. After rising 817.80 points or 3.51 percent on Monday, the day of the interest rate cut, the Nikkei 225 fell each day for the rest of the week, wiping out all of the gains and more. On Friday, the Nikkei 225 closed at 22,898.34, down 1,210.42 points from Monday's close and at its lowest level since Jan. 16.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng Index surged 96.14 points or 2.5 percent on Thursday and Friday, closing at 3,892.71. The move came as the British and Chinese governments reached broad agreement on a financial plan for a new airport. But there still could be problems if China balks when it is consulted on the details of the airport plan.

LENGTH: 1601 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/June 30-July 5

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Goliath Joins Goliath in the Computer Wars 

For the computer industry, this is the deal of the decade. Apple Computer Inc. and the International Business Machines Corporation, the two largest personal computer makers, agreed last week to share their technology, develop new technology jointly and even sell each other's products. New high-end personal computers and work stations are expected to emerge from the match. But it will take years before any brand new products make it to market. The deal gives Apple use of I.B.M.'s superquick RS/6000 chip, which would be made under license by Motorola Inc. It gives I.B.M. access to Apple's nifty new operating software, code-named "Pink." The alliance also leaves some powerful players out in the cold. Microsoft Inc., which developed I.B.M.'s current software standard and is increasingly seen as a rival to Big Blue, has no part in the deal. Also in doubt is the future of Apple's host of Japanese suppliers like Sony that produce everything from memory chips to disk drives for the company. All those parts are also made by I.B.M.
 
A Farewell to Power Master
 
The message from the government was clear: You can sell high-test malt liquor, you just have to give it a meek-sounding name. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said as much when it told the G. Heileman Brewing Company it could not sell a new malt liquor under the Power Master label. Power Master sounds, well, a little too potent, the bureau said. And it is. The brew has 5.9 percent alcohol content versus 5.5 percent for regular malt liquor and 3.5 percent for beer. Activists like the Rev. Calvin Butts in in Harlem also contend that Power Master, like the malt-liquor category in general, is aimed at poor, young black men. But the company takes exception, arguing that Power Master was supposed to be an upscale drink. Whatever its new name, the drink must fight for shelf space with meekly named rivals like Colt 45, also from Heilman; Red Bull, from Stroh Brewing Company, and Old English 800, from the Pabst Brew Company -- which is still being advertised, unchallenged, as "Eight Ball."
 
Shell Oil, Gentle With the Knife
 
After a delay of almost five years, the recession in the oil patch has finally caught up with the Shell Oil Company. Most other oil companies began dismissing workers way back in the mid-1980's. Shell was able to retain most of them and continue expanding production in Alaska and the Gulf of Mexico because it was more efficient than its rivals. No more. Hurt by falling natural gas prices and lackluster profits, the company announced last week that it would trim its work force over the next 12 to 18 months by 4,650 people. But it will leave its $2.3 billion capital budget intact. Shell, which is a unit of the Royal/Dutch Shell Group, has a total work force of 31,000 in the United States. The company has said it will be gentle when it cuts. Voluntary severance, attrition and a lot of counseling will accompany the knife.
 
Truth in Juice
 
The Food and Drug Administration is cracking down. First it was the word "fresh" -- you can't use the word unless your product really is. Then it was the "no cholesterol" claims that are pasted on everything from salad oil to spaghetti. Last week it was juice. The F.D.A. wants Americans to know what they are drinking. By November, beverage makers will have to list not only the total amount of juice in such things as soft drinks but specific percentages of each juice used in a blended drink. Previously, "100 percent juice," could be used on a product sold as raspberry juice, even if only a drop of the expensive stuff was blended into cheaper apple juice. Companies will have to rewrite about 2,500 labels and even rename products. The industry is begging for more time.
 
Soft Spots in Boeing's Backlog?
 
The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company may be doing fine, but its customers are going broke. Take America West Airlines Inc., the Phoenix-based carrier that two weeks ago filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. It is the fourth American carrier to file since December. America West had ordered $1.5 billion worth of new airplanes from Boeing. Those orders are now being re-evaluated, America West said last week. Because of the airline industry's slump, Boeing has been quietly stretching out delivery dates for its planes. So far there have been no outright cancellations, but analysts say it is just a matter of time before some of Boeing's backlog of orders dissappear.
 
One More Banking Loss
 
Bank performance across the country has been nearly uniform -- losses everywhere. Last week, First Interstate Bancorp, California's fourth-largest bank holding company and a powerhouse in the West, joined the growing list. The bank said it would report losses of about $80 million for the second quarter, would increase its provisions for loan losses and planned to cut its dividend to 30 cent from 75 cents. The announcement surprised the analysts. First Interstate has been regarded as a well-run bank with a good deposit base. On the news, the stock fell $5.375 to $26 a share and closed the week at $26.875.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Tokyo Lifts the Dow
 
Who says the world is not one big market? Last week, Japan's central bank lowered its discount rate a half-point to 5.5 percent in an effort to get its rapidly rolling economy rolling even faster. The Bush Administration has been urging Tokyo to do that for almost a year. On the news, the Dow Jones industrial average shot up 51.66 points to 2,958.41. Why the spillover from Tokyo to New York? Japan's lower rates, analysts think, will make investments in America more attractive. And a faster-running Japanese economy is certain to suck in more American exports. Japan as the world's economic engine is something new. Traditionally, that job (and the inflation that goes with it) was America's.
 
Going Private, Soviet Style
 
Last week, when the Soviet Parliament approved a law allowing private ownership of property, it stood to make a bundle: Selling state-owned properties to Soviet citizens and to foreigners could bring the central government as much as much as 450 billion rubles, some economists say. That is about $250 billion, at the commercial exchange rate. But the new law comes with a catch -- and it is a big one. It exempts certain industries and properties from the law's provisions. Just which industries? The law doesn't say. "This law is primarily a denationalization law and privatization is only a minor part of it," explained Anatoly I. Lukyanov, chairman of the Parliament. That distinction, too, could use clarifying.
 
A Well-Tarnished Bank
 
The Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International has long been suspected of doing nasty things. Money laundering, for instance, to which it admitted in January when it paid Washington $15 million in fines and was told to sell its controlling interest in First American Bankshares. Last week B.C.C.I., which has more than $20 billion in assets and operates in 69 countries, was shut down by the Luxembourg Monetary Institute and the Bank of England. Its problems tarnished the reputation of former Defense Secretary Clark Clifford, who served as chairman of First American and whose law firm represented B.C.C.I. in the United States.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Don't Count on Construction
 
The real estate recovery is more crab than jack rabbit. Every step in one direction comes with a slow step in another direction. Just consider spending on new construction. It dropped by 0.9 percent in May following a sharp increase of 1.2 percent for April, according to the Commerce Department. "In total dollar volume, the increase in residential single family homes was $88 billion," said Richard Peach, an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association. "But there was a decrease of $120 billion on the commercial side." The decline was a disappointment, and Mr. Peach expects that slump to continue for five years to a decade.
 
Weighing Those Jobless Figures
 
Unemployment usually rises slightly even after the economy has bottomed out. Businesses typically wait until they are sure a recovery is in place before they hire. But unemployment during this recession has been rising a little too long for some economists. Last week the Labor Department reported it reached 7 percent in June, higher than at any time since last October. "It is a tricky report," said Alan Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Company. "Fewer people are working, but they are working longer hours," he said. If it were not for all that overtime, Mr. Sinai said, "the report would seriously damage the notion that we're in a recovery."
 
The Auto Sales Data
 
Are auto sales finally rebounding? It depends on how you read the numbers. Most analysts compare sales last month to sales for the same month a year earlier. From that perspective, things are bad, with sales down 10.1 percent in June. But if examined as a continuum, the picture is brighter: month-to-month, sales have been improving since April.
 
On the Bright Side
 
Not all the messages about the economy are mixed. The National Association of Purchasing Managers reported last week a surge in its monthly index. The index, which uses a complicated formula to determine how many of the nation's businesses are increasing their orders for goods, rose to 50.9 percent for June from 45.9 percent in May. Readings above 50 indicate that the economy is expanding.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Even B-Schoolers Say It's a Bummer

BYLINE: By JEFF MADRICK; Jeff Madrick is a New York-based business correspondent for NBC and an author.

 BODY:
I had braced for a showdown at my 20th Harvard Business School reunion last month. Asked to speak on a panel about leveraged buyouts -- had they helped or hurt American competitiveness? -- I came prepared to denounce them to an unbelieving, unrepentant audience.
After all, when I was at the B-school, critics called it the West Point of Capitalism. I didn't expect more than a few supporters -- maybe Mark Drucker, who still sports a bump on his head from the Columbia University demonstrations of 1968, or Art Marks, who traveled to the Deep South to fight for desegregation in the 1960's, or Archie Edwards, a former art student at Harvard College. 
 I was wrong. From all around the room came expressions of doubt and concern -- and this from successful business executives in their 40's who have little reason to be bitter about Wall Street. What became very clear very fast was that these men and women are deeply worried about what's coming next. Concerns have trickled up: These people, who mostly have it all, were sounding very much like people who don't.
The panel discussion brought surprises from the beginning. The first speaker was a classmate, now a partner at one of Wall Street's most respected investment banks. Almost immediately, he conceded that leveraged buyouts had gone too far and so had the size of fees paid to bankers like him. Then he polled the group of perhaps 75 classmates. More than half said they believed that L.B.O.'s were bad for the economy.
Next came my turn to speak. I couldn't help but point out that my investment banker colleague was "mea-culpa-ing" all the way to the bank, a phenomenon common among my acquaintances on the Street.
I presented my case against L.B.O.'s -- data demonstrating the sorry state of productivity in America, the unprecedented growth of debt, the standstill in business investment and the freeze in the standard of living over the last decade. I received a far warmer reception than I anticipated. When Sam Hayes, a Harvard finance professor, followed me on the panel, he also criticized L.B.O.'s, albeit more mildly.
I began to wonder if L.B.O.'s were simply an easy target. But during the question and answer period that followed, it became clear there were deeper concerns about the economy, even anger over who was responsible, among these men and women who came from Dallas and Houston and Atlanta and Los Angeles and from all points of the Northeast. These were not the optimists I went to school with.
How will we unwind all this debt, asked one. Isn't it possible we might not come out of this recession for many years because of this level of debt, asked another. Why was it that minorities did not get their share of the economic pie in the 80's? Did too much of the investment in L.B.O.'s go to the wrong place? What about investment in education? There was even some antagonism among these generally conservative business executives toward unbridled market deregulation.
In my reporting for NBC, I have run across anger and confusion among all kinds of investors and workers who have had a pound or two of flesh taken out of them by the buccaneers of the last decade and the recession of this one.
There have been owners of insurance policies at the failed Executive Life and frightened retirees whose money was managed by First Capital Life, both insurance companies that invested heavily in "junk bonds." There have been elderly people who had bought junk-bond mutual funds without knowing it and are now sitting with hefty losses. There have been doctors and business executives seething over failed investments in limited partnerships sold to them by the cream of Wall Street brokerage firms. There have been jobless workers selling the family car because their unemployment compensation has run out.
Add to this list my former classmates from the Harvard Business School. Perhaps that should not be so surprising. But these are successful men and women who have more than their share of influence in this country, and the extent of their concerns says something about how deep the trouble is -- and how possible a serious political backlash is. These people believe that relief of our many economic ills is not waiting for us around the corner. And the undercurrent of anxiety about the economy stands in sharp contrast to the pious assurances from Washington that all is well. Many from the B-school think it is not. And that -- from the West Point of Capitalism -- is a telling sign.

HEADLINE: Israel Not Budging on Settlement Expansion

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 6

 BODY:
The Israeli Government is convinced it faces a tough choice between continuing its expansion of West Bank settlements or getting aid from the United States for the absorption of Soviet Jews. And it has made a clear decision: settlements will continue.
Israel greeted President Bush's latest criticism of its West Bank settlement expansion program, last Monday, with a low-key response that masked a deep and growing concern that the state may be forced to pay a heavy price for its settlement drive.Even though Mr. Bush softened his criticism by saying he did not believe there should be any quid pro quo between settlements and additional aid, officials here are convinced that Washington may refuse Jerusalem's request for $10 billion in loan guarantees for immigrant housing -- if Israel does not stop building new West Bank settlements or does not show more flexibility in the peace process. 
 Every day, ministers and members of Parliament publicly debate what Israel should do. Economists offer draconian predictions of what will happen if the money does not come.
And Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai has made it clear that Israelis should be ready for a contingency plan of huge tax increases and deep cuts in social services if the American aid is not granted.
All this comes two months before Israel even intends to present its formal request for loan guarantees -- and before anyone in the Bush Administration has publicly made any connection between settlements and the peace process or the request for aid.
Still, said a senior aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir: "We've learned not to take anything for granted here. If they're unhappy with us, we could have problems even if there is no direct linkage made."
Asked to analyze the situation on Tuesday, Oded Ben Ami, Israeli radio's correspondent in Washington, said, "One must be blind to think there will not be a linkage; there will be one."
But the settlement activity continues nonetheless. In fact, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon dedicated a new neighborhood in a northern West Bank settlement the very day President Bush's latest remarks were reported here, saying: "The settlements are not an obstacle to peace. The settlements are the best obstacle to war."
At the same time, his office has hired architects to create master plans for new Jewish cities in the West Bank that could accommodate 500,000 people or more, although formal Government approval and funding would be needed to carry out those plans.
The request for the $10 billion was first made during the Persian Gulf war, but at Washington's request the formal submission was put off until September. When Mr. Modai first raised the question, Israel was still being praised for its restraint during the gulf war.
But last Monday Mr. Modai complained that the expected recompense for that restraint had not come.
"I have a very uneasy feeling about the expectations that we had because, up to this very moment, I do not see that the position taken by the state of Israel, which was the key at the time, is being rewarded in any way," he said.
But Mr. Modai, like others in Government, said Israel would not change its policies or budge an inch, even if the price was a rejection of the aid request.
 "We're a stiff-necked people," Mr. Modai said. "Whoever doesn't remember that should read the Bible." Mr. Shamir and other officials have said essentially the same thing.
But Michael Bruno, governor of Israel's Central Bank, warned that "there's no way to absorb the massive immigration without help from the United States."
And as he announced his contingency plan, to be carried out if the aid is not approved, Mr. Modai said: "If we have to implement the plan, a very heavy burden will fall on the shoulders of the Israeli citizen, both present and the future. If, God forbid, we have to implement it, it will be very tough."
Mr. Shamir said: "I hope the pressures and conditions will stop. I hope the U.S. aid for immigrant absorption will come, just as it has in the past."

HEADLINE: Weicker and Legislative Leaders Resolve Little in a Short Meeting

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, July 6

 BODY:
Legislative leaders met with Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for only 45 minutes today in their fourth day of talks to come up with a tax plan to end the budget impasse here and enable 20,000 furloughed state employees to return to work.
Democratic leaders continued their discussions after Governor Weicker left their offices for the day at 1:45 P.M. Another session with Mr. Weicker was scheduled for Sunday at 9 A.M.
Little was said today as the short session broke up and Governor Weicker walked from the Legislative Office Building back to the Capitol, surrounded by television crews and news photographers.
There had been few expectations that today's meeting would resolve the divisions between income-tax advocates and opponents.
 
A Partial Shutdown
 But even without progress in the talks, it appeared likely that Monday could be the last day of the partial shutdown of state government ordered by the Governor. Mr. Weicker has until then to sign or veto a temporary budget resolution passed by the House and Senate at the start of the week or it will take effect without his signature. And any veto, legislators say, would immediately be overridden.
Governor Weicker has said that once the resolution takes effect, authorizing state spending for 14 days, he will end the partial shutdown of state offices that has furloughed nearly 40 percent of the work force.
Mr. Weicker said he would announce his intentions on the resolution Sunday morning, before the talks resume.
Connecticut has been without a budget since Monday, the start of the new fiscal year, prompting the Governor's shutdown of offices. Mr. Weicker said he had no choice but to suspend nonessential services, because laws require the state to have a balanced budget, and he had no budget at all.
 
Long-Term Source of Revenues
 Mr. Weicker, however, had vetoed two budgets approved by the House and Senate that relied on a broad expansion of the state's 8 percent sales tax to cover currently exempt goods and services.
The Governor insists that the budget provide a reliable long-term source of revenue while stimulating the economy by cutting the state's high sales and corporation taxes, and he says he cannot see how to accomplish those goals without an income tax.
The meetings between Mr. Weicker and the Democratic and Republican leaders of the House and Senate began Wednesday, the day after the Senate killed an income-tax plan that the House had approved and Mr. Weicker had said he would sign. It was the second income-tax plan to die in the legislature.
In the last two days the pace and length of the sessions between the Governor and the legislative leaders has slowed, as the legislative leaders have begun talking with their members and consulting on their negotiations.

HEADLINE: James Pie, Parochial-School Advocate, Dies at 69

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
James L. J. Pie, an advocate of state funds for private and parochial schools and a lawyer who wrote legislation that created the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transit Authority, died on June 30 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 69 years old.
He died of heart failure said his wife, Mary. 
 Mr. Pie joined the Philadelphia Solitictor's office in 1957 and retired in 1979 as a deputy solicitor. Specializing in mass transit issues, he drafted legislation for the transit authority and assisted in the development of the city's commuter tunnel and airport high-speed rail line.
In 1959 he founded the Pennsylvania Federation of Citizens for Educational Freedom, a nonprofit advocacy group seeking refunds for parents of children in private and parochial schools.
In the late 1960's, Mr. Pie wrote legislation for the State of Pennsylvania that authorized state funds for private and parochial schools and the refunds to parents. In 1973, the United States Supreme Court declared the legislation unconstitutional.
Mr. Pie, a native of Philadelphia, graduated from La Salle College and earned a law degree from the Catholic University of America in 1950.
In addition to his wife, the former Mary Frances Hensler, he is survived by four daughters, Maureen Pie-Bruno and Christina Pie O'Keefe, both of Philadelphia, Maria C. Hughes of Westmont, N.J., Elena C. of Philadelphia; five sons, Thomas, of St. Clairsville, Ohio, Joseph, of Philadelphia, Christopher, of Hatboro, Pa., John, of Wilmington, Del., and Paul, of London; a brother, John of Cherry Hill, N.J., and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: IN NOTE TO SOVIETS, BUSH URGES ACCORD ON STRATEGIC ARMS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
In a move to prepare for a superpower summit meeting this summer, President Bush sent President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a message today asking the Soviets to show more flexibility in negotiations on a treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons, Administration officials said.
Mr. Bush suggested that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, meet as soon as next week in Washington, if it would help seal agreement on a strategic arms reduction treaty, the officials said. 
 The failure to agree on such a treaty has delayed a summit meeting between the superpowers.
 
Meeting Deemed Helpful
 In his message to the Kremlin, Mr. Bush, who is spending the weekend at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., suggested that a Baker-Bessmertnykh meeting might be helpful, but only if the Soviets were ready to do business and if Mr. Bessmertnykh had full authority to deal.
A White House spokesman, Roman Popadiuk, confirmed that the United States Ambassador in Moscow, Jack F. Matlock Jr., delivered the message to Mr. Gorbachev today. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said Mr. Matlock's message was "urgent." Mr. Popadiuk said he had no details about the message. But those details were obtained from other Administration officials.
One such official said Mr. Bush's message was an attempt "to keep the Start process moving" after meetings over the last two weeks in Geneva, where the chief American negotiator, Under Secretary of State Reginald Bartholomew, made little progress in arms talks with a delegation of Soviet officials led by Aleksei Obukhov, a Deputy Foreign Minister.
 
Lack of Flexibility
 In today's message to Mr. Gorbachev, President Bush said that he had sent the American team to Geneva with a good deal of authority and flexibility to do business, but that the Soviet negotiators apparently did not have similar flexibility.
The American team included senior arms control officials from the State Department, the Defense Department and the National Security Council. By contrast, Administration officials said, the Soviet team included no high-ranking officials authorized to approve or initiate new positions.
A White House official said Mr. Bush's message was meant not as a threat but as a realistic statement of what remains to be done in arms-control talks if a summit meeting is to be held this summer, as the two Presidents have indicated thay they want.
"Both leaders would like to have a summit," said a White House official. "But I don't think either of them is so seized with the notion of a summit that they would make compromises on a Start agreement that they would not otherwise make. We want a good Start treaty, a treaty that you can defend and get approved by the Senate."
The treaty, intended to reduce United States and Soviet stockpiles of long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent, has been in negotiation on and off in Geneva for more than nine years. President Reagan announced the opening of talks in May 1982. The talks began a month later, broke off in December 1983, when the Soviet Union walked out to protest American deployment of intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe, and then resumed in March 1985.
 
Bush's Conditions
 Speaking with reporters today on the golf course at Holly Hills Country Club in Maryland, Mr. Bush offered no further details on the contents of his note to Mr. Gorbachev, other than to say, "I want to get their team moving as forward as fast as ours is."
 "I think he's very interested ," Mr. Bush said of Mr. Gorbachev. "What I want to do is be sure he energizes his bureaucracy just as we've energized ours. It's that kind of message that went to him. It's normal diplomacy."
 Mr. Bush, standing beside Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on the ninth green, seemed to indicate that he wanted to hold a summit session before the end of July. Mr. Gorbachev said on Friday that this was also his target.
 Mr. Baker told reporters that he thought it was possible to hold a summit meeting this month. "The idea is that we're getting short on time if we're going to have a summit before the end of July," he said when asked why Mr. Bush sent Mr. Matlock to see Mr. Gorbachev on Saturday.
 President Bush has made completion of the treaty a condition for his next full-scale summit meeting with Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev are expected to discuss the treaty negotiations, along with many other issues, when they meet in London for a two-hour session over lunch on July 17, after a conference of the seven leading industrial democracies. Mr. Gorbachev is expected to repeat his plea for large-scale financial or economic aid at that time.
 
Timing of Sumit Meeting
 The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said this week that "important work remains to be done" after Mr. Bartholomew's latest talks with Soviet officials in Geneva. The United States' position on timing of a summit meeting has fluctuated with the ups and downs of arms negotiations. In February, Mr. Baker said he hoped that the talks could be held in the first half of the year.
Last month senior American officials passed the word to journalists that the summit session might be held in June. They then hinted that Mr. Bush might go to Moscow in July.
Mr. Gorbachev sees a summit meeting as a chance to impress Mr. Bush with his determination to revamp the Soviet economy. Hard-liners in the Administration have seized on that opportunity to press the Soviets for concessions on the treaty limiting long-range nuclear weapons.
 
Agreement in Phases
 The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to reduce their arsenals of long-range missiles and heavy bombers in three phases over seven years, and they have also agreed on numerical limits for nuclear warheads. But four major disputes have blocked agreement on a treaty for months.
The four disputes, as described by American officials, concern procedures for inspecting missile factories; ways to distinguish new types of strategic ballistic missiles from modified versions of old ones; methods to limit the encryption of engineering data broadcast from missile test flights, and formulas to reduce the number of warheads on missiles not being dismantled.
The disputes all involve technical issues, but are important in the effort to insure that neither country cheats on the treaty, which would produce the most significant reduction of superpower nuclear arsenals since the beginning of the arms race.
The delays in concluding an arms treaty and scheduling a summit meeting may exasperate Mr. Gorbachev, but actually seem to have some domestic political benefits for Mr. Bush. In the last few weeks, Republican and Democratic members of Congress have said the Administration seemed to be rushing too fast to complete a strategic arms agreement, with the result that negotiators might make "mistakes."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Fumes Over Budget Impasse

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OCCUM, Conn., July 5

 BODY:
Behind the counter at the Occum Package Store in this small eastern Connecticut village, Dawn Raymond does the work bartenders usually do. She listens.
The last few days she has been listening to short-tempered talk from the people here, much of it about Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and his order on Tuesday to close much of Connecticut's government because of the budget fight in Hartford. "They're basically talking about the shutdown, that's all," Ms. Raymond said. "They're afraid of losing whatever they have." 
 Near the end of the first week of closed Thruway toilets, shuttered Motor Vehicle offices and barricaded public parks, the mood in Connecticut is irritable. People across the state are annoyed at its budget troubles and are beginning to let loose a new fury at the politicians whom they blame.
The growing anger did not allow much room for careful analysis, and some of those who raged loudest against the lawmakers' inability to agree on a budget did not acknowledge that legislators often cite public pressure to explain their votes. Many who disagreed vehemently with Mr. Weicker's support for an income tax said they had not supported his independent candidacy in the first place.
In interviews across the state today, some people were puzzled about why they needed a state government at all. Many said that after a lot of thought, they were sure of one thing: the trouble in Hartford will mean trouble at home, from higher taxes to layoffs of state workers, ever-shrinking state services and the ripple effect of fiscal austerity.
Governor Weicker came in for a large share of the blame because of his push for an income tax and his inability to control the legislators. "He doesn't really care about us," Ms. Raymond said as she rang up a quart of beer.
At Dom's Holiday Gulf Station on Union Street in Waterbury, Jim Norkus, who was pumping gas, said of the Governor: "It's almost like he's trying to punish everybody."
Over lunch at the Valley Diner in Derby, Angela DeGregoria, a bookkeeper, said Mr. Weicker seemed to like the power of his new office too much, and she suggested a few layoffs on the executive staff. The Governor, she said, moved too fast in proposing a broad new income tax just when people can afford it least.
"I know he's trying to fix the state finances," she said. "But he's trying to make us bite off more than we can chew. Taxpayers have enough to worry about."
In Danbury, Elaine Gerrish took a minute off from shopping with her infant grandnephew. The mention of Mr. Weicker, she said, was just enough to get her blood boiling. And she wanted to make clear that she was against the income tax proposed by the Governor, who inherited part of the Squibb pharmaceutical fortune. "It's the middle-class person that's going to suffer," she said. "Not Mr. Weicker's friends in Greenwich, that's for sure."
But Mr. Weicker, an independent who was elected without support of either major party, was was hardly the only politician who was singled out. The Governor's predecessors, other state officials and the legislators with whom Mr. Weicker is at war were also the objects of verbal abuse.
Richard Bimonte of Ridgefield called the current budget impasse the latest example of the hypocrisy in state government, saying politicians regularly ignore hard fiscal decisions until it is too late. "It's indicative of the fact that the politicians go their own way," Mr. Bimonte said as he waited for a bus in the rain. "They're always talking about fiscal responsibility, but they don't practice it themselves."
 
Lack of U.S. Aid Blamed
 On Ella T. Grasso Boulevard in New Haven, James A. Thompson, a city Parks Department supervisor, was also angry at politicians. But his targets were a little farther from home. The Federal Government, he said, can no longer afford to keep sending money off to help people in other parts of the world as the problems at home grow out of control.
Connecticut's problems, Mr. Thompson said, are beyond repair by local officials. "We just can't come down on the local politicians -- the governors and the mayors -- because it's happening in too many places," he said. "What we need at this point is Federal funds. If we don't have the money, the governors and the mayors can't balance the budget. The Federal Government is at fault."
Some of those interviewed suggested that the closing of much of the state government might prove a worthwhile experiment. One Fairfield County man, who declined to be identified, described how he broke the news of the budget impasse to his wife. "I said, 'They shut the state down.' And she said, 'What does that mean?' And I said, 'I can't think of anything.' "
But others are confronting the effects of what is already shut down as well as what may be coming. Although the state has not stopped public assistance payments, Lisa Brown, a social service worker for the town of Ansonia, said welfare recipients were overloading her office's phone lines with their worries about what might happen if the benefits do stop. And Ms. Brown said too little attention had been paid to people like her sister, a state worker who had been furloughed and was temporarily without the paycheck that helped support her family.
 
Gas Sales Drop Near Offices
 Dominic Rio, for the last 25 years the Dom of Dom's Holiday Gulf in Waterbury, said he detected a decline in gas sales since the workers in the state offices near his station were placed on unpaid leave. His station attendant, Mr. Norkus, said he had his own worries. After five and a half years of working toward a college degree he decided it was time to finish his schooling.
But when he took his financial aid application to the University of Connecticut at Storrs last week, he said, he ran into an unexpected roadblock. Because of the budget crisis, the financial aid office was closed. "I just worry about what's going to happen," he said.
Here in Occum, Dawn Raymond said, the shutdown provided a little lesson in economics. The package store, she said, relies on the state garage down the road for a good bit of its business. At the end of a long day, she said, state road workers assigned to the garage like to stop by for a package to bring home with them.
"Let's put it this way," she said: "Five days a week after they get out, they come here." At the end of this week, the road workers did not get out of work because they never went in to work, and the revenues of the Occum Package Store suffered.
 
Some Call Fears Overblown
 Some of those who have been watching the machinations over the budget from afar said politicians' warnings of dire consequences could sometimes be taken too seriously. Klaus J. Abstoss, who was born in Germany and moved to the United States five years ago, raised this possibility at the Greenwich train station while waiting for the Metro-North train to Manhattan, where he works for an international trading company.
In Europe, he observed, tax increases are imposed with much less debate.
"Maybe," he said, "it's -- What do you call it in the States? -- a power play. It's like baseball. It's like football." In the end, he said, somebody will score.
For others, the Hartford embarrassment is an unusual, if not always scintillating, glimpse of how government works. Chip Waterman, a 17-year-old who is spending the summer working at Brenner's Florsheim shoe store in the Danbury Fair Mall, is opposed to the income tax. Mostly, he said, because his father is opposed to it.
This weekend, he saw one effect of such political battles. His Boy Scout survival club had to cancel its monthly camping trip. The state park where it had been scheduled was closed.
But that did not diminish his interest in politics. From time to time, he said, he turns on the television to check on developments. But, he noted, there are not that many developments.
"I turn on the news to see if something happened," Mr. Waterman said. "Then I turn it off: It's all the politicians sitting around not doing anything."
