HEADLINE: Savoring Maine's Unspoiled Nature

BYLINE: By ROBERT ANDERSEN; ROBERT ANDERSEN lives in Kittery Point, Me.

 BODY:
JUST when you're ready to concede southern Maine to the fate of a development rampage in the likeness of Cape Cod, the sign for the Wells Reserve appears, and what was the flotsam and jetsam of a vacationland stupor becomes instead the flora and fauna of a seaside rapture. The contrast is as sharp as it is improbable. Having glazed the eye with its commercial stock in trade, Route 1 at the northern end of Wells delivers up one of the unremarked splendors of the Maine coast. Quite suddenly one is afield in a landscape pastoral and pristine, an unexpected domain of woodland and saltmarsh, fallow pasture and barrier beach.
From the high ground at the Laudholm Farm, the 1,600-acre reserve falls away to the Atlantic, revealing the lay of the land and the sweep of the coast. In the near view, on either flank, two glinting rivers curl and oxbow through the marsh to empty into the ocean, while in the distance the singular bulge of Mount Agamenticus rises as a lone sentinel. Overall the effect is to reclaim, in the mind's eye, an identity, indeed an integrity to this coast. One hikes the reserve's trails, inspects its forests, marsh and estuary ecologies, basks on its beaches and absorbs its serenity, and exults in its hard-won exemption from the flanking rampage. Somehow not even the condo clusters and beachfront subdivisions looming to the south can detract from the experience of seeing southern Maine in a salubrious light, as a natural wonder of distinctive if imperiled character. 
 A hike through the Wells Reserve and Brave Boat Harbor, to the south, is a reassurance that all has not yet been lost. The Wells Reserve is a singular environmental enclave whose variegated topography includes the watersheds of the Little River and the Webhannet River, together with the complete inventory of wetland habitats, from the evergreen forest of the upland edge to the saltmarsh, barrier-beach complex at the estuary mouth. With 1,200 of its 1,600 acres made up of marshland and a river system that is reputedly the cleanest in New England, the Wells Reserve is as pristine as one finds on the southern Maine coast. It is also a pastoral gem, preserving, in the imposing buildings and fields of the old Laudholm Farm, a reminder of a 300-year-old tradition of saltwater farming.
Acre for acre more fecund than the richest Iowa cornfield (generating up to 10 tons of plant matter per acre per year, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) the wetlands of southern Maine act as a bourse and buffer, hatchery and habitat, prodigy and progenitor. They also act, in their recent incarnation as a fragile and stressed environment, as a bellwether of a silent spring.
The wetlands, extending from Kittery Point to Cape Elizabeth, a distance of nearly 50 miles, originally comprised a vast interlacing ecosystem, a veritable aquatic empire. Formed some 12,000 years ago, they remained intact well into the 20th century. But their siting at the northern end of the Atlantic barrier beach system only insured their eventual demise, with the rise of Maine's so-called Gold Coast, an area that has been developed for tourism. The onslaught on "vacant" land has intensified in the past two decades, the consequence of a dramatic population influx into York County. In very short order what was once an empire has become a mere effigy of one, a fragmented remnant. Indeed, once the source of the fabled fisheries of the Gulf of Maine and the renowned saltwater farms of the York coast, the wetlands of southern Maine have been relegated to the fragile status of a "protected" environment. Shadowing Route 1 in a vestigial counterpoint, the marsh has become alien to the coastline that once so richly favored it.
The bulk of the Wells Reserve, a unique concatenation of local, state and Federal jurisdictions, is made up of most of two divisions of the Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge, and the plight of the refuge tells the story of wetland decimation. Responsible for preserving 3,400 acres situated in 10 divisions along 45 miles of coast, the Rachel Carson is woefully understaffed, underfunded and undersized. At the refuge headquarters three full-timers cope with managing a far-flung island chain, while a sorry budget for additional acquisition leaves the refuge stranded, 4,000 acres short of its federally mandated goal, in an area where land is much coveted by developers willing to pay top dollar. Indeed, several divisions are virtually ringed by construction. A bare bones operation since its founding in 1966, the refuge has become, for too many intents and purposes, not much more than a waterfowl logo found on the occasional boundary post. No small irony for a sanctuary dedicated to the memory of the author of "The Sea Around Us" and "Silent Spring," seminal works in the advancement of ecological awareness, the Rachel Carson Refuge bids to become a crude caricature of environmental concern.
Precisely because it encapsulates the estuarine environment in its manifold diversity, the Wells Reserve is a National Estuarine Research Reserve, one of 18 in the country and the first to be established in the Acadian biogeographical region (Calais to Cape Cod). Dedicated in 1986, the reserve exists primarily to support the research and conservation mandate of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and to educate the public about estuaries, with programs aimed at schoolchildren. But though the reserve is a natural field laboratory, to which public access is conditional (visitors are requested to register with the office), that access is not inconsiderable, given the completion, in 1989, of seven miles of nature trails, after Acadia National Park the largest trail system on the Maine coast.
From the trailhead at the Laudholm Farm, one can hike the reserve in a few hours. Trails lead to the Laudholm Beach, the estuary and marsh overlooks, and across pasture and "old fields" (first cleared in the 17th century) to the evergreen forest of the upland section. There are five main trails, each posted, none more than two miles long.
The place to begin walking, however, is at the Rachel Carson headquarters, on Route 9 half a mile from the Route 1 junction. There, an ecosystem overview is provided by a one-mile interpretive nature trail that is accessible to the handicapped. Though parking is tight (nine spaces), this trail is not to be missed, not least because it enters a beautiful hemlock and white pine forest. This forested section of the upland edge juts into the expansive marsh in headland fashion, enabling one to follow the meanderings of the Branch Brook on one side and the lazy current of the Merriland River on the other. These freshwater streams become tidal conduits that twice daily replenish a nutrient-rich "broth" from the detritus of the enveloping marsh. One learns, from the Carson Trail Guide, that the tidal zone is determining, and that the marsh grass found above the high tide mark, so-called salt hay (spartina patens), is quite different from the saltwater cordgrass (spartina alterniflora) subject to daily immersion. One also learns to distinguish salt pans, salt-laden tidal ponds, from their freshwater analogues. Salt pans are important feeding sites for the myriad waterfowl and shore birds that winter in the marsh, or flock there in the spring and fall migrations. At last count about 200 species of birds had been sighted in these marshes. (The brochure "Birds of the Rachel Carson," available at the kiosk, catalogues the sightings by frequency and season.) The ominous decline in songbird populations over the last 30 years makes the refuge all the more critical as a last bastion on the Atlantic Flyway.
From Route 1 the Laudholm Farm is about a mile, or, in terms of time, a distance of roughly a hundred years. Perched in august fashion atop a treeless knoll with a commanding view of the flatland to the south, the farm stands much as it did when the railroad magnate George Lord bought the property from the Clark family, in 1881, and transformed the Federal main house into an imposing Greek Revival mansion, with 32 rooms and a splendid wrap-around porch. Until 1952, when the Guernsey herd was sold at auction, the Laudholm Farm was a showcase operation, one of the largest and most productive saltwater farms in Maine. It was also the oldest, dating the clearing of the forest for pasture to 1643.
Indeed, for nearly 300 years the four families that held successive title to the land harvested salt hay in the upper marsh and clammed in the tidal flats of the Little River estuary. When a local environmentalist, Mort Mather, led the fight to save the farm from impending development, in the late 1970's, the forest had returned, the mansion had become a rundown old manse, and the lore of saltwater farming had been consigned to the archives as oral history. By the mid 1980's, however, an extraordinary grass-roots campaign mounted by friends of the Laudholm Farm, who had grown to 2,407 by 1986, succeeded in wresting the 245-acre property from Gold Coast designs, making it instead the cornerstone of an inviolate Wells Reserve. Today the beautifully restored Greek Revival edifice serves as a Visitor Center, and the farm has become a showcase of volunteerism. The envy of the reserve system and an object lesson in environmental insurgency, the Laudholm Farm contrasts with the beleaguered status of its next-door neighbor, the Rachel Carson.
It is not difficult to understand why there are now 2,800 members of the Laudholm Trust, the fund-raising arm of the reserve; or why firms and individuals donate thousands of hours of labor renovating and restoring; or why 51 docents and some 200 to 300 volunteers commit the flora and fauna of the reserve to memory. Clearly the farm is a labor of love, and the brief drive from the gate to the parking lot at the foot of the knoll puts this communal spirit in perspective. Acting as a grand proscenium, the sloping pasture culminates, at the crown of the knoll, in the dramatic lines of two magnificent buildings, the 120-ton barn and the Greek Revival farmhouse. Each is newly resplendent in the yellow facade and green roof of a prosperity well met, if radically redefined. The Laudholm Farm becomes the Farm-on-the-Hill, the emblem of New England proportion and harmony and the icon of Maine primitivism and heroism.
From the Maine coast to interior New England is two miles, if one reckons by the Laird-Norton trail, the longest and loveliest trail in the Reserve. Beginning on a boardwalk by the edge of the marsh, it proceeds from the lowland bog of a deciduous forest -- red maple, birch, alder -- to the upland meadow of an evergreen forest: pine, hemlock, spruce, birch, oak and maple. Along the way there are two platforms that invite closer scrutiny of the estuary and the marsh. The overview of the Little River estuary is especially mesmerizing. A broad open field acts as a buffer zone, linking lowland to upland, its thickly matted, spongy grass a natural futon from which to observe the passing cloud formations. The upland meadow, encircled by tall pines, is another world. Indeed, on Lord Road just this side of Route 1, tall trees have muted the insistent clamor of the surf line, enough to sustain the illusion that one is much farther inland. But backtrack a hundred yards and the Atlantic resumes its rhythmic noise, keeping this polyglot landscape in thrall. Indeed, what unites these disparate sections, these diverse habitats, is precisely that oceanic roar.
Of the 10 divisions in the Rachel Carson, the one that is most evocative of the woman and her writing, indeed, the one that can be said to manifest her spirit and her legacy, is Brave Boat Harbor, on Cutts Island in Kittery Point, at the very beginning of the Maine coast. Nearly 430 acres, going on 560 with the recent donation of the Raynes Property, Brave Boat Harbor is the least disturbed, most "indigenous" of all the wetlands in southern Maine, the only division, for instance, that permits the harvesting of shellfish.
Dominated by a surging tidal inlet that sluices through the expansive marsh along natural irrigation channels, Brave Boat cuts out the estuary middleman to effect a direct merger with the sea. Here the aquatic economy flourishes in simplified fashion, in the midst of a forest backdrop unimaginably distant from the mall economy scarcely four miles away. For those willing to brave mosquito swarms, black flies in attack formation, and a carpeting of poison ivy, the trek through the splendid pine, oak, maple, birch and ash forest that has sprung up on the site of the old pasture brings one to the edge of the marsh.
The quiet resolve and poetic grace of this place is remarkable, as if the pen of Rachel Carson had created it in the first place.
 
 
 
IF YOU GO

 
Wells Reserve
The sign for the Wells National Estuarine Research Reserve, (207) 646-1555, is on Route 1, about a mile and a half north of Wells Center. To avoid Route 1 take the Maine Turnpike north to exit 2, turning left after the toll gate onto Route 9. Proceed to Route 1, turn left at the stoplight and go north to the second blinker light. Take a right onto Laudholm Farm Road, and follow the sign to the gate (on Lord Road). The gate is open every day from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.
 
Visitor Center
 From July 1 to Oct. 31 the Wells Reserve Visitor Center is open from Monday to Saturday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and on Sunday from noon to 4. General and special tours are given; check the schedule for such docent-led tours as bird walk, sky watch and wildflowers. Each tour is $2.50 per person or $5 for a family. Admission is free if visitors do not take a tour. In July and August, however, there is a parking fee of $5 per car, which is waived if visitors take a tour. There is a 70-car parking limit.
 
Rachel Carson
 The Rachel Carson National Wildlife Refuge headquarters at the Upper Wells Division, (207) 646-9226, can be reached by staying on Route 9 for about a half mile past the junction with Route 1. Parking is severely limited. Built by volunteer labor in 1988, this handicapped-accessible trail constitutes the refuge's only formal public access.
 
Brave Boat
 The Refuge at Brave Boat Harbor can be reached by way of Route 103 and Chauncey Creek Road, in Kittery Point. The Raynes Property is on the left side of Seapoint Road on the way to Seapoint Beach. Just across from the tidal inlet from Cutts Island Lane is a small turnout. The trail to the left will take the hiker to the site of the old trestle, overlooking the marsh, a distance of about two miles.
 
Where to Stay
 Following are close to the Rachel Carson Refuge::
Gundalow Inn, 6 Water Street, Kittery, Me. 03904; (207) 439-4040). Six rooms, each with bath, in faithfully restored 1889 Victorian house. The inn has a no-smoking policy. Situated just the other side of Memorial Bridge from Portsmouth, N.H. (local Route 1), the Gundalow is five miles from Brave Boat Harbor. Rates to mid-October are $85 single, $95 double, with full breakfast.
Arundel Meadows Inn, Route 1, north of Kennebunk (Post Office Box 1129, Kennebunk, Me. 04043) ; (207) 985-3770. Five rooms and two suites, each with private bath, in 165-year-old farmhouse, five miles north of Wells Reserve. Rates are from $65 to $110 a night with full breakfast and afternoon tea.
 
Where to Eat
 Following can be recommended:
Cape Neddick Inn, Route 1, Cape Neddick, Me. 03902; (207) 363-2899. Halfway between Kittery and Wells on Route 1, the building is hung with the works of local artists and works of scuplture are displayed in the house and grounds. Open every day from 6 P.M. Specialties often include roast duckling with sweet-and-sour sauce $17; lobster macadamia tarte $23, and hazelnut chicken $17. Dinner for two $60 to $75 with wine.
Merriland Farm, Coles Hill Road, Wells, Me. 04090; (207) 646-5040). A mile from Route 1 near the Laudholm Farm Road turnoff, this pleasant outdoor cafe serves raspberry nutbread ($2.25), blueberry bread ($2.25), pies ($2.25 a slice; with fresh cream $2.75), crepes ($3.25), coffee and tea (both 65 cents).

HEADLINE: State Is Trying to Protect Its Endangered Species

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
MARGARET ARDWIN was turning over rocks in a small stream that feeds a reservoir outside Hartford, when she spotted a salamander. Ms. Ardwin, a botanist, said she might have found a spring salamander, considered a threatened species in Connecticut, and she went scrambling over the moss-covered, water-slick rocks for a better look.
A few days earlier, another member of her team, Adam Fry, had discovered a previously unknown site for the grasshopper sparrow, considered endangered in the state. To find a spring salamander would have been another conservationist's coup. 
 It was only a dusky salamander, though, which is not the focus of any special attention. Ms. Ardwin seemed cheerful anyway.
"Remember doing this as a kid?" she asked over her shoulder as she halfheartedly turned over a few more rocks. "I guess we never got over it."
 
One Endangered Mammal
 Many biologists like Ms. Ardwin and Mr. Fry are excited about finding new locations for rare species in the state, because of the promised protection of some new regulations. On Wednesday evening the State Department of Environmental Protection will conduct a hearing in Hartford on its draft regulations to implement a law passed three years ago to protect species considered endangered, threatened or of special concern.
The department is not handing out these designations lightly. Of 77 mammalian species in the state, only one is officially endangered -- the least shrew. No mammals are listed as threatened, but 12 are considered of special concern.
In all, 85 of 469 vertebrates were listed, along with 100 among an unknown number of invertebrates and 313 of the state's 1,644 plant species.
Each listing includes both the scientific and common name, so people can tell, for instance, that Alasmidonta heterodon, proposed for the endangered list, is really the dwarf wedge mussel.
Some developers say the law is making them the latest endangered species.
"There is a concern that it will be another level of regulation, which would add to the development cost of housing in the state," said Michael G. Lauzier, director of governmental affairs for the Connecticut Home Builders Association. "And right now, with the economy the way it is, we can't afford to do that."
He said his group was considering hiring an expert to examine the list for accuracy. "It's very hard to determine whether every listing is legitimate," Mr. Lauzier said.
 
Unanimous Decisions
 Dr. Kent E. Holsinger, a botanist in the department of ecology and evolutionary biology at the University of Connecticut and a member of the committee that helped draft the list of rare plants, said only species that are clearly rare made the preliminary list.
"In most cases, there wasn't even a lot of discussion," Dr. Holsinger said. "There were no cases where there was even strongly divergent opinion. And in all cases, even where some members had some questions initially, the decisions were reached unanimously."
Dr. Holsinger said that the draft regulations do not go far enough. "As they are written, they only really affect state-owned land," he said. "There's relatively little state-owned land in Connecticut, so in that respect it will have little impact in terms of legal protection.
"The law's main impact will be largely raising the consciousness of the public that there are rare species in the state."
Leslie J. Mehrhoff of the Department of Environmental Protection's natural diversity database staff, said private developers would be almost unaffected by the law. But some of its provisions would affect everyone, he added.
The regulations would make it illegal to take endangered or threatened species from state land or to collect them for sale or export from any land in the state, a provision that Mr. Mehrhoff said could cause some problems.
 
Refinements Ahead
 A person trying to drive a truckload of balsam fir, considered endangered, through Connecticut, could be liable for arrest. So could an entomologist who collects a Persius dusky wing butterfly.
"Right now, as the law reads, you can't collect anything that is threatened or endangered," Mr. Mehrhoff said. "Obviously, it is going to have to be refined."
But Mr. Mehrhoff was one of the earliest and most ardent supporters of the legislation. He recalled once taking a group on a botanical tour, pointing out species like the rare whorled pogonia, an orchid native to Connecticut. A few days later he returned to the site and found a hole where the pogonia had been dug up for some collector's plant window.
Enforcing the law will be difficult, since the enabling legislation provided no staff.
"More conservation officers are needed just to enforce existing regulatory provisions, and this will be more on top of that," said George Brys of the department's wildlife bureau.
 
Slimy Salamander Found
 Aiding the state are private conservation organizations that report sightings of rare species to add to the natural diversity listing, including the Nature Conservancy, the most aggressive of the groups.
Two years ago, soon after the legislature enacted the law, the Conservancy put together a team that surveyed Fairfield County, where it found 30 new locations of rare species like the slimy salamander and the northern metalmark butterfly.
Last year the team surveyed the lower Connecticut River Valley, and this year it is surveying the upper river, said the executive director of the Conservancy, Leslie N. Corey Jr.
The surveying costs about $75,000 a year, he said, and while the group would like to do the entire state, it must finance those studies privately. Connecticut is the only state where the Conservancy has undertaken the job without state assistance.
"The survey is the tool we use in applied science to determine which areas should be protected," Mr. Corey said. "And now is a good time to be trying to protect some of these areas, while the economy is slow, and land prices are down, and there is very little development."
Mr. Corey said, however, that in a time of tight budgets, it is difficult to justify spending on surveys or conservation.
 
'Richness Indicators'
 "If you've got something that's coming out of a pipe, people agree you have to do something about it," he said. "But when you're talking about the erosion of our ecological diversity, that's not something you can see. Social needs are so overwhelming, they inundate the system. But the environment is not a frill."
In a forest within a few miles of downtown Hartford one day recently, a Conservancy team leader, Juliana Barrett, explained that the group looks for "richness indicators," things like maidenhair fern and blue cohosh, that tell an observer whether the soils are of a type where rare plants would live.
With her canvas knapsack overflowing with field guides, notebooks, maps and pencils, and with field glasses strapped around her neck, Ms. Barrett began walking along a well-blazed trail, keeping a running map of the vegetation types she saw along the side. Then she struck away from the trail, hiking up a steep, rocky hill, where she found patches of hepatica, a small woodland flowering plant, and rattlesnake plantain, an orchid found in dry oak woods.
"You have to get off the trail, away from where everything has been trampled," Ms. Barrett said. "But even so, it's a real needle-in-the-haystack kind of thing.
"Just because we don't find something doesn't mean it isn't there. We have to cover a lot of ground very quickly, so we're bound to miss some things."
After scrambling along the flood plains of the Connecticut River once recent hot afternoon, wading through stinging nettles and playing pincushion to hordes of mosquitoes, the team from the Nature Conservancy found a green dragon.
That plant, related to the jack-in-the-pulpit, was the best find of the day, even though it is designated only of special concern, not even rare enough to warrant threatened, or endangered status.
Often, the group will not know whether a truly rare species has been found until the sample has been collected, mounted and examined under a microscope back in the office.
"It can be anticlimactic," said Ms. Ardwin. "There are very few of those exciting moments when you're sure you've found something. It's sort of a gradual realization as the evidence accumulates."
As the group works its way up the Connecticut River, its members are keeping careful maps that will be copied for the state's natural diversity database. And with the legal protection of the new regulations, and the growing public awareness of the need to preserve ecological diversity, the biologists of the Conservancy and other organizations said they were hoping those species will get a second chance.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: George E. Hill;
Municipalities Face Some Tough Times

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
FOR the past 25 years, George E. Hill has been a professor in the Institute of Public Service at the University of Connecticut, which provides training for municipal officials and does research on issues of interest to municipalities. Mr. Hill is also the Mayor of Mansfield, president-elect of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities and a member of the State Municipal Finance Advisory Committee, which is monitoring the financial problems of Waterbury, Stratford and New Haven.
Mr. Hill has been involved in municipal government issues since the mid-1960's, when he served as budget director in Hartford. 
 In an interview at his office at the Institute of Public Service in Storrs, Mr. Hill answered questions about the problems facing Connecticut municipalities. Here are some excerpts from the conversation.
Q. How has the Municipal Finance Advisory Committee's work evolved over the years?
A. It started in 1977 with the virtual bankruptcy of New York City, Cleveland and Yonkers. And there were some problems with the City of Waterbury. The legislature thought it would create a purely advisory board to advise the Governor and the Secretary of the Office of Policy and Management how to proceed when municipalities did get into fiscal distress.
In all of the years I've served on it, close to 10 years, the main area of interest was reviewing the audit reports of municipalities. Once in a while we'd send out a letter saying, "Your audit needs to be improved in these areas," etc., etc. We never got into the issues we're facing today.
But the 1980's were a period of affluence for tax-receiving organizations. There was the expansion of the sales tax for the state and increases in grand lists on the local level. So we were able to do tremendous program improvements. The problem is perhaps some of those improvements shouldn't have been made, because when the bottom fell out of the economy, the state government told towns and cities it couldn't fulfill its statutory obligations and it was cutting back grants.
At the same time people weren't building, which meant grand lists weren't increasing, which meant municipalities had to raise taxes or cut services, and most towns had to do a combination of both.
For the first time in my memory we've actually been charged by the Secretary to review the financial condition of three cities. Bridgeport is being reviewed under a special agency. And there are several other communities heading towards a review by the Municipal Finance Advisory Commission.
Q. What are some of the signs you look for in deciding which towns to monitor?
 A. They're having a reduced property tax collection rate; no growth in the grand list; high debt per capita, which means they're bonding too much; low grand list per capita, which means the resources aren't there to pay for the services they want to provide. We look at whether they've met their budget goals for expenditures and revenues for the past two years -- a lot of towns have not. All of those indicators show next year may be even a busier year for the municipal advisory board.
Q. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. has proposed a new panel that would have significantly more power over communities in fiscal distress. Do you think that's necessary?
 A. I have some problems with the bill. I thought it could be improved by having a majority of the membership made up of municipal officials, so that when a mayor gets in fiscal distress and comes to the board, his peers are saying: "Hey, you've got problems. How are you going to work it out?" It's a much easier process to have someone who's been in your shoes advising you on how to proceed. The Governor's board, the majority would be state officials, which I think would be a terrible mistake.
It also has provisions for, once a town is cited as being fiscally distressed, it gives the board the power to negate collective bargaining agreements. I don't see it passing the legislature in that form. And there should be some sort of administrative appeals process. As it is now it leaves too much discretion in the hands of state officials, who have not exactly done a wonderful job on the finances of the State of Connecticut.
 Q. How would the commission handle it if one of the member's towns got into fiscal distress?
 A. Obviously, they would be prevented from participating in any board action. Several members of the board have professional relationships with some of these cities that are in fiscal distress and have excluded themselves. We make sure there is no conflict of interest.
 Q. Why has Hartford, which has the same sort of problems as Bridgeport and New Haven, so far escaped the commission's scrutiny?
 A. Most people point to Hartford as having a very efficient form of government; they've had a series of very professional city managers, and their charter is a very strict charter. It doesn't allow them to manipulate the property tax collection rate projections, which has happened in other cities. Some have had very high estimates of collection rates to balance their budgets.
Hartford's charter requires it to use an average of the last three years, which prevents the council from saying, "Well, we're collecting 88 percent of taxes, let's predict 94, so we can balance the budget," which some municipalities have done. They have never run a deficit in Hartford, which shows you strong management, if given the political support, even in a New Haven or Waterbury, can make it, but the decisions are very difficult ones.
It means saying to the unions, "We're having givebacks or layoffs." It means saying to the Board of Education, as they did in Hartford: "You know that 3 or 4 million dollars you wanted? You're not getting it."
 Q. How are the towns that are being monitored by the commission responding?
 A. Stratford seems to have a plan to bring it out of trouble. I have talked with the Mayors of Waterbury and New Haven, and they're making decisions that you would normally never see a mayor make in an election year. You're going to be on the ballot in November, and you're laying off firemen and policemen and teachers and cutting recreation programs?
They are making decisions I haven't seen since the 1977-78 recession. This is the worst I have ever seen municipalities, financially.
 Q. Waterbury has come up with an interesting plan to reduce its deficit. What's been the reaction?
 A. The board is examining it. It's called a leaseback, where they're leasing their delinquent taxes to a financial institution who will loan them $10 million, then give them back to the city, which will collect the taxes and pay off, over a five-year period, the $10 million. Very creative. State law prohibits bonding for debt for municipalities. This new financial device, of leasing their accounts receivables, gets around that prohibition because it's under the general powers clause of the statutes, which allows cities the power to lease, and they've got tentative approval from a highly respected bond counsel. But this may be an area the General Assembly would like to look at.
 Q. If they are successful, will other towns try the same thing?
 A. Every town is going to be in serious financial condition if the economy doesn't turn around, not just the Waterburys and New Havens. What Waterbury is banking on is that the economy will turn around. Right now they've got a mass of delinquent accounts, and they're foreclosing on properties, but they can't find a buyer, there is no market for foreclosed properties in Waterbury, or anywhere in this economy.
If they sell them now, they may get 10 cents on the dollar, and then other taxpayers are going to go in an ask for a reduction in their assessment, based on those sale prices, so the effect would snowball.
They're banking that the economy will regenerate, start producing more jobs, higher property-tax collection rates, and let them gradually sell off their liened properties, and receive fire-sale prices. I think it's not an unfair assumption.
 Q. As a mayor, how would you feel about the commission, or an even stronger panel, looking over your shoulder?
 A. As a mayor, I would try to make sure we never get to that point. I would insist on being in control of my own financial destiny. But the problems of Mansfield are so insignificant compared to the Hartfords and Waterburys and Bridgeports. The poverty and the crime and the other problems are beyond the control of any municipal officials. We in small towns are not faced with those tremendous societal ills. We can get by tough times, without facing deficits, by making a few tough decisions. In large cities, without massive state or Federal intervention, the condition is not going to change unless the economy turns around very quickly.
 Q. How are Connecticut towns faring compared with others in the Northeast?
 A. I'll give credit to Governor Weicker and the General Assembly, they're not dismantling state and local government the way they are in Massachusetts under the Democratic party. I have to give Governor Weicker and the legislature accolades.
They may not be giving us all we think we need in grants, but they're not drastically dismantling a fine state-local cooperative effort as they are in Massachusetts.
In New Hampshire they're cutting $40 million in state grants to towns and cities. Massachusetts has a $300 million reduction.
In Connecticut we're basically maintaining the status quo. All in all, we're pretty fortunate.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor George E. Hill of Mansfield, who is the president-elect of the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities.
(Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Focus: Proposition 13;
California's 'Tax Revolt' Faces Challenge

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
A CASE challenging Proposition 13, California's "tax revolt" law, is wending its way toward the U.S. Supreme Court. If the court agrees to hear the case, its decision is likely to affect every homeowner in California.
At issue is the law's way of taxing property. Its critics say it lets homeowners of long standing pay far less in property tax than newcomers. Stephanie Nordlinger, the Los Angeles lawyer who is asking the High Court to hear her case, says the law creates enormous disparities in property taxes. 
 Ms. Nordlinger bought a two-bedroom tract house in suburban Baldwin Hills in 1988 for $170,000. Under Proposition 13, which limits property taxes to 1 percent of the purchase price plus negligible annual increases, she pays about $1,700 a year in property taxes.
But some of her neighbors, who live in identical houses that they bought years before, pay a fixed tax of little more than $300, reflecting the lower prices then.
"I'm paying the same tax as the owner of a $2 million house in Malibu," an exclusive beachfront area, she said.
Her situation is common among home buyers. A survey of 10,000 recent property buyers in Los Angeles County shows that the new homeowners commonly pay 5 to 17 times the property tax of their neighbors, according to a study commissioned by Ms. Nordlinger's lawyers, Hall & Phillips of Los Angeles. The study was prepared by an economist, David Gold.
Ms. Nordlinger acknowledges that she has "always been against Prop 13." She voted against the measure in 1978, and, as a Los Angeles County public defender in the late 70's, participated in an earlier, unsuccessful suit brought by county employees denied promotions and raises because of budget cuts prompted by Proposition 13.
Yet Ms. Nordlinger said she did not set out to make a test case of Proposition 13 until she discovered the difference between her tax payments and those of her neighbors while perusing public records.
After the Center for Law in the Public Interest, a local nonprofit advocacy group, agreed to pay the legal fees for the challenge, Ms. Nordlinger sued Los Angeles County and County Supervisor Kenneth Kahn, seeking declaratory relief under the equal-protection clause.
Her case lost in both Superior Court here and on appeal; in both cases, judges cited a 1978 decision by the State Supreme Court upholding Proposition 13. In June, Ms. Nordlinger asked the United States Supreme Court to hear the case, since the justices had agreed to hear R. H. Macy & Company's challenge to the same law this spring. Macy's later withdrew the suit, saying other California taxpayers could suffer ill effects if the law were overturned.
Before Proposition 13, property taxes set county by county were 2 to 3 percent of assessed value, high by California standards, and varied with location. Those high rates posed hardships for the two most vulnerable classes of homeowners -- first-time buyers and retirees on fixed incomes, said Mack Powell, a Sacramento broker and president of the state's Association of Realtors.
"Taxes were becoming outrageous," Mr. Powell said. " Some homeowners were not able to hold onto their properties."
Antitax and antigovernment sentiments prevailed in 1978, when Howard Jarvis, who has since died, rallied California voters with his slogan, "I'm mad as hell." The proposition passed with the approval of 66 percent of the electorate.
The law "gave people security in keeping their property, and continues to give them certainty on their tax payments," said Joel Fox, president of Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, a local nonprofit advocacy group.
AMENDMENTS to Proposition 13 have enlarged the powers -- and the loopholes -- available to taxpayers. Under one amendment, tax rates can be passed on from generation to generation by allowing parents to transfer their tax rates to their children along with property.
"We are creating this feudal class of people who will go into the next century not paying any higher taxes, simply because they were lucky enough to own property at the right time," said Ms. Nordlinger.
The biggest beneficiaries have been homeowners who bought their houses in 1978, when tax levels were rolled back to 1975 levels. Carlyle Hall, the lawyer who represents Ms. Nordlinger, called this the "welcome stranger" provision of Proposition 13.
"The entire tax increase is being carried on the backs of the newcomers," he said. "Everybody who was fortunate enough to own a house in 1975 pays very little more than they did in that base year."
Mr. Fox of the Jarvis group defends the wide tax differentials. "When newcomers come in, they enjoy the schools and infrastructure paid for by the taxes of those who have been there for a long time," he said.
Proposition 13's effect on consumers is difficult to gauge. Some people say they are reluctant to sell their current home and buy a new one, fearing a heavier tax burden, said Richard Peiser, director of the Lusk Center of Real Estate Development at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles.
Empty-nesters, he said, are "holding onto their houses when their kids have moved, and are 'consuming' more housing than they need, because if they move their costs will go up, even if they go to smaller housing."
Yet Proposition 13 has not led to the same grassroots protest as did high taxes in the 70's. The promise of fixed tax rates has lulled many taxpayers "into accepting an inequitable tax structure," said the Report of the Senate Commision of Property Tax Equity and Revenue to the California State Senate, which appeared in June.
The study says the new property owner "may wince at learning that her neighbor in an identical house pays significantly less in property taxes," yet may acquiesce to the tax rate when she realizes that she will be "paying relatively less taxes as time passes."
Many California home buyers, indeed, seem unaware that they are paying a disproportionate amount of property tax. Mr. Powell said he finds it "amazing" that home buyers rarely quiz him on taxes when viewing homes for sale. Ira Norris, an Orange County home builder who specializes in the first-time market, said buyers are primarily concerned about price, not taxes. Instead, he said, when he talks to buyers, "they ask only, 'Is this the place I want to live? Does my builder have a good reputation? How much do I have to put down, and how much do I have to pay a month?' "
Home sales agents are nervous about what may happen to the home market if the court or the legislature changes Proposition 13. If taxes are to be based on market value rather than original purchase price, "older people on fixed income will be forced to move out of their homes," said Barbara Baerg, a sales associate with First National Realty-Gribin Von Dyl of Sherman Oaks. Buyers, on the other hand, may feel some anxiety about their inability to predict the future costs of homeownership.
If the Supreme Court strikes down Proposition 13, the Senate Commission offers several possible remedies to be enacted by the California legislature.
ONE is to slowly raise property values to market level while protecting against overall tax increases by lowering local tax rates, county by county. To shield low-income homeowners from a crushing tax burden, the study would raise the property tax exemption to $50,000 from the current $7,000. Owners of income property would pay a higher rate than homeowners, to redress the current tilt on the tax rolls toward new homeowners. And children would no longer be allowed to inherit tax rates along with property.
Mr. Powell of the realtors' group said he had no opinion on the choice of remedy but wants to preserve at least the predictability of Proposition 13. Ms. Nordlinger, however, rates "fairness" above predictability.
"People ask for certainty, but life is uncertain," she said. "The most important issue is equitable taxation."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An arcticle on July 7 about a suit challenging Proposition 13 in California misidentified a defendant and his office, and omitted the identity of a second defendant. A recent letter from the plaintiff, Stephanie Nordlinger, notes that the defendants are Kenneth E. Hahn, the Los Angeles County Tax Assessor (not Supervisor), and the county itself.

PERSON: NORDLINGER, STEPHANIE; NEWMAN, MORRIS

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
California's Tax 'Revolt' Faces Challenge

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
A case challenging Proposition 13, California's "tax revolt" law, is wending its way toward the U.S. Supreme Court. If the court agrees to hear the case, its decision is likely to affect every homeowner in California.
 At issue is the law's way of taxing property. Its critics say it lets homeowners of long standing pay far less in property tax than newcomers. Stephanie Nordlinger, the Los Angeles lawyer who is asking the High Court to hear her case, says the law creates enormous disparities in property taxes. 
Ms. Nordlinger bought a two-bedroom tract house in suburban Baldwin Hills in 1988 for $170,000. But some of her neighbors, who live in identical houses that they bought years before, pay a fixed tax of little more than $300, reflecting the lower prices then.
 "I'm paying the same tax as the owner of a $2 million house in Malibu," an exclusive beachfront area, she said.
 Her situation is common among home buyers. A survey of 10,000 recent property buyers in Los Angeles County shows that the new homeowners commonly pay 5 to 17 times the property tax of their neighbors, according to a study commissioned by Ms. Nordlinger's lawyers, Hall
Phillips of Los Angeles. It was prepared by an economist, David Gold.
 Ms. Nordlinger acknowledges that she has "always been against Prop 13." She voted against the measure in 1978, and, as a Los Angeles County public defender in the late 70's, participated in an earlier, unsuccessful suit brought by county employees denied promotions and raises because of budget cuts prompted by Proposition 13.
 Yet Ms. Nordlinger said she did not set out to make a test case of Proposition 13 until she discovered the difference between her tax payments and those of her neighbors while perusing public records.  Her case lost in both Superior Court here and on appeal; in both cases, judges cited a 1978 decision by the State Supreme Court upholding Proposition 13. In June, Ms. Nordlinger asked the United States Supreme Court to hear the case, since the justices had agreed to hear R. H. Macy
Company's challenge to the same law this spring. Macy's later withdrew the suit, saying other California taxpayers could suffer ill effects if the law were overturned.
 Before Proposition 13, property taxes set county by county were 2 to 3 percent of assessed value, high by California standards, and varied with location. Those high rates posed hardships for the two most vulnerable classes of homeowners -- first-time buyers and retirees on fixed incomes, said Mack Powell, a Sacramento broker and president of the state's Association of Realtors.
 "Taxes were becoming outrageous," Mr. Powell said. " Some homeowners were not able to hold onto their properties."
 Antitax and antigovernment sentiments prevailed in 1978, when Howard Jarvis, who has since died, rallied California voters with his slogan, "I'm mad as hell." The proposition passed with the approval of 66 percent of the electorate.
 The law "gave people security in keeping their property, and continues to give them certainty on their tax payments," said Joel Fox, president of Howard Jarvis Taxpayers Association, a local nonprofit advocacy group.
 Amendments to Proposition 13 have enlarged the powers -- and the loopholes --available to taxpayers. Under one amendment, tax rates can be passed on from generation to generation by allowing parents to transfer their tax rates to their children along with property.
 "We are creating this feudal class of people who will go into the next century not paying any higher taxes, simply because they were lucky enough to own property at the right time," said Ms. Nordlinger.
 The biggest beneficiaries have been homeowners who bought their houses in 1978, when tax levels were rolled back to 1975 levels. Carlyle Hall, the lawyer who represents Ms. Nordlinger, called this the "welcome stranger" provision of Proposition 13.
 "The entire tax increase is being carried on the backs of the newcomers," he said. "Everybody who was fortunate enough to own a house in 1975 pays very little more than they did in that base year."
 Mr. Fox of the Jarvis group defends the wide tax differentials. "When newcomers come in, they enjoy the schools and infrastructure paid for by the taxes of those who have been there for a long time," he said.
 Proposition 13's effect on consumers is difficult to gauge. Some people say they are reluctant to sell their current home and buy a new one, fearing a heavier tax burden, said Richard Peiser, director of the Lusk Center of Real Estate Development at the University of Southern California in Los Angeles.
 Empty-nesters, he said, are "holding onto their houses when their kids have moved, and are 'consuming' more housing than they need, because if they move their costs will go up, even if they go to smaller housing."
 Yet Proposition 13 has not led to the same grassroots protest as did high taxes in the 70's. The promise of fixed tax rates has lulled many taxpayers "into accepting an inequitable tax structure," said the Report of the Senate Commision of Property Tax Equity and Revenue to the California State Senate, which appeared in June.
 The study says the new property owner "may wince at learning that her neighbor in an identical house pays significantly less in property taxes," yet may acquiesce to the tax rate when she realizes that she will be "paying relatively less taxes as time passes."
 Many California home buyers, indeed, seem unaware that they are paying a disproportionate amount of property tax. Mr. Powell said he finds it "amazing" that home buyers rarely quiz him on taxes when viewing homes for sale. Ira Norris, an Orange County home builder who specializes in the first-time market, said buyers are primarily concerned about price, not taxes. Instead, he said, when he talks to buyers, "they ask only, 'Is this the place I want to live? Does my builder have a good reputation? How much do I have to put down, and how much do I have to pay a month?' "
 Home sales agents are nervous about what may happen to the home market if the court or the legislature changes Proposition 13. If taxes are to be based on market value rather than original purchase price, "older people on fixed income will be forced to move out of their homes," said Barbara Baerg, a sales associate with First National Realty-Gribin Von Dyl of Sherman Oaks. Buyers, on the other hand, may feel some anxiety about their inability to predict the future costs of homeownership.
 If the Supreme Court strikes down Proposition 13, the Senate Commission offers several possible remedies to be enacted by the California legislature.
 One is to slowly raise property values to market level while protecting against overall tax increases by lowering local tax rates, county by county. To shield low-income homeowners from a crushing tax burden, the study would raise the property tax exemption to $50,000 from the current $7,000. Owners of income property would pay a higher rate than homeowners, to redress the current tilt on the tax rolls toward new homeowners. And children would no longer be allowed to inherit tax rates along with property.
 Mr. Powell of the realtors' group said he had no opinion on the choice of remedy but wants to preserve at least the predictability of Proposition 13. Ms. Nordlinger, however, rates "fairness" above predictability.
 "People ask for certainty, but life is uncertain," she said. "The most important issue is equitable taxation."

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1991

HEADLINE: Prosperity Born of Pain

BYLINE: By Jonathan Kandell; Jonathan Kandell, author most recently of "La Capital: The Biography of Mexico City," writes frequently about Latin America.

 BODY:
It's a few days before the traditional summer break, and just about every Chilean with a savings account is packing for a long holiday on the Pacific beaches. Hyperinflation and recession, self-doubt and pessimism are worries for the rest of Latin America. In Chile, opinion polls register confidence, optimism, even a touch of smugness.
An economic miracle has been under way here for some time. In five of the last six years, the gross national product surged by at least 5 percent, and will probably climb faster in 1991. There is no debt crisis. Foreign investment is pouring in at an annual rate of $1 billion, and middle-class income is rising. Salaries have lagged among the poor, but unemployment rates are near historic lows. 
 And while the miracle has been tarnished by its association with Gen. Augusto Pinochet's harsh dictatorship, the country's image has soared over the last year, thanks to a new, elected president, Patricio Aylwin. With democratic stability and the promise of prosperity, Chile has become a model for the third world. "The admiration would have come sooner if the country had not been governed by such a repressive dictatorship," says Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard professor who advises governments in Latin America and Eastern Europe that are eager to carry out Chilean-type economic policies.
True, as vacations approached there was some unfinished business with General Pinochet, who has insisted on remaining army commander in chief until 1998. With the National Commission for Truth and Reconciliation -- a nonpartisan group appointed by President Aylwin to investigate all the killings carried out under the general's 17-year reign -- poised to release its findings, even Pinochet's admirers were hoping he would make a quick and quiet exit.
The general, however, wasn't following the script. Early on a Wednesday evening before the great summer exodus, he placed his troops in a state of alert. Panicky rumors of a coup in progress swept Santiago during the 17-hour military exercise. After the alert ended, General Pinochet agreed to meet with an enraged President Aylwin. But his point had been made: If Chileans want to enjoy the capitalist virtues of his regime, then they better accept and forgive its human rights sins.
Those sins were numerous, according to the National Commission for Truth and Reconciliation. Its report, since released, cites the dictatorship's victims by name, and describes the ghastly circumstances of their deaths. In all, more than 2,000 executions and disappearances are attributed to the state's security forces.
The fortunate among the doomed were simply executed by firing squads. The unlucky were beaten, mutilated, half-drowned or electrocuted before their bodies were ripped by bullets. Most of the victims were urban workers and peasants, but intellectuals, small-business men and politicians also perished. Leftists predominated, though many of the dead had no known political affiliation.
The randomness of the killings was especially evident in the early days of the Pinochet regime:
 In Santiago, on Sept. 23, 1973, army troops detained three young workers at the Sumar textile factory. Their bullet-riddled corpses were later found on a highway.
 In Paine, an agricultural community south of Santiago, 22 peasants ranging in age from 20 to 54, were taken away by police officers and army troops on Oct. 16, 1973, never to be seen again.
 In San Bernardo, on the outskirts of Santiago, three factory workers -- brothers still in their teens -- were seized at home by soldiers on Oct. 21, 1973, driven to an isolated hillside and placed before a firing squad. Miraculously, one of the brothers survived and was carried by sympathetic civilians to a hospital, where he recounted the tragedy to his doctors. The next day, police kidnapped him from his bed. He became a desaparecido -- a disappeared one.
President Aylwin's promise of financial reparations for the victims' families enjoys broad public support. Yet, surprisingly to many outsiders, there is little pressure for bringing the torturers and assassins to justice. Chileans seem reconciled to the reality that the most brutal dictatorship in their history presided over the creation of the soundest economy in Latin America.
None of the luster of Chile's economic miracle seems to have improved General Pinochet's wretched image abroad; virtually no foreign government will receive him officially. Nevertheless, to most Chileans his regime's atrocities are a thing of the past. Almost nobody wants to risk derailing economic growth and democratic government by punishing a few hundred culprits. The significant exceptions are three small left-wing terrorist factions that have assassinated several police officers, an ex-military physician, and most recently, a prominent right-wing senator, Jaime Guzman. The groups say they are seeking to avenge General Pinochet's victims.
 To an overwhelming degree, however, pragmatism now rules in Chile. "The truth is important in order to publicly vindicate the victims and fill a black hole in our history," says Jose Zalaquett, a lawyer who wrote much of the report of the Commission for Truth and Reconciliation. "But before the country decides on punishment, it has to ask whether or not it can afford to do so. Don't forget, Pinochet still heads the army, and he keeps saying, 'None of my men will be touched.' "
The general seized power in a 1973 coup because under the democratically elected, Marxist Government of Salvador Allende the country was sliding into chaos. Agrarian reform devastated agriculture. Factories were occupied by workers. Inflation reached three, then four digits. Demonstrations rocked Santiago almost daily in protest over shortages of food and other essentials. Washington did its utmost to cut off Chile's access to foreign credits and markets, and the Central Intelligence Agency helped finance major Allende opponents. Long a middle-level Latin American country -- with living standards somewhere between Argentina and Mexico -- Chile was descending into the poverty of Peru and Bolivia.
So the coup was no surprise. Neither was General Pinochet's promise "to extirpate the Marxist cancer," nor the savage way he went about it. But few people took seriously his vows to dismantle the state's dominant role in the economy, unloose private enterprise and "change the mentality" of Chileans. Those were goals that would require a generation of iron-fisted rule, both skeptical supporters and opponents said. The general, it seems, took heed and stayed in the presidential palace for almost a generation.
Even today, it's impossible to speak of Pinochet in the past tense. His military firepower remains intact. The Supreme Court is packed with his appointees. So is the Central Bank, whose directors share his obsession with fiscal prudence.
Most of all, it is the economy that bears his stamp. Long before the rest of Latin America rediscovered Adam Smith, Chile sold off its state companies, removed protectionist barriers to foreign goods and investment and encouraged businessmen to think of their market as the world rather than just the 13 million consumers living within the country's borders. While no better endowed than its neighbors, Chile soon surpassed them in the exploitation of its natural resources.
"We may not like the Government that came before us," says Finance Minister Alejandro Foxley. "But they did many things right. We have inherited an economy that is an asset." And in contrast to other third world countries, where development is concentrated in a few major cities, the Chilean boom has spread the entire 3,000-mile length of this sliver of a nation.
In the northern desert, farmers are using Israeli drip-irrigation techniques to produce bumper harvests of grapes that are sold in North America and Europe during the winter. High in the Andes, a consortium of Australian, British and Japanese investors has opened the world's largest privately owned copper mine. Renewable pine forests in southern Chile are exporting almost $1 billion annually in lumber, wood chips and pulp. Still further south, rain-drenched archipelagos and fjords have hatched a salmon industry with revenues that rival those of traditional fishmongers like Ireland and Scotland. Tourism also has become a billion-dollar business, as hordes of visitors discover the beaches, ski slopes, Swiss-style lakes and primeval forests of a country that embraces every ecosphere except a tropical zone.
Now that democracy reigns in Santiago again, officials from Buenos Aires and Mexico City, Warsaw and Bucharest, arrive almost monthly for cram courses on privatizing state industries and picking export winners. Eventually, these pilgrims make their way to the doorstep of Hernan Buchi, the 42-year-old former Finance Minister of the Pinochet Government.
Buchi lost the 1989 presidential election to Aylwin by a large margin, but he continues to be recognized as the genius behind Chile's economic miracle. A shy, ascetic man, Buchi is an unlikely icon for the glitzy new entrepreneurial class his policies have spawned. ("I'd feel more comfortable if he played polo and owned a BMW," says a young investment banker who admires him.)
Buchi's advice to his foreign suitors is blunt and discomforting. Before economic reforms can be undertaken, he tells them, their countries must pass through the sort of chaos Chile experienced in the Allende period. "Only after hitting bottom will the general population accept major transformations," he says. And don't look to the established business community for support, he adds. "When we started opening up our economy to the world, some of our strongest opposition came from businessmen."
Their resistance was understandable. Private enterprise in Latin America has always expected the state to provide a risk-free environment: ample and cheap credit lines, protection from imports and the near absence of domestic rivals. When these guarantees were suddenly removed by General Pinochet, a lot of elite firms went belly up. In their place rose a new class of entrepreneurs who were contemptuous of the old business ways.
These new Chilean businessmen like to cite CAP, a major steel producer, as an example of the past follies of private enterprise. CAP was created after World War II when the substitution of foreign imports by domestic manufactures became the rage in Latin America. From the day its ovens were first fired up, the company was a white elephant. Designed to manufacture every type of steel the country needed, CAP was unable to achieve high-volume efficiency for any one product. But high tariffs shielded it from competition from abroad. Moreover, CAP paid no corporate taxes, and the private entrepreneurs who owned most of its shares could always rely on their minority partner -- the Government -- for emergency loans.
The only losers were Chilean taxpayers, who paid a subsidy of $30 million a year to keep the company afloat. Nobody has ever bothered to calculate how much additional money consumers lost by not being allowed to buy cheaper imported steel.
"It was a real sweet life," recalls Roberto de Andraca, who has spent 32 years as a CAP executive. "We fixed any problems by talking to the very Government people who protected us: the central bank guy, the customs man, the tax official."
CAP's honeymoon with the Government ended after the Pinochet coup. On the advice of Chilean economists trained at the University of Chicago, public subsidies to corporations were withdrawn and tariffs on foreign imports were sharply reduced. "When we protested to Pinochet and his Finance Minister, they told us to go bankrupt if we couldn't compete," Andraca says. And to emphasize its resolve to let CAP swim or sink, the Government put its stake in the company up for sale.
In desperation, CAP embraced both orthodox austerity and unconventional financial policies. The company trimmed its product lines, turning out only those goods that could compete with foreign imports. The labor force was slashed. The remaining employees were induced to buy 15 percent of the company's shares with loans guaranteed by their pension funds. Another 15 percent of CAP was purchased by management. The rest of the shares were picked up by assorted institutions and private investors.
Even while it was servicing a mammoth $550 million foreign debt, CAP used its annual cash flow to buy other companies. "One of the reasons to diversify was to make it easier to sell our shares," explains Andraca, a tall, voluble 56-year-old engineer-turned-promoter. "Nobody wanted us just as a steel company."
Today, Andraca is chairman of CAP's holding company, which owns 19 firms -- enterprises ranging from mines to real estate to forestry -- with annual sales exceeding $600 million. Exports account for half of these revenues. CAP's steel division claims to be among the most efficient producers in the world. For Andraca, the biggest paradox is that CAP continues to be the largest provider of steel to the Chilean market: "Funny, when you think that we got into everything else because we thought we could never compete as a steel maker."
Nowadays, the Chilean economy is dominated by a score of business conglomerates, a few of them even larger than CAP. The Luksic Group, for example, rang up over $1 billion in sales last year from assorted ventures like mining, fishing, forestry, beverages, food products, rail transportation, real estate, hotels, telecommunications and banking. The rationale for such rampant diversification is the cyclical nature of businesses in Chilean history. "How do you know there will always be a market for fruit abroad, or that beer consumption will continue to rise at home?" asks Gonzalo Menendez, who runs the group's bank. "It makes sense to spread the risk. And of course, there's another reason: The economic boom in this country just keeps opening more and more opportunities that are too lucrative to cede to competitors."
Such frenzied growth is straining the traditional family structure of the big Chilean enterprises. In the old days, the patriarch staffed the top posts with his sons and nephews. But now, "the business groups know they have to reach beyond the family for good managers, and pay them good salaries," says the 42-year-old Menendez, who has the clear-eyed, exquisitely tailored look of the modern Chilean chief executive officer. There are perhaps only 150 to 200 executives in the country who earn annual incomes above $100,000. In the next few years, Menendez predicts, "there will be many more," and stock options will proliferate as companies fight for the loyalties of senior executives.
Just a few blocks west of Menendez's sumptuous Beaux-Arts bank headquarters, Santiago levels down to one-story houses and shops with a drab, provincial look of faded pastels and broken-tile roofs. Income also levels down, to a few thousand dollars or less a year. The men fixing motorbikes on the sidewalks and the pushcart vendors hawking empanadas -- meat-and-vegetable turnovers -- haven't heard of stock options. This is the neighborhood chosen by some of the more important trade unions for their headquarters.
During most of the dictatorship, they were shut down and their leaders incarcerated. The right to strike was rescinded, and union membership rolls shriveled. When the Pinochet era ended, the great fear among businessmen was that the pendulum would swing back, and that a resentful labor movement would force a soft-hearted new government to concede sharp wage increases that would undercut all those prosperous companies.
But nothing of the sort has happened. Under President Aylwin, a grandfatherly Christian Democrat, there have actually been fewer strikes than in Pinochet's last year, when they were still illegal. Union membership hasn't noticeably surged. There has been no wage explosion -- only moderate rises, well within the range deemed affordable by entrepreneurs.
"Maybe we've been too prudent," says Miguel Vega, the burly, 42-year-old leader of the textile workers, the most combative union in the Allende era. "But we don't want to be accused of social agitation. Who's to say Pinochet won't use labor unrest to come marching back into power?"
Probe a bit more, though, and Vega cites more far-reaching reasons for the lack of labor militance. The majority of Chilean enterprises, he notes, were created after the 1973 coup. "That's a generational problem for us because young workers have never been in contact with trade unions," Vega says. "Many of them are a lot better educated than their parents. I spent eight years in school, so I'm practically considered a scholar among my union colleagues. But it's not at all unusual to see young workers with high-school diplomas. It's hard for them to look up to union leaders who are so much less educated. The old speeches on class struggle and solidarity leave them cold."
Free-trade policies have also transformed the labor scene. "Years ago, we could insist that all textile factories pay the same wages," Vega says, because their goods were sold only in Chile and protectionism eliminated the threat of foreign competition. "But many businessmen have convinced workers that markets here and abroad will be lost if wages rise too quickly."
Yet another big change is the private pension system, which has virtually replaced state-run social security. Before its advent a decade ago, hyperinflation melted savings into small change. Workers who had spent decades laboring for poverty wages retired into even greater penury. Under the new system, employees put part of every paycheck in any of 50 private pension funds, which invest the money in blue-chip stocks and Government bonds. If workers are dissatisfied with their fund's performance -- the results are published weekly -- they can switch their money to another one.
The private pension system now covers 90 percent of all employees, and helps explain why Chile's savings (and thus, investment) rate has skyrocketed. But trade unions initially denounced it as a ploy to commit workers to the new capitalism. "That was a mistake," Vega admits. The private pension funds "are obviously very popular among workers," he adds, "and we no longer object to them."
Vega blames all these factors for labor's sagging recruitment efforts. At Hilados y Tejidos Garib, one of the more modern textile plants, his union couldn't attract enough members to displace the company union as the workers' representative in contract negotiations.
Jose Cornejo was among the many Garib workers who failed to sign up with Vega. At 30, he considers himself a blue-collar employee on a faster track than laborers of his father's generation. He was barely a teen-ager when the military coup took place. That night his father, Antonio, a watchman at a Government building, was arrested at his work post by army troops. Tortured, threatened with execution three times and barely fed during his 16 days in detention, he "came home looking like a rag doll," Cornejo recalls. "Dad had nothing but bad luck after that. He hurt himself in a construction accident. And since then, he cadges tips looking after parked cars."
After quitting school at 17 to help his family make ends meet, Jose Cornejo labored as a supermarket deliveryman, a construction worker and ballboy at a country club, where he met owners of the Garib factory on the tennis courts. He has been working the last six years at the textile plant, and is now in charge of a computerized Swiss machine that finishes cloth for export. "I'm the one who decides if the material is good enough to ship abroad," he says.
Besides a steady rise in income to $300 a month, he received a loan from his boss for a mortgage down payment. He lives with his wife and two daughters in a modest two-bedroom house, part of a new working-class community, still treeless and unpaved, that sprawls over former vineyards in the shadows of the snow-streaked Andes Mountains.
"I've been treated well by my boss -- but I deserve it," Cornejo says. "I show up even on vacations if there's work to be done, and I don't screw up on the machines. My wages have gone up every year, so I have to believe they'll continue rising." And his politics? "Like my dad's. I'll always vote for the left."
But what kind of left? Certainly not the same one Cornejo's father knew a generation ago. The "change of mentality" engineered by Pinochet was not confined to the business community. As the dictatorship lasted through the 1970's and then into the 80's, leftists also changed their outlook. The collapse of Marxist regimes in Eastern Europe -- and the disastrous economic legacies exposed in their wake -- shook the assumptions of even orthodox left-wing Chileans. And capitalist Chile seemed to be an oasis in a continent ravaged by mega-inflation and mini-growth. "The more Marxist one was, the more stupefied one became," says Luis Maira, a leading socialist politician.
The ideological retreat was painful enough for leftist intellectuals. Far more excruciating was their attempt to fit into a society they loathed. Radicals who were in their 20's during the Allende era became thirtysomething liberals with growing families to feed. They joined private enterprise. Some of them even agreed to work for the hated Government.
Carlos Fuensalida, an urban planner, became the first known leftist to be hired by the Pinochet Government when he accepted a post at the Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs in 1978, shortly after his return to Chile from exile in Spain. He was told by ministry officials to omit his wife's name on his job application because her sister was said to be a dangerous Marxist. And he was warned to keep his political views to himself.
For two years he did little more than collect a paycheck. Contempt for public works was so pervasive at the ministry, Fuensalida says, that "whenever I suggested a project I was told to leave it to private enterprise." But capitalism-run-riot was devastating downtown Santiago. Traffic snarls, fumes, noise, grime and general tawdriness were obliterating the historic city center.
In 1980, Fuensalida was finally allowed to form a task force, with a minimum budget. "I picked people of my same professional and political background, and I gave them a lot of breathing room," he says. He recruited them among eager students and underemployed faculty in the urban planning departments of the universities. They pelted the ministry with ideas, which for the most part were batted down. But some notions did survive.
The most important was to preserve the architecture of downtown Santiago, for economic as well as esthetic reasons. For several years, a full-scale business exodus had been under way. Corporate offices were moving to new mirrored high-rises in the affluent neighborhoods closer to the Andean foothills, and stores soon followed them into California-style malls.
Fuensalida came up with an effective -- and cheap -- solution. Offering tax breaks, he convinced merchants and corporations to put up most of the money to sandblast their buildings' facades and replace asphalt streets with cobblestoned pedestrian walks. Turn-of-the-century museums and theaters were refurbished with private donations. Public monuments were polished. Parks and plazas were pruned and replanted. Santiago, which never inspired paeans, suddenly became a model of urban renaissance for planners in Mexico City, Lima and Buenos Aires -- cities with far more impressive architectural inventories.
"I wanted to insure that the Government that followed Pinochet's would inherit a livable capital," Fuensalida says. The new Government has given Fuensalida control of all public investment in urban Chile and a mandate to revive other major cities.
For all the plaudits, Fuensalida still did not earn enough to cover the expenses of a three-child household. So his wife, Elena Serrano, a lawyer, applied for an opening in the public relations department of the Santiago branch of a major American bank six years ago. Fluent in English, articulate and poised, she beat out dozens of other candidates for the job.
At first, she remembers feeling like a left-wing Alice fallen deep down the rabbit hole into a conservative wonderland. "I discovered a world that adored the dictatorship, people who were infinitely in love with Pinochet," she recalls. "Even their language sickened me. They spoke of 'presumed human rights violations' when they really meant torture and executions."
Then came the months of angst. Friends accused her of soldiering for American imperialism. "The nicer ones would just warn me to be careful or I'd become a convert," she says. "I told myself I was hibernating until the dictatorship ended."
As years went by, she was promoted to vice president, and became less timid about making her views known to the senior executives. She persuaded them to spend the bank's charitable funds on public-school gymnasiums that could double as evening community centers in poor neighborhoods -- instead of making yet another donation to Santiago's symphony orchestra and ballet.
"I started to think of myself as a bridge between the dictatorship and the coming democratic Government," says Serrano, whose own politics were shifting to the center. "I let my bosses know there was a whole world of Pinochet opponents outside our doors, and that they had nothing to fear from them."
She campaigned for Aylwin and his center-left coalition in the 1989 elections. When the new Government took power, its economic team turned to people like her for advice on dealing with conservative money men. She was with Finance Minister Foxley in New York for his first meetings with some of Chile's largest creditors.
"I had to explain to him what Brooks Brothers was," Serrano recalls. And she reviewed the speeches of his chief debt negotiator to strike out words that might bewilder or offend United States bankers. "He kept wanting to use the phrase 'moral principles,' " she says, with a barely concealed smile. "I convinced him that it just wasn't part of their vocabulary."

COUNTRY: CHILE (96%); LATIN AMERICA (94%); EUROPE (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (55%);
