HEADLINE: Astrakhan Journal;
Hotel for Young Lovers? Perestroika Turns Pale

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASTRAKHAN, U.S.S.R., July 5

 BODY:
Tired of trysting in stairwells and graveyards, young people here persuaded one of the new insurgent city councilmen to propose that the city build a special youth hotel, with Bohemian cafe and hourly bedroom rates, to allow privacy for spooning.
In doing so, the councilman, Valery V. Karpov, touched one of the sorest spots of Communism -- the inhibitions of communal apartment living -- with one of the sharper issues of glasnost: how libertine should the new freedoms and candor be allowed to become. 
 "I am sorry I ever proposed this," said Mr. Karpov, acknowledging that the hotel was unlikely to be built any time soon and estimating that the uproar was about to drive him from politics.
"This is an idea for the intellectuals," Boris M. Glukhman, deputy chairman of the city council, said dismissively of an issue that, in its own way, is as much a matter of self-determination out here in the political provinces as any of the more celebrated sovereignty and economic plans being furiously debated in Moscow, 800 miles to the northwest.
"But we are not ready to solve this special problem of the individual on such a social scale," Mr. Glukhman added, reflecting the view not just of the Communist-controlled council but of the ordinary people who have been complaining directly to Mr. Karpov for proposing such a new frontier of moral tolerance in this ancient city on the Volga.
 
A Lesson in Puritanism
 Mr. Karpov said he thought the subject was a basic issue of human rights, one that proceeded from his being chairman of the city's 20-member youth commission, where the idea arose and was approved. Instead, he has received a lesson in what he terms puritanism and the power it carries in a society newly opened to free speech. "I've discovered the Soviet Union is a match for the United States in at least one area -- puritanism," contended Mr. Karpov, a 36-year-old teacher of modern history.
"Hypocrisy has been the main feature of our society," he said. "I thought the time had come to balance our old socialist realism with some capitalist realism. What I proposed is nothing more than the sort of purpose motels in America are put to."
Mr. Karpov's supporters say he is what true perestroika reforms need, someone to speak his mind and push the limits of free debate, even if the specifics of his proposals can be too strong. They note, for example, that his anti-hypocrisy crusade embraces a raft of issues, including an end to the longtime practice of imprisoning individual fishermen here on the Volga sturgeon grounds for daring to compete with the state monopoly in caviar harvesting.
"Some poor fisherman can get 10 years in jail for 10 kilograms of caviar," he noted angrily. "That's an abuse of human rights."
At the very least, Mr. Karpov provides a measure of the extent to which freethinking is advancing here in the Russian boondocks. But, elected only last year, Mr. Karpov said he has painfully found the limits of democratic politics here in this city of 500,000.
"Out of a hundred detailed proposals I've submitted to the city council to make life better, only sex gets any attention," he said ruefully.
This is doubly understandable in this society, perhaps, because of the inhibitions encouraged across the decades of Communism. These include communal apartments with all their social awkwardness and invitation to snooping, and a police-state pervasiveness that still employs a domestic passport system to account for everyone's unusual whereabouts, particularly at hotels.
The Soviet people have been ingenious about the problem. The better known lovers' ploys of the era of stagnation included the Red Arrow overnight train to Leningrad with its multi-bed compartments, and, similarly, the private cabins of the slow, daylong Bukhta Radosty (Harbor of Joy) boatride outside Moscow.
Mr. Karpov, who speaks several languages and says he would prefer that the spelling of his surname start with a c instead of a k, is fast trying to fill in the many blanks of Soviet history for his students now that they are finally free to be told. His early loathing of Communist faculty meetings caused him never to join the party, he related, and thus he was ready and eager when insurgent, anti-Communist politics swept some new personalities to the fore in the city in the last few years. He talks of sex as a measure of the importance of the individual rights, while conceding the fun of it.
"I myself when I was a student ccasionally sneaked off with my girlfriend to the family dacha when my parents were away, but not everyone has a dacha," Mr. Karpov said. "You know old man Freud had it right -- the sexual aspects of life will surface regardless."
But Mr. Glukhman, the council official, decorating his sense of romance with dialectic, makes something of the same point in opposing the hotel with a smiling nod toward tradition.
"This is a problem of every individual understanding the task set before him by nature and taking into account the ingenuity of each individual at solving this problem," said the 54-year-old deputy chairman. "Depending, of course, on each individual's sense of urgency about this subject."
The young, who can be found congregating at night in the darkness along the concrete Volga levee, have responded to Mr. Karpov's sense of candid politics in different ways.
"Karpov is a good man with many good ideas," said Valentina Sabeshkina, a local 26-year-old newspaper reporter. "But I don't know whether we need such a hotel right now, particularly when so many people have nothing much to eat or wear."
"First, solve the basic problems," she declared, saying the hotel could wait, even if everyone was talking about it.

Karpov, a city councilman in Astrakhan, U.S.S.R., who proposed building a hotel with hourly rates for young lovers. He stood outside city's conventional hotel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Putting a Price on the Soviet 'Grand Bargain'

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
A year ago, the idea of the "grand bargain" -- radical Soviet political and economic reform in exchange for tens of billions of dollars in Western aid -- would have been dismissed as an insult by the Kremlin and as a waste of money by the White House.
Now, the impossible seems at least plausible, and the issue of how much aid should be promised under what conditions may overshadow all others at the London economic summit meeting later this month. 
 The obvious explanation is that the economic crisis in the Soviet Union has reached such proportions that it can no longer be ignored. Soviet output fell 6 percent last year and, according to PlanEcon, a Washington consulting firm, is likely to plunge another 18 percent in 1991. Perestroika has become just another word for nothing left to lose.
But the turnabout also reflects new thinking about the best way to make the leap from socialism to capitalism. Most Western analysts, who were initially loath to second-guess Mikhail S. Gorbachev's quest for a painless transition, are now convinced that change must be rapid and that reforms must be buttressed with substantial foreign aid if they are to keep popular support.
Their views are mirrored, albeit weakly, in the Soviet Union.
While some Soviet reformers cling to the view that some cleverer, less obtrusive form of planning could jump-start the economy, a small group of younger economists with a grasp of how markets work has recently been in a position to influence the Soviet policy scramble. Grigory Yavlinsky, the most visible of the new breed and the father of the grand bargain, reportedly spent hours making his case to Mr. Gorbachev last month.
The way has also been eased by the growing recognition of how badly some of Mr. Gorbachev's early efforts, from the creation of a superbureaucracy to monitor industrial quality control to the destruction of vineyards in the name of sobriety, have disrupted output without yielding productivity gains.
Some policies that were better conceived, like the legalization of cooperatives and farmers' markets, have been partly sabotaged by local Communist Party bosses. And some that were truly revolutionary -- for example, the law of enterprises that removed Moscow ministries from the business of setting production targets -- have simply been ignored.
Long experience in coping with bureaucratic contradiction allowed the system to muddle through the 1980's. But the cumulative stresses are now showing.
PlanEcon says production at Soviet factories is falling even faster than the nation's total output, and less of what is produced is making it to factories, farms and retail stores. Just this week, Anatoly Dmitrievsky, a Soviet energy expert, predicted that oil production this year, which is critically needed to finance the country's ballooning bill for imported food, will be 15 percent below the 1989 peak.
But this bad economic news could prove liberating.
Last year, Mr. Gorbachev reportedly rejected the 500-day crash reform plan when its patron, Stanislav Shatalin, acknowledged that production would initially fall by as much as one-third and that millions would lose their jobs. "In fact," said Stanley Fischer, the former chief economist for the World Bank, "the collapse is happening without the reform."
 
Complications of the Decline
 The effects of unchecked decline are bound to spill beyond the Soviet Union's borders, particularly into Europe. While many analysts doubt that a poorer, Balkanized state would threaten Western security, there is widespread agreement that the Soviet Union's troubles are complicating Eastern Europe's transition to capitalism. Factories tied to the old East bloc trading system have been devastated, forcing governments to waste money to protect them from bankruptcy.
The deeper worry in Western Europe is that the Soviet Union's woes will produce a flood of economic and political refugees -- a flood that is especially unwelcome in light of Germany's problems in absorbing its impoverished east. That is apparently why European leaders, notably Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, are so eager to buy insurance against Soviet instability. Mr. Kohl, not coincidentally, met Mr. Gorbachev in Kiev on Friday, to help set the table for the summit meeting.
 
Argument for Big Bang
 The sea change in attitudes among economists in both East and West has in part been pushed by the abject failure of Mr. Gorbachev's half measures. But it largely follows from the insight that stagnant socialist systems share most problems of the overregulated, inflation-prone economies of the third world. Only a big bang, a striking break with the past, it is argued, is likely to create the conditions for self-sustaining change.
At a minimum, the argument goes, this means an end to virtually all price controls, credible protection of private property, elimination of most government subsidies and an immediate opening of the economy to foreign competition. It also implies a need for large-scale foreign assistance -- the quid pro quo of the grand bargain.
Creating free markets overnight is bound to disrupt production and distribution, cutting already low living standards. To manage the transition without destroying the nation's fragile democratic impulse, Mr. Fischer insists, the fall in consumption would need to be buffered with imports financed with foreign money.
Similarly, opening the economy quickly would be possible only if rubles were freely convertible to dollars. And instant convertibility depends on the availability of foreign credit.
Poland is the most advanced test of a big bang supported with substantial infusions of Western cash. And by one conventional measure, the experience has been sobering: output has yet to top pre-bang levels. But Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economist and a consultant to the Polish Government, counters that there are better ways to judge the test.
Some 375,000 businesses have sprung up, he notes, and shops are full of goods, both domestic and imported. Unemployment is running at 7.7 percent -- high by socialist standards, but in line with Western Europe.
Herbert Levine, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania, points out that the 20 percent decline in Polish output is a misleading indicator of living standards: Many goods no longer produced in Poland are goods nobody wanted to buy.
 
Unspoken Little Bargains
 Bush Administration officials insist that a public bargain, aid linked to a timetable for political and economic reforms, is not in the cards. What is conceivable, they say, is a series of unspoken little bargains in which Soviet leaders are generously rewarded for bold moves toward democracy and capitalism.
Analysts suggest this might not prove as convoluted a process as it appears. Political conditions need not be negotiated: Mr. Gorbachev is already committed on paper to a new constitution guaranteeing free elections, limiting the Kremlin's authority and laying out reasonable conditions for individual republics to leave the union.
Nor would it be difficult to avoid the appearance of an economic diktat that humiliates the Soviets and commits Western taxpayers' money in advance. Mr. Gorbachev wants provisional membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Giving it to him would create a neutral forum in which to hammer out a reform plan conforming to international lending practices. It would also allow the West to insist on sharp cuts in Soviet military spending and foreign aid in the name of fiscal prudence.
All this suggests that it makes sense to watch what the officials at the summit meeting do -- rather than what they say. "I take this one seriously," one high-ranking American official said.

HEADLINE: 2d Florio Budget Is Study in Survival

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, July 3

 BODY:
With his second budget now in place, Gov. Jim Florio has demonstrated that whatever else he stands for, he is a dedicated practitioner of the politics of survival.
In his first six months in office, Governor Florio and fellow Democrats in the Legislature championed an unabashed kind of class politics. They raised income taxes on the affluent. They redirected a river of money to poorer school districts. And they loosed a barrage of fiery oratory against the insurance industry as an exploiter of the common man. 
 This year, with the Democratic majorities in both houses facing re-election, Mr. Florio and the legislators produced a budget that a Republican would be proud of: it raises no taxes, increases aid to suburban homeowners and slims down government by several thousand workers.
So marked is the turnabout that the Republicans can be expected to ask in the coming months what exactly Mr. Florio and the Democrats stand for, or if they stand for anything at all.
 
Debate Over Democrats' Message
 "They have been sending out a mixed message," said Stephen A. Salmore, a Republican Party consultant who is advising its 1991 legislative candidates. "In the first year, the Democratic policies were clearly perceived by the public as a redistribution of income. In the second year, much of what has happened in Trenton was designed to blunt that perception. Put together, the message is one of confusion."
But the Florio administration and Democratic legislative leaders say the new budget only clarifies the message they have been trying to send the voters since they took office: that they are coming to the aid of middle-class taxpayers who are struggling to get by.
Under the $14.7 billion budget passed by the Legislature and signed by Mr. Florio late on June 30, the state will lay off between 2,000 and 3,000 workers, and most state agencies will have their budgets cut 8 percent from the budget in the previous fiscal year.
There will be a freeze in aid to state colleges for the third year in a row, and the state's 400,000 welfare recipients will see no increase in their aid for the fourth year in a row. The budget also cuts $4 million from the state's major job training program for the unemployed poor.
 
Heart, Soul and Property Taxes
 But overall spending increases by $2.3 billion. The largest share of the increase, nearly $2 billion, is directed to reduce the burden of property taxes on homeowners.
"The heart and soul of this budget is property-tax relief for the middle class," said Jon Shure, the Governor's director of communications. "And we have gotten the job done in tough economic times."
The budget comes at the end of six months in which the Governor has sharply revised the goals and tone of his administration.
Shortly before he took office in January 1990, Mr. Florio talked about an ambitious set of liberal goals, including an assault on urban poverty, a crackdown on overdevelopment, and changes in a health care system that leaves more than one million New Jerseyans uninsured.
In his first months in office, Mr. Florio raised taxes, including a $1.4 billion increase in income taxes on wealthier New Jerseyans. Much of that rise was used to increase aid to poor and middle-income school districts. Mr. Florio also appointed an environmental prosecutor, and pushed through the Legislature a ban on assault rifles and a new automobile insurance system that the administration says will lower most customers' premiums.
"They call themselves the 'good hands' people," Mr. Florio said the day after the Allstate Insurance Company announced it would sue to block Mr. Florio's insurance plan. "The question is: What part of our anatomy do they have their good hands around?"
But after elections last November demonstrated that most voters were angered by Mr. Florio's tax package, he began a campaign to win back middle-class voters.
In March he approved a revised version of his tax and education bills of 1990, shifting more than $360 million from school aid to aid to municipalities to reduce property taxes.
This spring, Mr. Florio assailed the state's school boards as bureaucracies marbled with fat. And he castigated the state's public employees unions for refusing to give back wages and benefits already granted in their contracts.
In signing the new budget on June 30, Mr. Florio said he took pride in realizing one of the administration's major goals: making government smaller.
Steven DeMicco, the executive director of the New Jersey Democratic State Committee, said Democrats running for re-election this fall would argue that they had brought state spending under control, reduced local property taxes and stemmed the rise in automobile insurance rates.
"All of them were out of control under the Republican administration," Mr. DeMicco said, referring to Mr. Florio's predecessor. Gov. Thomas H. Kean. "They have been reined in by bold actions."
The Republicans in the Legislature, Mr. DeMicco added, have refused to offer alternatives.
But Mr. Florio and other Democrats can expect to be attacked from both left and right in the months to come.
 
Suit Fights School-Aid Revision
 Marilyn J. Morheuser, the director of the Education Law Center in Newark, has filed suit against the state over the revision in Mr. Florio's Quality Education Act, saying it defies a state Supreme Court decision on school financing handed down last year.
Ms. Morheuser, who successfully sued to force the state to increase aid to the poorest school districts, says the decision by Mr. Florio and the Legislature effectively guts the promises to help poor districts that Mr. Florio made last year.
The Republicans, meanwhile, argue that it will be difficult for legislators who voted in the largest tax increase in the state's history in 1990 to run as advocates of small government in 1991.
"They represent the idea of taking from suburban New Jersey and giving to urban New Jersey, taking from affluent districts and giving to the poor" said Donald Sico, executive director of the Assembly Republican office. "This is a budget it is going to be hard for them to sell."

HEADLINE: Gray Skies for California Banks

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 7

 BODY:
California's big banks are being hit with some big shocks, and the state's slumping economy is just one of them.
A Labor Department report issued on Friday, showing that California's unemployment rate surged in June to its highest level in seven years, underscored the difficult economic climate facing the state's four largest banking companies: the BankAmerica Corporation, the Security Pacific Corporation, Wells Fargo & Company and the First Interstate Bancorp. 
 The state's unemployment rate jumped to 8.2 percent in June, up from 7.7 percent in May and 5.1 percent in June 1990. It was the highest jobless rate in California since March 1984, when the rate reached 8.3 percent. The national unemployment rate in June was 7 percent, the Labor Department said.
 
Three Increase Reserves
 Analysts said the sharp rise in unemployment reflected broad problems in the state's economy, including the effects of a drought, the slowdown in Pentagon spending, an overbuilt commercial real estate market as well as the national recession. And the unemployment rate explains some of the problems behind the large increases in loan-loss reserves taken in recent weeks by Security Pacific, Wells Fargo and First Interstate.
Because of the additions to their reserves, Security Pacific and Wells Fargo said they would post sharply lower earnings for the quarter ended June 30; First Interstate said it would post a loss for the period.
BankAmerica said that it was having more problems in many parts of its loan portfolio but that they were more than offset by improvement in its loans to other countries. BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, said it expected its second-quarter earnings to be flat compared with the similar period a year earlier.
 
Basically Sound
 The California banks are still basically strong, analysts said, and no one sees evidence yet that any of them will suffer the devastating losses like those that crippled many banks in the Northeast, Texas and other markets suffering from prolonged economic and real estate troubles.
But the deteriorating condition of the California banks' loan portfolios has burst a recent surge in confidence among investors that the banks would weather the recession without much difficulty.
With business slow, more companies, especially those with heavy loads of debt, are having difficulty meeting all of their payments. Developers and owners of commercial real estate are having trouble filling office buildings and shopping centers, putting more real estate loans in jeopardy.
"The common thread in what's happening to the banks is the softening California business climate and the slumping commercial real estate market," said Denise Petsis, an analyst at Argus Research in New York.
After running up sharply this spring, Wells Fargo's stock closed at $66.50 a share on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.125 for the day but down nearly a third from its peak of $98.75 in early June. First Interstate's shares have fallen from a high of $42.50 this year to $26.75 a share, up 12.5 cents on Friday.
Security Pacific's shares have dropped from a recent high of $33.125 two months ago to $21.125 on Friday, down 12.5 cents on the day. Even BankAmerica, which was hurt the least by loan problems in the second quarter, saw its stock driven down from $40.375 a share earlier this year to $34.50 a share on Friday, up $1 for the day.
In addition to the difficulties posed by the California economy, the banks are also paying a price for the business strategies they pursued in recent years.
First Interstate, based in Los Angeles, was battered in the second quarter by its push into neighboring states, with its Nevada and Oregon operations reporting more loan problems. Security Pacific, also based in Los Angeles, suffered from loans it made in Britain and Australia. The problems of Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, were mainly with companies that borrowed heavily to finance buyouts or other transactions.
"Each of their operations and loan compositions are different," Ms. Petsis said.
 
Tougher Regulation
 Moreover, the banks are contending with regulators who are suddenly applying stricter standards than ever, in some cases forcing the banks to deal more aggressively with potentially troubled loans than the institutions think is necessary.
"It appears that regulators are applying the same generally tougher standards they were in the East last year," said Mark Lynch, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company.
At Wells Fargo, the company's addition of $350 million to its reserves for bad loans was made primarily at the direction of Federal banking regulators from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, industry executives said. In announcing the step on June 25, Wells Fargo pointedly noted that it was counting among its potentially bad loans about $400 million on which the borrowers were up to date on all interest and principal payments. About half of those loans were related to buyouts or other deals that regulators called highly leveraged transactions.
An industry publication, The American Banker, has reported that the regulators based their decisions about the loans' soundness on their assessment of the borrowers' prospects several years in the future, a new approach that Wells Fargo strongly objected to.
A spokeswoman for Wells Fargo declined to comment, and a spokesman for the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency could not be reached.
Similarly, regulators reportedly took a very hard line with First Interstate, creating serious disagreements with the bank's managers, especially in Nevada. Donald Snyder, chairman of First Interstate's Nevada bank, resigned in the wake of the intense regulatory scrutiny, as did the Nevada bank's president and several other top lending officers.
 
Softness in Real Estate
 One big uncertainty now facing California banks is the real estate market. Residential real estate is showing signs of bouncing back after a period of little sales activity and declining prices in many markets. The commercial market is very slow and is plagued by an excess of available space, especially in Southern California.
In making its earnings projection last week, Security Pacific said it was adding $200 million in commercial real estate loans to its pool of troubled loans. Wells Fargo said real estate loans were not a serious factor in its problems. First Interstate reported some moderate problems and warned that the California real estate market "retains elements of unpredictability that may result in changes in the level of nonperforming assets, as well as in further exposure to credit losses."
The other big question is how soon the state's once-robust economy will bounce back. Economists said California will probably lag the national recovery from the recession because the drought, continuing layoffs in the aerospace business and a bad slump in housing construction will continue for some months at least.
The state's budget crisis is not helping, either. The package of tax increases and spending cuts being pieced together by Governor Pete Wilson and the Legislature to close a $14.3 billion budget deficit could leave consumers and businesses with less money to spend. More layoffs in state and local government could also result.

HEADLINE: Optimistic Economists Vs. Gloomy Executives

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
With few exceptions, statistical indicators now portray an American economy climbing solidly out of the recession.
Retail sales are up, along with other gauges like factory orders and output, consumer psychology and the length of the work week. Indeed, on the assumption that the recovery is now so firmly grounded that no additional impetus is needed from lower interest rates, a few economists have begun to speculate about possible moves by the Federal Reserve to restrain the recovery by raising rates. 
 But the people who actually meet payrolls and otherwise run the nation's businesses seem to be hearing a different drummer. Ask them how business is and chances are you will be told that things are considerably somewhat less than wonderful.
 
Natural Divergence
 Since the business cycle affects industries at different times and downturns are felt with different degrees of severity, some divergence of views is natural. What is striking is how sharp is the contrast between professional economists and those who manage corporations of all sizes.
The proportion of economists holding that the economy is in the process of making at least some sort of a comeback is overwhelming: 84 percent of participants in a survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter in Sedona, Ariz., think the recession will be over this month, with 65 percent contending that it was over by the end of June.
But Peter T. Rogers, president of the Marion Plywood Corporation in Marion, Wis., whose veneers and plywoods go into pianos and skateboards as well as into doors and other construction products, said in a phone interview last week that "I can't say the economy is really looking better." His father, Thomas, the chairman of the $17 million-a-year family-owned concern, added, "It's pretty spotty."
 
Laid-off Workers Recalled
 On the other hand, things are not really so bad. Marion has recalled all 60 or so of the workers it laid off since last summer and expects by year-end to restore the work force to its pre-recession level of 300. And profits in the fiscal year ending this summer are likely to match those of 1990.
Still, there is an undercurrent to the business evaluations of company executives that is decidedly at odds with the numbers flowing these days from Washington's statistics mills. It is basically a skepticism about the recovery that could inhibit inventory-building and other actions that would hasten the recovery, a skepticism shared by the heads of many of the biggest American corporations.
The disparity between the views of professional economists and corporate managers was particularly evident at the semiannual meeting of the Business Council this spring, where the chiefs of the biggest 100 companies were considerably less optimistic than a team of economists from their own companies.
Part of the explanation may be that economists take a broader, less parochial view of what is happening with business trends, while executives must worry about more concrete matters: whether to keep a marginal plant open in a depressed area or whether the Government will impose new health-care requirements.
 
Different Standards Used
 But the main explanation is probably that the two groups use different standards of evaluation. Economists scrutinize month-to-month changes while corporate chiefs, with the implicit encouragement of security analysts on Wall Street, focus on year-to-year comparisons.
"When you talk to an economist or Government statistician, they usually relate to the previous quarter or month," said Walter K. Joelson, manager of economic research and forecasting for the General Electric Company, a man with a foot in both worlds. "When you talk to a business executive, you always get comparisons with a year ago."
One reason for this is that few companies make, even for internal use, adjustments for seasonal variations in such things as their orders and shipments. By simply comparing the second quarter of 1991 with the second quarter of 1990, for example, this problem is avoided, since seasonal factors can generally be assumed to be the same.
 
Poor Sources of Information
 But this tends to make executives poor sources of information about a recent turn in the economy, even if their companies and industries are good bellwethers. A few months after a recovery gets under way, said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, executives will be asserting that "business is still pretty lousy" because it trails that of a year earlier, even if it is better than the immediately preceding month or two.
Executives, in other words, look at levels of business while economists look at changes, said Stuart G. Hoffman of the Pittsburgh-based PNC Financial Corporation.
So even though a business chief may be paid millions of dollars to run a huge, multi-industry empire and has a wealth of proprietary data at his fingertips, he may not have the best perspective on whether the recession is over.
Keep in mind that the economist considers the recession to be history when the economy starts moving up, said Maury N. Harris, chief economist for Paine Webber Inc. To the executive, he added, there will be no such assertion until "you're higher than you used to be" at some time in a prosperous past.

HEADLINE: American Expertise Meets Harsh Reality: The Angolan Business Climate

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LUANDA, Angola

 BODY:
At first glance, it is a triumph of American business ingenuity.
Less than a week after a cease-fire ending Angola's 16-year civil war was signed, a small company based in Los Angeles has begun building the prototype for what will eventually become a 2,000-unit single-family housing development. 
 Not only does the company, American Overseas Development, hope to make a substantial profit, but it will also provide a desperately needed product at a relatively low cost. While Luanda's population has grown to more than double its prewar level of about 1.2 million, no new housing has been built here in at least eight years, Government officials say.
But the story of the housing project is also a cautionary tale about what happens when the rare American entrepreneur braves this war-shattered country. Until now, virtually the only American companies doing business here have been big oil companies.
The housing project began about 18 months ago when Cesar Celestino, the president of the company, which specializes in building houses using pre-cut wood paneling, signed a construction contract with the Angolan Government. In turn, the company will eventually help send about 300 Angolan citizens to the United States to learn how to repair and maintain the household appliances.
Armed with the agreement, Dwight Brown, a 57-year-old construction engineer, arrived here in April to start work on building two model homes and a 40-classroom school.
Mr. Brown first became acquainted with Africa in the early 1980's while working in Liberia on a similar project. By Western standards, Liberia is considered a hardship posting, whose withering tropical heat and often-primitive conditions wear down even the hardiest. Yet Mr. Brown says he thrived there.
Angola, he thought, would be much the same. What he found, instead, was that the long years of civil war had made Luanda, once called the Rio of West Africa, a filthy, smelly city of crumbling buildings and decaying infrastructure.
"Never by any stretch of the imagination did I expect to find anything like this," he said. "I was devastated."
It had also become a city of the disabled and the orphaned. "You have to become accustomed to seeing one-legged people everywhere. And all the kids, I've never seen so many in my life."
To make matters worse, he said, the Government had contracted to build a foundation for the model homes and provide some tools and building materials, but virtually nothing had been done. And there was neither water nor electricity at the job site.
Mr. Brown also soon discovered that the most building supplies -- nails, for example -- could not be bought in bulk on the local market and had to be imported. Getting supplies through the port and airport, however, proved to be another headache. "First," he said, "they wanted $50,000 in what they called import fees for stuff that was only worth about $8,000."
In the meantime, despite the fact that the shipping container was under 24-hour guard, it was broken into and several items, including a power generator, were stolen.
 
A Frustrating Bureaucracy
 But the biggest frustration in doing business here is Angola's byzantine government bureaucracy. "The Government seems to be trying its best," he said, "but there's a real attitude problem here. We'll go to an office where we're supposed to get something done, and they'll pass it on to the next guy, then the next guy, and then the next."
As for hard work, he said, the concept barely exists. "The Government pays everybody, and there are no bonuses for a hard-working person," he said. "So, if you don't work, you get paid."
Mr. Brown's complaints are unusual only in their frankness, several Angolan and foreign residents here said.
For years, Angolan officials attributed their country's economic plight on the chaotic period after independence from Portugal in 1975, when nearly 300,000 European settlers fled virtually overnight, taking with them essential know-how, as well as vital machinery and parts needed to keep the economy going.
The new Marxist-oriented leaders sought to deal with the crisis by adopting the Soviet model of state-run industry and agriculture. But Angolans and foreigners increasingly agree that many of Angola's problems stem from the Government's own unwieldly centralized policies.
Mr. Brown is nonetheless optimistic that with the end of the war, and economic decentralization, "things will eventually sort themselves out."
As far as others contemplating doing business here, he advises, "Be prepared to bring everything."

HEADLINE: Sheepshead Bay Losing Its Old-Salt Air

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
At that rare time when most New York City roads are virtually empty, at 6 A.M. on a midsummer weekend, cars full of fishermen jostle for parking spaces along Emmons Avenue in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn. Party-fishing boat operators beckon like carnival barkers, urging them to spend $27 for a day at sea, much as they have for generations.
At first glance history seems to have made its way up to about 1960 along the avenue, and then stopped dead in its tracks: Helen Randazzo serves the same hot-and-medium sauce that has made her Sheepshead Bay clam bar famous for 35 years; George Richford "works the bay" aboard party-fishing boats much as he has since 1955, and George Schultz, the owner of Pip's, is still on the lookout for another new talent at his comedy club like Rodney Dangerfield, Lenny Bruce or Buddy Hackett.
 
An Uphill Struggle
 But despite the survival of the fishing boats and institutions like Randazzo's, longtime residents of Sheepshead Bay say they are fighting an uphill battle to preserve the character of their community as the city's last quaint ocean-front fishing village. 
 Neither "progress" nor urban blight is alleged as the culprit for the neighborhood's perceived decline. Instead, residents blame a complex mixture of demographic change, poor city planning, a radically transformed fishing industry, squabbles between dinner-cruise boat operators and the city and the aftereffects of the 1978 demise of Lundy's, once the world's largest restaurant.
Sheepshead Bay's once solidly Italian- and Irish-American population has recently become more ethnically diverse, and the community has one of the highest percentages of elderly residents of any New York City neighborhood, said Hilda Mirwis, the chairwoman of the community board that includes much of the South Brooklyn waterfront. While Lundy's remains an empty hulk, much of Emmons Avenue to its east is now a patchwork of nondescript low-rise condominiums, insurance offices, vacant lots and fast-food restaurants, with only a handful of old wooden houses and fishing-tackle shops.
"There used to be dozens of fishing boats and the avenue was lined with restaurants," Mrs. Randazzo said. "The street would be filled with people at night, and chauffeur-driven limousines would be parked in front of Lundy's."
"Now, the kids don't believe in fishing like years ago," she added. "A lot of people have died, and you don't really know the new people who've moved in." She, too, will have to move in two years, she said, because her restaurant, like much Emmons Avenue real estate, was owned by Frederick Lundy and sold by his heirs to developers.
 
Fewer Hard-Core Old Salts
 The sense of change, or decline, is most profound along the waterfront, where a diminishing number of boats with names like the Dorothy B VII and Apache V still carry hundreds of urban fishermen in search of sea bass, bluefish, mackerel and even tuna. The ranks of these party boats have plummeted to 18 today from 45 in 1970, Mr. Richford said, and many of the approximately 70 people who work the boats say they believe that their fleet's days are numbered.
"There are so many things against you now in this business," said Mr. Richford, the owner of Pastime II. "The economics are bad. Fuel and insurance are way up, but we can't raise our prices because people can't afford it. We don't get the hard-core fishermen anymore -- the old salts who'd go out all winter -- and not enough young people are interested in fishing. And our parking lots, that Lundy's owned, have been eaten up by condos."
Offshore fisheries have also been depleted by foreign fishing fleets and "draggers, who come out at night and drag the beaches for fish," said Jeff Moser, a mate on the Zephyr.
Meanwhile, several dinner-cruise boats that have long operated from Sheepshead Bay piers have become embroiled in a bitter dispute with the city over the right to sail. The boats have the cautious support of many fishermen and have contributed to the community's maritime flavor, but the city contends they have no right to berth at the piers.
The Department of Ports and Trade filed suit last month to force out the Romance and the Royal Princess, which take customers for three-hour evening cruises with dinner and dancing for $39.50 to $60 a person.
 
City Bars VIP Yachts From Piers
 "They're not supposed to be there," said Wallace L. Ford 2d, the former Ports and Trade Commissioner who became Commissioner of the new Department of Business Services last week. That department and the city's Development Corporation now oversee the functions of Ports and Trade, which was eliminated last week. The boats, which are operated by VIP Yachts, do not have permits to berth at Sheepshead Bay piers, which are intended for fishing boats, he said.
Despite a decade-old legal provision stipulating that the piers are for fishing, the city had essentially looked the other way -- while collecting $30,000 a year in fees from VIP -- until this March, when Commissioner Ford filed the restraining order, said Michael Barry, VIP's lawyer.
"VIP has been here 40 years, taking people out to eat, fish and for parties," Mr. Barry said. "There are 10 piers with five slips each, and most are vacant, not producing any revenue for the city. The city has designated one pier for excursion boats, which they finished reconstructing several weeks ago, but they've refused to open it. We've offered to pay for permits at the new pier, but they refuse to take our money."
Although some fishermen are bitter about the dinner boats, Mr. Richford said, "Everybody can co-exist if there were enough parking."
 
Fishermen Call Parking Crucial
 Margaret McCord, the 88-year-old unofficial mayor of Sheepshead Bay, said that the parking problem posed the most serious threat to the fishing fleet's future. "Fishermen have to come by car," she said, sitting on a pier at the Knights of Columbus building, pointing to the new Waterview apartments on Emmons Avenue that have replaced long-time parking lots. "They can't carry all their gear and fish on the subway. If there isn't parking, the fishing industry could die."
The city has developed several plans during the last 15 years for revitalizing Sheepshead Bay, including a slowly progressing $12.3 million refurbishing of its piers and esplanade. But the studies and plans have failed to yield the promised parking lot, zoning changes to protect the area's character or any broader strategy to capitalize on the bay's potential for drawing tourists, said Thomas Bowers, the president of the Sheepshead Bay-Plumb Beach Civic Association.
"Other cities, like Miami, San Francisco and Baltimore, value their waterfronts as a beautiful natural resource, but administration after administration in this city has let ours deteriorate," said Ms. Mirwis, the community board leader. "This is a beautiful scenic community, not phony like the South Street Seaport. They spent $300 million on it. We need only $23 million for development here."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Dinkins Finds A Key to the City Is Togetherness

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
In their vague agreement last week to agree on a budget, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, underlined only two words in the full 15 paragraphs:
Together, which was how they had managed to forge an agreement that established the Council as a full partner in setting the agenda of New York City government and marked what may be the beginning of a more respectful relationship. 
 And Independence, which was what Mr. Dinkins had pledged to maintain at all costs. He succeeded for now by fending off the state Financial Control Board and, apparently, by braking Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed new vehicle to help the city ride out the recession.
A week later the togetherness and independence seem less tenuous than the budget, which largely neglected fundamental restructuring.
"Not only are there clear indications that municipal services have deteriorated while promises go unfulfilled," a panel created by the Governor concluded, "but there is also a sensation of helplessness -- a feeling that there is no one or no place in city government to go for assistance or redress, and that no one is held accountable. Productivity reports issue from City Hall, yet nothing appears to change. Increase in municipal employment has not meant an increase in service delivery."
That Governor was not Mr. Cuomo, but a predecessor, Nelson A. Rockefeller, who with Mayor John V. Lindsay was guilty of the sin of commission. Twenty years ago, both recruited panels of experts to embarrass each other.
Governor Rockefeller's version reached a conclusion that reverberates today: "In simplest terms, the city can no longer command the resources required to perform the staggering tasks of income redistribution and service provi sion to which it has committed itself; but its leaders have not yet adjusted their atti tudes or their spending decisions to this situation."
 Mr. Cuomo was a member of Mr. Lindsay's commission, but he acknowledged that nothing much came of either one. The vehicle that he now wants to create by merging his two-year-old New York, New York initiative with Mr. Dinkins's management advisory task force would be different, Mr. Cuomo maintains, because "the new reality" dictates that reforms that were once dismissed as merely "convenient improvements" now represent "a matter of survival."
The Governor's decision not to unilaterally impose a new vehicle on the city was no oversight. "There are people out there would say, if you want to restructure the city you shouldn't ask them to do it," he said, "but the only way to do it is together." Mr. Cuomo said of the Mayor: "He loves the idea of restructuring."
Mr. Cuomo's impatience with the pace of reform, though, was evident at last week's meeting of the Control Board, although the Governor directed his pique at Edward V. Regan, the State Comptroller -- interrogating him about which branch libraries were being closed -- and at Republican obstructionists in the State Legislature.
Considering Mr. Cuomo's relationship with state legislators, his characterization of the City Council as the city's "new legislature" -- a reference to the fact that it was recently vested with the budgetary powers that Governor Rockefeller's commission had recommended -- may have been as much a warning to Mr. Dinkins as a gesture of respect to the Council.
The give and take that preceded last week's city budget agreement gave a new dimension to the word bonding. Mutual resentment and mistrust evolved into begrudging respect between the Deputy Mayors, particularly Bill Lynch and Sally Hernandez-Pinero, and certain Council members and staff -- a respect that apparently did not extend to the two principals. Wasn't it unusual, Mr. Vallone was asked after the agreement was announced Sunday night, that he and Mr. Dinkins had not even spoken for more than 48 hours? "Not for this Mayor," Mr. Vallone replied tartly.
For months, the crisis atmosphere that might have compelled cooperation never materialized and it was uncertain whether the July 1 deadline alone would suffice. In the end, the deadline was more or less met by everybody except organized labor -- whether because the players wanted to flee before the Independence Day weekend or because the Council, edgy in the knowledge that its threat to pass its own budget was largely a bluff that might play into the Mayor's hands, decided to declare victory, rescind its demands for greater control over spending, and wait until next year.
"It's like paying a debt -- we've got to acquire these powers in installments," said Herbert E. Berman, the Brooklyn Democrat who heads the Council's Finance Committee. Meanwhile, he said, tongue-tied from nearly nonstop negotiations, "we have stepped back from the abyss, but we're still in troubled waters."
Clinging together independently, though, without fully grasping the life preserver offered by the Governor.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Signs of a Weak Housing Rebound

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
HOUSING industry stocks, after soaring early this year, have abruptly stopped climbing and begun to trail the overall stock market.
The rise of the housing stocks, which began last November, served as a signal that the deep housing recession might end far sooner than many had expected. But the new weakness in prices has kept one home builder from going through with a planned stock offering, even though many others succeeded and another is hoping to sell shares soon. And the falloff in stock prices could signal that the rebound in housing is going to be weaker than had been optimistically hoped for only a few months ago. 
 "After the end of the Persian Gulf war, there was a huge enthusiasm" among home buyers, said Kenneth Campbell of Audit Investments, an analyst who follows the real estate industry. "But there is only a modest follow-through."
Last week, the Commerce Department reported that sales of new homes fell 3.3 percent in May, and revised April's previously reported 1.2 percent gain to show a small drop of two-tenths of 1 percent. Still, the annual rate of 474,000 home sales was 14.5 percent higher than the low of 414,000 reached in January.
The fall in part reflected worries over rising interest rates, which have pushed up the cost of buying a new home. Bulls on the industry generally expect rates to come down soon, helping to stimulate sales, but a strengthening economy could have the opposite effect.
An index of 11 housing stocks, weighted by market capitalization, has fallen 11.5 percent in the last five weeks, a period during which the Standard & Poor's 500 slipped only 4 percent.
But that retrenchment came only after an extraordinary period for the housing stocks. From Nov. 2 to the end of May, a period when the S.& P. 500 rose 25 percent, every home-building stock at least doubled, and the index rose 135 percent.
That rise left some industry analysts gasping. "You have to look for a very substantial upswing in earnings" to justify the prices, Mr. Campbell said. "It is hard to believe they will do it just on economic recovery. You have to believe in a very substantial increase in market share" for the publicly held builders.
That market share increase may arrive, at least for some builders. Bankers vow that never again will they lend to undercapitalized housing developers. This time, they say, builders will have to put a substantial amount of their own capital at risk.
Such pledges of caution have been violated in the past, but they are likely to endure for some time. And that will put builders without access to additional equity investments at a disadvantage. Last week, Hovnanian Enterprises sold two million new shares at $7.50, following in the footsteps of companies like Toll Brothers Inc. and the Del Webb Corporation. Continental Homes Inc. last week filed to sell 1.8 million shares, including 300,000 to be sold by current shareholders. Shares of the Arizona home builder were unchanged, at $7.875, for the week.
The Ryland Group, a national home builder, had planned to sell two million shares, but it withdrew the offering late last month, complaining that its stock price -- which had fallen to less than $19 after topping $25 -- was too low. Last week its shares closed at $19.75.
With signs of a less-than-robust rebound in home sales, analysts have been pushing out earnings estimates, no longer looking to this year for a big rebound, but focusing on 1992 and even 1993 as the likely time for a surge of profits.
Over all, Stephen J. Dobi of Smith Barney said in a recent report, "1991 will be the least active home-building year in more than three decades." But he forecast that "housing will post a modest recovery in the second-half of 1991." He wrote before last week's report of falling sales of new homes, and could not be reached for comment on Friday or over the weekend.
In the retrenchment of share prices that began in June and continued in the first week of July, the three worst performers, down about 20 percent each, were Standard-Pacific, the Kaufman and Broad Home Corporation and the PHM Corporation, the parent of Pulte Homes. Each of them builds homes in California, where a string of banks surprised Wall Street last week with warnings of disappointing profits.
The only winner over the period was UDC-Universal Development, which raised new equity capital in a private transaction last month, selling stock at $11.875. The price has since risen to $13.375. Among the buyers were the company's top officers.

INTERNATIONAL
A powerful new economic pragmatism is sweeping third world capitals from Brasilia to Bangkok. Countries that were once proud economic nationalists are now trying to forge closer ties with the rest of the world. Government officials and economists say they are committed to changes like allowing market forces to flourish, abandoning fiscal and monetary policies that were politically motivated and opening borders to foreign goods and investment. [Page A1.] India has begun a fundamental shift in priorities that looks to South Korea and prosperous Southeast Asian nations as guiding economic symbols, its new foreign minister says. [D3.]
A year ago, the idea of the "grand bargain" -- Soviet reform in exchange for Western aid -- would have been dismissed as an insult by the Kremlin and as a waste of money by the White House. The impossible now seems at least plausible. Economic Watch. [D1.] Interviews with scores of Americans reveals a deep ambivilance about the idea of a Soviet bailout financed by the United States. [A1.] 
 With a third Michelin star, a French chef hopes to increase his revenues by 50 percent and save himself from drowning under $40,000 in monthly debt payments. [A1.]

Economists may see the economy climbing solidly out of recession, but the people who meet payrolls and run the nation's businesses seem to be hearing a different drummer. [D1.]
California's big banks are feeling some big shocks, and the state's slumping economy is just one of them. [D1.]
Coal producers and coal-burning utilities are deciding whether to go national with an ad campaign challenging the idea that burning fossil fuels will change the climate. [D2.]

[B1.] Connecticut's Governor ordered state employees to report back to work beginning today, but the state is no closer to a resolution of its budget impasse. [B1.]

HEADLINE: Third World Embracing Reforms To Encourage Economic Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A powerful new economic pragmatism is sweeping third world capitals from Brasilia to Bangkok, and countries that were once proud economic nationalists are now trying to forge closer ties with the rest of the world.
The broad changes are the subject of the World Bank's annual World Economic Development Report, which was made public this morning. And in interviews last week, government officials and economists from third world nations said they were committed to allowing market forces to flourish free of government restraints, abandoning fiscal and monetary policies that were politically motivated but economically unsound and opening borders to foreign goods and investment.
 
'Time for Fresh Thinking'
 "Everybody is convinced it is time for fresh thinking," India's Finance Minister Manmohan Singh said in an interview last week. [Page D3.] 
 And Sebastian Edwards, a Chilean economist at the University of California at Los Angeles, said, "For Chile, there is no turning back."
Argentina, for example, has caught tax-reform fever. Mexico is selling its Government-owned businesses. Peru is cutting its budget deficit. Turkey has thrown off its decades-old protectionist blanket. Thailand kept its budget balanced and held inflation to a modest 3 percent. Ghana and a handful of other African nations no longer tax their farmers out of producing.
"The change in thinking is really remarkably pervasive," said Stanley Fischer, former chief economist at the World Bank and now a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "Ten years ago, for example, Mexicans insisted that their main job was to protect themselves from the imperialist U.S."
If the nascent economic changes take root and spread, the four billion people who live in the developing world could enjoy a better standard of living. The changes could also provide a wealth of opportunities to businesses and investors in the United States and other rich countries.
What started the revolution? For one thing, the stunning growth of South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and other Asian economies. For another, the collapse of socialism in Eastern Europe.
The belief that this revolution is an enduring one is strongest among early reformers who have already reaped the rewards of faster growth. Hasan L. Ersel, deputy governor of Turkey's central bank, said, "If Turkey doesn't experience an enormous external shock, it is highly unlikely that these policies will be reversed."
Certainly, the road to economic reform is lined with ruts. Steps toward reforms in Argentina and Brazil have been derailed by a repeated failure to control inflation. Despite progress on trade and liberalizing financial markets, Turkey has not brought its budget under control. Ghana's far-reaching reforms have not yet persuaded many investors to come aboard. And Eastern European political leaders have found that their commitment to market-driven economies -- with the layoffs and higher prices these bring in the short run -- have brought strikes, protests and challenges to incumbent officials.
But it now seems clear that in many developing nations there is a new sense of realism, much of it inspired by the hardships of the last decade.
 
'Nothing Inevitable About Stagnation'
"The enormous differences in performance among developing countries in the 80's suggests that there is nothing inevitable about stagnation" said Lawrence H. Summers, chief economist at the World Bank. While many economies in Africa and Latin America shrank during the decade, Botswana, Chile, Indonesia and Thailand, among others, expanded.
"The key," Professor Fischer of M.I.T. said, "is moving away from saying that world is unfair to saying however unfair it is, we want to make the best use of it."
The international economy is widely expected to hold modest expansions among the wealthier countries, continued high interest rates, weak commodity prices and persistent debt problems.
So the poorer nations, already starved for investment, are likely to have to compete for scarce capital.
The good news, the World Bank says, is that reform is sufficiently widespread that the economies of the developing countries should grow, on average, 5 percent a year, faster than in the 1980's. That is also faster than the 3 percent rate the bank expects for rich countries.
Countries that have adopted economic reforms, the bank says, include Chile, Ghana, India, Indonesia, South Korea, Mexico, Morocco and Turkey. Even China, which doubled its growth rate in the 1980's by allowing some farmland to be privately owned, is on the list. "You can see reasons for optimism in what developing countries are doing in almost every part of the world," Mr. Summers said.
 
Countries Will Lag Without Reforms
 Those reformers that succeed could narrow the gap between their standards of living and those of rich countries at a rapid pace. But countries that continue to mismanage their economies -- tolerating inefficiency for political ends, squandering precious resources on wars, investing too little in education -- may be doomed to fall further behind. "It no longer makes sense to think of the third world as one group," Mr. Summers said.
The old strategy for transforming a poor country into a rich one, advocated from the 1930's through the 1960's, called for rapid government-led industrialization at the expense of agriculture, protecting infant industries from foreign competition and replacing imports with domestic production for the local market.
At the nub of this philosophy was the notion that government should guide economic development. Thus came a tight web of licensing requirements, restrictions on who could enter or leave industries, constraints on bankruptcy filing and layoffs, and price controls.
"These views have not stood test of time," the World Bank says bluntly. The institution is bankrolled by rich nations that dispenses aid, loans and advice to poor countries.
And seemingly small steps toward deregulation have often produced great spurts of economic activity. Ghana, for instance, used to levy confiscatory taxes of 50 percent or more on cocoa, and some farmers left crops to rot in the fields or smuggled them out. When it sharply lowered the taxes, cocoa production and exports soared. When South Korea lifted interest rates on bank deposits in the 1970's, the size of its banking system quadrupled in less than four years. Morgan Stanley & Company estimates that United States exports to the third world have lately grown at three times the rate of sales to other rich countries. And third world stock markets from Mexico City to Taipei have been booming.
Many developing countries also tried to build up local industries by shielding them from competition. The result was often that inefficient companies turned out shoddy goods that cost too much. Many Argentines drive cars that Detroit might have been proud of in, say, 1960, and Indians buy homemade steel that costs more than the imported kind. In disastrous cases -- Tanzanian shoe companies, Polish shipyards, Chinese car companies -- the products have been worth less than the cost of the raw materials used to make them.
 
An Avalanche Of Borrowing
Many third world countries also saw foreign ownership as a greater threat to sovereignty than borrowing. After an avalanche of borrowing, many countries had more debt than they could carry, and they lost control of their economies.
Mexico, Brazil, South Korea, Poland and Ghana, among others, borrowed half a trillion dollars -- most of it from commerical banks -- and put the money into government-sponsored projects. But many borrowers found they could not pay their debts.
Some countries tried to renegotiate the terms of their loans, stretching them out over longer periods to reduce payments, or seeking lower interest rates. If the banks balked, the borrowers threatened to halt debt payments. Brazil and Argentina eventually negotiated more favorable terms on their huge foreign debt. Peru, on the other hand, simply announced that it would no longer pay its debts, and lost its ability to borrow abrood, with calamitous consequences for its economy.
In the last three years, the United States offered what came to be known as the Brady plan, for Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, which encouraged banks to forgive some the debt in return for promises that economic reforms that improve the climate for private investment. Other industrial nations supported the Brady plan, which has had at least one notable success -- Mexico.
Mexico obtained relief of roughly a fifth of its $60 billion outstanding private debt. That, along with Mexico's economic reforms, gave a big boost to investor confidence.
Argentina, on the other hand, is still trying to qualify for debt reduction. Its President twice signed an agreement with the International Monetary Fund, only to have Parliament reject it. The result has been that Argentina has been unable to get new loans.
 
Foreign Investment Needed for Growth
Many of these countries that preferred to borrow now see foreign direct investment as a catalyst to growth. Chile, for example, laid out the welcome mat to overseas investors, many from the Pacific Rim.
Private investment has doubled since its low in the mid-1980's, according to Guy Pfeffermann, an economist at the International Finance Corporation, with most of the increase in East Asia, Latin America and, to a lesser extent, Africa. It is rising fastest in countries like Morocco, Chile, Mexico, Botswana and Thailand, where the business climate is improving.
Many countries have also learned the dangers of a boom-bust economy. The old populist prescription was to take windfall gains -- from a surge in commodities prices, say, or oil -- and throw a party. After oil prices surged in 1973, Nigeria tripled its public payroll to 1.5 million. After the 1979 jump in oil prices, Mexico's budget deficit soared to 17 percent of G.N.P.
But today Mexico has slashed its budget deficit to 4 percent of gross national product, which compares favorably with the United States. And it has cut tax rates and ended the practice of taxing dividends twice, which discourages investment. At the same time, the Mexican Government has beefed up tax collection by closing loopholes and prosecuting corporate tax dodgers in record numbers.
It has taken to heart a notion that has won converts in Eastern Europe: when it comes to government, smaller is better. Since 1982, Mexico has sold 875 of 1,155 Government-owned companies, including giants like TelMex, the national phone company; Mexicana, the airline, and Cannanea Copper. Banamex, Mexico's largest bank, will soon go on the block.
The payoff has been three years of 3 to 4 percent growth and an inflation rate that is less than 20 percent -- low by Latin standards. Even more promising, an estimated $10 billion that had been taken overseas has returned, as investors' confidence in the stability of Mexico's economy has grown.

HEADLINE: Administration Faulting States Over Increasing Costs of Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
In a new study, the Bush Administration asserts that states have systematically underestimated the huge and rapid increase in Medicaid costs in the last few years, resulting in billions of dollars in unexpected medical bills for the Federal Government.
State officials say unanticipated economic trends, especially the recession, caused much of the rise in costs, by increasing the number of people eligible for Medicaid because of lower incomes. 
 But the study says the recession is responsible for "a relatively small percentage" of the cost increase. A confidential draft of the report, marked for "internal use only," says one-fourth to one-third of the unexpected increases were attributable to "technical problems" in the way the states estimated costs, including a failure to recognize foreseeable trends.
Alarmed at the increases, the Federal budget director, Richard G. Darman, announced April 30 that he was sending out what officials described as "SWAT teams" of Federal budget and health officials to investigate.
Erroneous estimates by the states cause problems for the President and Congress because the Federal Government relies on state estimates in writing the budget for Medicaid, which finances health care for 27 million poor people. The program last year cost $72 billion: $41 billion in Federal money, $31 billion from the states.
Under law, the Federal Government reimburses each state for Medicaid, paying from 50 percent to 80 percent of the cost depending on the average income of the state's workers.
 
Adding to Federal Deficit
 There is no trust fund or other special source of money to pay for Medicaid. When costs increase, they contribute to the Federal budget deficit. One objective of the report is to give the states guidelines and incentives to improve the accuracy of the estimates.
In November 1989, the report says, states estimated that their Medicaid programs would cost the Federal Government $44.4 billion in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, 1990. But this May they projected Federal costs for the same period at $52.6 billion, an increase of 18 percent in just 18 months.
Estimates of 1991 hospital costs for Medicaid recipients quadrupled in Alabama, tripled in Massachusetts and doubled in Pennsylvania.
Steven M. Lieberman, assistant director of the Office of Management and Budget, who coordinated the Medicaid review, and Kimberly Gibson, a spokeswoman for the budget office, declined to discuss the report. John M. Gibbons, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said no one would discuss it "on the record."
The report notes there has been a "rapid increase in Federal Medicaid mandates," requiring the coverage of millions of additional children and pregnant women, and it implies that Congress would be less willing to expand the program if it had a truer picture of future costs.
The report lays a foundation for Federal efforts to curb the use of techniques by which states obtain extra Medicaid money from the Federal Government while putting up little or no extra money themselves.
 
States Getting Donations
 All nine states visited by the Federal teams use the techniques of soliciting "voluntary donations" by hospitals or imposing special taxes on hospitals. The states then use the extra money as part of their share of the Medicaid costs, and hospitals usually get back from Medicaid more than they paid in "donations" or taxes.
The nine states were Alabama, California, Florida, Maryland, Massachusetts, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Texas. Together, the report says, they account for almost half of projected Medicaid spending in 1991 and 1992, and for about 55 percent of the increase in estimates.
The report lists other reasons for increases in Medicaid costs, including state decisions to raise payments to hospitals and nursing homes in response to court orders or threatened lawsuits. It says state officials need "definitive guidance" from Washington to help them resist such lawsuits.
State officials cooperated with the investigation, but say the Federal budget office, which frequently underestimates the Federal budget deficit, is in no position to lecture the states. They point out, for example, that the Federal deficit in the 1990 fiscal year, $220 billion, was 78 percent higher than Mr. Darman estimated in January 1990.
 
Difficult to Untangle
 In analyzing the rise in Medicaid costs, the study acknowledges that it is often difficult to untangle economic factors, technical problems in estimating techniques and policy changes in the program.
"Economic trends have clearly contributed to the increase," the report says, but it adds that "a relatively small percentage of the increase in estimates was due solely to changes in the economy."
By contrast, James L. Martin, director of state-Federal relations for the National Governors' Association, said, "It's inevitable that the current recession is a major factor in state estimates of revenues and expenditures, including Medicaid."
When people lose jobs, their income usually declines, and some become eligible for assistance under the main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. People enrolled in that program are automatically eligible for Medicaid.
From 1985 to 1990, the report says, Congress passed seven major laws containing hundreds of provisions altering Medicaid, and states are now feeling the impact of those changes.
Thus, it says: "One state estimated that a 1986 provision, requiring emergency care for undocumented aliens, would cost about $65 million annually when implemented in October 1988. The state now estimates that the fiscal year 1992 cost of the provision will be 10 times that amount, or $650 million. The Federal share of the cost is $325 million."
The state is not named, but California and Florida have incurred substantial costs for undocumented aliens.
"One state initially saw 40 percent participation rates for newly Medicaid-eligible pregnant women, infants and children, but now is finding about 70 percent to 80 percent participation for the lower-income eligibles," it said.
The Medicaid review was conducted by officials from the Office of Management and Budget and the Department of Health and Human Services led by Mr. Lieberman, the assistant director of the budget office, and J. Michael Hudson , deputy chief of the Health Care Financing Administration.
